webTitle: Former minister dies after 13-hour Lords session

fields.headline: Former minister dies after 13-hour Lords session
fields.trailText: The former Conservative minister, Lord Mackay of Ardbrecknish, collapsed and died on his way to the House of Lords yesterday - hours after he had been presiding over the upper house at the end of a marathon 13-hour session.
fields.body:
The former Conservative minister, Lord Mackay of Ardbrecknish, collapsed and died on his way to the House of Lords yesterday - hours after he had been presiding over the upper house at the end of a marathon 13-hour session.

Colleagues dismissed suggestions that 62-year-old Lord Mackay was the victim of an excess burden of work as their main home affairs spokesman until recently.

As such he faced a deluge of detailed legislation in successive sessions under Labour after being a hard-working junior minister and whip in various departments in the Thatcher-Major years.

In the half-reformed House of Lords where Tory peers have been trying to assert their new constitutional "legitimacy" the price of fighting the Labour-dominated Commons has been more late sessions. "John always prepared meticulously for debates," recalled one Lords official who knew him well. As such he shadowed Labour's Home Office minister, Lord Bassam, until last autumn when he took on the lighter duties of chairman of Lords committees.

The former MP for Argyll and Bute from 1979-87, who had been "on the woolsack" - the equivalent of Commons Speaker - when the Lords rose at 3.32am yesterday, was rushed to St George's hospital in Tooting, south London, with a suspected heart attack. But he was found to be dead on arrival.

William Hague, who worked with Lord Mackay as junior social security ministers, praised him as "a distinguished politician" who would be greatly missed. Lord Strathclyde, Tory leader of the Lords, said: "John Mackay was the kind of person who gives politics a good name." As an MP John Mackay helped the Tory revival in Scotland in 1979, but lived to see all its MPs defeated and the party revived only through PR elections for the Scottish parliament which he opposed. Married with three grown-up children he was a keen freshwater fisherman.

fields.headline: Zombies, freaks and sports fans
fields.standfirst: Want to know what the six-tackle rule is? Or why Milly was slammed?  Or which British comedian turned up at her hotel? Or what her favourite thing to eat on the beach is? Find out all this, and how she's managing it on only five hours' sleep a night
fields.trailText: Week 12, Coogee Want to know what the six-tackle rule is? Or why Milly was slammed? Or which British comedian turned up at her hotel? Or what her favourite thing to eat on the beach is? Find out all this, and how she's managing it on only five hours' sleep a night
fields.body:
Thursday the 15th was one of the longest days of my life - well, my travelling life anyway. Rising with my alarm at the ever popular time of 5am I dragged myself into work for the breakfast shift in the hotel restaurant. There were three of us working that morning, shut in a cupboard to do the kind of dogsbody work that keeps us out of trouble, but also means we can have a lot of fun on our own.

We had two hours' break - time for a quick drink across the road - before we started our second shift of the day. That evening I was serving at a wine-tasting conference, and the phrase thrown in at the deep end seems entirely appropriate here. Besides dropping a tray of wine down myself and some of the hotel furniture nothing went too badly wrong, and I even got to finish early. At midnight.

Another traveller, Amanda and I went across the road again for a drink. It was here I met another of my occasional freaks. He had just arrived from LA, alone, and was keen to sit and buy us a drink, so we let him. Shortly after that Amanda looked down to see his hand in her bag, to which he commented: "I hope you don't think I'm trying to steal anything!" We both quite certainly did. We made excuses to go pretty quickly - he'd also said some other odd things too, and people like that are best when you're a long way away from them.

Before we left we warned the bouncers about him so I think he'd have been leaving very shortly after us. Do I meet a disproportionate number of oddballs or have other travellers found the same?

So I finally got home at 3am - approaching 24 hours after I left the house.

On Friday, I wasn't physically capable of doing anything. To give myself a sugar hit I bought an apple pie (up 'til now I've been comfortably living on hotel meals) and accidentally ate it all. I have a vague memory of dozing on and off and watching some of Toy Story before my evening shift.

The do was a charity auction and we were slammed (that's the technical word for being ridiculously busy). There were over 600 happy bidders just dying for me to give them more wine - this job at least makes you popular. One good point was the evening's entertainment, which was Ronnie Corbett. Fortunately we got to watch him. He was hilarious - several British-orientated jokes too, which I haven't heard for a while.

That evening, I found out my mum is coming to Sydney on the 28th of this month (see, I have mentioned you!), so soon there will be someone to give me another view on the city, and I'll have an excellent excuse to take some time off work.

I don't know why but, after the auction function I couldn't sleep well, and failed to wake with my alarm the next morning and so jolted awake 15 minutes before I was due to start work. Suffice to say I didn't make it on time. Still, it didn't really matter as the rest of my day was spent hosting. I have nothing good to say about it, so I won't.

That night me, Brian and two boys from my old hostel headed off to Homebush Bay (Olympic Park) to watch a double rugby game. Up to now I've had no interest in the sport, and I didn't know the rules, so the others spent a lot of the first game explaining what was going on. It's all to do with the six tackle rule. If that means something to you, excellent. If not go watch a match anyway - they're a lot of fun.

There were four local teams playing in two matches, and multi-coloured supporters in their thousands. In the first match, Paramatta Eels thrashed Penrith panthers, after which we were treated to an appallingly bad cheerleader show before the next match. The Sydney Roosters were playing in this, and I decided that since they were my local team I would support them - and realised how easy it is to get sucked in to the passion of sport.

The crowd were getting steadily drunker and we managed to get a Mexican wave flowing continuously round the stadium. Several fights broke out and I think by the end of the second game (Sydney won) more attention was being paid to these outbreaks than the game itself. Still, I really enjoyed my evening and would definitely recommend going to see a local sport if you're travelling - one of my few regrets from Canada was not watching an ice-hockey match.

Sunday morning I had to work after less than five hours sleep. I think the craziest thing was that this amount was more than any other staff member I spoke to had got. That evening Brian and I settled for sharing a chocolate cheesecake and a box of wine - they're just so fantastically cheap, how can you refuse?! I collapsed semi-conscious while trying to watch a video, but at least I had a good rest.

Monday I had a WHOLE day off! I indulged in one of my favourite hobbies - eating fresh fruit on the beach. I think maybe I was a bit excessive as I brought a whole pineapple, but there's just something great about it - in fact a group next to me got up and left saying "I fancy some pineapple." Brian and I went to Bondi to have a stab at a pub quiz without all the arguing you get in a big group. Unfortunately we were totally hopeless, but we did get given a jug of beer for no reason. Unfortunately Brian doesn't drink beer so you can imagine where that all went.

Whereas I described Thursday as my longest day, I think Tuesday could safely be my illest day. I looked like a walking zombie at work that morning, though miraculously I made it through without falling over or anything messier. Predictably I returned to my apartment that evening and collapsed until the next morning, which is absolutely necessary if I'm going to make it through that one. Wednesday involved a breakfast and lunch function. It was a total nightmare as I kept tripping over the closely squashed together tables, though nothing got thrown on the floor, which is a bonus.

The big buzz at the hotel was about a particular celebrity who's staying there, and it's bits of excitement like this that make me enjoy my job and think at least I'm seeing something new every day. And tomorrow is payday, which is perhaps another reason why I enjoy my job . . .

Until next week (when I'll see both famous faces and family faces)
Milly

PS Reading through your emails, I notice there is a bit of a developing war on the theme of "New Zealand: Time of your life or time to get wet and bored?" Anyone else got any comments?

fields.headline: BA award spotlights sustainable tourism
fields.trailText: UK tourists and tourism organisations are being asked to nominate environmentally sensitive tourism projects for the British Airways Tourism for Tomorrow awards. The annual awards aim to raise the awareness of the world's role models for sustainable tourism.
fields.body:
UK tourists and tourism organisations are being asked to nominate environmentally sensitive tourism projects for the British Airways Tourism for Tomorrow awards. The annual awards aim to raise the awareness of the world's role models for sustainable tourism.

Awards will be given to projects in the UK or abroad in six categories, including national parks, accommodation (including resorts and cruiseships), old and new buildings, tour companies, tour companies and large-scale projects.

The judges, chaired by David Bellamy, are looking for projects with benefit the local community, protect the natural and cultural heritage, control energy and water use, educate local people and visitors and contribute towards a better life in the future.

Entries have to be received May 1. For more details see www.britishairways.com/tourism, or read about last year's winners.

webTitle: 'Arrogant' Lord Irvine refuses to say sorry

fields.headline: 'Arrogant' Lord Irvine refuses to say sorry
fields.standfirst: Lord chancellor speaks for first time about his decision to send donation letters to barristers
fields.trailText: An unrepentant lord chancellor, Lord Irvine, yesterday faced new                                                  Tory charges of arrogance when he refused to apologise for                                                  raising funds for Labour, insisting he had broken no current                                                  rules.
fields.body:
An unrepentant lord chancellor, Lord Irvine, yesterday faced new Tory charges of arrogance when he refused to apologise for raising funds for Labour, insisting he had broken no current rules.

During a tense 15 minute cross-examination, and standing the traditional two paces away from his seat on the woolsack, Lord Irvine told peers he had not undermined the integrity of his unique office.

In his only concession to critics who claim he has compromised the political independence of his post, he said he would comply with any future rules restricting such fund-raising.

He also pointed out that, from next month, a commissioner for judicial appointments will scrutinise the integrity of all appointments to the judiciary.

Speaking for the first time since he came under attack, Lord Irvine told peers: "I do not believe I have done anything wrong nor do I believe I have broken any current rules. If I did I would be the first to apologise.

"There is no real difference between party political campaigning and fundraising because I believe that fundraising is an inherent part of party political campaigning."

Every minister from the prime minister downwards was involved in fund raising for the party, he said.

Asked by Lord Strathclyde, shadow leader of the Lords, whether he would raise funds again, Lord Irvine replied that unless the rules were changed, he would consider doing it again. But he added that in practice he would first consider the furore which the issue had caused.

He insisted he did not believe any lawyer attending the Labour party fundraising dinner which he hosted could have conceivably thought it could have "bought" them an advantage in gaining appointment.

Lord Irvine's judgment was widely challenged after it emerged at the weekend that he sent a letter to Labour-sympathetic lawyers asking them to donate £200 at a party fund-raising dinner.

Lord Irvine said it was misconceived to claim that the lord chancellor was not a party political post, pointing out that Tory predecessors, including Lord Hailsham, had spoken in election campaigns.

The Labour headquarters at Millbank supplemented the claim by highlighting politically controversial interviews given in the 1992 election campaign by the last Conservative lord chancellor, Lord Mackay of Clashfern. Millbank also asserted that previous Tory lord chancellors had attended party fund raising events.

However, the former Conser vative deputy prime minister and barrister, Lord Howe, said Lord Irvine had transformed the position by personally conducting fundraising.

He said: "None of Lord Irvine's predecessors acted as hosts of fund raising dinners attended solely by people over whose professional careers they have profound influence."

Some Labour MPs and Liberal Democrats also asserted that no cabinet minister should ever seek political funds from anyone dependent on the same minister for their professional preferment.

Bob Marshall-Andrews, a Labour backbencher and QC, said: "The one thing no minister must conceivably do is to attempt to solicit funds for political purposes from those over whom he has influence, power or patronage."

Since 26,000 annual public appointments are made by ministers, such a principle would effectively prevents ministers from any fund-raising activity.

During question time in the Lords yesterday, the Liberal Democrat peer, Lord McNally, pressed Lord Irvine "whether the role of lord chancellor is compatible with that of a party fundraiser?"

He added: "There's a blurring by your behaviour of your responsibilities as a minister and your responsibilities as a politician."

Later Lord Strathcyle said: "The lord chancellor arrogantly failed to offer any kind of apology for action that has been universally condemned. He showed no humility, no sense of personal responsibility or any shred of concern for the storm of criticism".

Lord Irvine did not rule out the Labour policy of a judicial appointments commission, so handing the appointment of judges to an independent body.

He said: "It is a very controversial proposition, and you know well that there are many who are really opposed to that proposition because of the dangers which it is said to pose to appointments on merit only, as distinct from appointments which make compromises."

webTitle: Hague attacks red tape with new website

fields.headline: Hague attacks red tape with new website
fields.trailText: Conservative leader William Hague has launched an anti-red tape website to highlight what he claims are the burdens the government has placed on British businesses.
fields.body:
Conservative leader William Hague has launched an anti-red tape website to highlight what he claims are the burdens the government has placed on British businesses.

The site is called the ministry for silly regulations  based on Monty Python's ministry for silly walks  and catalogues the rules and regulations facing UK busineses which it alleges are costing businesses up to £6bn a year.

The satirical site features photographs of pinstriped men in bowler hats standing on the beach at Dover eyeing the Continent suspiciously through telescopes.

At the site's launch today, Mr Hague dubbed the prime minister "Red-tape Tony" and said: " I am particularly delighted be launching a new web site, sillyregs.com.

"While the name might be lighthearted it carries a deadly serious message. I might not agree with everything that is said on the website  but I very much agree with its objectives.

"This website will give news about new regulations, and give business people everywhere the chance to comment publicly on them, particularly those that are burdensome and excessive. Businesses will be able to send in private emails that the task force will then follow up."

The site highlights cases such as the north-east grocer Steven Thoburn who was prosecuted for selling goods in pounds and ounces rather than the metric system.

It is part of the Tories' pre-election campaign to fight the government on lifting the burdens on businesses. Mr Hague also announced today that the Conservatives would establish an independent deregulation commission chaired by former Cadbury-Schweppes boss Sir Paul Judge.

The body would examine all regulations proposed by government departments and  if the commission thought they were unnecessary  force a vote on them in both the Commons and the Lords.

They would also impose "sunset clauses" on new regulations, giving them a set duration after which they must be abandoned or re-negotiated.

But trade and industry minister Stephen Byers hit back at the "common sense on regulation" campaign, branding it: "a return to the days of poverty pay."

He said: "The Tories may regard these as silly regulations, but for millions of workers they offer dignity and security of employment.

"It is now clear that the Tories want to return to the days of poverty pay, ending the minimum wage, ending the right to four weeks paid annual leave and the right to time off for family emergencies."

Useful links:
Ministry for silly regulations

webTitle: Labour likely to impose shortlist in safe seat

fields.headline: Labour likely to impose shortlist in safe seat
fields.standfirst:
Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Labour is set to impose a shortlist of candidates for the safe Lancashire seat of Leigh.
fields.body:
Labour is set to impose a shortlist of candidates for the safe Lancashire seat of Leigh.

The move follows a refusal by the constituency party to put two "Londoners" on the shortlist - one being Andy Burnham, adviser to culture secretary Chris Smith - amid charges that party HQ in Millbank, and the Cabinet Office minister, Ian McCartney, who sits for neighbouring Makerfield, were pulling strings.

Last week regional officials warned the Leigh executive to pick a shortlist of six or eight - including Mr Burnham and Jenny Smith, a London-based union official - or see the process suspended.

When the executive voted nine to seven for four local activists, suspension followed. Labour's national executive is sure to insist on the wider shortlist next month.

It has caused resentment, not least because last year Wigan councillor Mark Hale was told by the national executive he could not be shortlisted for fear of adverse publicity. He had cleared himself after being suspended from the party for allegedly exploring "adult material" on council computers - saying he was trying to prove computer security was not properly safe.

The retiring MP, Laurie Cunliffe, has a majority of 24,496.

Mr Burnham, 31, lived in Leigh, where his parents remain, until university. He had won branch and union nominations. Ms Smith used to work for Bill Morris, head of the T&GWU union, which sponsors Mr McCartney.

It has caused resentment, not least because last year Wigan councillor Mark Hale was told by the national executive he could not be shortlisted for fear of adverse publicity. He had cleared himself after being suspended from the party for allegedly exploring "adult material" on council computers - saying he was trying to prove computer security was not properly safe. The retiring MP, Laurie Cunliffe, has a majority of 24,496. Mr Burnham, 31, lived in Leigh, where his parents remain, until university. He had won branch and union nominations. Ms Smith used to work for Bill Morris, head of the T&GWU union, which sponsors Mr McCartney.

webTitle: Catherine Bennett on Lord Irvine's intelligence

fields.headline: Where were Derry's brains when he needed them?
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Some point to the wallpaper incident as the earliest, surest sign that Lord Irvine of Lairg QC was a prize twerp. Or, as Lord McNally delicately put it yesterday, "not a very good politician".
fields.body:
Searching the past for clues, some point to the wallpaper incident as the earliest, surest sign that Lord Irvine of Lairg QC was, as well as being one of Tony Blair's boon companions, a prize twerp. Or, as Lord McNally delicately put it yesterday, "not a very good politician".

The election was won in May 1997; by July, the new Lord Chancellor had already written to Black Rod, offering his wife's services as a guide to his soon-to-be-refurbished apartments: "Lady Irvine and I have had a lifetime's interest in fine art." At this point, the £650,000 decoration of the Lord Chancellor's quarters, featuring, it will be remembered, a £3,000 Pugin-style lav as well as extensive borrowings from public galleries, had yet to be approved by the House of Lords.

Later, after he had been exposed as the driving force behind the palace makeover, Irvine maintained that he had done it all for us. Or, at any rate, for our children and our children's children. "Future generations will be grateful," he instructed a commons select committee. "I read the commentators who say, 'Three cheers that this work has been done!' And three cheers for the committee that chose to make the decision!"

It's true, Irvine had some loyal champions. Even after he had gone on to surpass himself in chumpishness, describing himself as Blair's Cardinal Wolsey, Irvine was still being described in profiles as "brilliant". Or "very brilliant". A profile in the Sun referred to his "brilliant, razor-sharp mind." In the Observer, Andrew Marr wrote: "He is very clever ... When he speaks in public, it is often through meticulously prepared lectures, using the classical cadences of jurisprudence, and arguing from philosophical first principles." So that's what Irvine had meant by that comment, in defence of his gothic refit: "You are not talking about something down at the DIY store." Marr went on, impartially: " Derry provokes. Challenges. Invigorates. I like him." Three cheers for Derry's mighty brain!

In fact, it is this very cleverness, rather than his pomposity and conceit that seems to provide the key to the Lord Chancellor's current difficulties. Not only do very clever people rarely seem to prosper in politics, recent history reveals them to be more accident-prone than the dim. Intelligence, even genius, was once reputed to be the defining characteristic of Peter Mandelson. Brains, of dimensions the bog-standard cerebellum can scarcely begin to compass, were once said to be the main point of Lord Falconer, the minister for the Millennium Dome. A dazzled colleague described him as "smarter even than Derry Irvine".

The fabulously clever were, of course, among the most striking casualties of the past conservative administration. David Willetts, "two-brains" as he was nicknamed by our own Michael White, was obliged to resign in 1996 after a spectacular display of alpha double plus mental agility in which he attempted to convince a select committee that the expression "wants our advice" should actually have been interpreted in the archaic sense as "is without/in need of our advice".

He recently admitted to the writer Sabine Durrant that he had been "Too clever by half. The big Tory criticism. I probably did try to argue my way out. It was chastening. Until then I thought you could argue your way round anything".

He wasn't the only one. Hard as it is to imagine, since they all faded, or plummeted out of sight, the Conservative party used to rather pride itself on its prize collection of wonks, particularly its two fellows of All Souls, John Redwood, author of Reason, Ridicule and Religion: The Age of Enlightenment in England, and William Waldegrave, author of a book of political theory, The Binding of Leviathan. Like Willetts's casuistry, Waldegrave's attempt to argue his way of the arms-for-Iraq affair only made matters worse. He was accused by Sir Richard Scott of "sophistry".

If his friends and admirers are to be believed, the current Lord Chancellor is as clever as any All Souls pointyhead. Cleverer, as a matter of fact, as he has more than a few precious little pamphlets and an unread PhD thesis to show for it. Irvine was, remember, a QC at 37. Master of his own chambers at 41. Rich as you like. This means that he is also described as "formidable", graced with a "chess-player's mind", "an impressive performer". At the time of his appointment, three years ago, Baroness Helena Kennedy described him as "incredibly clever and enormously astute politically".

So, how are we to explain the fact that he could not see what a child could have told him: that his fund-raising would compromise his office? Why, over and over, does Lord Irvine behave like a clown? If the man is so clever, why does he act so stupid? Not only that: when confronted with evidence of his clownishness, Lord Irvine always makes it worse, like those silly Tory boys before him, by his woeful attempts to argue his way out of it. Again, as Margot Asquith once said of Birkenhead: "His brains have gone to his head."

Faced with reasonable questions about the need for a separation of powers, that enormous lump of premier-quality grey matter yesterday whirled into action, and delivered this: "I think that there is no real difference between party political campaigning and fundraising." A response so wide of the mark that the intellectual in you cried out for a nice bit of sophistry, the merest hint of a jurisprudential cadence.

Maybe too much power, too quickly, has literally addled Irvine's brains. That might explain Alastair Campbell's and Mandelson's recent lapses too. Or maybe, in the courts where so many of our current leaders have honed their razor-sharp minds, the arrogant Wolsey-style patter really does pass for forensic genius. Who knows, perhaps all you really need to succeed, in the profession that created Blair and his circle, is modest ability and a lot of bluster. If so, three cheers for QCs! And no cheers at all for the man who keeps putting them in the government.

Life after Jay? Only one woman for the job ...

The vacancy left by Baroness Jay, once she has left to re-adjust her work-life balance, will not easily be filled. While it may not be difficult to round-up candidates to parrot government policy in the lords, finding a fitting successor as minister for Women may be more problematic.

Assuming, as we must, that Blair deliberately filled the job with a woman with an almost unique ability to alienate her own sex, where will he now find an adequate replacement? Who else can project the same mixture of arrogance and tangential understanding of real life that proved so effective in keeping British women on their toes?

Eminem? A promising candidate, though there are those who say his misogyny is all an act. Lord Falconer? He should shortly be looking for a new job, and shares Jay's talent for winding up those he calls "ordinary". Then again, his own fuller-figure might make it difficult for him to lecture women, as Jay did, on the importance of keeping fit.

Sophie Dahl, that living rebuke to body-fascism as tackled in the women's unit summit? Though she is, like Jay, both privileged and tall, most women rather admire her.

Lady Victoria Hervey, (pronounced pervy)? Here, I think, we have a contender. Lady Victoria, to judge by her interview with Simon Hattenstone this week, combines invincible self-esteem with a genuine desire to set more feckless women an example and send them out to work. She is, as recent nude photographs demonstrate, wholly at ease with her body image. Her social diary suggests an almost perfect work-life balance. Where Jay had a close relationship with Good Housekeeping, Lady Victoria has the more up-to-date GQ. Finally, like Jay, she is a born aristocrat, requiring only the marginal promotion to go out into the world, and start doing good. Why wait?

fields.headline: 'The smoke of pyres drifted everywhere'
fields.standfirst:
Britain's 1967 epidemic left farmers traumatised

Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Britain's worst foot and mouth epidemic began on October 25, 1967, with a vet's routine call to Norman Ellis's small mixed farm at Nantmawr, just outside Oswestry in Shropshire. It was to be the start of an agricultural nightmare that has haunted the Welsh border and dairy farmers ever since.
fields.body:
Britain's worst foot and mouth epidemic began on October 25, 1967, with a vet's routine call to Norman Ellis's small mixed farm at Nantmawr, just outside Oswestry in Shropshire. It was to be the start of an agricultural nightmare that has haunted the Welsh border and dairy farmers ever since.

Mr Ellis had reported three lame pigs, and earlier that day had taken two cows to the market. When the vet raised the alarm, the authorities acted with commendable speed. The police intercepted one of the cows on its way to a new owner and nearly 2,000 animals, including Mr Ellis's second cow, were immediately detained at Oswestry's outdoor market . There was chaos in the small market town.

By next morning all Mr Ellis's pigs had been found to be infected and within hours, remembers David Lloyd who was the National Farmers Union spokesman at the time, all his 71 cattle, 67 pigs and 47 sheep had been shot and burned.

Three days later there was a second outbreak and within a week 23 farms, mostly in the region, had been found to be infected. The next week the toll rose to 104, and by the third week to 222. By this time the epidemic had spread north to Cheshire and Lancashire and there were fears it would hit the whole of Britain.

Mr Lloyd, now a broadcaster, remembers a "horrible, sad time" with the smoke of funeral pyres drifting over the countryside as hundreds of animals at a time were piled on old railway sleepers and burned with coal before being buried in pits of quicklime. The army was called in because local contractors could not cope with the disposal of the animals. Vets were drafted in from around Britain and Europe to inspect each farm.

Farms found to have the disease were immediately sealed off with no one allowed on or off the premises. Police were stationed outside the gates.

"It closed everything", said Brian Barrett, a local journalist at the time. "Nothing happened in the villages because no movement was allowed off the farm. Children could not go to school, women could not shop. Food and milk was delivered to the farm gate." Social life ground to a halt and Oswestry became a ghost town. Footpaths were closed, hunting, shooting, fishing and horse racing were suspended, and car rallying, cross-country running, camping, canoeing, football, gliding and mountaineering were all affected.

The epidemic devastated the region economically and traumatised thousands of farmers for years. Few went bankrupt because of the compensation offered, but many were out of business for more than six months. Pedigree flocks and herds were lost.

The disease did not spread into the uplands but was mostly confined to the border regions, north east Wales, Cheshire and dairy areas.

It peaked in November 1967, with more than 400 farms affected in a week, and then tailed off. By the time the al clear was sounded on June 4 1968, there had been 2,364 outbreaks and 433,987 animals had been slaughtered - 211,825 cattle, 113,766 pigs 108,345 sheep and 51 goats.

An inquiry chaired by the Duke of Northumberland blamed a shipment of Argentine meat for the epidemic. But critics point out that Britain was waging a "meat war" with Argentina at the time, and that the disease had been documented in Britain since 1839, with almost annual outbreaks between 1910 and 1967.

fields.headline: Council poaches Audit Commission director
fields.trailText: Luton borough council has poached an Audit Commission director as its new chief executive, adding to the UK's small band of local authority top managers from ethnic minority backgrounds.
fields.body:
Luton borough council has poached an Audit Commission director as its new chief executive, adding to the UK's small band of local authority top managers from ethnic minority backgrounds.

Darra Singh, the commission's northern region director of best value inspection, is understood to be the organisation's senior non-white manager.

Mr Singh, who has been with the commission for just a year, has a reputation as a "rising star" in local government circles. He is expected to join Luton in the spring.

"Darra has got amazing contacts and extensive knowledge of best value. Luton will be pleased to have him," said one local government observer.

"The best value regional directors were appointed knowing it wasn't a job for life but a stepping stone to a chief executive job. But Darra has made the step up quickly."

Prior to joining the commission Mr Singh was chief executive of a London-based housing association.

The government this week called on public services to ensure ethnic minorities are fairly represented in top jobs as part of a package of new duties to promote race equality.

webTitle: New universities 'in crisis' as student numbers drop

fields.headline: New universities 'in crisis' as student numbers drop
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Teachers' leaders warned yesterday of a crisis gripping the new universities - the former polytechnics - as they are forced to shut courses no longer viable and scale down facilities in the face of dwindling student numbers.
fields.body:
Teachers' leaders warned yesterday of a crisis gripping the new universities - the former polytechnics - as they are forced to shut courses no longer viable and scale down facilities in the face of dwindling student numbers.

Hundreds of jobs are under threat as the institutions, which were given university status in 1992, struggle to fill places in competition with more established rivals.

The National Association of Teachers in Further and Higher Education (Natfhe) predicted that one in three was now faced with the prospect of making staff redundant, while opposition MPs said the news showed the goverment's ambitious target to expand higher education was ill-advised.

Tony Blair recently reiterated that the government wants to expand enrolment to 50% of all young adults by the end of the decade - one of three key targets in higher education. Extra government-funded places have been created predominantly at the older, more established universities.

Tom Wilson, head of universities at Natfhe, said: "In our view it's absolutely the old universities which are creaming the former polys."

He blamed inadequate government funding for the new universities, which receive only half as much income for teaching as the old universities, as well as students' worries about debt since the introduction of tuition fees.

At Luton University, 98 academic and managerial jobs are at risk in a £4m cost-cutting exercise announced this week to compensate for falling student numbers. Courses such as history, maths, technology and English, where numbers are down, are to be cut back in favour of more popular subjects, such as business, computing, and media studies.

De Montfort University has announced a "strategic withdrawal" from its Milton Keynes campus due to an 8% drop in students. The pro-vice-chancellor, John Coyne, said yesterday that the site represented 3% of its 27,000 student population. "Every institution has a student target, and many have had to work harder to meet those recruitment targets, including ourselves," he said. "We have no illusions that we have to work harder than the so-called elite universities."

Frank Gould, vice-chancellor of East London University, warned that a 12% slump in applications would lead to job losses and closure of some parts of its teaching.

"There is a two-tier system" Professor Gould said. "We don't have the history and wealth, we come from a different starting point. It will take us 20 years to catch up (from 1992)."

Sheffield business school - part of Sheffield Hallam University - is to be closed, and its activities "refocused" elsewhere in the college.

A parliamentary answer to Tim Boswell, Conservative MP for Daventry, stated that 51 institutions in England missed their student targets by more than 2% this academic year. Next week the funding councils will reveal numbers for each university and higher education college.

A spokesman for the Department for Education and Employment commented: "Management and staffing issues are a matter for individual institutions. Funding follows students' choices, which means that popular courses have been able to expand. The government is putting substantial additional investment into higher education institutions - an extra £1.7bn in the next four years."

webTitle: Free childcare - if young mums go back to school

fields.headline: Free childcare - if young mums go back to school
fields.standfirst:
Guardian Unlimited Education
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The government is considering giving all teenage mothers free full-time childcare if they undergo training or return to school. A pilot scheme will be unveiled today in which mothers under 20 will be able to   leave their children with registered childminders in a "rights and responsibilities" deal designed to haul them out of poverty and into work.
fields.body:
The government is considering giving all teenage mothers free full-time childcare if they undergo training or return to school. A pilot scheme will be unveiled today in which mothers under 20 will be able to leave their children with registered childminders in a "rights and responsibilities" deal designed to haul them out of poverty and into work.

The move is prompted in part by the government's determination to curb the number of teenage pregnancies. Britain has the highest rate of teenage births in western Europe - double the number of Germany, three times that of France and six times that of the Netherlands.

The £3m pilot scheme, which forms part of the government's commitment to erase child poverty, will initially help 200 teenage mothers who have little support from their families, have left home or are in care.

Four areas with low levels of education and training and high instances of teenage pregnancy will be targeted. But ministers expect the scheme to be extended nationwide to cover all teenage mothers, should the three-year pilot prove successful.

"Obviously, where families support the mothers, there isn't the need for the extra money, so we've been focusing on the most isolated cases, but if it works then we'll expand it," Margaret Hodge, the education and employment minister, said.

The move builds on the recommendations of a report into teenage pregnancy by the social exclusion unit, commissioned by the prime minister, which stressed that "young parents should have the chance to complete their education", but acknowledged that they faced "a range of barriers" including the availability and cost of childcare. The cost of a childminder averages £90 a week, with a nursery place around £110.

The report, published in June 1999, also found that teenage mothers were less likely than their childless counterparts to finish their education, less likely to find a good job, and more likely to end up both as single parents and to bring their children up in poverty.

Young girls in care are particularly likely to be caught in the teenage pregnancy trap, with a quarter pregnant at 16 and nearly half pregnant within two years of leaving care.

Last night Ms Hodge stressed that the government was trying to reduce the "unacceptable" levels of teenage pregnancy through clearer sex education in schools. She added: "When teenagers do have children - and where there is no family support, perhaps because the mother has been in care - it is in the interests of both the mother and the child for the mother to stay in education and training.

"At present 90% of teenage mums live on benefits and they are more likely to stay on benefit for longer. We must change that."

Mothers, who will initially be drawn from Blackpool, north-east Lincolnshire, and Greenwich, Dagenham and Barking in south-east London and Essex, will be able to place their children with registered childminders who will look after no more than three children each.

webTitle: US fires on Iraqi air defence positions

fields.headline: US fires on Iraqi air defence positions
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: US warplanes struck Iraqi air defence targets in northern Iraq today, going into action for the first time since last week's attack on targets near Baghdad, the US military said.
fields.body:
US warplanes struck Iraqi air defence targets in northern Iraq today, going into action for the first time since last week's attack on targets near Baghdad, the US military said.

The US European command said the strike was launched in retaliation against Iraqi anti-aircraft artillery fire at coalition aircraft patrolling a no-fly zone in the north of the country. No British planes were involved in today's attack.

"Coalition aircraft responded to the Iraqi attacks by dropping ordnance on elements of the Iraqi integrated air defence system," the command said in a statement. The statement added that all aircraft had returned to base safely.

The Operation Northern Watch coalition has patrolled the no-fly zone above the 36th parallel for nine years. It claimed that today's strike was in response to anti aircraft artillery fired from sites north of Mosul, a city 250 miles north of Baghdad.

The coalition said aircraft were also targeted by Iraqi radar from sites south-east of Mosul.

Meanwhile the Pentagon has admitted that the results of last weekend's airstrikes on Iraqi air defence sites were mediocre at best. A senior Pentagon official said today that far fewer than half the targeted radar were damaged.

Early assessments indicate a new satellite-guided missile fired by Navy planes was mainly to blame.

"We have detectable damage on 38-40% of the radars, and we still have some (data) coming in," said the official, discussing the Pentagon's preliminary bomb damage assessment on condition of anonymity.

Most of the misses were by a margin of 30 to 45 meters, he said.

webTitle: Chesterfield charged with breaching Football League regulations

fields.headline: Chesterfield charged with breaching Football League regulations
fields.trailText: The Football League have charged Chesterfield with a number of breaches of its regulations, following a recent investigation conducted by the Football League in conjunction with the FA.
fields.body:
The Football League have charged Chesterfield with a number of breaches of its regulations, following a recent investigation conducted by the Football League in conjunction with the FA.

The charges relate to breaches of player transfer regulations, irregular payments, and the under-reporting of gate receipts.

In addition, individual charges are also being made against a number of officials and employees of the club.

Chesterfield, currently 14 points clear at the top of the Division Three, have 14 days in which to respond to the charges.

webTitle: Hull City saved by mystery buyer

fields.headline: Hull City saved by mystery buyer
fields.trailText: Hull City have been granted a stay of execution after a mystery buyer agreed to plough £85,000 into the club to keep it trading until a meeting scheduled for March 8.
fields.body:
Hull City have been granted a stay of execution after a mystery buyer agreed to plough £85,000 into the club to keep it trading until a meeting scheduled for March 8.

The cash injection will pay the players' wages and the rent on the club's Boothferry Park ground.

Earlier this month Hull were put into administration after surviving a winding up order - and the future of the club seemed bleak until the deal was revealed in the High Court today.

The court was told how Hull City owed £800,000 to Customs and Excise and the Inland Revenue in addition to smaller debts to other creditors.

But Giles Maynard-Connor, counsel for Leeds-based administrators Kroll Buchler Philips, said with a purchaser on board, a sale would allow the club to survive.

The administrators have refused to confirm reports that two mystery American millionaires are behind the bid for the cash-strapped club. It is rumoured that the Americans have had lengthy talks with various bodies including club officials and representatives from the Football League and FA.

Other reports suggested that a London consortium had joined forces with the Tiger Co-operative to mount a £750,000 offer.

The club's future will now be decided at a meeting scheduled for March 8, where creditors and shareholders will be asked to vote on a Creditors Voluntary Arrangement which would see the Tigers sold for £360,000.

But during the half-hour court hearing it details of a rival bid also emerged. The judge Bertie Maddocks ordered that the terms of that and any further bids should be circulated to creditors prior to the meeting.

The Hull players have not been paid this year and have had to rely on collections by fans who have rallied behind the team, boosting gate receipts.

webTitle: Fate in a Pleasant Mood, Space is the Place, and Sound of Joy

fields.headline: Fate in a Pleasant Mood, Space is the Place, and Sound of Joy
fields.trailText: A GOOD DAY IN THE NORTH
fields.body:
A GOOD DAY IN THE NORTH

Sometimes we're all guilty of getting sucked into the Premiership and SPL soap opera: how Ken Bates's trousers are chafing his thighs, or how Jim McClean's anger-management course is going, that sort of thing. Meanwhile, down the divisions, clubs are struggling to survive. Clubs like Airdrie and Hull City. So now and again it's nice to report some good news: today saw - in a move probably unheard of since those heady days of Queen Elizabeth I - not one, but two stays of execution.

Earlier this afternoon, the Scottish Football League agreed to postpone Airdrie's game against Ross County this weekend to allow administrators KPMG to find a solution to the club's financial problems. Obviously the decision is a lot more humane - and sensible - than that of the Scottish FA, who last week threw Airdrie out of the Scottish Cup (where they could have made some money). However, despite the good news, Airdrie aren't safe yet. SFL secretary Peter Donald today admitted that "this type of offer is not open-ended, and although no cut-off date has been set it clearly cannot go on for ever".

Even so, no reason to grieve just yet. And later on, there was better news for Hull City, who survived a winding-up order after a mystery buyer agreed to plough £85,000 down a drain - sorry, into the club - to keep it trading. Rumours abound as to whether this buyer is an American millionaire - "Jeez, I just love these bouncing Tiggers" - or a London consortium which has joined forces with the Tiger Co-operative. But either way it's got to be great news for the club: the players will be paid for the first time since Christmas, and the rent on Boothferry Park will be also be met up to March 8 - when two rival bids will be discussed in a meeting between creditors and shareholders. It's been a good day: let's hope an even better one is just around the corner.

SPACE IS THE PLACE

Claudio Ranieri, manager of top people's boutique Chelsea's of Chelsea, didn't have a row with any of his players during last Sunday's FA Cup rumble with Arsenal. Not even with chippy shop steward Dennis Wise - and the club are prepared to sue anyone brave enough to put it in an exclusive on their back page (ie: The Sun). "There was no confrontation at half-time," explained Chelsea Village commissionaire Colin Hutchinson. "As I understand it, Ranieri did not say a lot. He sat down and was reflective. He then said some inspiring words before going out for the second half."

But while we accepted the burly doorman's account - and reflected on how a chap must feel when "inspired" by one of Ranieri's successful orations (what was the score at half-time again?) - we were at a loss to explain today's developments. It seems the entire Chelsea's of Chelsea playing staff has left the fashionable Kings Rahd in favour of Tenerife - leaving poor Claudio behind. Luckily, before anyone could say "I think we both need to give each other some space", Hutchinson was on hand to ease our troubled mind, the epaulettes on his blazer lightly flapping in the light West London breeze.

"It was never intended that Claudio would go with the players to Tenerife," Hutch told London's Evening Standard newspaper, before explaining how Ranieri has flown home on a pre-arranged visit to Italy to visit his family, watch some games and "hopefully do a bit on his English as well". Big Colin continued: "It was decided to let the players have a break from Ranieri and for him to have a break from them. There is nothing sinister in it." That's as maybe, but the Fiver knows from bitter experience that trial separations rarely work out. And with the commissionaire reiterating his support for the boss - "it's too early to judge Ranieri" - some Chelsea players shouldn't be surprised if they come back to find their stuff on the doorstep and the locks changed.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I feel useless" - Like Woody in Toy Story, the once-loved but now overlooked Valencia midfielder Didier Deschamps sits slumped on a bench feeling sorry for himself.

LET'S GET READY TO RUMBLE

It gets dull when the same few teams win all the time. And like you, the Fiver is sick of seeing the likes of Manchester United, Chelsea and Leicester pick up all the gongs season after season. So thank God for this year's Worthington Cup final, which pits two unfashionable and perennially hopeless outfits against each other for the big prize. Neither Birmingham nor Liverpool have won anything for decades, so whatever the outcome in the Millennium Stadium on Sunday, it's bound to be a breath of fresh air.

And the crazy Cup fever began in earnest today, with Birmingham's Michael Johnson outlining his plans to outfox opponents Liverpool with some crafty psychological warfare. It seems the Blues "psyched out" Ipswich in the semi-final by shouting at them in the tunnel before the game, and as they won that one 4-1 after extra-time, a repeat could be on the cards. "We were chanting in the tunnel before the second leg of the match with Ipswich. Most of it couldn't really be repeated in public!" chortled the fun-loving defender.

So while Johnson will be rocking with mirth all the way down to Cardiff, the Liverpool players must make their journey with trepidation, fearing they may be subjected to the sort of dirt and filth Ipswich had to suffer - lines like "Ipswich don't fancy it tonight", "we really want this" and "they won't be able to play on this pitch". Sends a chill down the spine, doesn't it? Of course, the Anfield club were accused of famously bottling it in the tunnel before the 1988 FA Cup final against Wimbledon, but that was with totally-comfortable-with-his-sexuality actor Vinnie Jones screaming in their faces. This won't be the same at all. Will it?

THE RUMOUR MILL

Fatih Terim will take over from Alberto Zaccheroni as manager of AC Milan, while former Argentina and Uruguay boss Daniel Passarella will become boss of Internazionale, according to Juventus general manager Luciano Moggi. "Terim has been lined up as Milan boss for a long time, and also Passarella is on his way to Inter," Moggi told journalists from Italian paper Corriere della Serra.

Leeds "have been linked with an unlikely move" for AC Milan striker Oliver Bierhoff, claims Planet Football. They don't provide any evidence to back up their claim, though.

Manchester United are ready to make a £15m summer swoop for Parma's French international right-back Lilian Thuram, according to the Sun.

Juanjo looks set to quit Hearts after snubbing a new contract offer.

NEWS IN BRIEF

The Football League have charged Chesterfield with a number of breaches of its regulations. The charges relate to breaches of player transfer regulations, irregular payments, and the under-reporting of gate receipts. In addition, individual charges are also being made against a number of officials and employees at the club. Chesterfield, currently 14 points clear at the top of the table, have 14 days in which to respond to the charges.

The Premier League have announced a deal for overseas television rights worth £178m over the next three years. The agreement with a consortium including Canal Plus, Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, TWI and Octagon represents a rise of around £80m on the previous overseas rights deal.

Uefa have confirmed that Leeds and Galatasaray would not be deliberately kept apart if both sides made it into the Big Cup quarter-final draw. "We know what happened last year was terrible, but if they were drawn together, the match would take place," a Uefa spokesman admitted.

Christoph Daum, dumped as the next Germany coach after failing a doping test, has admitted he is on a drugs rehabilitation course. "I go there twice a week for four hours. We talk about how it happened to me and, most importantly, about what I have to do to make sure it never happens again," he told Bild newspaper.

Ipswich have completed the signing of Celtic striker Mark Burchill on loan until the end of the season. Burchill goes straight into the squad for Saturday's match with Everton, as Town will be without strikers Marcus Stewart and Richard Naylor.

fields.headline: Murdoch lays claim to more Premiership rights
fields.trailText: 4.30pm: A group of broadcasters, including News Corp, has snapped up the overseas broadcast rights to the football Premiership, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch has strengthened his grip on the football Premiership after a consortium including his News Corporation group snapped up the overseas broadcast rights to the league.

The consortium, which includes French pay-TV operator Canal Plus, sports marketing giant Octagon and sports broadcaster Trans World International, has paid £178m for a three-year deal that begins next season.

"After lengthy negotiations, we have concluded a deal that recognises the enormous global strength of the FA Premier League.

"The exposure this gives us will enhance the reputation of the league and its member clubs throughout the world," said Richard Scudamore, chief execuitve of the Premier League.

News Corp controls BSkyB, which paid £1.1bn for the UK broadcast rights last summer.

However, the drawn out negotiations over pay-per-view show no sign of ending, with some parties expressing doubts about making a profit from a deal.

Sources close to the negotiations said a deal was still being thrashed out and was unlikely to be sealed until April.

The interested parties are understood to include Cable company NTL, pay-TV broadcaster U>direct and BSkyB.

webTitle: The reading group on: An Equal Music by Vikram Seth

fields.headline: The reading group on: An Equal Music by Vikram Seth
fields.standfirst:
February's choice for the reading group is Vikram Seth's An Equal Music. Reactions have been mixed, ranging from "nauseating" to "deeply evocative and hugely emotional". Read the highlights of the discussion so far here, then go the talkboards to read on, or join in.

Read the rest of the discussion
Introduction to the reading group
fields.trailText: Gillian68: I loved this. It had me gripped from the moment he sees his ex-lover from the bus. Seth is a good writer but I'd never thought of him as brilliant before - A Suitable Boy was enjoyable and Golden Gate was clever, but this is a whole new side to him.
fields.body:
Gillian68: I loved this. It had me gripped from the moment he sees his ex-lover from the bus. Seth is a good writer but I'd never thought of him as brilliant before - A Suitable Boy was enjoyable and Golden Gate was clever, but this is a whole new side to him.

Fmk: ...Too staid, too formal, too dull

Caliban: It's dull only if you don't understand the passions the book is talking about: obsessive love, lives spent trying to recapture perfection. The mechanics of the plot are familiar, but that shouldn't be a bar to the success of the novel... I have very high praise for Seth's style (never before having read any of his books); wonderfully sparse yet deeply evocative and hugely emotional; highly appropriate when the characters are so intense.
Staid, formal and dull? Absolutely not. There's more to be achieved with the novel than the pursuit of specious "innovation", in any respect. Writing a novel about music is a genuinely difficult undertaking... but Seth has managed to write a novel that actually accurately conveys a great deal of the emotions it inspires. Hugely enjoyable and highly recommended.

Fmk: If you love classical music, you'll love this book. If you don't, don't bother trying. The author didn't.

Caliban: I'm disappointed that you feel that this book is only for lovers of classical music. I abhor Schubert, and I've always subscribed to the view of Bach that can be summarised by "too many notes". But the emotions conjured by music are very much like that of love: powerful, universal and yet individual. Surely that's a central theme of the novel? I feel that anyone who responds emotionally to music, in whatever idiom, would get something from this book. How many people does that leave out?

Lizzygirl: I studied (classical) music and know a bit about that world. Generally, I found [this book] very over-researched and not at all realistic. Most musicians are just not that spiritual and soul-searching about their music! They didn't seem like real, breathing characters to me - only cardboard cutout 'musicians'. He overdoes the whole Art of Fugue/Schubert thing too and, although I have a fondness for music by both these composers, I found it quite nauseating. Also, the writing style seems cliché-ridden, stale and rather bland.

CL2K: What I found so satisfying and so moving about An Equal Music was its open-hearted admission of artistic imperfection; of the imperfection of human experience and the attempt to describe it... In An Equal Music Seth exposes the reality and the difficulties of coming to terms with flawed characters as imperfect as ourselves; cadences and relations of music and of speech which we cannot always hear clearly when our hearing is not removed; beauties of art or of character which depend entirely on the beholder and his or her innate weaknesses, and a world in which the acceptance of the mediocre as the best we can achieve is an act of courage - a recognition of the human condition and of all its frailties in its own artistic expression of itself.

AlargeElk: This certainly wasn't a flawless novel, and there was an awful lot that was inaccessible, or at least very much more difficult, for somebody like me understanding very little about classical music. I think the strength of the book for me lies in the characters. I think they do ring true - CL is right, they are all in some sense flawed, but this is simply a reflection of real life... On the whole I enjoyed this, but did come away feeling slightly that there was a whole other novel underneath the one that I'd read, one that I would need to know a lot more about music to appreciate.

Lindawebb: On the whole I also enjoyed this book. I, again, don't have a classical music background but I envied the close relationship of the quartet and the pleasure music gave them - which was I suppose the point of the ending of the book... Still it was a shame to have yet another disabled character in literature (see Lois Keith's book "Take up thy Bed and Walk) who is "courageous" in facing her disability but has no other distinguishing features to round out her character. I also think the places in which the action takes place are stereotypes of London, Venice and Vienna rather than the real thing.

asandk: I was looking forward to reading this, and overall found it somewhat disappointing. It's a super ambition, to try to capture in a novel how great music can interlace our lives. But I don't think Seth can really be said to have pulled it off.

webTitle: Number of looked-after children on the rise

fields.headline: Number of looked-after children on the rise
fields.trailText: The number of abused, neglected or at-risk children being looked after by councils in England is on the increase, according to government statistics released today. Linda Steele reports
fields.body:
The number of abused, neglected or at-risk children being looked after by councils in England is on the increase, according to government statistics released today.

The number of children looked after because of potential or actual abuse or neglect rose by 11% of the looked-after total in four years to March 2000. Nearly one-third (31%) of looked-after children in 1999-2000 had been at risk or had actually been abused or neglected, compared with one-fifth in 1995-96.

But Association of Directors of Social Services (ADSS) said it was not yet possible to determine whether the figures represented a rise in child abuse and neglect or a greater vigilance on the part of social workers.

ADSS president Moira Gibb said: "There's a general trend upwards and towards the younger children - and we don't have enough data on why," she said. "There must be a connection with the number of children in poverty and the fact that there has been an emphasis on neglect and the fact that [neglected] children aren't allowed to drift."

The number of children being looked after by local authorities in England on 31 March 2000 was also up by 5% on the previous year and was 18% higher than the same date in 1994. The total number of children looked after at any time during the year was 92,400 (or 82 for every 10,000 children aged under 18 in England).

The figures did, however, express the "churn" in children being looked after. "Because children come into care doesn't mean to say they stay in care," said Ms Gibb. "There's a huge turnover. Lots of people go in and go out and the snapshot and the total can be two different groups. But it will explain part of the pressure on children's budgets."

Social services departments are gradually approaching the government's target of no more than 16% of children in care having three or more placements in a year. Nearly a fifth (18%) of children in care had had three or more placements during the year to March 2000. But that was down from 19.6% in 1997-98.

There has been an upward shift in the age of care leavers. During 1999-2000, 2,700 young people left care aged 16, (down from 3,300 a year earlier); 2,700 left care on their 18th birthday (compared with 2,300 in 1998-99.) The figures appear to reflect increased incidence of good practice requiring councils not to discharge young people too quickly but to continue to act as "good parents".

The figures, which are for the year ending 31 March 2000, also confirm a trend towards greater use of the courts. They show that the proportion starting to be looked after under single voluntary agreements has fallen - down from 77% in 1995-96 to 68% in 1999-2000. The number of children who started under interim care orders was 13%, up from 7% in 1995-96.

"This suggests that the complexities of the [child protection] task and of children's lives and tasks are greater," said Ms Gibb. "But we don't know enough to say quite why those trends are occurring."

The statistics also show the number of looked-after children being adopted has also gone up by 500 to 2,700. This represents more than half of all adoptions in England.

Foster parents were looking after 65% of looked-after children, similar to proportions in previous years.

Other statistics released today show that children in need form about 2% of the total population aged up to 18. Approximately a quarter of children in need are looked after.

These figures highlight a wide and currently unexplained variation in the incidence of children considered in need. Shire counties have "noticeably lower" and London authorities "markedly higher" incidences than the national average, according to the Department of Health (DoH).

"These variations cannot be wholly explained in terms of social factors alone," according to the DoH.

Social services in England spend money on about 230,000 children in need in a typical week.

Under the Children Act 1989, a child is looked after if he or she is placed in their care by a court (under a care order) or provided with accommodation by the authority's social services department for more than 24 hours. Children are in need if they will have their health or development impaired if they don't get a service.

The looked-after statistics released today are based on data provided by 149 authorities. The children in need statistics are based on data from 139 councils.

fields.headline: Leeds storm into the last eight
fields.standfirst:
Smith strikes twice as O'Leary's men join Real in qualifying
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: Alan Smith struck twice on a glorious night for Leeds as David O'Leary's men ruthlessly overpowered the Belgian champions to reach the quarter-finals with two games to spare after Lazio failed to defeat Real Madrid.
fields.byline: Daniel Taylor  at Stade Constant Vanden Stock
fields.body:
When it comes to Europe things just get better and better for Leeds United. There is something about these nights, the intoxicating atmosphere of European football at its highest level, that brings out the best in David O'Leary's team and now they stand heroically on the brink of further glory.

By ruthlessly overpowering an Anderlecht side who had won their last nine European ties on home soil Leeds not only enhanced their blossoming reputation as fearless travellers here last night but also propelled them into the quarter-finals with two group matches to spare.

That was due not only to their own efforts but to Lazio's failure to beat Real Madrid in Rome where Raul's equaliser earned the holders a 2-2 draw and ended the Italian champions' interest in the competition.

It may be asking too much of Leeds to win the European Cup but as long as they continue to defy the odds in such a startling way the shock-waves will reverberate through Europe, from Madrid to Munich, Milan to Moscow.

"I'm so proud of my players. The incentive was there to prove people wrong and we've done just that," said O'Leary. "We're not a bad little team and we can only get better. I'm sure we have surprised a lot of people across Europe."

Even by the high standards Leeds have set on previous foreign excursions this was extraordinary stuff. For long spells at Elland Road nine days ago Anderlecht had played the more intelligent football but after 38 minutes here the Premiership side had scored three times.

Alan Smith had not scored since poaching the late winner against Lazio in the Italian capital last December but the coltish striker struck twice in the first half and his tireless running, aided and abetted by the rejuvenated Mark Viduka, was the catalyst for one of the finest results achieved by an English club on foreign soil in recent times.

Smith's double sandwiched a fine breakaway goal from Viduka and, though Jan Koller headed a consolation on 76 minutes, Ian Harte's penalty five minutes later gave the score a more accurate reflection. Leeds were that good.

It all started after 13 minutes when Eirik Bakke's dummy run threw the Anderlecht defence and Smith darted in to side-foot his shot past Zvonko Milojevic.

Then on 34 minutes Dominic Matteo set off on a surging run down the left flank. His deep cross reached Viduka at the far post and the Australian's looping header seemed to stay in the air for an age before dropping into the goal.

The home defence were still conducting their inquest when O'Leary and his coaching staff were cavorting on the touchline again. David Batty's tenacity won the ball in midfield and, with the home players caught out, his through-ball was weighted perfectly for the alert Smith to run clear and dink an exquisite shot over Milojevic.

Leeds fans with long memories will remember the last time they played here when Billy Bremner chipped the only goal of their European Cup quarter-final with such delicacy that Anderlecht's goalkeeper Leen Barth trotted upfield to shake his hand. No repeat here: poor old Milojevic could barely pull himself to his feet.

On a playing surface resembling a potato field Smith and Viduka continued to weave their elaborate patterns after the re-start and, rather than rest on their laurels, Leeds maintained the upper hand.

Moreover, Rio Ferdinand and Lucas Radebe stifled the Belgian attack so expertly that Nigel Martyn spent much of the second half as a spectator until Koller headed in Didier Dheedene's free-kick.

That prompted a few flutters but, when Glen de Boerk bundled Viduka to the ground, Harte finished emphatically from the penalty spot and O'Leary had the excuse for a childish spat with Aimé Anthuenis after the final whistle. "My players read what you came out with," he said, referring to derogatory pre-match comments attributed to the home coach. "Goodbye."

Anderlecht's awesome record here had already incorporated wins over Manchester United and Lazio this season and the Brussels press has been crammed with articles all week suggesting this would be another night for beery Belgian celebrations on Grand' Place.

Instead the Leeds fans in this Lego-like stadium will have made for home with thoughts already turning headily to the quarter-final draw on March 16. The adventure goes on.

Anderlecht: (4-4-2) Milojevic; Crasson, De Boeck, Ilic (Dindane, 37min), Dheedene; Stoica, Baseggio, Vanderhaeghe, Goor; Koller, Radzinsky.

Leeds United: (4-4-2) Martyn; Mills, Radebe, Ferdinand, Harte; Bakke, Dacourt, Batty, Matteo; Viduka (Kewell, 83), Smith.

Referee: R Pedersen (Norway).

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Careless Gunners caught at the post
fields.trailText: Edmilson headed in a last-minute corner to cancel out Dennis Bergkamp's strike and make Arsenal's passage to the last eight all the more complicated.
fields.body:
The sense of disappointment at Highbury was palpable and Arsène Wenger may have felt that more acutely than most. In the summer the Arsenal manager was forced to drop interest in Edmilson because of passport problems. This morning he must wish the Brazilian had not been allowed in by customs at all.

By heading in a last-minute corner to equalise for Lyon last night Edmilson has muddied Arsenal's path to the quarter-finals. Had Wenger's players held out they would have needed only a victory at home to Spartak Moscow on March 6 to be certain. Now they may need to go to Bayern Munich the following week in search of points.

Yet, if the manner and timing of the goal will anger Arsenal, they can have few complaints at having to settle for a draw. This was a far from impressive performance and Edmilson in particular will feel justice was done after being shoved by Dennis Bergkamp in the lead-up to the Dutchman's 32nd-minute goal.

After a bright opening in which Arsenal looked to have too much strength, pace and movement for their opponents, they struggled to find much fluency and lacked a killer instinct with their final pass. Rarely at home can they have created so few clear chances.

Lyon may not have forced a serious save out of David Seaman all night but they had Arsenal on the back foot for long periods as Wenger's players seemed strangely content to settle for a repeat of the 1-0 win they achieved in France nine days ago. It was a dangerous policy against a team who could not afford defeat. Wenger said fatigue had played its part.

"The technical quality suffered because the players were tired," he said. "And in the second half that, linked with the fact that we didn't come out enough, put us under threat of making a mistake." Like Manchester United on Tuesday they made it late.

After the collapse from 2-0 up against Bayern Munich before Christmas and the way late goals conceded against Lens cost them in the Champions League two seasons ago, this will bring back bad memories. Yet Arsenal remain in second spot and need only finish level on points with Lyon to go through, having taken four points off them. "I'm still confident," Wenger said.

He will know, though, that too few of his players performed to their best last night. Patrick Vieira impressed, though he was beaten in the air by Edmilson for the goal. Ashley Cole did well in front of the watching Sven-Goran Eriksson and Gilles Grimandi was tenacious at the back in the absence of the injured Tony Adams. Bergkamp, too, had some fine moments.

Yet he became increasingly peripheral as Lyon, who had shown a willingness to commit players forward from the start, went in search of an equaliser. The wide midfielders Robert Pires and Freddie Ljungberg could make little headway and apart from a Grimandi volley, a Thierry Henry shot and a deflected Lauren header Arsenal rarely threatened in the second half.

How different it had looked at the start. With Bergkamp full of ideas and Arsenal dominant in midfield, they had swarmed forward with real menace, using the flanks to good effect.

No sooner had Pires struck a cross-shot wide than Parlour had a great chance to give them a 13th-minute lead. Supplied by Bergkamp's cushioned header he wastefully sliced a volley into the side-netting from eight yards.

After Lyon had shown signs of their danger on the counter attack, Arsenal took the lead in controversial fashion. Bergkamp appeared to push Edmilson out of the way as he chased a Pires pass but the Slovakian referee Lubos Michel allowed play to go on and the Dutchman coolly curled his shot beyond Grégory Coupet.

Wenger may have seen the challenge as a "typical English shoulder-to-shoulder" but that looked generous. "He pushed me," Edmilson said. "It should never have been a goal so the fact that I scored was some type of justice."

That goal, though, took time in coming. As Arsenal soaked up most of what Lyon had to offer it seemed they would get the victory they craved. But Vikash Dhorasoo, who came on to add real verve and skill to the French side who ended with four strikers, sent over a corner which Edmilson headed in. Having hauled themselves off the bottom so impressively last week, Wenger must hope this does not prove costly.

Had Wenger's players held out they would have needed only a victory at home to Spartak Moscow on March 6 to be certain. Now they may need to go to Bayern Munich the following week in search of points. webTitle: SMG ups stake in Scottish Radio Holdings

fields.headline: SMG ups stake in Scottish Radio Holdings
fields.trailText:
4.30pm: Scottish Media Group has increased its shareholding in Scottish Radio Holdings to 23%, writes Dan Milmo.
Dec 18: SRH increases grip on Scottish Radio Holdings
fields.body:
SMG has raised the stakes in the battle for control of Scottish Radio Holdings after another raid on the company's much-coveted stock.

SMG, owner of the Scottish Television and Grampian ITV franchises, has paid £11.9m for 2.3% of SRH's shares, taking its holding in the company to 23%.

"We were offered a line of stock at a sensible price and we felt it was in SMG's long-term interests to take it," said a spokesman for SMG.

The Glasgow-based group is nearing the shareholder threshold of 29.9%, when stock-market rules dictate it must table an offer for the whole company.

However, SMG faces competition from Scottish rival DC Thomson, the privately owned publisher of the Beano and Dandy comics.

DC Thomson owns 9.6% of SRH and has closer ties with the radio broadcaster, which owns Radio Clyde in Glasgow, Edinburgh's Radio Forth and the Ireland on Sunday newspaper.

The other obstacle in SMG's path is the 1996 Broadcasting Act.

This bars the holder of a regional ITV franchise from holding a commercial radio licence in the whole area.

But sources close to the tussle for control of SRH claim the guidelines - which were barely mentioned in last year's communications white paper - are sufficiently lax to sneak through some kind of deal.

"The rules are not specific and do not detail the percentage of stock you can hold in different companies," said one source.

A spokeswoman for SRH said the company is still undergoing a strategic review to determine the company's future, and it is negotiating with "a number of interested parties".

Shares in SRH became hot property following the publication of the white paper, which hinted at scrapping current restrictions on ownership of commercial radio stations.

Big players in such as Emap, GWR and Capital Radio cannot expand much further under the current guidelines.

They are keen to consolidate the industry from around a dozen companies to just three.
