webTitle: Jacko bans TV from Oxford Union address

fields.headline: Jacko bans TV from Oxford Union address
fields.trailText: 4.15pm: The carefully orchestrated PR drive surrounding Michael Jackson's UK trip has become a nightmare, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
The carefully orchestrated public relations drive surrounding Michael Jackson's trip to the UK has turned into a PR nightmare.

PR company MacLaurin has just agreed a deal to handle the eccentric star's March 6 Oxford Union address.

But sources say the singer, who is known to be a control freak, has decided to ban radio and TV journalists from the event.

It means ITN, Sky News and the BBC, who will all want to cover the unusual event on their news bulletins, will be unable to get pictures.

TV cameras camping outside will be unable to get a glimpse of Jackson because of the huge security entourage that will surround him.

Jackson, who has undergone dramatic cosmetic surgery and occasionally wears a surgical mask, is hyper-sensitive about his public image.

Today it emerged there will also be severe restrictions on the number of journalists who will have access to the Oxford university event.

More than 200 reporters have already requested accreditation but access will be limited to 50 places.

And it is not even clear if these will get access to the inner chamber where the debate will take place.

MacLaurin's deal comes only two weeks after Mark Borkowski PR resigned the same job.

It is understood MacLaurin also had difficulties with Jackson's team and newspaper reporters say company chief Brian MacLaurin was on the verge of resigning the account this morning.

It is understood the outspoken Rabbi Shmuley Boteach, president of Jackson's Heal the Kids charity and a close adviser to the star, forms part of the LA team responsible for organising the trip.

More than 20,000 people applied for tickets to hear Jackson make his first ever public address at the Oxford Union.

The singer will use the appearance to launch his Heal the Kids charity in this country.

The police are expected to cordon off the streets surrounding the 178-year-old union's debating chamber.

During Jackson's week-long visit, he will be the best man at the wedding in Henley of psychic Uri Geller.

He will also attend the launch of Geller's and Rabbi Boteach's book, the Confessions of a Rabbi and a Psychic, published by Robson Books under the Chrysalis Books umbrella.

The singer also appear at a fan club event called the Michael Jackson Day.

fields.headline: A lethal dose
fields.standfirst: How much do you have to drink in one night to kill yourself? In the wake of two deaths, Laura Barton investigates
fields.trailText: How much do you have to drink in one night to kill yourself? In the wake of two deaths, Laura Barton investigates.
fields.body:
It tastes like cinnamon. And not altogether dissimilar to the sort of confection they sell by the quarter in old-fashioned sweetshops, along with the barley sugar and the colt's foot and the sarsparilla. Yet it is as strong as whisky, and, at £25 a bottle, will make a hefty dent in your pocket money. After Shock is a 40% proof available in cinnamon or peppermint flavours. It comes in a four-square frosted bottle with its name emblazoned across it, comic-book style. And it will get you drunk. Fast.

Some bars refuse to sell it. Others ration the number of shots each customer may down. It's a Friday-night-and-let's-get-drunk sort of drink, rather than a smoochy glass of red, or a quiet pint at the local. As such, it has, not surprisingly, become something of a craze with younger drinkers, who have a vast amount of falling over, snogging and throwing up to do before their curfew time. With its kiddie-pleasing flavour, After Shock is fast becoming the Sunny Delight of the spirits world.

It is believed that Angela Watts, 16, was drinking After Shock last Saturday night. She went out with her boyfriend and some friends, drinking cocktails at a restaurant, and then continuing drinking at a house party. Her boyfriend's mother woke at 3am to hear Angela being sick. The mother put her back to bed in a spare room, but the next morning, Angela would not wake up. She died in hospital, of presumed alcohol poisoning.

The story of her untimely death is the second story of a lethal dose of alcohol in the past week. George Butterworth died, aged 36, after a late-night drinking game at Slaithwaite working men's club. During the game, he downed eight pints and eight double Pernods in 20 minutes. Afterwards the club president, David Thornton, said: "Mr Butterworth seemed to know what he was doing. He looked like he was having a good time."

People who drink a vast quantity, over a short period of time, usually know what they are doing. They are getting drunk as quickly as they can. What they are probably not aware of, however, is that a lethal dose can be suprisingly low. Experts say stories about famous boozers downing umpteen bottles of spirits on a night out - and surviving - don't reflect the real dangers. We know long-term alcohol abuse leads to liver damage and all sorts of health nastiness. But do you know how many pints will kill you? Or how many glasses of wine?

Alcohol affects different people in different ways. A 20 stone man of 6ft 3in is less likely to collapse under the weight of six vodka and Red Bulls than a seven stone woman of 5ft 5in. Similarly, how you react to alcohol depends greatly upon whether you have eaten recently, whether the alcohol is consumed with that meal, whether you are used to drinking substantial amounts, and also how fit you are. If the strongest thing you have touched all day was that grande skinny latte this morning, and then you wallop down six pints of Stella, don't be surprised to find yourself vomiting in the high street by closing time.

So taking all the whys and wherefores into account, what is a lethal dose? Dr Guy Ratcliffe, executive director of the Medical Council on Alcoholism, says that after a dose of about 500mgs of alcohol, "you are at risk of not surviving". (To put that into perspective, if your blood alcohol level is at 80mgs and you attempt to drive, you lose your licence. A bottle of spirits, or about 15 pints, contains approximately 500mgs.)

"If you consume 600mgs, death is pretty well nigh certain," Ratcliffe adds. "The effects of alcohol are largely on the nervous system: you will experience a loss of self-control, you will start to stagger, your speech will be slurred, you may experience some difficulty remembering things. You will become oblivious to your surroundings, you may feel sleepy and eventually you may fall into a comatose state." Apparently, this is due to "depression of the higher centres of the brain, which controls respiratory function and triggers the heart to beat".

After a bottle and a half of gin, you are almost certain to be in a comatose position, and in need of intensive care and respiratory support while your body metabolises the alcohol.

Strangely, anyone who does survive such a "major alcohol insult" is unlikely to experience any long-term effects. It is while under the influence that they are most at risk. And one of the big risks, of course, is that feeling very drunk makes you feel sick; but anyone in a semi-comatose state is also in danger of choking on his or her own vomit.

But being sick aside, what exactly is it about a huge dose of alcohol that can kill you? It's quite simple. As Dr Martin Plant, director of the alcohol and health research centre in Edinburgh, puts it: "In large quantities, alcohol is simply a poison."

webTitle: Health: Diary of a marathon runner

fields.headline: Marathon man
fields.trailText: There are some delicate subjects which should only be referred to in hushed tones. One of them is toilet training for a marathon.
fields.body:
There are some delicate subjects which should only be referred to in hushed tones. One of them is toilet training for a marathon. Anyone who has been running for any length of time will probably, at some point, have experienced what the Americans tautologically call the runner's trots: the desire to head for the nearest isolated bush and relieve yourself.

All very well in the Rockies or Arizona desert, but uncomfortably public on The Mall or crossing Tower Bridge with a BBC camera on your tail. According to those who, for some reason, wanted to find out, about one in three marathon runners suffers from diarrhoea. The reason is pretty simple: running shakes up your insides. During a long jog, blood is diverted from your digestive system to your heart and muscles. Without enough blood, the gut won't work normally. It is starved of oxygen, excess water is left in the intestines and eventually the gastrointestinal process breaks down, leading to cramps and diarrhoea.

Not pleasant. So how can you avoid it? An internet search throws up a few tips, not all of them altogether useful. One is to run in a park or an area which has a scattering of portable toilets. Genius.

Another says that if you feel something sort of coming on then slow your pace to a walk, breathe deeply and "think about something else, say, the writings of Nietzsche". More bizarrely, there is this suggestion: "Carry a plastic bag, toilet paper and towelette (and take your trash with you)."

That's the management side. There is also prevention. This is basically not eating or drinking certain things. Before the race, cut out caffeine and alcohol which irritate digestion and watch out for high-fibre carbohydrates. A banana is the best as it's easily digestible and high in nutrients.

But if all that fails, there will be toilets every two miles of the marathon. They include a 440ft continuous urinal trough and three urinal trailers. Relief all round.

fields.headline: 'If you weren't sick, you would think it was a five-star hotel'
fields.standfirst: This centre offers reflexology, wonderful staff and first-class pain relief. Demand for places is huge. So why are half the beds empty?  Esther Addley on hospices in crisis
fields.trailText: This centre offers reflexology, wonderful staff and first-class pain relief. Demand for places is huge. So why are half the beds empty? Esther Addley on hospices in crisis.
fields.body:
Pat Davis presides over one of Bristol's largest retail businesses. A sharply turned out executive with an alphabet soup of letters after her name, she has 27 shops under her management in the city, and oversees the financial arrangements for 220 paid staff and more than 700 volunteers, juggling investments and an annual turnover worth millions.

She works from an office in central Bristol, but we meet in her business's premises in the north of the city, an impressive modern building with beautiful, landscaped gardens, dotted with rose bowers, benches and water features. It is a lovely place to work. It is an even more enviable environment in which to die.

Those lucky enough not to have required the services of a hospice are likely to be surprised by St Peter's hospice, for which Davis works as fundraising director. Nowhere to be seen are the cracked pipes and grubby paintwork of too many NHS wards. The decor is light and breezy; cheerful nurses sweep along corridors decked in fresh flowers. It feels calm, quiet, restful.

But this is not the hushed, stifling quiet of imminent death. The corridors are silent because almost half of the beds are empty. Demand for a place is unrelenting, says Davis, but the hospice can't afford to staff them. Despite the 27 charity shops dedicated to raising funds for the hospice, she can't find the cash to care for any more than 10 in-patients at a time.

Most of us, doubtless, prefer not to think of it, but St Peter's is just the place where we would like to imagine ourselves dying: local, pleasant, lavishly staffed by NHS standards, and with a level of specialisation in pain management that is often missing in state-provided health care. The beauty of the place, says Chris Salt, 73, one of the patients, is in the detail: "Every tray comes with a vase of flowers, it makes such a difference."

Reflexology and aromatherapy are as much part of the care as that of the specialist palliative nurses who work there. Rooms are often ensuite, and the baths are fitted with jacuzzis. "If you weren't sick," says Salt, "you would think you were in a five-star hotel."

They have even taken care in the decor, says Hazel Elliott, the nursing director, her voice dropping to a whisper. "I told them we weren't to have any of the bedrooms painted green or yellow. If you are a bit jaundiced, the last thing you want is your skin being reflected in the walls."

We may hope to end our days somewhere so humane, but the question is whether, after we have used up the remainder of our allotted four-score-and-whatever, there will be any hospices left. Of the 230 hospices dotted around the UK, a few are NHS run, others are managed by specialist charities such as Marie Curie Cancer Care, but the vast majority (185) are independent, voluntary set-ups like St Peter's. They are local charities, locally managed - and almost entirely locally funded. And that, says Davis, is the problem.

The sector's umbrella group, Help the Hospices, has just issued a bleak warning that more than half the hospices in the UK are in financial trouble. Beds are closing, nurses are being laid off, others are dipping into investments and reserves that are just about keeping the bailiffs at bay, but will not last for ever.

The St Peter's site in north Bristol was built three years ago to expand the services offered at another site; in total, it has 20 beds open in the city. But, says, Davis, the organisation's funding from the NHS has gone up "hardly at all", despite the fact that service provision has doubled.

As well as the in-patients, up to 120 patients attend St Peter's' two sites weekly through day sessions, where they can have their hair done, consult a doctor, or chat with other patients. The hospice also employs nurses who work in the community, helping patients in their homes and providing specialist training to GPs and district nurses. Within the space of a year, 1,200 patients come into direct contact with its services.

While homes for the dying were run by religious groups from the 19th century, the modern hospice movement can trace its origins to the late 1960s, when a small number of hospices were established. But as the population has aged and palliative medicine - offered to those for whom a cure is no longer a possibility, but who need help managing pain - has become more sophisticated, governments have recognised that they have a moral responsibility to care for the dying. There is something about end of life care that is different from having a broken leg or getting your tonsils out."

In September, the government announced an extra £50m for palliative care - very welcome, all say, but it remains to be seen whether any of this money will filter down to funding those services under threat.

"But that is no way to die."

webTitle: Health: Luisa Dillner on body dysmorphia

fields.headline: Luisa Dillner
fields.standfirst: On the very lovely (and very unfat) Uma Thurman, body dysmorphia and the folly of misusing medical terms
fields.trailText: On the very lovely (and very unfat) Uma Thurman, body dysmorphia and the folly of misusing medical terms.
fields.body:
Tere's only one thing worse than seeing a beautiful, slim, world-famous actress being interviewed and that's hearing her moan about her body. What is it about actresses that they forever rub our noses in our own imperfections by whining that they're too fat, that they hate their perfect, cute, button noses, and taut, impossible-to-achieve-in-my-lifetime, buttocks. Now Uma Thurman, a classic beauty if ever there was one, has upped the ante. The 30-year-old star of Pulp Fiction and Dangerous Liaisons told Talk magazine: "Ever since I had my baby I've had that body dysmorphic disorder. I see myself as fat."

If Thurman does have body dysmorphic disorder, then this is serious indeed. Enrico Morselli, a 19th century physician wrote of it: "The dysmorphic patient is really miserable: in the middle of his daily routines, everywhere and at any time, he is caught by the doubt of deformity."

According to the New Oxford Textbook of Psychiatry, half of all sufferers are women and the condition usually starts in adolescence. People with the condition usually dislike their skin, hair and nose and have no insight into their preoccupation. More than 90% will obsessively check, groom and camouflage their appearance and many find it hard to have friends, to date or to go to restaurants. One third will attempt suicide. Some people will also have eating disorders, depression, be phobic about social situations, and many will never fully recover.

The list of symptoms is to show that feeling fat is not enough to qualify. Feeling fat is the female condition, the equivalent of being born with original sin in the Catholic church. Diet you may, but you will never get rid of feeling fat. Thurman is reported to be getting thinner, while being openly terrified of carbohydrates - a sure sign of a persistent dieter. "I don't want to eat bread," she is said to have exclaimed in a restaurant recently.

Jane Fonda, meanwhile, has spurned the more esoteric diagnosis for a more familiar one. The well-honed actress who terrorised a generation of women into hurting themselves in the gym in the pursuit of the perfect body, now admits she has a life-long history of bulimia and anorexia.

"For 25 years I could never put a forkful in my mouth without feeling fear," she says. Well, thanks Jane, for dedicating your life to making so many of us feel the same. But then women may be worse than men for acting as diet police. A survey by newwomen.co.uk of 3,000 women aged 25, found that it was other women's critical comments, rather than men's, that gave them negative feelings about their bodies. A dismal 1% of women were completely content with their appearance. As Lorraine Eames, the website's editor, says: "It is time we let go of the unattainable perfect body dream and celebrated the female form in all its uniqueness."

Fat chance. However causal or not the link is between feeling fat and developing an eating disorder, there is evidence that eating disorders are on the increase in the western world. A study in the International Journal of Eating Disorders found that the incidence of anorexia nervosa, particularly in women aged between 15 and 24, has been steadily rising over the past half century. Both anorexia and bulimia (uncontrolled overeating and purging) are associated with severe dieting.

Pictures of slim, gorgeous actresses and models may not cause eating disorders, but they remind us of what an ideal woman's body should be like. How confusing then, when these women whine about their bodies. But much more confusing if they give their insecurities a medical-sounding name, because a social explanation isn't good enough. We can no longer just be sad or bad, we must be depressed or have a personality disorder.

I had some body dysmorphism of my own last night. But then I have a legitimate medical name for my condition. It's called pregnancy.

 Sarah Boseley is away.

fields.headline: Diary of a hypochondriac
fields.standfirst: It's 10 years since he was stabbed during a robbery. But as all his friends know, Matthew Norman doesn't really like to talk about it ...
fields.trailText: It's 10 years since he was stabbed during a robbery. But as all his friends know, Matthew Norman doesn't really like to talk about it ...
fields.body:
Friday: The 10th anniversary of One Lung Day is on Thursday, and tonight after dinner the psychosomatic effect kicks in. While playing solo darts and contemplating a 127 check out (treble 19, treble 18, double eight), I suffer sharp pain in the back beneath the left shoulder blade, where the nerve ends for the lungs are located. It was 10 years ago that a young burglar broke into the Johannesburg house I was staying in, breaking my friend's skull and back, and then giving me hammer scars on head and arms preparatory to popping a knife into my left lung. Ten years. How much I have changed.

Saturday: As my friends know, I never talk about the incident ... and yet the approaching anniversary has an impact. Over the dinner my wife has so lovingly prepared (the insouciant way she scoops the bindi bhaji out of the foil carton, the assurance with which she presses the microwave buttons), I remind her how, once the pneumothorax operation had worked and the lung was reinflated, my surgeon Dr Wolfie Frankel pointed at the proximity of the wound to both heart and aorta on the x-ray, and said: "You, sir, are a very, very lucky boy." "Well, yes, it's always been an ambition," I replied. "I even wrote to Jimmy Savile once, but he never wrote back." Perhaps baffled by the reference, he didn't smile, just handed me the x-rays and the bill.

Sunday: The 10th anniversary of One Lung Day is on Thursday, and tonight after dinner the psychosomatic effect kicks in. "Oh God, no, please no, not the x-rays." Rebecca walks into the sitting room and finds me fetching the brown envelope from the top drawer of my office chest. "Not the 18th of an inch. Not the 0.8 of a millimetre short of the aorta." When this metaphorical stab in the back is matched by a literal one (the lung nerve ends are more sensitised by the hour), I return the x-rays and head morosely up to bed.

Monday: A trip to St Mary's, Paddington, reminds me of the day itself - one that dawned for me on a trolley in the reception area of a dismal, underfunded Jo'Burg general hospital and dusked in a private room on the other side of town in a charming private room. The gulf between public and private health is just as wide here now, of course, and in an NHS ward with the traditional peeling walls air of gloom, I visit someone in their 90s being cared for by overstretched nurses making increasingly fraught phone inquiries after a hungry patient's meals.

Then it's over the road to the private wing, where I go to see a day-old baby girl and her mother. Here I am offered champagne. What crude contrasts between the opposite ends of both the life cycle and the health care spectrum these are, and sloping off towards the tube through the late afternoon drizzle I feel a bit like Alan Bennett, only without the wit and acuity to do these contrasts justice.

Tuesday: On the way to work, I pass the old Grove health clinic in Goldhawk Road, an employment agency agency now, but still a ringer for a curiously above-ground nuclear shelter. It was here a decade ago that I first met Dr Sarah Jarvis when I took my chest x-rays for her inspection. It feels like 10 years, too.

Wednesday: Friends come round for supper, and when over the coffee one asks why I'm so subdued, he gets a sharp "don't start him off" glance from Rebecca. "It's nothing," I say, "except, well, you know I really don't like to talk about it, but it's 10 years tomorrow since ..." "Eighteenth of an inch," says the friend. "And this close," chips in his wife, bringing her index and middle together to convey minuteness, "to the aorta."

Thursday: I awake dehydrated and very early. It is not quite 4.30am, the time when the panic sirens went off. I shuffle downstairs and take out the x-rays. Like everyone else, I recall, Dr Jarvis wasn't interested and told me to take them home. Presumably having heard reports from my previous physician, Fleur Navey, she did ask whether this near-fatal experience had helped cure my hypochondria. Oh yes, I said, absolutely.

Well, once you realise how fragile life is, you quickly grow out of fretting about unlikely problems and get on with some carpe diem living. She nodded approvingly, and I got up to leave. "Oh, by the way," I said, Colombo-style, turning back, "just one other thing. I'm sure it's nothing, but I think I've noticed something here, on the base of my skull." She felt it thoroughly and I asked her, the familiar nausea welling up at the expectation of the death sentence, if she had an idea what it was.

"I'm afraid I do, yes," she said gravely. "It's what we doctors call a skull." Ten years on, here I am, older, fatter, balder and uglier, I reflect, as I put the x-rays away for good at the back of my bottom drawer, but quite unchanged and just as petrified as ever I was.

webTitle: Health: How to treat common ailments

fields.headline: What works
fields.standfirst: The definitive guide to treating common ailments
fields.trailText: The definitive guide to treating common ailments.
fields.body:
No 31: Cancers of the stomach, oesophagus and pancreas

Almost one in 10 cancers strike the upper gastrointestinal (UGI) system (the stomach, oesophagus or pancreas). Most sufferers are elderly, although younger people are occasionally affected. Prognosis is generally poor - only about a quarter of UK patients survive a year after diagnosis. International studies show better survival rates elsewhere.

Diagnosis

Early diagnosis is difficult. Typical symptoms - such as dyspepsia, nausea and stomach pains - are common to many other, less serious, complaints. Government guidelines stipulate patients should have investigations within two weeks if they show symptoms including jaundice, dysphagia (when foods sticks on swallowing), or dyspepsia, when combined with other warning signs such as weight loss or family history of UGI cancer. Anyone with suspected oesophageal or stomach cancer should have an endoscopy; ultrasound is best for suspected pancreatic cancer.

Treatment

For stomach cancer, the UK's five-year survival rate of 12% is almost half the 21% European average. Later diagnosis and poorer hospital care seem to be key reasons. A major study of UGI cancer care in 29 hospitals in England and Wales found doctors who saw more patients had lower death rates.

The trend is confirmed in US studies. Surgery to remove the cancerous area is the main treatment when cancer is diagnosed early enough, but it is risky. Patients often die within one month. A large study has shown that chemotherapy before surgery for oesophageal cancer improves survival by 10% after two years.

Combining chemotherapy with surgery for stomach cancer has a slight benefit, according to analysis of several studies. Radiotherapy seems to help only a minority of patients with oesophageal cancer. For most people, palliative care to relieve symptoms is the main need. Inserting metal tubes can help swallowing.

 What works? is based on reviews of the most up-to-date and reliable evidence available. It is written in collaboration with the NHS Centre for Reviews and Dissemination at York university (01904 433 634) and verified by experts. Details can be seen at CRD.

webTitle: Foot and mouth halts hunting season

fields.headline: Foot and mouth halts hunting season
fields.standfirst: Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: Hunting was today suspended for a week across Britain because of the foot and mouth disease outbreak.
fields.body:
Hunting was today suspended for a week across Britain because of the foot and mouth disease outbreak.

The voluntary suspension from the hunting associations will be reviewed after seven days depending on the spread of the disease, the Countryside Alliance said. A spokesman confirmed the decision was in direct response to the crisis.

Farmers were today warned they would have to wait at least a week before the full extent of the outbreak is known. An export ban on meat and dairy products has effectively put Britain in quarantine and is estimated to cost the industry £8m a week.

The warning came as farming leaders met the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, in London. Mr Brown emerged from the hour-long meeting saying there had been no new cases of suspected foot and mouth reported today.

"We are going to keep the position under review but our plan is to get through this as thoroughly and quickly as we can.

"Work continues both on finding the original source of last year's classical swine fever outbreak, and this outbreak of foot and mouth disease."

Mr Brown said he wanted a full report from his staff, even if they could not pinpoint the exact source.

National Farmers' Union president Ben Gill warned of worrying times ahead for farmers. He called for farmers to be extra vigilant in checking their livestock.

At present, a total of five farms are being inspected following Tuesday's announcement that 27 pigs had been found infected at the Cheale Meats abattoir in Little Warley, Essex.

Since then, some 300 pigs and 60 cattle from the abattoir and its adjoining farm have been slaughtered in an attempt to contain the disease.

Mick Sloyan, of the meat and livestock commission, predicted the extent of the crisis would be known within a week but added that if it went beyond that there would be severe consequences for the industry.

Meanwhile, the location of the fifth farm to be placed under special restrictions emerged today.

A ministry of agriculture, fisheries and food spokesman today confirmed that tests on a farm in Hook, east Yorkshire, were being carried out after it was to have sent one of the infected pigs found in Essex.

The spokesman stressed the measure was purely precautionary and that veterinary inspectors investigated more than a dozen reports of suspected foot and mouth at abattoirs and farms every year.

webTitle: War crimes tribunal convicts Bosnian Serbs

fields.headline: War crimes tribunal convicts Bosnian Serbs
fields.standfirst: Special report: Yugoslavia war crimes
fields.trailText: A UN war crimes tribunal in The Hague today convicted three Bosnian Serbs on charges of rape and torture, the first case of wartime sexual enslavement to come before an international court.
fields.body:
A UN war crimes tribunal in The Hague today convicted three Bosnian Serbs on charges of rape and torture, the first case of wartime sexual enslavement to come before an international court.

The tribunal convicted Dragoljub Kunarac of sexually assaulting and torturing Muslim women at rape camps during the Bosnian war, sentencing him to 28 years in prison. The court said Kunarac was involved in a "nightmarish scheme of sexual exploitation" that was "especially repugnant".

"You abused and ravaged Muslim women because of their ethnicity, and from among their number you picked whomsoever you fancied," said the presiding judge, reading the first verdict.

The second defendant, Radomir Kovac, was found guilty of war crimes and crimes against humanity by rape and sentenced to 20 years.

The final defendant, Zoran Vukovic, was convicted of raping and torturing a 15-year-old girl - who was about the same age as his own daughter - but was acquitted on most other charges for lack of evidence. He was sentenced to 12 years imprisonment.

Florence Mumba, the presiding judge, went through the testimony of woman after woman who had told horrendous tales of rape and torture in the Bosnian town of Foca, southeast of Sarajevo. Muslims were herded into separate prison camps for men and women after the town was overrun in April 1992.

The verdict follows months of testimony from dozens of witnesses, including 16 former rape victims who came to The Hague to confront their alleged former tormentors.

The women told how Bosnian Serb paramilitary soldiers entered detention centres and selected women and girls as young as 12 for nightly gang rapes and sexual torture. They were charged with about 50 counts of war crimes and crimes against humanity, including rape, torture, enslavement and outrages upon personal dignity. The crimes carried maximum life sentences.

Some witnesses sobbed and others shrieked with rage as they recalled being assaulted by up to 10 soldiers at a time in classrooms of the high school where they were detained or in soldiers' private apartments - so-called "rape camps".

Judge Mumba said the defendants carried out their rapes in full knowledge of the systematic attack against the Muslim population ordered by the Bosnian Serb leadership.

They were not "political or military masterminds behind the conflicts and atrocities," she said. "However, they thrived in the dark atmosphere of the dehumanisation of those believed to be enemies."

The tribunal was established by the UN Security Council in 1993 to go after the alleged architects of the Bosnian war's bloody "ethnic cleansing" campaigns, including the former Bosnian Serb president, Radovan Karadzic, and his military chief, Ratko Mladic, who remain at large.

However, prosecutors indicted the three irregular soldiers to spotlight the widespread use of rape as a weapon throughout the 1992-1995 war. Human rights groups have estimated that tens of thousands of people, mainly Muslim woman and girls, were raped in the war. The sexual assaults were designed to intimidate Muslim families into flight and force women to bear Serb babies.

webTitle: More than 100 killed in Borneo violence

fields.headline: More than 100 killed in Borneo violence
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: Security forces were today patrolling a town on the Indonesian island of Borneo in an effort to stop a series of clashes between rival ethnic groups that have left more than 100 people dead.
fields.body:
Security forces were today patrolling a town on the Indonesian island of Borneo in an effort to stop a series of clashes between rival ethnic groups that have left more than 100 people dead.

Indigenous Dayaks and immigrants from other parts of Indonesia have been fighting since Sunday in the town of Sampit, about 800km [480 miles] north-east of Jakarta in the central Kalimantan province.

Many of the victims were mutilated and at least 20 bodies were beheaded, said Sergeant Tigei, a local police officer. The state news agency, Antara, said gangs had paraded severed heads around the town.

The fighting was still continuing, said Sgt Tigei, and several houses were on fire. Police were firing rubber bullets to disperse the crowds.

Hospital official Komaruddin Sukhemi said at least 93 bodies had been brought to local morgues. Hundreds of people were seeking shelter in the hospital complex and at police stations. Thousands more were fleeing the town, police said.

National police chief, General Suroyo Bimantoro, said two battalions of police and soldiers had been dispatched to boost security in the region. A navy warship was also on its way to the area to help evacuate refugees, he said.

Police said that about 80 people had been arrested in the past few days and hundreds of home made weapons, including machetes and spears, have been confiscated. Two local government officials, accused by police of inciting the violence, have also been detained.

The latest fighting highlights the breakdown of law and order in Indonesia, as old ethnic hatreds erupt after more than three decades of authoritarian rule.

Enmity between the Dayaks and the migrants, mainly from Madura island, has erupted into violence several times before in the region. Fighting is often triggered by land disputes. At least 260 people were killed in 1999, while dozens also died in attacks in 1997.

Elsewhere in Indonesia, a mob yesterday stabbed three people to death on Seram island in the eastern province of Maluku, government spokesman John Tomasoa said. Christians and Muslims have been fighting for two years in the region. At least 5,000 people have died despite efforts to quell the disturbance.

Indonesian president Abdurrahman Wahid flew out of Indonesia today for a 14-day trip to the Middle East and Africa. He told reporters he was unconcerned about leaving amid the corruption scandal threatening his presidency and renewed ethnic violence.

Defence minister Mohammad Mahfud said there was a possibility that the president's political rivals could cause further dissent during his absence. "I am sure that there are many parties that will act up," he said, after leaving the president at the airport.

Mr Wahid has been implicated in two multimillion dollar corruption scandals and was censured by parliament earlier this month, the first step towards possible impeachment. The president has denied any wrongdoing and rejected calls to resign.

Hundreds of protesters jeered Mr Wahid's motorcade as it sped toward the airport today and held up signs saying: "Do not bother coming back!"

fields.headline: Crunch meeting for Cosla
fields.trailText: The Convention of Scottish Local Authorities (Cosla) is likely to face some tough decisions tomorrow when council leaders gather for a crunch meeting at its Edinburgh headquarters.
fields.body:
The Convention of Scottish Local Authorities (Cosla) is likely to face some tough decisions tomorrow when council leaders gather for a crunch meeting at its Edinburgh headquarters.

Cosla has had a bumpy ride, to say the least, over the past two weeks. First, Glasgow city council - its largest member and biggest subscriber - decided to pull out, disgruntled at its share of the local government settlement, taking with it its £300,000 membership fee.

Three more councils quickly followed - Falkirk, Clackmannanshire and Dundee - and at least three others have announced they are to review their membership to see if they are getting good value for money.

Glasgow aside, most of the desertions have been inspired by the Scottish national party. Clackmannanshire is SNP-controlled while in Falkirk and Dundee the Labour minority administrations were forced by the SNP to dump Cosla to get a budget agreement.

But among the other councils considering pulling out - South Lanarkshire, Renfrewshire and Angus - only Angus has an SNP majority, the others being Labour-controlled.

So where does it leave Cosla? It doesn't take a mathematician to work out that nearly half a million out of a budget of £2.4m will result in some radical surgery and redundancies among Cosla's 50 full-time staff.

Cosla, however, is bravely carrying on and last Friday predicted a "positive future" based on a three-year budget to reflect council spending. Council levies are proposed to increase by 6.6% next year, 5.8% in 2002-03 and 4.1% in 2003-04 - mirroring the recent increases in the local government settlement.

Cosla president Norman Murray said: "I regret that Scottish local government could be damaged by the actions of a few councils. But the vast majority of councils pledged support to the organisation as they set their budgets. We will work with them as a single effective voice for local government."

"Cosla will survive because it has to, but whether it survives in its current shape will be decided tomorrow. Clearly, we are looking at cutbacks in the organisation and cutting back on the services we currently provide.

"There will be redundancies - we can't ask councils to pick up the tab - and a major cutback in services which is a retrograde step as far as I am concerned. I believe it will take local government back and will definitely weaken our voice in Scotland."

From the outset, Councillor Murray has accused the SNP of orchestrating the current crisis, claiming the nationalists are using Cosla as a "political football".

But this is hotly denied by the SNP, which maintains there is no "high command directive" to break up Cosla. "It is clear that many of our councils have lost patience with Cosla, particularly with regard to how it conducts its internal business. SNP members feel excluded from decision making on key issues," said a party spokesman.

"However, this is secondary to the fact that councils are beginning to question whether they are receiving value for money for what Cosla supplies. Clearly, certain local authorities don't think so and believe the money would be better spent elsewhere."

Local government expert Arthur Midwinter, professor of politics at Strathclyde University, believes that even if Cosla did fold, something else would emerge from the ashes. "There has to be a national association. Ministers have a statutory duty to consult with Cosla. If they all back out of Cosla, they will have to reform into something else," he says.

Prof Midwinter claims a lot is down to "gesture politics" with the SNP accusing Cosla of being too dominated by New Labour.

"Glasgow is the only one to have dropped out purely because of disaffection with Cosla. Ironically, it comes in a year when Glasgow has the largest single percentage grant increase since reorganisation, which I think shows poor judgement and a lack of leadership," he says.

Prof Midwinter predicts that in the short-term Cosla will tighten up its budget and some of the wayward councils will return once the general election over.

"I expect the Labour party machinery to operate to sustain some kind of mechanism, and behind the scenes pressure will be put on Labour councils to stay in Cosla," he said.

"But I also think Cosla needs to think about how it operates. The Labour group should not assume the majority position in Cosla. If they only represent the party view, they are heading for trouble."

The Scottish executive has been supportive, saying it "very much regrets" the decision of any council to leave Cosla. "Ministers will meet individual councils, as they have always done, but will continue to discuss collective issues with Cosla," said a spokesman.

Meanwhile, inside Cosla the mood seems to be one of quiet resignation. "People seem to be getting on with the job. Obviously, individuals are concerned about what it will mean for them but I am surprised at how upbeat people are," said one staff member.

Whatever the outcome of tomorrow's meeting, one thing is clear - something has to be done and done quickly.

fields.headline: What the farming papers say
fields.standfirst:
Derek Brown surveys the trade press for the farming industry's reaction to the potential foot and mouth epidemic threatening the UK

Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Derek Brown surveys the trade press for the farming industry's reaction to the potential foot and mouth epidemic threatening the UK.
fields.body:
The Farmer's Guardian trade weekly gloomily reports that the export ban will cost the industry £8m a week. The site also picks up the urgent appeal by National Farmers' Union chairman Ben Gill for the public to stay away from countryside areas containing livestock.

The Farmer's Weekly Interactive site is also dominated by dire warnings of devastation in the meat and livestock industry. Last year, according to the Meat and Livestock Commission, Britain exported 764,000 live sheep and 94,000 tonnes of lamb, together worth £212m. Also, 97,000 live pigs and 219,400 tonnes of pig meat were exported with a total value of £183.4m.

Sheep farmers are worried that, with the loss of continental markets, home-produced lamb will flood the domestic market, driving down prices. And now farmers are worried about the implications for animal welfare, if livestock has to be kept back on farms because abattoirs decide it is not worth killing without a market.

In its breaking news section, Farmer's Weekly Interactive reports that infected meat is now thought to be the most likely source of the outbreak. The excellent site run by the National Pig Association reflects the desperation of producers, by leading with a prayer submitted by the Rev Alan Robson, an agricultural chaplain in Lincolnshire. It concludes rather plaintively: "As we unravel the mistakes may we learn the lessons, whatever they may be. Above all as we seek to support each other through this time may we simply rediscover how precious is our dependence on each other. Amen."

The site addresses the urgent question of compensation, noting that even farmers with healthy animals can be driven quickly to bankruptcy, if he cannot get his stock to market: "Unable to move the animals, farmers must nevertheless continue to feed them, until the money runs out, or pay to have them slaughtered Over the next week, the farming industry will want to ensure that on this occasion full compensation is available to farmers with zone-trapped animals."

The NPA also makes a poignant appeal to journalists to spread the message that the disease is horribly infectious: "Can we ask you to stress to your readers/listeners/viewers the importance of staying away from livestock farms for the time being. Foot and mouth is extraordinarily infectious and until it is known where the source of the outbreak is, any casual visit to any farm could potentially spread the disease.

"For instance, if a passer by were to 'talk' over the fence to an infected sow, lamb, or an inquisitive heifer, the virus would reach his or her nose where it would remain for up to two days. During this period if he or she were to come into close contact with any other susceptible animal, the disease would be spread."

And now farmers are worried about the implications for animal welfare, if livestock has to be kept back on farms because abattoirs decide it is not worth killing without a market. In its breaking news section, Farmer's Weekly Interactive reports that infected meat is now thought to be the most likely source of the outbreak. The excellent site run by the National Pig Association reflects the desperation of producers, by leading with a prayer submitted by the Rev Alan Robson, an agricultural chaplain in Lincolnshire. It concludes rather plaintively: "As we unravel the mistakes may we learn the lessons, whatever they may be. Above all as we seek to support each other through this time may we simply rediscover how precious is our dependence on each other. Amen." Foot and mouth is extraordinarily infectious and until it is known where the source of the outbreak is, any casual visit to any farm could potentially spread the disease. "For instance, if a passer by were to 'talk' over the fence to an infected sow, lamb, or an inquisitive heifer, the virus would reach his or her nose where it would remain for up to two days. During this period if he or she were to come into close contact with any other susceptible animal, the disease would be spread." Email dbrown445@aol.com Talk about it What do you think? webTitle: How the export ban will bite

fields.headline: How the export ban will bite
fields.standfirst:
Latest blow leaves rural industries reeling

Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: More than half of Britain's 240,000 farmers are expected to be affected to some extent by yesterday's export ban:
fields.body:
More than half of Britain's 240,000 farmers are expected to be affected to some extent by yesterday's export ban:

Milk

The dairy industry, with its herd of 1.5m cows and up to 100,000 farmers, may be the worst hit. It exports more than 400,000 tonnes of products a year, including 209,000 tonnes of liquid milk, 95,180 tonnes of cream, 61,028 tonnes of cheese and 43,842 tonnes of butter, mainly to Europe.

A spokesman for the National Dairy Council yesterday said the ban would inevitably have a great impact if it lasted more than a week or two. Some of the exports, such as UHT milk, are heat-treated and are expected to escape the ban, but the industry is still waiting for guidance from the government.

Beef

Britain's beef farmers, who are only just beginning to recover from the three-year beef export ban which followed the BSE crisis, were last night fearing the worst for their £520m export industry.

A spokesman for the meat and livestock commission said: "Anything that affects the trade will have a serious effect on an already vulnerable industry."

Several thousand beef farmers left the industry during the BSE ban and, says the National Farmers' Union, if the bars on exports continue, the industry can expect to lose many more.

Pigs

The outbreak is bound to have an immediate impact on the export of pig meat. Among the British industry's main customers are Germany, Japan Singapore and the US.

After several years of strife the past few months had seen an improvement in the fortunes of Britain's 3,000 pig farmers, who are mostly based in Norfolk and the north-east. Pork exports are worth £139m a year, bacon £21m and sausages and processed meat £14m.

Specific areas could be particularly badly hit. For example, a lot of meat ends up in Germany to be turned into sausages. At the height of the BSE scare - when Germans stopped eating all types of sausage - the price dropped from 75p a kilogram to 35p. It had only just climbed back up to the 70p level.

Another specific area which could be hit is the American market. During spring and summer the US imports thousands of tonnes of ribs for barbecues.

Richard Longthorp, director of the National Pig Association, said: "This will make the price plummet again. We have had years of struggle. This is such bad timing for the industry."

Sheep

Around 30% of lamb produced in Britain is send abroad. Some 94,000 tonnes of carcasses and 8,000 live animals are exported - a trade worth about £212m. France, Belgium and Germany are the main destinations. There are about 6,000 sheep farmers in the UK.

Experts said the crisis was likely to force down the price of lamb on supermarket shelves across Britain.

Ironically, farmers had recently witnessed an increase in live lamb exports because of the ongoing fears about BSE. Sheep farmers will be especially hard hit because they have just spent the winter feeding their animals up.

Les Armstrong, chairman of the National Farmers' Union livestock committee and a sheep farmer himself, said: "This is potentially disastrous."

Deer

The deer industry is split into two areas; producers of farmed venison and those who trade in wild venison. Most farmed venison is sold to the home market so is not likely to be be affected. But around a dozen farmers export around 500 animals a year as breeding stock.

Wild venison - there are around a million wild deer in Britain - is also exported to Germany, France and Belgium. About 75% of the deer shot in Britain is exported. An import ban on wild venison could have a devastating effect on game dealers, especially in remote areas such as the Scottish Highlands, which rely heavily on the industry.

Horses

Horse racing was suspended during the 1967 outbreak, though no horses had to be destroyed. The racing industry is at threat because the animals are moved about so frequently.

Any similar suspension could have a huge impact on the racing and betting industries. Racing is Britain's sixth biggest employer and 5m people went to the races last year. In addition, £5bn was bet off course.

John Maxse, spokesman for the Jockey Club, said the betting industry would probably be harder hit than Britain's 59 courses. But if racing was suspended on one of the big days courses depend on - for example, Easter Monday - substantial losses could follow.

"We are monitoring the situation," Mr Maxse said. "There is no immediate threat to racing but we will continue to review the position."

Goats

The impact on goat farmers is likely to be minimal. Most dairy products from goats are sold to the home market: in fact, Britain probably still imports more goats' cheese and milk than it produces, though specific figures are not readily available.

There are some farmers who export live animals for breeding. They will certainly be hit but in general theirs are relatively small concerns.

fields.headline: Farms: yet another crisis
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: An immediate ban on all UK animal exports was imposed last night following the confirmation of highly contagious foot and mouth disease in pigs and cattle at an Essex farm and abattoir. It brought another hammer blow to Britain's depressed farming industry.
fields.body:
An immediate ban on all UK animal exports was imposed last night following the confirmation of highly contagious foot and mouth disease in pigs and cattle at an Essex farm and abattoir. It brought another hammer blow to Britain's depressed farming industry.

The export ban, agreed between the European Union and the UK immediately the outbreak was confirmed, will cost farmers and food producers £1m a day in live animal and food products, including dairy products.

The source of the disease is unknown but is so virulent it can spread on the wind. The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, last night asked all farmers to check their stock, and said the government's priority was to stop the outbreak.

"Potentially this is a very, very serious situation," Mr Brown said. "We will slaughter all the infected animals and destroy all the carcasses. We will act swiftly, firmly and comprehensively. We have to get on top of this outbreak."

It is the first foot and mouth outbreak since a small one in 1981, but brought memories of 1967, when 2,500 farms were affected and hundreds of thousands of cattle, sheep, pigs and goats were destroyed over a six-month period.

"The outbreak has potentially catastrophic implications for the whole of the British livestock industry," said Ben Gill, the National Farmers Union president.

"The priority now is to contain it and we fully support all the measures which have been speedily put in place by Maff [the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food]. While these measures will be devastating to the farms involved, it is in the interests of the whole UK livestock industry that this disease is stopped dead in its tracks."

Sixty cattle and 300 pigs were being slaughtered at Cheale Meats in Little Warley, south of Brentwood, where 27 pigs developed the disease on Monday. A bull at a nearby farm owned by the same company was confirmed with the disease on Tuesday night and three more cattle had developed symptoms yesterday.

Jim Scudamore, the government's chief vet, said the strain of the virus had been identified as Type O, a most virulent pan-Asiatic strain that develops within 48 hours of infection. "This means this outbreak could spread extremely fast," he said. "We have no idea of its origin or where the infection in Essex came from.

"It can spread many miles by air to other species, by touch, or frequently by lorry which has carried other infected animals. The next 48 hours are crucial."

Three farms which sent pigs for slaughter in Essex were under restrictions last night. Two at Great Horwood in Buckinghamshire and Freshwater Bay on the Isle of Wight were placed in a three-mile exclusion zones. A Selby farm which sent one of the infected pig was restricted but without an exclusion zone, because the pig had arrived at the abattoir so late on Sunday night that vets do not believe it could have caused the illness in the other pigs.

Mr Scudamore said none of the animals on the quarantined farms had become ill, so they were not suspected of being the source of the outbreak. "We are keeping them under restrictions as a precaution but we are looking elsewhere for the source of the outbreak and we know we have not found it yet."

A fourth farm at Stroud in Gloucestershire was placed under precautions because animals were ill, but there was no confirmation that the illness was foot and mouth disease.

The plight of the affected farmers was illustrated by Rachael Fidler, whose husband runs Faringford farm at Freshwater Bay. She was at work when the restrictions were imposed and cannot go home to her husband and two children. "It is devastating," she said. "I could go to the farm but it would mean I would not be able to leave, so I am currently having to stay with neighbours."

Dozens of farms as far away as Northern Ireland and Scotland, which have sent animals to the slaughterhouse in the past three weeks were being investigated last night. All farms visited by lorries from the abattoir were being tracked to make sure the infection had not been passed on.

Mr Brown said the source of the outbreak was almost certainly the result of illegal activity. "It is almost impossible to visualise how this could have happened as a result of a series of legal transactions," he said. "Something illegal has happened to bring this into the country."

Lady Hayman, the junior agriculture minister, told the House of Lords that although humans could get the disease, it was rare and not fatal.

webTitle: Farmers become prisoners on their land

fields.headline: Farmers become prisoners on their land
fields.standfirst:
We are now trying to source every animal which arrived here in recent weeks. That will involve thousands of animals and many weeks of work

Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Essex farmers were virtual prisoners on their own land yesterday as the threat of foot and mouth disease - the stuff of nightmarish legend in British agriculture - became a sudden and terrifying reality.
fields.body:
Essex farmers were virtual prisoners on their own land yesterday as the threat of foot and mouth disease - the stuff of nightmarish legend in British agriculture - became a sudden and terrifying reality.

Emergency barriers sealed off the Cheale's Abattoir in the village of Little Warley outside Brentwood, where 27 pigs were found on Monday night to exhibit "highly suspicious" symptoms of the disease. An exclusion zone prevented the movement of live farm animals in or out of a five-mile radius of the site.

Little Warley was already taking on some of the characteristics of a plague village last night, as residents were asked to limit any movements that could lead to the spread of the disease.

Those with dairy and livestock herds inside the zone angrily warned visitors not to approach their properties, and some were refusing to venture from their farms to avoid the risk of picking it up. But they may have been fighting a hopeless battle: the disease can be carried by birds, vehicles and on the wind.

"It's the equivalent of the Black Death for us," said one local farmer.

Farmers in the area were already insisting that grain delivery trucks be pressure-washed before arriving on their properties, raising the prospect of knock-on economic problems for other industries.

"We're going to have to appeal to local people not to use public footpaths if we are really going to address this thing," said a farmer, Tony Evans.

In a brief statement at the gates of the abattoir, where officials in protective clothing were spraying outgoing vehicles with pesticide, director Paul Cheale said the infected pigs had been among 700 received on Saturday at the facility, which slaughters 6,000 sows each week.

He said the abattoir was cooperating fully with Ministry of Agriculture, but warned it could take weeks to establish the source of the outbreak.

"Everyone in the industry has been left shattered by this," he said. "We are now trying to source where every animal which arrived here in recent weeks came from. That will involve many thousands of animals and many weeks of work."

The local National Farmers' Union spokesman warned that the exclusion zone would soon be widened to cover the entire county. "We don't know where our future is now," said Kevin Harding, who farms livestock at Clay Tye Farm adjacent to Cheale's.

"We have been living on prayers since the outbreak of BSE, anyway. We're already only getting the same money for cattle now as at the beginning of the 1980s, and now this."

He expressed surprise that the disease had surfaced at the abattoir, and said he felt sure that its origins were elsewhere. Echoing a widely held sentiment in the local community, he said: "I've seen some abattoirs that are really horrible, but you could eat your dinner off the floor at Cheale's."

A planned meeting of the local beef and sheep committee of the National Farmers' Union to address the crisis was cancelled yesterday to avoid the danger of bringing farmers from areas unaffected by the outbreak into contact with those who might be carrying it on their clothes.

"This thing is desperately serious, far more serious than swine fever, because of the wide range of animals it can infect," said Mr Evans, the chairman of the committee. "It's all very well saying that this is a farmers' problem, but we are talking about a national crisis of food supply if it spreads."

It was left to those with long farming careers and equally long memories to recall the last time the disease had wrought havoc in the area.

"It's fabled, really, isn't it?" said David Ramsey, 63, a former pig farmer who lives half a mile from the abattoir. "I did come across it earlier in my life. I was extremely lucky not to be directly affected, but whole herds had to be destroyed.

"Something like this will affect us so drastically here that there's no saying what will happen. You could end up with funeral pyres in the fields."

webTitle: Ailing industry braces for hammer blow

fields.headline: Ailing industry braces for hammer blow
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The UK livestock industry was last night braced for another catastrophe as the National Farmers' Union warned that this week's outbreak of foot and mouth disease could prove "disastrous" for its members.
fields.body:
The UK livestock industry was last night braced for another catastrophe as the National Farmers' Union warned that this week's outbreak of foot and mouth disease could prove "disastrous" for its members.

Farmers are faced with another crisis at a time when they "already have too many problems to deal with," the NFU said. However, it accepted that the export ban was a "necessary evil" to control the disease and the industry was determined to stop its spread "dead in its tracks".

Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, admitted that he was unable to predict how long the ban on exports would be in place. "I cannot promise that these measures will not be prolonged, but we have to do whatever we have to do," he said. "I apologise if what we appear to be doing seems heavy handed, but it is essential."

The image of a whole industry going up in flames haunts livestock farmers again. Devastated by BSE, rocked by international economic crises in the 1990s and complaining of floods of cheap imports that keep prices down below the cost of production in many instances, farmers were last night bracing for what could be the worst shock yet.

The outbreak of the disease follows a spate of farm closures last autumn after swine fever was detected.

Professor Allan Buckwell, of the Country Land and Business Association, said: "Reports of foot and mouth outbreaks strike fear into the hearts of our livestock farmers who have been working like hell to pick themselves off the floor."

The National Sheep Association said the outbreak would have a adverse effect on an industry which was just starting to recover from fears of BSE in lamb. Its chief executive, John Thorley, said: "The sheep industry has had to suffer from the problems of BSE in cattle and will now take another knock as a consequence of foot and mouth in pigs."

The Liberal Democrat agriculture spokesman, Colin Breed, said it was a "hammer blow" to farmers.

Farmers' income fell by 25% last year, and in real terms it has probably fallen by at least 70% since its peak in 1995, Some of the 33,000 hill farmers earn little more than £1,000 a year from their herds or flocks. Yet millions of animals are slaughtered each year - about 1.8m cattle, 17m sheep and 12m pigs - to feed a population that demands ever cheaper food.

Millions of cows have been destroyed in recent years to protect the food chain from BSE, and beef prices have never really recovered, even though consumption may have returned to pre-catastrophe levels because the meat is much cheaper.

Sheep farmers, especially in the hill country, who had suffered from the collapse of both the Asian and Russian economies had been kept afloat in the last two years by the developing live export market. They were cashing in too on the beef panic on the continent. Now prices are likely to drop as a glut develops on the domestic market.

Pig farmers raked in the money during the mid-90s as they expanded to move into new foreign markets. But the centre of the UK industry, East Anglia, faced restrictions placed on farmers last autumn because of an outbreak of swine fever. Yet pig prices may not suffer too much. The size of the herd has been reduced and Britain has always had to import a quarter of its annual consumption of pig meat, much of it in the form of bacon from Denmark and the Netherlands.

But livestock farmers will be remembering another salutary lesson from the BSE crisis. When the EU commission slapped an export ban on British beef in 1996 , the trade was worth £520m a year, more than all our other current exports of meat and livestock. The ban was lifted in August 1999 and last year we exported only 500 tonnes, worth £5m.

A combination of increased productivity and the return of the bad times means that the number of farmers , wives and farm hands in the UK is falling fast. Ten years ago more than 660,000 people worked in the industry, many of them even then part time. Now the figure is diving towards 550,000.

The actual number of farmers may be nearer 250,000 - 40,000 have left in the last two years alone. Huge subsidies and aid packages from the EU and the Treasury, running to the tune of £4bn a year, have done little to turn round an industry worth just £7.6bn a year to the national economy . It employs 2% of the workforce, even if it takes up three-quarters of the land mass.

The government is trying to make farmers diversify into tourism, leisure and other activities, but few at present make substantial income from such sources, and many have wives who work in full-time jobs elsewhere.

Such changes will take time to make a substantial difference - too long to save thousands more farmers and families from leaving the land.

fields.headline: Postponement gives Airdrie time
fields.trailText: The Scottish Football League today agreed to postpone crisis club Airdrie's weekend fixture with Ross County - but warned that time is fast running out for the Diamonds.
fields.body:
The Scottish Football League today agreed to postpone crisis club Airdrie's weekend fixture with Ross County - but warned that time is fast running out for the Diamonds.

Administrators KPMG made the request in an attempt to buy time to find a solution to the club's well-publicised problems.

As a result the visit of Ross County to the Shyberry Excelsior Stadium has been shelved - but the SFL are keen to treat the move as a one-off.

SFL secretary Peter Donald said: "The application was considered, and it was agreed to postpone in order to help KPMG find a solution to the problem.

"But no provisions are in place for clubs that do not fulfil their fixtures. A club can only exist if it is playing its matches.

"This type of offer is not open-ended, and although no cut-off date has been set it clearly cannot go on for ever."

When Steve Archibald was stripped of his status as "preferred bidder" last week the way was opened for other interested parties to come forward.

KPMG have revealed they are talking to possible buyers, with one believed to be former Airdrie shirt sponsor John Dalziel who owns a bakery business.

KPMG's tearing up of the management agreement it had had with Archibald since the summer amid claims he did not have the finances to complete the deal effectively sacked him as the club's manager and also forced the postponement of the previous match.

That was the potentially lucrative Scottish Cup tie with Peterhead last Saturday, and the Third Division side went through to the quarter finals on a bye.

The contracts of all but six Airdrie players expired at midnight on Saturday, but Archibald has insisted he is still desperate to buy the club.

He told supporters so at a rally in the town over the weekend and has kept the displaced squad together despite being locked out of the stadium.

Archibald also made an attempt to tie up one of the many loose ends involved with the take-over deal, the work required to secure the deeds to the ground from North Lanarkshire Council.

KPMG, as the club's current custodians, own the stadium. But the council owns the land it stands on and has so far rented it out for free this season.

But for a buyer to secure the deeds money must be paid to pay for environmental improvements on land surrounding the stadium.

On Monday, Archibald pledged £880,000 to the council but soon discovered it could not be accepted.

A council spokesman said: "As soon as Steve Archibald fell out with KPMG he was working off his own back.

"We have a legally binding agreement with Airdrie FC, but Steve Archibald no longer represents Airdrie because of the fall-out with KPMG."

Airdrie's next scheduled fixture is away to Alloa on March 3.

webTitle: Two dead in Basque bomb blast

fields.headline: Two dead in Basque bomb blast
fields.standfirst: Special report: violence in Spain
fields.trailText: A car bomb exploded in the northern Basque coastal city of San Sebastian this morning, killing two men and injuring at least four others, authorities said.
fields.body:
A car bomb exploded in the northern Basque coastal city of San Sebastian this morning, killing two men and injuring at least four others, authorities said.

The authorities suspect that Basque separatist group ETA is behind the killings. The blast occurred at 8am local time (7am GMT) in the Martutene neighbourhood, about 200 meters from a commuter train stop, an Interior Ministry spokesman in the Basque region said, speaking on condition of anonymity.

Ambulances rushed victims to the Aranzazu hospital, which said two men had died. They were identified as Jose Angel Santos Larranaga and Josu Leones Azkona, workers for Electra, an electricity company.

Four other men were being treated for injuries at the hospital.

One of the injured was identified as Ignacio Dubrueil Churruca, a councillor from the Socialist party in the nearby Basque town of Ordizia, party member Rosa Diez said. Mr Dubrueil was only slightly injured, she said.

ETA has frequently used car bombs as part of its 32-year-old campaign for Basque independence in which some 800 people have been killed.

The group has been blamed for one killing so far this year, also in San Sebastian. If today's killings are linked to ETA, they would bring the number of victims to 26 since the armed separatists ended a 14 month cease fire in December 1999.

Today's explosion followed the announcement two days ago that the Basque government would hold early elections in the region in May. It occurred exactly one year after another car bomb killed Fernando Buesa, a leading member of the Socialist party in the Basque region, and his police bodyguard.

webTitle: Sectors continue to invest in arms

fields.headline: Sectors continue to invest in arms
fields.trailText: Charities, NHS trusts, trade unions and the Labour party among organisations accused of compromising ethical principles.
fields.body:
Charities, NHS trusts, trade unions and the Labour party are still holding millions of pounds in arms company shares despite pressure to invest ethically, a new report reveals today.

Campaign Against Arms Trade (CAAT), which conducts an annual survey to find out which organisations hold shares in the UK's biggest arms companies, has found that some of the largest shareholdings come from organisations, including the Co-op, which publicly promotes ethical policies.

Organisations whose holdings are likely to cause embarrassment for their supporters include the Leukaemia Research Fund, a charity with more than 200 research teams. It has 10,000 shares in BAE Systems, Britain's biggest arms company. It manufactures shells tipped with depleted uranium which have been linked to leukeamia and other cancers.

Depleted uranium shells were used by US aircraft in Kosovo and by British and US tanks in the Gulf war.

The Labour party, whose government pledged an ethical dimension to its foreign policy and to work for human rights - and has banned the use of anti-personnel landmines by British troops - has 34,721 shares in BAE Systems.

Publicity surrounding organisations committed to ethical trading and found to have shares in arms companies has led to some disinvestment. The Red Cross was found to have arms trade shares two years ago and has since disinvested. The Church of England has followed the lead of the Catholic Church in getting rid of its shares in arms companies.

A spokesman for the Leukaemia Research Fund said he saw no contradiction in devoting itself to curing leukaemia and investing in a company whose shells are alleged to cause the illness.

"BAE Systems is a respected British company. We need to invest widely and wisely and ensure that we get the best returns for our money. BAE Systems are not responsible for what went on in Kosovo," a spokesman said.

The position regarding the Co-op is more complicated. There are several individual societies that the Co-op Group says are separate entities and determine their own ethical policies. The Co-op Group owns the Co-op Insurance Society (CIS), one of the biggest shareholders surveyed with 21,375,136 shares in BAE Systems.

But it says CIS is a separate entity despite being owned by the group and makes its own decisions. The Co-op Group holds shares in BAE Systems, Rolls Royce and GKN in their pension fund. It is a matter, they say, for their trustees to determine.

The Labour party's response was similar. A spokesman confirmed that Labour's position on investing in the arms trade had not changed since it was "outed" a year ago. "Our pension fund investments are a matter for the pension fund trustees," he said.

Crest, the new electronic system for holding shares, means they are often held in undesignated nominee accounts so that it is not possible to trace the beneficial owner by inspecting the company register.

The law only requires that a custodian is identified and does not require the identity of the beneficial owner be publicly available. The campaign is calling for all shares to be held in designated accounts and for one shareholder to be able to request the identity of another to improve transparency and accountability.

A campaign spokesperson said: "We know that the majority of people in the UK oppose most arms sales and support ethical investment. Despite the annual naming and shaming by CAAT, hundreds of public institutions continue to compromise their own objectives and principles by taking this dirty money."
