fields.headline: Are you buying or selling?
fields.standfirst:
If Sotheby's is too stuffy or Loot too limited then try David Rowley's guide to auctions on the net
More net news
fields.trailText: If Sotheby's is too stuffy or Loot too limited then try David Rowley's guide to auctions on the net
fields.body:
Internet auctions were one of the web's earliest successes and the benefits are clear - no more tiny classified ads, no more unwinnable arguments with second hand dealers and no more musty collector emporiums. They are also, you should be warned, very addictive.

While some publicity has been attracted to merchant auctions such as the bit by bit sale of Wembley Stadium by www.qxl.com, the classic, original and still most popular internet auction is the one that lasts seven days, held between ordinary members of the public and typified by those at www.ebay.co.uk.

Common auction logic says that your first step should be as a buyer. The buyer has less to do than the seller and through their first auction gets a feel for the greater responsibilities of the seller. Before you can place a bid though there are some legal niceties. Unlike the seemingly pointless chore that is the registration page at internet shopping sites, at auction sites this page binds you to a contract, which states that any bids placed on the site must be honoured.

There is also the business of finding your self a user ID. My own instinct on this is that a sensible or even a dull name is more likely to inspire confidence in those looking to buy, say a £500 laptop from you. This theory can of course be junked if you consider that Parrothead88 is the user ID of the most prolific internet auction user ever - 26,500 auctions completed at www.ebay.com.

Now you are ready to bid, which is the easy part. Check the descriptions and photo carefully and the shipping costs. If anything is unclear, use the "ask seller a question" link before, and not after, you bid.

As a buyer you will have a natural anxiety over sending a cheque in the post to someone you know very little about. Why shouldn't they just take the money and run? This is possible, but unlikely. Firstly, every auction user should have the number of successful trades they have completed next to their user ID. Anyone with at least 20 of these feedback points is a good bet.

Secondly, trust your common sense over what looks suspicious. Most internet auction frauds concern the sale of fake luxury goods particularly Rolex watches.

A third safeguard is provided by sites such as www.iescrow.com, www.tradesafe.com and www.paypal.com which provide escrow services that ensure no money is handed over until the goods arrive. QXL runs its very own escrow service, while www.ebay.com is shortly getting round to providing such a service too.

Lastly, as extra insurance, eBay, Amazon auctions and QXL all offer a compensation scheme for those who are conned out of amounts up to £120 at eBay and £150 at QXL and Amazon.

If this has reassured you, now place your bid by clicking on the link provided: it is at the bottom of the page at eBay. Again, anxiety about getting yourself involved in some whirlwind bidding war can be allayed. Many auctions will only attract a single bid; others at the most usually three or four bids.

If you decide that the item on view must be yours come what may, you should make use of your auction sites automatic bidding device. This works by letting you state in secrecy the highest amount you are willing to spend. Each time you are outbid, the Auto bid as it is often known (at eBay it is called proxy bidding) will up your bid by a prearranged increment. Even if you do not use this, most auction sites will email you whenever you are outbid.

Lastly, for buyers there is another nifty tool that eBay pioneered called the Personal Shopper page, which can be found under the buyer and seller services link. This is for those looking for anything that they cannot see on the website. Tell the "personal shopper" what you are looking for and they should email you automatically whenever something of that description is listed for auction.

Meanwhile, selling requires more strategy and work. Unlike the speedy process of bidding, setting up your own auction, especially your first, takes time and patience.

Most grief is caused by putting photos on to an auction - so much so, that many forgo them altogether. Yet while it is possible to sell items without a photo, the lack of one will lose you bids and a good sale price.

Your first step is to get the image onto your desktop. A digital camera is ideal, though a scanner can be used for flat items and conventionally taken photos. You could also try your photo developing service, most of which should be able to put your photos onto a disc or park them on the web. This latter service is handy as photos put on your desktop by a digital camera, scanner or disc next have to be put on the web. eBay offers a cheap and speedy service for this, though I have always found the free service offered by www.auctionwatch.com quite adequate.

Price your item slightly less than what you hope to get for it: 10-20% less is recommended. A low price will attract more bidders who may bid up your item to your ideal price, if not above. Include in the price your shipping and packaging costs, which should be broken down in your description. Bear in mind also the small charge or percentage taken by the auction site.

When writing your advert always put in a few emotive words and phrases - such as, for example, good as new, rare, shiny, in original wrapping, bonus and free - where they are warranted. Write the ad before going online and cut and paste it onto the site.

Now click the Submit button and your auction is underway. To keep up with it easily on a daily basis, go to your auction page and right click with your mouse on the "create a shortcut" option to creatre a direct link to this page on your desktop.

Do not get dispirited if you receive no bids for several days. It is quite common to receive most of your bids on the final day, and sometimes in the final hours of an auction. eBay's current spin on the number of successful auctions is that at least a half of all auctions on their site find a buyer, and this is the highest ratio for any site. This will, however, depend on what you are selling. The hottest categories are in collectables and computers. Household appliances, in my experience, sell very poorly.

Once the auction ends, the onus is on the seller to contact the buyer with their real world address and phone number. The worst problem a seller faces is a recalcitrant or deadbeat bidder who is slow or reluctant to complete a deal.

Be warned: disputes at this stage must be sorted out by yourself. The auction site does not have the manpower or the inclination to deal with this.

Once payment from the seller arrives, send off your auction item promptly and wait for the glowing feedback to arrive.

 David Rowley is the author of The Virgin Internet Auction Guide, £5.99.

Auction websites
www.auctionwatch.com
Auction help site, that provides photo hosting, lively chat pages and the sort of news that eBay would rather you did not know.

www.ebay.com
The original auction site from the USA and vastly bigger than the UK version.

www.ebay.co.uk
The best UK site, with strengths for collectables, computers and cars.

<A HREF="http://www.qxl.com"" TARGET="_NEW">www.qxl.com
Many promotional B2C auctions as well as C2C auctions.

<A HREF="http://www.firedup.com"" TARGET="_NEW">www.firedup.com
B2C auctions only.

www.auctions.amazon.com
Good for books, videos and CDs.

www.auctions.yahoo.com
Low tech, but for the time being, free auctions.

www.sothebys.com
Good for some surprisingly cheap and popular collectables items.

www.ibidlive.com & www.theauctionchannel.com
Take part in live auctions at Christies, Bonhams etc through a computer link.

www.holidayauctions.net
Cheap package holidays

www.loot.com
Best for practical items or ordinary online classifieds if you prefer.

Firstly, every auction user should have the number of successful trades they have completed next to their user ID. Anyone with at least 20 of these feedback points is a good bet. Secondly, trust your common sense over what looks suspicious. Most internet auction frauds concern the sale of fake luxury goods particularly Rolex watches. A third safeguard is provided by sites such as www.iescrow.com, www.tradesafe.com and www.paypal.com which provide escrow services that ensure no money is handed over until the goods arrive. QXL runs its very own escrow service, while www.ebay.com is shortly getting round to providing such a service too. Lastly, as extra insurance, eBay, Amazon auctions and QXL all offer a compensation scheme for those who are conned out of amounts up to £120 at eBay and £150 at QXL and Amazon. If this has reassured you, now place your bid by clicking on the link provided: it is at the bottom of the page at eBay. Again, anxiety about getting yourself involved in some whirlwind bidding war can be allayed. Many auctions will only attract a single bid; others at the most usually three or four bids. If you decide that the item on view must be yours come what may, you should make use of your auction sites automatic bidding device. This works by letting you state in secrecy the highest amount you are willing to spend. Each time you are outbid, the Auto bid as it is often known (at eBay it is called proxy bidding) will up your bid by a prearranged increment. Even if you do not use this, most auction sites will email you whenever you are outbid. Lastly, for buyers there is another nifty tool that eBay pioneered called the Personal Shopper page, which can be found under the buyer and seller services link. This is for those looking for anything that they cannot see on the website. Tell the "personal shopper" what you are looking for and they should email you automatically whenever something of that description is listed for auction. Meanwhile, selling requires more strategy and work. Unlike the speedy process of bidding, setting up your own auction, especially your first, takes time and patience. Most grief is caused by putting photos on to an auction - so much so, that many forgo them altogether. Yet while it is possible to sell items without a photo, the lack of one will lose you bids and a good sale price. Your first step is to get the image onto your desktop. A digital camera is ideal, though a scanner can be used for flat items and conventionally taken photos. You could also try your photo developing service, most of which should be able to put your photos onto a disc or park them on the web. This latter service is handy as photos put on your desktop by a digital camera, scanner or disc next have to be put on the web. eBay offers a cheap and speedy service for this, though I have always found the free service offered by www.auctionwatch.com quite adequate. Price your item slightly less than what you hope to get for it: 10-20% less is recommended. A low price will attract more bidders who may bid up your item to your ideal price, if not above. Include in the price your shipping and packaging costs, which should be broken down in your description. Bear in mind also the small charge or percentage taken by the auction site. When writing your advert always put in a few emotive words and phrases - such as, for example, good as new, rare, shiny, in original wrapping, bonus and free - where they are warranted. Write the ad before going online and cut and paste it onto the site. Now click the Submit button and your auction is underway. To keep up with it easily on a daily basis, go to your auction page and right click with your mouse on the "create a shortcut" option to creatre a direct link to this page on your desktop. Do not get dispirited if you receive no bids for several days. It is quite common to receive most of your bids on the final day, and sometimes in the final hours of an auction. eBay's current spin on the number of successful auctions is that at least a half of all auctions on their site find a buyer, and this is the highest ratio for any site. This will, however, depend on what you are selling. The hottest categories are in collectables and computers. Household appliances, in my experience, sell very poorly. Once the auction ends, the onus is on the seller to contact the buyer with their real world address and phone number. The worst problem a seller faces is a recalcitrant or deadbeat bidder who is slow or reluctant to complete a deal. Be warned: disputes at this stage must be sorted out by yourself. The auction site does not have the manpower or the inclination to deal with this. Once payment from the seller arrives, send off your auction item promptly and wait for the glowing feedback to arrive.  David Rowley is the author of The Virgin Internet Auction Guide, £5.99. Auction websites www.auctionwatch.com Auction help site, that provides photo hosting, lively chat pages and the sort of news that eBay would rather you did not know. www.ebay.com The original auction site from the USA and vastly bigger than the UK version. www.ebay.co.uk The best UK site, with strengths for collectables, computers and cars. www.qxl.com Many promotional B2C auctions as well as C2C auctions. www.firedup.com B2C auctions only. www.auctions.amazon.com Good for books, videos and CDs. www.auctions.yahoo.com Low tech, but for the time being, free auctions. www.sothebys.com Good for some surprisingly cheap and popular collectables items. www.ibidlive.com & www.theauctionchannel.com Take part in live auctions at Christies, Bonhams etc through a computer link. www.holidayauctions.net Cheap package holidays www.loot.com Best for practical items or ordinary online classifieds if you prefer.

fields.headline: Eminem
fields.standfirst: The world's most maligned rapper performed at the Grammys with Elton John. Here's our guide to the best sites on the controversial sex symbol
fields.trailText: The world's most maligned rapper performed at the Grammys with Elton John. Here's our guide to the best sites on the controversial sex symbol.
fields.body:
1. Elton John outraged gay activists last night by performing at the Grammys with controversial rapper Eminem, who's been attacked for his allegedly sexist, homophobic lyrics.

2. The gay icon filled in for the chorus on Stan, previously sung by Dido. But in view of recent readings of the ditty as one of the greatest tales of unrequited gay love ever penned, then maybe Elton should have voiced the suicidal Stan or, surreally, Eminem himself (then we'd have got to hear him rapping as well!).

3. So where does Eminem stand on gay issues? The University of Sheffield students' union was pretty clear about it, recently banning him from its club nights and media because a handful of students complained he was offensive.

4. Eminem, of course, hit the big time last year with the single My Name is... , in which he claimed producer Dr Dre had sent him to "tick the world off".

5. He's given it his best shot: gay rights groups accuse him of promoting violence against homosexuals and say his records should be withdrawn from sale.

6. Then there's his mother. She suing for $10m [£6.8m] in damages after, she claims, the rapper portrayed her as an unstable, lawsuit-happy drug user in his press interviews.

7. He still faces legal action from his grandmother (for sampling his dead uncle's voice) and has only just settled with his wife, Kim, who demanded custody of their child and $10m for a song in which he fantasises about killing her.

8. And he treated the UK to a pantomime dose of his bad self earlier this month, appearing on stage in London and Manchester with a chainsaw and goading the authorities with his Ecstasy-dropping jibes.

9. Luckily for Eminem, he has many fans in the rap world (including Missy Elliot and Ice Cube) who regard him as a brilliant and ironic lyricist drawing on his upbringing in a rough district in east Detroit.

10. The controversy has not stopped the award from piling up on Eminem's shelf, as last night's three gongs at the Grammys demonstrate. He also won two top honours at the MTV video music awards last year and was given the nod at this year's NME Carling awards. Doubtless next week's Brit awards, where he'll make his next UK appearance, will bring him even more plaudits.

fields.headline: Keeler brings the house down (again)
fields.trailText: 2pm TV overnights: Christine Keeler's account of the Profumo affair on ITV trounced the competition last night. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Life's basics - sex and food - were the winners in last night's TV schedule.

Christine Keeler's candid account of the Profumo affair in ITV's Christine Keeler: Sex Bomb trounced the competition at 10.35pm.

The show attracted 4.4m viewers and a 35% share.

This was enough to give it an easy lead over Food Wars, the BBC's exploration of how the European Union has affected people's eating habits.

The programme was watched by 2.1m viewers - a 14% audience share.

Meanwhile, Channel 4's Sex and the City started off with 2.2m viewers and an 11% share.

The second instalment of the double bill attracted 2.5m viewers and a 17% share after 10.30pm.

After that, comedy drama Metrosexuality opened well with 1m viewers and an 11% share at 11.15pm.

The six-part comedy drama is set in Notting Hill and examines the blurred sexual boundaries of young urban types.

Despite its lukewarm critical reception, initial interest gave the show a respectable debut.

Meanwhile, Twiggy and David Gower helped the BBC draw one-all with ITV's the Big Match at 9pm with 35% of share apiece.

Although 8.5m people watched Arsenal draw against Lyon, almost as many switched on to Celebrity Ready Steady Cook on BBC1.

With a 7.9m audience, the cookery show did well to match the football's share of eyeballs.

Sir Trevor McDonald's News at Ten continues to win the ratings war with the BBC's bulletin.

Last night's ITV offering had 6.4m viewers against the BBC's 3.3m.

It got more than twice the share - 34% to the BBC's 16%.

However, the tables were turned at lunchtime, when the BBC took the lion's share of the audience with a 44% share and 3.2m viewers.

ITV's lunchtime news attracted just 2m viewers and a 32% audience share.

webTitle: Leader: Agriculture's woes continue to multiply

fields.headline: Down on the farm
fields.standfirst:
Agriculture's woes continue to multiply

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: A new nightmare is threatening British farmers, already reeling from BSE-infected cattle, the fall in lamb prices and swine fever. An emergency ban on the export of meat and live animals was introduced last night following the first outbreak of foot and mouth disease for 20 years.
fields.body:
A new nightmare is threatening British farmers, already reeling from BSE-infected cattle, the fall in lamb prices and swine fever. An emergency ban on the export of meat and live animals was introduced last night following the first outbreak of foot and mouth disease for 20 years.

A five-mile exclusion zone has been set up round an Essex abattoir, where vets have found 27 pigs infected with the disease, and a neighbouring farm, where cattle have been found to be infected.

Two other farms - on the Isle of Wight and in Buckinghamshire - which supplied the abattoir with pigs, plus a fourth farm in Gloucestershire, are also in quarantine. Dozens more are being examined.

The moves may seem draconian, but there are few more virulent viruses than foot and mouth. The last major epidemic, in 1967, spread rapidly across Shropshire, Cheshire and Wales, infecting 2,346 farms in an eight-month period and requiring 433,000 animals to be slaughtered before it was eliminated.

Infection can spread via vehicle tyres, human feet, contact with diseased animals or even through the air. Rats and even starlings were thought to have been involved in spreading the 1967 epidemic. Hence the five mile exclusion zones. The wife of the Isle of Wight farmer whose pigs are suspect was stranded outside her farm yesterday and staying with neighbours. It could take up to 10 days to clarify whether the farm was a source of the infection.

The new food standards agency rightly moved quickly to reassure the public yesterday that the disease posed no serious threat to the human food chain. The disease is confined to animals with cloven hooves. Nor can intensive factory farming methods be blamed for this outbreak.

The disease dates back at least 150 years, long before farmers began speeding up growth by turning natural herbivores, such as cows, into meat eating animals by feeding them minced up meat ends and chicken litter - a procedure now banned following the BSE scandal. Undoubtedly the hygiene of the food chain, from farm through processors, distributors and retailers, could still be improved, but foot and mouth cannot be blamed on a dirty food chain.

There was a small infection in 1981, which was quickly snuffed out with a rigorous quarantine regime and the slaughter of animals on suspect farms. Ministers ought to re-examine the alternative approach, used by some European states, of vaccinating animals against the disease.

Meanwhile, the National Farmers Union fully supported the government's moves: "While these measures will be devastating to the farms involved, it is in the interests of the whole UK livestock industry that this disease is stopped dead in its track."

Maintaining this cooperation is crucial. The most effective way will be to ensure that, unlike their treatment in 1967, compensation for affected farmers is fair and comprehensive.

webTitle: Code drawn up on unsolicited messaging

fields.headline: Phone companies crack down on 'spam'
fields.trailText:
12.30pm:Mobile companies are drawing up a code of practice to ban unsolicited text messages, reports Julia Day.
Feb 22: January text messaging breaks records
fields.body:
As mobile phone text messaging soars to new heights, mobile companies are planning to crack down on advertisers that send "spam" messages to users.

Orange, BTCellnet and Vodafone are supporting a self-regulating code of practice to stop companies sending unsolicited messages.

The code, drawn up by new body the Wireless Marketing Association, bans spamming and states all wireless marketing must be permission-based.

But the WMA admits the code will be difficult to enforce.

There are no controls on non-WMA members because mobile phone marketing is not regulated by any other body.

The body hopes advertisers will conform to the standards.

However, Steve Wunker, WAM chairman and chief executive of Savafone, said: "If it pays to send a 30p unsolicited mailer through consumers' doors - which will only be read by 2% of people - it will pay to send a 5p text message that will be read by everyone who receives it."

The code also establishes that mobile phone users who don't want to receive messages or promotions must opt out rather than opt in.

The WMA will also set up a customer complaints system and a consumer protection committee.

The promoters of a message must be identified clearly and all information on recipients must be held securely and be made available to them on request.

If WMA members contravene the code they must correct their campaign or risk expulsion.

The use of mobile phones to target consumers with messages about services, products and promotions is set to rocket as new generation mobile technology allows more sophisticated data and graphics to be sent to phones.

McDonald's, American Express and lastminute.com are trialling mobile phone text messaging promotions and advertising as a way of interacting directly with consumers.

The WMA was founded in October last year and is seeking to set standards for wireless marketing.

Its board consists of executives from seven mobile phone companies, including Anne de Kerckhove, managing director of 12snap.

Mr Wunker said: "We believe we've put the right and proper safeguards in place to make sure wireless marketing isn't abused.

"It's a powerful tool that is set to take off on a massive scale. As an industry we take that potential seriously."

fields.headline: Games watch
fields.trailText: Hard pressed | Dream on
fields.body:
Hard pressed
The move from the Sony PlayStation to the PlayStation 2 has, not surprisingly, hit sales of PlayStation magazines, with sales of Future's official title falling from 300,459 to 215,508 a month. But in what looks like a more general downturn, sales of many other games magazines have also fallen, leading to changes in the industry.

Future Publishing, a huge success over the past two decades, is closing six magazines in the UK and six in the US, and others may be sold. Five websites will also be closed. The company expects to shed up to 350 of its 2,000 staff, with about 90 UK staff to be made redundant.

Emap has gone further and sold all but one of its games magazines to Dennis Publishing, which publishes PC Zone and PC Pro. Emap's titles included CVG, which enjoyed a rise in circulation from 43,509 to 45,606. However, in its heyday as Computer & Video Games, it sold more than 100,000 a month.

But in this market, magazines rise and fall with the popularity of consoles and computers. On the upside, Future's Official PlayStation 2 had an audited circulation of 81,883. It will also be publishing the official Xbox magazine.

Dream on
Sega may be getting out of the console hardware business, but it is still keen to increase the Dreamcast's user base. The company has just cut the price of is machine, launched at £300, to £99.99, and will release some of its best- selling titles in a budget range. The last price cut, from £200 to £150, was last September.

In the pipeline
Codemasters plans to launch LMA Manager 2001, its latest football management game, for the Sony PlayStation, on March 9.

As well as offering updated stats, the new version lets players manage Scottish league clubs too.

Rage hopes to make a splash with Hostile Waters, which is due on March 30. The game has taken four years to create and includes a cast of Tom Baker (Dr Who), Paul Darrow (Blake's 7) and Glynis Barber (Dempsey and Makepeace). See www.rage.com/hostile

Peter Molyneux's long-overdue game, Black & White, is finally scheduled to appear on April 6. There is a "massive world exclusive review" in the March issue of PC Zone, which claims it will be out mid/late February, but believe it when you see it.

fields.headline: Energy and utilities
fields.trailText: Figures from Friends of the Earth show that 22% of greenhouse gases come from domestic energy use so making your house as energy efficient as possible is an important first step towards becoming an ethical consumer. Get your home properly insulated by installing double or triple glazing and draft proofing.
fields.body:
Figures from Friends of the Earth show that 22% of greenhouse gases come from domestic energy use so making your house as energy efficient as possible is an important first step towards becoming an ethical consumer. Get your home properly insulated by installing double or triple glazing and draft proofing.

Electricity is also available green sources. Renewable energy is available from both Servista and Royal Society for the Protection of Birds.

Energy-saving light bulbs can also make a difference. Although they cost more than regular light bulbs they last significantly longer.

fields.headline: Games reviews
fields.trailText: Phantasy Star Online | Three Kingdoms: Fate of the Dragon | Globetrotter
fields.byline: Greg Howson, Andy Bodle and  Mike Anderiesz
fields.body:
Phantasy Star Online
Sega Dreamcast £39.99 Sega *****
It is up there with trainspotting and learning Klingon, but online gaming has finally broken free from geekdom. The reason is Phantasy Star Online: the world's first console-based online role playing game (RPG). Unlike the bearded fantasy cliches of PC titles such as Everquest, PSO offers a colourful futuristic environment, albeit with a limp sci-fi plot.

Despite a manual twice the size of most console games, PSO is wonderfully easy to pick up but has enough depth to satisfy serious stat-addicts. Your first task is to create your character and it is wise to spend time on this. You could patiently weigh up the combat or magic potential, or just play around with hair colours. It is this great dichotomy between accessibility and complexity that makes PSO such a revelation.

The next choice is simple - on or offline. Offline play lets you build up your character and undertake some interesting side-missions but the only way to truly play Phantasy Star is online. Getting connected is a cinch and before long you will be creating your own team or joining another. Then it is time for some planetside monster-bashing. As you cannot harm your team mates, co-operation is all and combat strategy is essential for success.

Thankfully communication is easy, with instant translation into five languages, and standard icons used to create an unrivalled team atmosphere. In fact, the communication element is perhaps the biggest achievement of PSO, taking the relatively simple hack'n'slash gameplay to a new level.

Sumptuous graphics are the icing on the cake and the only downside to Phantasy Star Online is cost. With the average session lasting more than an hour, you can expect heavy phone bills. In this rare case, they are worth it. (GH)

Three Kingdoms: Fate of the Dragon
PC CD-Rom £29.99 Overmax/Eidos Interactive ***
After Civilization, Age of Empires, and the legion of inferior imitators, the historical real-time strategy game seemed a used-up genre.

Three Kingdoms is not about to change that. Sure, the setting is rich and colourful. The game takes us back to second century China, where three warlords are engaged in a fierce battle for control of the fragmented empire. Using an isometric view, you can play as any of the three, each of whom has unique forces at his disposal. You know the shtick.

In order to build up those forces, you must first develop your home city by chopping wood, mining, building farms, and training peasants. Yay. Resource management. Has no one yet told games designers that resource management is the opposite of fun? Some of us have enough trouble remembering to buy milk, for goodness sake.

Anyway, once the city is up and running, things get slightly more enjoyable as you send out your troops, occupy county towns, besiege enemy cities and invent new technologies. You know. The usual. (One tiny difference here is that you must remember to keep your troops supplied with food or they will weaken and become useless in battle. Personally, I would rather spend a little longer training the soldiers until they were intelligent enough to forage for themselves.)

Military might is not the only route to victory, however. You can also win by making more scientific progress than your rivals, or by skilful use of trade and diplomacy. Hey, there has to be somebody out there who wants to try that.

Graphically speaking, it is pretty and the soundtrack is marginally preferable to having a plate scraped in your ear.

I know, I know, I have just described every historical RTS you have ever seen. But then, that is what this is. A dead horse being flogged, albeit in a competent and moderately entertaining way. (AB)

Globetrotter
PC £29.99 Vsion Park/EA *
In many ways there's something charming about Globetrotter, in that it harks back to days when games were a cottage industry and A-list titles frequently arrived with photocopied instructions and labels stuck to cassettes by the programmer's mum. Globetrotter turned up looking decidedly low-budget and boasting the most useless insert ever seen - a poorly drawn departure schedule. Not a promising start.

But wait. Having installed it, up popped a very professional video montage of people travelling to exotic locations, easily up to Lonely Planet titles and accompanied by some funky original music. Perhaps I have judged this too early?

Nah - it's rubbish. Video over, the game kicks in with hilarious results. Imagine Pokemon Snap without the 3D engine, with gigantic characters strutting across unconvincing, out-of-scale maps. Every level involves much the same thing: you have to go to a location and take photos of it, returning to base or travelling elsewhere within a set time limit. Some places can be walked to (simply point on the map and click); others need train, plane or boat connections. Along the way, you may be asked one of 4,000 simple trivia questions loosely based on local history. For instance, in London we are asked what performance led to the rise of the Beatles. Yes, it is the Ed Sullivan show - and that's London summed up, don't you think?

In fairness, there is the potential here for quite an interesting game, perhaps using a Sim City-style engine. But alas there are far too many problems to be cured by a simple makeover.

As a game, Globetrotter's credentials are uncertain; as a travel aid it is one stage below chronically inept. For example, although major bridges are pointed out on the map, characters can still wade through rivers leaving tell-tale splashes in their wake. Somehow, being able to choose their sex (it makes no difference to the gameplay, of course) fails to make up for so many laws of physics, geography and common sense being broken all at once.

All in all, Globetrotter looks and plays like a school project and cannot be recommended even to lovers of kitsch (which it so nearly is).

Whoever Vision Park is, this merely adds weight to the claim that developing videogames is a big boy's game these days. (MA)

The reason is Phantasy Star Online: the world's first console-based online role playing game (RPG). Unlike the bearded fantasy cliches of PC titles such as Everquest, PSO offers a colourful futuristic environment, albeit with a limp sci-fi plot. Despite a manual twice the size of most console games, PSO is wonderfully easy to pick up but has enough depth to satisfy serious stat-addicts. Your first task is to create your character and it is wise to spend time on this. You could patiently weigh up the combat or magic potential, or just play around with hair colours. It is this great dichotomy between accessibility and complexity that makes PSO such a revelation. The next choice is simple - on or offline. Offline play lets you build up your character and undertake some interesting side-missions but the only way to truly play Phantasy Star is online. fields.headline: Crossroads reopens on March 5
fields.trailText:
1pm: ITV has announced revamped soap will hit TV screens on March 5, writes Matt Wells.
Nov 28: Crossroads confirms star line-up for comeback
Oct 27: Dickson snubs Crossroads remake
fields.body:
Crossroads has been closed to the viewing public for more than 13 years - but patient fans have only just over two weeks to wait for the grand reopening.

ITV has announced the once-reviled soap is to return twice a day from March 5, with a special peaktime airing on March 6 to relaunch the series.

The show will go head to head with BBC1's Neighbours at 1.30pm, with a second helping at 5.05pm.

And the network is pulling out all the stops to ensure the show is a hit.

The first two episodes will be rolled together for an hour-long special at 9pm on March 6.

The soap will open with ex-owner-turned-alcoholic Jill Chance returning to claim her share in the revamped four-star hotel.

"We wanted to give as many people as possible a taste of what Crossroads is all about," said ITV director of programmes David Liddiment.

An aggressive marketing campaign is already under way.

The show is being heavily trailed to peaktime viewers as well as to the core daytime audience.

Carlton, which is making the programme, hopes to attract a wide range of viewers to the show.

"There is something for everyone," claimed series producer Kay Patrick.

webTitle: Extract from Did Things Get Better? (IV)

fields.headline: Hard Labour
fields.standfirst:
Our fourth extract from a new book assessing the government's performance finds the number of offenders sent to prison has soared
Extract one: Well, did things get better?
Extract two: social justice
Extract three: environment
Extract five: health
Polly Toynbee and David Walker pick their top 10 politics books
fields.trailText: Our fourth extract from a new book assessing the government's performance finds the number of offenders sent to prison has soared.
fields.body:
The circumstances facing Jack Straw when he took over the Home Office were in their way almost as benign as Gordon Brown's at the Treasury. Prior to 1997, crime had been falling across the developed world - in the UK for four years in a row. It kept on falling, since crime mirrors unemployment.

So why did the prison population soar by 6,000 above the total bequeathed by Michael Howard, to more than 66,000? No extra criminals were caught; instead the courts started giving longer sentences. Magistrates and judges listen to home secretaries. There is evidence that the prison population mirrors political rhetoric. It fell sharply when Douglas Hurd repeatedly pleaded with courts not to imprison petty offenders, then shot up after Michael Howard's first speech claiming "prison works", and rose again under Mr Straw.

So why did he take the hard line? Labour made a compact with what it imagined to be middle England, encapsulated in Tony Blair's famous slogan: "Tough on crime, tough on the causes of crime." If Labour were to be generous to the poor, tackling the causes of crime by spending on a multitude of poverty programmes, then the quid pro quo was belabouring criminals, asylum seekers and anyone else fingered by the Daily Mail.

Ritual abuse of Hampstead liberals and soft liberal policies was a signal to Mondeo man that Jack Straw was custodian of toughness. He was the attack dog which would keep the law-and-order tabloids off Labour's back. He drew inspiration too from the Blackburn estates where his child curfews, parenting and anti-social behaviour orders and curbs on nightmare neighbours all chimed with the respectable Labour heartlands.

A leaked memorandum showed Mr Blair calling for some law 'n' order to spice up a dull speech. This was delivered in Germany and the spice was a threat to march drunken louts to cashpoint machines. The chief constables thought it ridiculous.

Mr Blair proclaimed 4,000 vacancies in the jails for offending yobs - yet over-crowded prisons offering inmates no education, training or treatment were being damned time and again, not just by the chief inspector but by the civil servant who headed the prison service too. Last year the prison service failed to reach its - very modest - target of ensuring every prisoner had at least 24 hours a week of work, education or training out of their cells.

It was shameless cynicism that had nothing to do with what works and destroyed trust. Yet behind the scenes, better policies for crime were pursued and some might even work. A national youth justice board was set up to oversee 155 local youth offending teams. For every young offender, action plans are being arranged for training, drug treatment or education - both for offenders in custody and outside again in the community.

Since teenagers commit 40% of burglaries and 28% of violent offences, identifying them first time round and giving them a coherent programme may reduce the rate at which people reoffend. In future Rat Boy - a conspicuous multiple offender - would not keep on getting cautioned but would be delivered immediately to his local youth offending team.

But this constructive approach also saw the arrival of new detention and training orders to lock more young offenders away. The number of young offenders imprisoned shot up by 10%, many crammed in over-crowded institutions with no chance of effective treatment, often hundreds of miles from home.

Youth crime, however, will be one area of Labour failure. The only one of the five famous pre-election pledges that will not be met by May this year is the promise to halve the time between arrest and sentencing for juveniles. It has been cut from 142 to under 90 days.

What really worked on the crime front, quickly and measurably, were dull measures with no front-page potential. Better locks on cars cut car crime by 30%. There was a 5% reduction in burglaries in high-crime areas after £400m was spent on "target-hardening" locks, bars and entry-phones for the worst estates.

There was no public boasting about another success - letting non-violent offenders out of prison early, on electronic tags. Some 2,000 are now on tags - far cheaper than prison though it is too early to tell whether a regulated life in the community with compulsory training will lead to less reoffending.

Asylum swelled into a major issue throughout Europe. Labour's polls showed it topped the list of popular concerns: Mori found 80% of voters thought the UK a soft touch. The Tories left behind a backlog of 60,000 cases to be assessed, which rapidly rose to more than 100,000 and has now dropped back to some 66,000. Draconian new rules to appease the British public, but purportedly to deter all comers, led to vouchers instead of cash benefits, sub-poverty level payments and compulsory dispersal around the country into sink estates.

Despite screw-tightening, numbers seeking asylum continued to rise and it proved impossible to send back most of those refused refugee status. Calling them "bogus" and "abusive" only stirred up fear and hatred.

fields.headline: What's new
fields.trailText: Big shot | Boxing clever
fields.body:
Big shot
Sanyo has announced a high storage capacity digital camera that doubles as a basic camcorder. Due next month, the IDC-1000Z uses Sanyo's new 730MB ID Photo Magneto optical disc system to house up 11,000 stills or two hours of video files. It can also be used to archive up to 24 hours of voice dictation. Another key facility is the camera's Sequential Shot Function, which can take up to 30 shots in one second. The IDC-1000Z, which has a resolution of 1.5 megapixels, is due to retail for around £700. Sanyo has also become the latest Japanese consumer electronics manufacturer to offer its take on the MP3 format with its just launched personal-sized player, the £250 SSP-PD7. In addition to playing MP3, the unit is also compatible with AAC (Advanced Acoustic Coding) files. If AAC is used, the player can store up to an hour of music on its removable 32MB MultiMedia card, whereas MP3 compression stores around half an hour. AAC download times are also twice as fast MP3 ones. The player comes with rechargeable batteries, which deliver around five hours of playback. Sanyo is also joining Philips, Bush and Goodmans in offering a personal CD player that will read MP3 files burned on to CD-ROMs. The CDP-M300, which also boasts a 45-second anti-shock system, goes on sale in July. No news on prices yet.

Snap and sing
Kodak has joined Samsung and Fuji in offering a digital camera with a built-in MP3 player. Scheduled for a March launch, the £200 MC3 is also one of the cheapest digital cameras to offer both video capture and an LCD screen. The camera comes with a 16MB CompactFlash card, which will store up to 110 digital images or 20 minutes of video, but a paltry 15 minutes of standard-quality MP3 music. Larger-capacity CompactFlash cards are available, although adding a 64MB card, which archives more than an hour of music, ramps up the cost by a further £140. The camera's other audio facilities include a built-in speaker, a headphones socket and an output for connection to a home or car stereo. Snappers are offered a self-timer, auto white balance and exposure and an image resolution of 640 by 480 pixels. (AN)

Boxing clever
Yorkshire-based Pace Micro Technology has unveiled a television set-top box that incorporates a Sega Dreamcast games console. The system includes a 40 gigabyte hard drive to store up to 60 games, which can be downloaded and updated via a cable or modem or data broadcasting connection. The drive can also be used to record TV programmes, like TiVo's digital VCR, and in the next five to 10 years, Pace thinks it could develop into a "home gateway" to connect up other devices. Andrew Wallace,Pace's marketing director, says: "Fundamentally, what we are offering is cost-effective access to a new market of casual gamers. We don't expect keen gamers to buy this product."

In fact, neither type of gamer will be able to buy the product. Pace is offering the system to cable and satellite TV operators, who will charge their subscribers a higher monthly fee - perhaps $20 - to rent the system. The deal is non-exclusive on both sides. Pace remains free to integrate rival games systems in similar set-top boxes, while Sega is talking to other device manufacturers about using its games technology. (JS)

fields.headline: Humans safe, food agency insists
fields.standfirst:
Consumers confidence dealt new blow

Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The food standards agency last night reassured consumers that the European commission ban on the export of UK meat and dairy produce had no direct implications for   human health, but there were fears that shoppers' confidence would be dented by the latest food crisis.
fields.body:
The food standards agency last night reassured consumers that the European commission ban on the export of UK meat and dairy produce had no direct implications for human health, but there were fears that shoppers' confidence would be dented by the latest food crisis.

"There are no implications for food safety," said a spokesman for the FSA, the independent body responsible for food standards and public health. "The ban is purely on animal health grounds."

Human cases of foot and mouth disease are extremely rare. "There was one case of human foot and mouth disease in 1967 but we believe it was not food-borne. Very, very rarely a human may show symptoms of foot and mouth disease but it always arises because of close proximity to animals," the FSA added.

Tesco confirmed that the abattoir near Brentwood in Essex where the disease was detected was one of its suppliers. It said it would continue to source most of its meat from the UK.

The meat most likely to be affected is lamb. Britain imports an increasing amount of its pork, and British farmers have been unable to export beef anyway. But about 30% of British lamb is exported, and much of that could now land on the UK market.

Tim Lang, professor of food policy at Thames Valley University, said: "This is a sober reminder to consumers that farming is not producing healthy products. Why are we getting the return of a disease that had disappeared 20 years ago? Where you've got very intensive farming, you get disease."

The home secretary is legally entitled to set minimum jail terms for killers serving mandatory life sentences, the high court ruled today.

The court rejected accusations that Jack Straw's powers to fix tariffs for retribution and deterrence were unlawful because they were "incompatible" and inconsistent with the European Convention on Human Rights and in breach of the new Humans Rights Act.

The ruling will come as a relief to the government. A decision against the home secretary could have paved the way for many of the country's most notorious criminals, including Moors murderer Myra Hindley, to gain their freedom.

Hindley's QC Edward Fitzgerald had applied for a test case declaration on behalf of two other lifers that judges - not politicians - should set the minimum terms for mandatory lifers. Anthony Anderson and John Taylor both had their tariffs for murder increased by the home secretary.

Dismissing their application for judicial review, Lord Justice Rose, sitting with Mr Justice Sullivan and Mr Justice Penry-Davey, said: "I conclude that parliament by primary legislation has conferred on the home secretary the power to fix the tariff for mandatory lifers."

A Home Office spokeswoman had earlier indicated that most of the tariffs for the country's estimated 3,000 mandatory lifers had been set in line with the recommendations of judges - but there were still hundreds of cases where the home secretary had raised the tariffs. Had today's ruling gone against the government, those tariffs could have come become liable for review.

Mr Fitzgerald was granted leave to appeal.

Related articles

14.02.2001: Act helps brutal killer avoid justice

fields.headline: Has Beckham been sussed?
fields.trailText: Have we seen the best of David Beckham? That's the question Erik Thomas is asking after watching him struggle against Valencia's defence yet again.
fields.body:
Have we seen the best of David Beckham? That's the question Erik Thomas is asking after watching him struggle against Valencia's defence yet again.

"In the two games against Valencia it appears Beckham can be shut out of games at will by clever tactics from the opposition," he says. "I have never considered him a 'great' footballer, but rather a good athlete with an outstanding ability to manipulate a ball with his right foot. With Valencia sussing how to stifle his limited talents you can bet the rest of the football world won't be slow to catch on. It will be interesting to see how he copes.

"I think Beckham's lost a lot of his cutting edge by playing inside: he's just not quick-witted enough to play there," Erik continues. "My advice to him is: stay out wide to create space and whip those balls in to the penalty area, concentrate on pushing your fullback up the field - and leave the congestion in the middle of the park to those with a more all-round game."

Harsh words, but not as harsh as those Lee Calvert has for Leeds manager David O'Leary.

"David 'modesty' O'Leary is really beginning to get on my nerves," he says. "When will the day come when he actually tell us what he is really thinking, ie: 'We have the best young squad in England, possibly Europe so we really should be doing as well as we are doing, and should be doing better in the league.'

"Instead we have to put up with "blah blah, young babies, blah blah terrible injuries, blah blah we're never going to win nothing, blah blah strong south-easterly wind, blah blah boots don't quite fit, blah blah every team in the world is better than us (apart from Bradford)." It really is getting irritating!

"Well done to Leeds though for qualifying for the Champions League," he adds, sardonically.

More flak for the Guardian

Another day, another sack of letters taking a pop at the Guardian. Ah well, we might as well start somewhere

"I think that it is absolutely scandalous that you include Gavin McCann in the same category as Spencer Prior and Dean Windass as potential England call-ups," writes Martin.

"Prior and Windass are both over thirty, and are currently playing for teams that will most probably get relegated this season, while McCann is a 22-year-old midfielder who Peter Reid - not a bad midfield player in his day - reckons will represent his country in the future.

"If Mr Lacey honestly thinks McCann deserves to be categorised alongside Prior and Windass then if I was you I would seriously consider his ability to be a football correspondent, as he obviously lacks the knowledge of the game someone in his position should hold," Martin adds.

Burnley v Fulham: was the Guardian even there?

But Martin's criticism is fairly mild compared to the flak David Hopps has taken for his Burnley v Fulham match report on Tuesday night.

"This article is a real 'hack' job built around three supposed 'facts': that Fulham haven't won at the Turf since 1951, that Burnley are reputed to be a physical team, and that Burnley is a make-and-mend 'cotton town'. Less colour and more actual reporting on the match, please," says David Leaver.

And Mr Leaver is not the only one.

"Brilliant report, especially your description of our equalising goal," says Tony Scholes, who is the Membership Secretary and website editor of the Clarets Independent Supporters Association.

"You say 'Weller's right-wing cross, Taylor's far-post header, and Moore stooping to head the final few inches'. Can I suggest that if you wish to insult our wonderful club then you get your facts right. The cross was in fact from Mitchell Thomas. An easy mistake to make though: Weller is 5ft 8ins tall and white, Mitchell is 6ft 2ins and black.

And watch out, David, there's more to come. "Was David Hopps really at Turf Moor?" asks Andie Brown. " If so, he was certainly standing in the Cricket Ground end with the other couple of dozen Fulham fans."

"This was a superb game of football, and Hopps's inadequate and unbalanced account does the game and both teams a disservice. Find another reporter or lose a reader," he warns.

And PB agrees. "If The Clarets are the bruisers that you are suggesting would not your stats on free-kicks be reversed?" he claims.

"It's nice to see the Northern cliches are still alive too - it's a long time since Burnley's been a cotton town," he continues, before signing off with: "Must dash, the whippet needs a walk before teatime, black pudding tonight!"

There's also criticism from several Tranmere fans, who say we've concentrated too much on Southampton's three goals and not given enough space to their club's sterling comeback.

Fair point. But while we suffer under this barrage, it's comforting to know at least one supporter is happy.

"Thanks for all the coverage this week," says Tranmere fan Jonathan Roberts. "It's great to see the club you've loved getting a bit of recognition before they once again vanish into oblivion. Watch out Liverpool!"

fields.headline: Lord Mackay of Ardbrecknish
fields.standfirst: Conservative peer with an irreverent, stylish flair for debate which endeared him to all sides
fields.trailText: Conservative peer with an irreverent, stylish flair for debate which endeared him to all sides.
fields.body:
Spirited, engaging Lord (John) Mackay of Ardbrecknish, who has died suddenly at 62, was formerly the Tory MP for Argyll and then for Argyll and Bute, before being "kicked upstairs" in 1991 after his 1987 defeat at the hands of the Liberal Democrats. Having been a junior Scottish minister in the Commons from 1982-87, he became a minister of state for social security in the Lords under John Major from 1994-97.

When William Hague purged Lord Cranborne and his cohorts in December 1998 for their secret deal with Tony Blair, he made Lord Mackay deputy leader of the Conservative opposition in the Lords. As such, he made some of their best speeches, claiming for the Tories the role of the effective reforming party. He gave up this post last November, nominally to become chairman of the committees of the Lords, the most senior member of the House after the Lord Chancellor.

Widely popular, he did not seem to fit wholly in with the new, increasingly rightwing and Europhobic regime. Only last week he took a major job outside the House. A man of modest means, he required extra employment when deprived of ministerial pay. When he lost Argyll and Bute, he became chief executive of the Scottish Conservatives from 1987-90.

Irreverent, he even dared make fun of the hereditary backwoodsmen who came out of the woodwork to make up Tory majorities in the Lords. In November 1998 he said: "There are some people here I have never seen before and (was) wondering who they were." According to Viscount Thurso, his witty debating style was "rather like a well executed Scottish reel. There is lots of style, much movement, lots of euching and at the end you find that you are back where you started!"

Mackay was the son of a policeman. He was educated at Dunoon grammar school, as were Labour ministers George Robertson and Brian Wilson, and the late Labour leader John Smith, and at Campbeltown in Argyll. After Glasgow University, where he started a lifelong friendship with the late Donald Dewar, he became head of the maths department at Oban high school. After a brief flirtation with the Liberals in his early years, he sought a Westminster seat for the Tories when he contested the Western Isles and then Argyll, in the two general elections of 1974.

But it was not until five years later that he succeeded, becoming MP for Argyll in 1979 when he snatched the seat from the SNP.

In the 1980s he had a three-year stint as chairman of the Sea Fish Industry Authority.

He was a keen angler but was allergic to dogs, confessing in a debate: "In close proximity with dogs, I become unwell." adding, "cats are worse and rabbits worse still." He leaves his wife, Sheena, two sons and a daughter.

 John Mackay, Baron Mackay of Ardbrecknish, politician, born November 15 1938; died February 21 2001.

Related story
Former minister dies after 13-hour Lords session

fields.headline: Race dreams turn to mush
fields.standfirst: Alaska's famous sled race, the Iditarod, is threatened by a lack of snow, reports Jane Martinson
fields.trailText: Alaska's famous sled race, the Iditarod, is threatened by a lack of snow, reports Jane Martinson.
fields.body:
It's February and Roy Monk, a hardy Lancastrian, is worried about suffering from heatstroke in Alaska.

Not that he fears for his own safety in temperatures of about 20 degrees Fahrenheit (minus 4 Celsius). He worries about his dogs, a team of Alaskan huskies training for the Iditarod, the gruelling sled race considered by many to be the toughest in the world.

An unusually warm winter in a country where temperatures average minus 40 below at this time of year has caused unusual problems for the mushers preparing for next week's (March 3) Iditarod. Joanne Potts, race director, says, "We are having one of the worst winters on record."

Mushers living in Anchorage, along with about half of Alaska's 600,000-strong population, have been forced to travel 300 or 400 miles north to train around the colder mountain ranges.

Monk, the sole Englishman among the 68 running the race this year, has been forced to train mostly at night when the temperatures drop to a level that enables the dogs to keep running. "This weather has been terrible. We have to rest between midday and five o'clock as it's just too warm for the dogs," he says.

The weather has been bad, or warm, all winter long. Potts, who has lived in Alaska since the year after the race started in 1973, cannot remember another year in which temperatures did not drop below minus degrees Fahrenheit in Anchorage.

The mushers, who have to fend for themselves and their dogs on the arduous 1,049-mile long trip, are worried that the lack of snow cover will allow tree stumps and other parts of the route to tear through the dogs' specially made booties and cause their sleds to crash.

The favourite to win this year is Doug Swingly, not only because the Montana-based musher has won thrice before but because the "lower 48" US states have all enjoyed more snow than Alaska this year.

Not that Alaskan is expected to pull out of the 18th annual race in the face of such hazards. Locals still make up the bulk of participants in spite of the odd Canadian, German or Brit.

The race, which has taken teams as little as 10 days and as much as more than three weeks, is the sporting event of the year. Every Alaskan can tell you that the race owes its origins to the diphtheria-serum run of 1925 when a team of dog mushers rushed medicine across Alaska from the port town of Nenana to the stricken town of Nome in western Alaska.

But most will also delight in the tales of killer moose and winds of up to sixty miles an hour that make the route from Anchorage to Nome such an arduous one.

The total prize money of more than $300,000 and the chance of enduring fame in Alaska - where winning mushers are accorded the status of Hollywood celebrities - do not really explain to the uninitiated why so many people decide to race every year.

Monk, for example, admits there is "zero chance" of his winning the race or even receiving more than the $1,000 awarded to all who manage to get across the finish line. The 63-year-old grandfather has taken part six times before and braves the cold and the unknown for "pleasure".

"I do it because I enjoy doing it. It isn't to win, although I would love to, but I don't have the dogs or the dedication and I am too old."

The oldest musher to complete the race was 83-year-old Norman Vaughan in 1990. After breaking six ribs and being knocked unconscious, Vaughan said that the race was against himself and time rather than anything else.

Monk and his wife, Lesley, have been spending six months of every year in Alaska for the past 15 years. Lesley, a personal trainer, was bitten by the bug first and raced the Iditarod before her husband in 1988. She has only taken part once more after receiving the Red Lantern, awarded to those who finish last.

Monk, who sold his small chemical company and retired 11 years ago, believes that animal rights protesters, more numerous in the UK than mushers, are wrong to worry about the conditions for the dogs during the race.

"As in any walk of life, there are going to be people who abuse things," he said. "But the mushers I know take far better care of their dogs than 90 per cent of pet owners."

The cost of racing must also weed out the half-hearted. Unless you happen to be one of the handful of mushers with big sponsorship deals, keen racers pay about $50,000 for a team and equipment. Monk estimates that keeping his 40-odd dogs fed every year costs about $20,000 on top of that.

He thinks the cost is probably what deters most Brits from following his lonely example and entering the Iditarod. That, and the usually cold weather.

webTitle: Golden NHS handcuffs on offer to consultants

fields.headline: Golden NHS handcuffs on offer to consultants
fields.trailText: A golden handcuff scheme for hospital consultants was unveiled by ministers yesterday in an attempt to persuade the profession to commit more time to the NHS and less to private practice.
fields.body:
A golden handcuff scheme for hospital consultants was unveiled by ministers yesterday in an attempt to persuade the profession to commit more time to the NHS and less to private practice.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, offered a contract with a £10,000 increase in starting salary, raising the consultant's basic rate to £60,000. He said this would be the launchpad for a sequence of bonuses and merit awards that should raise average earnings of NHS consultants with 10 years' service by almost £20,000 to £82,500.

In return he demanded that all newly-qualified consultants work exclusively for the NHS for the first stage of their careers. A consultation paper suggested "perhaps seven years", although the term may be reduced in negotiations with a hostile British Medical Association that are expected by both sides to drag on until after the general election.

Mr Milburn coupled the rise with a performance-related pay scheme. He expected two-thirds of consultants would pass a test of commitment and performance to qualify for a £10,000 annual bonus within five to eight years of qualifying. Most would get a further £10,000 performance bonus after another five to eight years.

Mr Milburn said: "The offer will remove a perverse incentive for NHS consultants not to work full-time for the NHS. I want to turn that on its head. Peter Hawker, chairman of the BMA's consultant's committee, said the ban on newly qualified consultants working outside the NHS was "unacceptable and insulting to the profession." Since ministers were encouraging more patients to be treated in the private sector, a ban would be "illogical, unworkable and probably illegal.

The proposals are the first fundamental overhaul of the contract agreed in 1948 by Nye Bevan, founder of the NHS, who admitted securing a deal with the consultants by "stuffing their mouths with gold".

This time the gold on offer would be subject to a string of conditions to make consultants more accountable to hospital managers. But they would remain free to work outside the NHS after the first seven years, and workaholics might be able to increase their NHS earnings.

Mr Milburn refused to cost the package, on the grounds it might weaken his hand in negotiations.

Documents published by the Department of Health said "a clear majority" of consultants could be between 15% and 20% better off within 12 years as a result of the proposed changes.

This suggested a price tag of about £200m on top of normal annual cost of living increases. But that sum would be dwarfed by the cost of the government's plan to increase the number of consultants by 50% to 39,000 by 2009.The proposals would scrap the "maximum part-time contract", whereby consultants can forgo one 11th of their NHS salary and do as much private work as they want once they have completed five to seven health service sessions a week.

Instead, consultants would be free to do private work without reducing their NHS income and entitlements as long as they did not supplement their earnings by more than 10%. Those wanting to earn more from private practice would be paid according to the time and commitment they put into the NHS.

Consultants putting in a full working week with the NHS as well as extensive private practice could earn a full NHS salary, but their access to performance pay thresholds would not be automatic.

Mr Milburn said there would be three phases to most consultants' careers: seven years building up expertise exclusively within the NHS, followed by a period of maximum hands-on commitment until about 55, when there would be scope for reducing workload while mentoring colleagues.

Stephen Thornton, chief executive of the NHS Confederation representing hospital managers, said the proposals were a step towards making consultants more accountable.

Sally Williams, of the Consumers Association, said: "It is essential that new contracts include mechanisms to make sure consultants stick to their job plans."


Sugar on the pill

 £10,000 extra on starting salaries for newly qualified NHS consultants

 Performance pay bonuses for those who continue to give a full commitment to NHS

 Most to get a bonus of £10,000 after 5-8 years service and a further £10,000 after 10-16 years

 Number of consultants to increase from 26,000 to 39,000 by 2009

 Job plans for all consultants to increase accountability

 Fairer distribution of clinical excellence awards to remove bias in favour of older white men

 Ban on private work for the first seven years
fields.bodyText: A golden handcuff scheme for hospital consultants was unveiled by ministers yesterday in an attempt to persuade the profession to commit more time to the NHS and less to private practice. Alan Milburn, the health secretary, offered a contract with a £10,000 increase in starting salary, raising the consultant's basic rate to £60,000. He said this would be the launchpad for a sequence of bonuses and merit awards that should raise average earnings of NHS consultants with 10 years' service by almost £20,000 to £82,500. In return he demanded that all newly-qualified consultants work exclusively for the NHS for the first stage of their careers. A consultation paper suggested "perhaps seven years", although the term may be reduced in negotiations with a hostile British Medical Association that are expected by both sides to drag on until after the general election. Mr Milburn coupled the rise with a performance-related pay scheme. He expected two-thirds of consultants would pass a test of commitment and performance to qualify for a £10,000 annual bonus within five to eight years of qualifying. Most would get a further £10,000 performance bonus after another five to eight years. Mr Milburn said: "The offer will remove a perverse incentive for NHS consultants not to work full-time for the NHS. I want to turn that on its head. Peter Hawker, chairman of the BMA's consultant's committee, said the ban on newly qualified consultants working outside the NHS was "unacceptable and insulting to the profession." Since ministers were encouraging more patients to be treated in the private sector, a ban would be "illogical, unworkable and probably illegal. The proposals are the first fundamental overhaul of the contract agreed in 1948 by Nye Bevan, founder of the NHS, who admitted securing a deal with the consultants by "stuffing their mouths with gold". This time the gold on offer would be subject to a string of conditions to make consultants more accountable to hospital managers. But they would remain free to work outside the NHS after the first seven years, and workaholics might be able to increase their NHS earnings. Mr Milburn refused to cost the package, on the grounds it might weaken his hand in negotiations. Documents published by the Department of Health said "a clear majority" of consultants could be between 15% and 20% better off within 12 years as a result of the proposed changes. This suggested a price tag of about £200m on top of normal annual cost of living increases. But that sum would be dwarfed by the cost of the government's plan to increase the number of consultants by 50% to 39,000 by 2009.The proposals would scrap the "maximum part-time contract", whereby consultants can forgo one 11th of their NHS salary and do as much private work as they want once they have completed five to seven health service sessions a week. Instead, consultants would be free to do private work without reducing their NHS income and entitlements as long as they did not supplement their earnings by more than 10%. Those wanting to earn more from private practice would be paid according to the time and commitment they put into the NHS. Consultants putting in a full working week with the NHS as well as extensive private practice could earn a full NHS salary, but their access to performance pay thresholds would not be automatic. Mr Milburn said there would be three phases to most consultants' careers: seven years building up expertise exclusively within the NHS, followed by a period of maximum hands-on commitment until about 55, when there would be scope for reducing workload while mentoring colleagues. Stephen Thornton, chief executive of the NHS Confederation representing hospital managers, said the proposals were a step towards making consultants more accountable. Sally Williams, of the Consumers Association, said: "It is essential that new contracts include mechanisms to make sure consultants stick to their job plans." fields.headline: Another year, another premier
fields.standfirst: With Japan's politicians readying themselves yet again to choose a new prime minister, the country's voters could be forgiven for a case of déjà vu, says Jonathan Watts
fields.trailText: With Japan's politicians readying themselves yet again to choose a new prime minister, the country's voters could be forgiven for a case of déjà vu, says Jonathan Watts.
fields.body:
There's the former Takarazuka showgirl, the brylcreemed kendo expert, the raffish political maverick and the hard-man from the wrong side of the tracks.

It could be the line-up for one of the weekly melodramas that Japanese television companies do so well, but instead this is the cast of candidates in the latest episode of an all-too-familiar guessing game: who will be the next prime minister? After seven premiers in the past eight years, this has become an almost annual activity in Japan.

As a result, despite the colourful cast of characters and the frenzy of speculation in the corridors of Nagatacho (Tokyo's political heartland) about who will replace Yoshiro Mori, many in the jaded viewing public could be forgiven for thinking that they are merely seeing repeats.

For the moment, of course, the country is at least nominally still tuned into MoriVision, a show that promised to be educational and high-tech when it began last April, but has since turned out to be a depressingly old-fashioned comedy.

Most of the electorate has long since switched off as a result of Mori's verbal gaffes (he has averaged about one a month since taking office), persistent rumours of his links with gangsters and corruption scandals that have forced the resignations of three ministers.

What little sympathy there was left for the premier has evaporated in the past two weeks after it emerged that he chose to continue playing golf rather than respond immediately to the news that Japanese schoolchildren were struggling for their lives, after the sinking of the Ehime Maru by a US nuclear submarine.

Mori appears to be doomed by his ratings. According to a raft of opinion polls, he is the second-most unpopular prime minister in Japanese history with ratings as low as 6%. Investors have also panned him: the Nikkei index of the Tokyo stock market has lost more than 35% since he took the reins.

With his coalition allies, New Komeito - who hold the balance of power in parliament - now calling for his resignation, his fate is all but sealed.

The betting is that he will be forced from office as soon as lawmakers approve the budget - probably in early March. A decision on Wednesday by George Bush to cancel a summit with Mori scheduled for early March did nothing to dispel such speculation.

Now that Mori's fall is seen not in terms of "if" or even "when", the question on everyone's lips is "who will replace him?" Although no candidates have put themselves forward for this star role, the media has begun auditions in their absence.

The favourite is Junichiro Koizumi, an outspoken maverick popular among voters. In an indication of the overall crustiness of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, he has somehow held onto a reputation as a young reformer even though he will turn 60 this year.

His main appeal for the LDP lawmakers who will pick the next leader is that his popularity may help the party avoid a meltdown in their vote in the upper house election in July. Against him, however, is the fact that he is a member of Mori's faction and must take some of the blame for his leader's failings.

The second most frequently mentioned name is Hiromu Nonaka, one of the most intriguing and powerful figures in modern Japanese politics. A hard man in the Norman Tebbit mould when it comes to party discipline, he has been the backbone of several recent administrations. But on social issues, he often takes a remarkably liberal stance - especially on questions of gender equality and the rights of minorities. Although the Japanese media refuse to mention it, he is known to be from the "dowa" or "untouchable caste", which could count against him among conservatives.

Former prime minister Ryutaro Hashimoto is third on the list. The kendo expert has made a stunning comeback since he stepped down in 1998 to take responsibility for a crushing defeat in the last upper house election. He returned to the cabinet last year with a powerful portfolio covering administrative reform, Okinawa and the disputed northern territories. A dashing figure who is popular with women voters, his only problem is that he may be seen as a loser.

The most surprising figure in the frame is Chikage Ogi, a former singing-dancing actress in the popular all-female Takurazuka Review who has served as construction minister since last summer. If chosen, she would be the first woman prime minister of Japan and the first national leader from New Komei, a lay Buddhist party.

None of these candidates appears at all thrilled at the prospect of playing the role of fall guy ahead of the expected drubbing of the coalition in July's election. Unless one of them is pushed into the part, it is even being suggested that LDP dinosaurs like former prime ministers, Kiichi Miyazawa and Yasuhiro Nakasone, should step forward.

Meanwhile, the two most popular politicians in Japan - right-wing Tokyo governor Shintaro Ishihara and firebrand lawmaker Makiko Tanaka - are out of the picture. If it was left to voters, one of these two figures would have the starring role, but the final audition will be held by the LDP, which has clung on to power for all but one of the past 46 years by rotating top government jobs among the party's factions. Ishihara and Tanaka are both outside that set-up.

So whether Mori stays or goes, Japan looks to be in for another season of political re-runs. And rather than generating excitement about "who will be next?" or "what will change?" many in the electorate are more likely to wonder: "Does it matter?"

fields.headline: Youssef Allan
fields.trailText: Palestinian representative to Ireland was the best known international activist on the British trades union and political conference scene for more than 20 years.
fields.body:
The Palestinian representative to Ireland, Dr Youssef Allan, who has died aged 47 at his home in Dublin was the best known international activist on the British trades union and political conference scene for more than 20 years. Not even the smallest trade union conference escaped Allan's attentions.

I first met him in the late 1970s when he arrived to take his doctorate in fluid dynamics at Dundee University, where I was then the Labour party organiser and active in Palestinian solidarity work. He announced himself as the newly arrived Palestine Liberation Organisation representative in the city and from that day until his last I never knew him to rest from his ceaseless struggle to return to his village, Halhoul, near the West Bank town of Hebron as part of the emerging Palestinian state.

The first week I knew him, he cooked a Palestinian dish translated as "upside-down", which he tipped on to a newspaper tablecloth, and won my heart - and that of almost everyone else he ever met. Educated at the University of Baghdad and then as a Fatah activist on West Beirut's streets in the 1970, he made his mark on the Scottish and then the British political stage.

Allan was a pivotal force in the controversial twinning of Dundee and the West Bank town of Nablus in 1980. This led to the first ever Palestinian flag flying from a public building in the western world. He helped to organise the visit to Dundee of the mayor of Nablus, Bassam Shakaa, who two years before had lost his legs in an Israeli terrorist car bomb attack.

The same year, in the kitchen of my flat in Dundee he co-founded the Trades Union Friends of Palestine with Dundee MP Ernie Ross, myself and other activists. The TUFP played the decisive role in the 1982 Labour conference victory in Brighton, where for the first time Labour recognised the PLO as the "sole legitimate representative of the Palestinian People" and called for "a Palestinian state on the West Bank and Gaza Strip with East Jerusalem as its capital". This provoked a walk-out of the Israeli representatives at the conference.

Leaving Dundee to live "underground" in London - his student visa having run out - Allan was seen off by the Dundee police pipe band.

If a Palestinian state ever does come to pass, his name and his contribution should be etched upon its pillars. He is survived by his widow, Jayne, whom he met when she worked at the London-based Medical Aid for Palestinians. They had no children.

 Youssef Allan, activist, born 1953; died January 17 2001
