webTitle: 'Promoting race equality should be the norm'

fields.headline: 'Promoting race equality should be the norm'
fields.standfirst: The Race Relations Amendment Act will ensure public services promote racial equality across the board but, asks Naaz Coker, when will we see equality without the need for leglislation?
fields.trailText: The Race Relations Amendment Act is welcome in ensuring the promotion of racial equality across all services but, writes Naaz Coker, true equality will only come about without the insistence of the heavy hand of the law.
fields.body:
The government has announced how the Race Relations Amendment Act will affect public services. Instead of the previous duty simply not to behave in a discriminatory fashion, all public services now have a positive duty to promote equality in every area of their work. Not only that, but the duty is enforceable by law - and not a moment too soon.

Reams of research reports tell us that people from many of Britain's black and minority ethnic communities have lower than average incomes, suffer more ill health, experience more problems getting work and are at greater risk of becoming victims of crime.

In public services such as the NHS, there is a growing body of evidence to show discrimination blocks both access to appropriate services and opportunities for employment. Sadly, it is clear that voluntary compliance with the previous Race Relations Act has been sporadic at best in the NHS. From entry to medical school through to places in top management, black and minority ethnic people are disadvantaged by a system that has tackled neither the underlying causes of ethnic inequality nor the impact of prejudice in decision making and everyday practice within their organisations.

Then came the Macpherson report. With a strong definition of institutional racism and a clear message that "colour-blind" policies and practices were insufficient to tackle it, the Macpherson report gave a new impetus to action against all forms of racist behaviour. The Race Relations Amendment Act is the statutory conclusion of that process.

It requires public services to abandon colour-blind practices to ensure that in employment and service provision they are equally accessible to everyone. In particular, it specifies that all public sector bodies should develop, implement and audit race equality strategies, and that every major proposal to change service provision is assessed for its impact on black and minority ethnic users.

In practical terms, this presents new challenges for anyone working in the public sector. It means looking at what services it provides and the degree to which it meets the needs of all the different communities it serves. It might mean either developing specific services for communities with particular needs, or changing the way mainstream services behave in order to reach out to groups who do not use them (or benefit from them) sufficiently. Either way, there must be a commitment to long-term funding, rather than short-term initiatives.

In addition, public services will need to monitor their employment and training procedures for discrimination (especially indirect discrimination) and harassment and find ways of tackling them. Specifically, this may mean developing new training programmes to promote skills learning among black workers, it may mean providing mentoring support for individuals taking on new jobs, or it might mean taking a tougher line on those who abuse black staff.

All of these things are happening somewhere in the NHS and other public services. There are plenty of examples of successful initiatives to improve access to services, to help professionals to be more responsive to community needs, to invest in staff from black and minority ethnic backgrounds, and to take strong action against workplace bullying.

Those good practices must now become universal, by law. But a nagging question remains. When will this approach become normative? When will we see automatic commitment to genuine race equality without the heavy hand of legislation compelling it? Because if the principle of equality is to mean anything in public services, then a dramatic change in culture will be needed in many places.

 Naaz Coker is director of race and diversity at the King's Fund

webTitle: Oftel sets cap on unbundling claims

fields.headline: Oftel sets cap on unbundling claims
fields.trailText: Telecom operators that install equipment in BT exchanges cannot claim more than £20m a year in compensation if things go wrong, writes Nicholas Bannister.
fields.body:
Telecom operators that install their own equipment in BT exchanges will not be able to claim more than £20m a year in compensation if things go wrong, the telecom regulator, David Edmonds, ruled yesterday.

BT and the operators had been unable to agree a compensation scheme, leaving BT facing unlimited liability for operators' costs and lost profits if it failed to deliver agreed services.

To resolve the situation, Mr Edmonds has capped the amount that any operator can claim in a year to £20m and limited claims relating to an individual exchange to £500,000 a year.

The compensation limits are included in terms and conditions for local loop unbundling published yesterday.

BT said the terms were recognition that the machinery Oftel had initially put in place to handle an expected flood of demand for direct access to the local loop had been unnecessary. A spokesman said: "In terms of meeting real demand from real operators, it will be handled on a business-as-usual basis."

Oftel has forced BT to allow telecom operators to install their own equipment in its 7,500 exchanges to break monopoly control of the local loop - the last few hundred yards of line from the local exchange to homes and offices.

Such installations will give the operators direct access to local lines and enable them to offer additional services to customers.

Under the new arrangements, BT will have to pay immediate compensation to operators if service levels are not met. Within the capped total compensation, Oftel will set the scale of compensation rates if BT fails to agree a system with the operators by April 30.

Mr Edmonds also ruled that operators who have ordered too much space in a BT exchange can trade the surplus with other operators. Surplus space which is not used will return to BT ownership.

webTitle: Social services 'a step ahead' on race relations

fields.headline: Social services 'a step ahead' on race relations
fields.trailText: Social services departments are a step ahead of some public services in promoting good race relations, according to race equality experts.
fields.body:
Social services departments are a step ahead of some public services in promoting good race relations, according to race equality experts.

Speaking on the day that the Home Office published a consultation document on implementing the Race Relations (Amendment) Act 2000 in the public sector, a Commission for Racial Equality (CRE) spokesman said the "race dimension" already formed a part of social work.

"Social work departments are ahead of some other areas of the public sector," he said. "Social workers have been forced to think of race because of acute problems facing children, issues of race and adoption." He added that, for example, transport planners and perhaps doctors might be less aware of the race equality implications of their work - "although one can't generalise".

But social services departments should audit their policies, services and employment practices to ensure they are promoting good race relations, he said. Social care agencies needed to look at who were their clients and the services they were providing. And councils with small ethnic minority populations, where "they've tended to think 'there's not a problem here'" will have more catching up to do, he said.

Social services should "debate these proposals, not just in terms of employment targets but also in terms of the service they offer their clients and how effectively do they serve all groups", he said. "And that discussion should not just be an internal one but should, for example, ask the local black community what they think of the performance of their local social services department."

Ratna Dutt, director of the REU (Race Equality Unit), agreed that: "In terms of social care agencies, there is a history of trying to address issues of race equality. Race equality is much more the agenda of social care agencies than other agencies - it's been written about and talked about for over 30 years."

But now, she said: "The question is how far they've been able to address them."

Ms Dutt listed areas of concern for social care staff. "We still have black children - especially of mixed heritage - who are disproportionately represented in care statistics," she said.

"There are disproportionate numbers of young black people in court and being cautioned.

"We have black people being over-represented in mental health system.

"We still find that black and ethnic people are not accessing support services - for example, family centres - and services for older people may not be appropriate.

"Then, if you look at something like employment, while they have recruited black and ethnic minority staff, higher up the scale, there is no picture of huge change."

The consultation document recommends that local authorities audit publish an action plan, following assessment of their "functions and policies" and public consultation, outlining how they intend to meet their duties under the act.

Wilf Sullivan, Unison's national black members officer, argued that "all of social services functions and policy will be relevant because they are serving diverse communities".

After the consultation period, which ends on 15 May, the CRE will prepare codes of practice, including one for local government and one for health.

The CRE has raised the following race equality pointers for social services:
 ethnic minority communities are more likely to live in deprived areas and in unpopular and overcrowded housing;
 people from ethnic minority communities are more likely to be poor and unemployed, regardless of their age, sex, qualifications and place of residence;
 social services should be "a dynamic, positive force in tacking inequality and promoting social inclusion", according to government policy;
 however, a social services inspectorate (SSI) survey of eight authorities in 1999 suggested that most councils did not have strategies in place to deliver appropriate services to ethnic minority users;
 since 1999-2000, performance assessment framework indicators (PAF) have included data on the ethnicity of children in need;
 the first data on the ethnicity of looked-after children will be published in autumn 2001 and will provide estimates of the extent to which children from different ethnic origins receive social services;
 three new PAF indicators relating to adult services will be published in autumn 2001;
 the national training strategy for England (published by the Training Organisation for the Personal Social Services) outlines action to improve the collection and use of equal opportunities data about the social care workforce and to ensure that ethnic minorities are adequately represented at all levels;
 the Association of Directors of Social Services, REU, SSI, Improvement and Development Agency and CRE have been working together to support ethnic minority managers through the ranks.

webTitle: BBC delays freelance pay says NUJ

fields.headline: BBC to delay freelance pay says NUJ
fields.trailText:
9.30am: The NUJ claims the BBC is planning to change to its payment processes to delay paying freelances, reports Jessica Hodgson.
Feb 21: BBC staff to work to rule
fields.body:
The BBC plans to introduce changes to its staff payment processes, which could allow it to delay paying freelances in order to save money, according the National Union of Journalists.

The NUJ has accused the BBC of planning to introduce a system it says will polarise freelance employees in a two-tier system.

Freelance payments to staff are currently made on a self-billing basis, with payments going directly into staff's bank accounts at the end of the payment month.

But under new plans, according to the NUJ, freelance production staff will have to invoice the BBC for payment, giving the BBC leave to wait up to 60 days before paying them.

Meanwhile, "talent" - front-of-camera actors, sports stars and presenters - and other key production personnel will have clauses built in to their contracts to ensure they are paid monthly.

Paul McLaughlin, the NUJ's broadcast organiser, said the union had written to the BBC advising it of the changes, which will go through at the next financial year in April.

Because of the contract-based nature of much of the work in the BBC, the changes could affect up to 8,000 staff, according to Mr McLaughlin.

He said the changes would be made across several departments.

The NUJ has also written to broadcast union Bectu and the actor's union Equity to inform them of the changes.

Mr McLaughlin said: "Apparently the rationale is to withhold money from freelances for as long as possible to save money.

"This is akin to the kind of attitudes demonstrated by the more despicable ends of the media and broadcast organisations.

"We would be astonished if, in an effort to drive down costs, the BBC would be prepared to do this," he said.

The BBC was not available to comment on the plans.

webTitle: Director blames Crowe-Ryan affair for film's failure

fields.headline: Director blames Crowe-Ryan affair for film's failure
fields.trailText: Director Taylor Hackford accuses the much-publicised affair between Proof of Life stars Russell Crowe and Meg Ryan of causing the film's failure in the US
fields.body:
In London to attend the premiere of their hostage thriller Proof of Life, star Russell Crowe and director Taylor Hackford found themselves at odds over the reasons behind the film's box-office failure in the US.

Proof of Life features Crowe as a hostage negotiator and Meg Ryan as the wife of a captured American engineer. But the film's shoot was dogged by reports of the two actors' off-screen affair which, critics claim, led to Ryan's split from husband Dennis Quaid. fields.headline: BBC confirms freelance pay overhaul
fields.trailText:
12.15pm: The BBC has admitted plans to change its freelance payments system, writes Jessica Hodgson
Feb 22: NUJ accuses BBC
Feb 21: BBC staff to work to rule
Feb 21: BBC staff lambast Dyke
fields.body:
The BBC has admitted it is planning to change its freelance payments system as part of the so-called Apollo finance overhaul.

But a spokesman denied the move was driven by a desire to save money, as the National Union of Journalists has claimed.

"As part of the Apollo system, we are working on plans to move to a system that is more consistent," the spokesman told MediaGuardian.co.uk.

"In the past, freelance payments have been made at different times.

"We want to change it so everyone gets paid at the same time."

He said the system would be phased in "gradually, in order to avoid problems".

However, he was unable to guarantee all freelances would receive payment within a month of submitting their invoices.

Yesterday, the NUJ claimed the BBC was introducing the changes to save money and argued up to 8,000 freelance workers could be out of pocket.

The NUJ's objections follow a separate row over BBC expenses.

NUJ members at the BBC are now on work to rule after changes in the expenses policy which include a £6 cap on lunch costs.

fields.headline: Games without frontiers
fields.standfirst: With sparks flying again between Moscow and Washington, Simon Tisdall asks is this Cold War II?
fields.trailText: With sparks currently flying again between Moscow and Washington, Simon Tisdall asks is this Cold War II?
fields.body:
A spy working for Russia is discovered in the heart of the FBI; tactical nuclear weapons are secretly deployed along the frontiers of Europe; an American president plans a massive new strategic missile system; the Kremlin tests allied defences with air patrols over the north Atlantic and the Sea of Japan.

Between Washington and Moscow, angry rhetoric and accusations fly back and forth. Sound familiar? For those whose memories stretch back to 1989 and before, it certainly does.

During the cold war between the US and the Soviet Union, such threatening events were considered the norm. But alarmingly, all the episodes sketched out above have occurred in the past few months, raising the question: are we on the brink of a second cold war?

The idea is not as far fetched as it might seem. Although the underlying ideological confrontation between communism and capitalism is absent this time around, age old rivalries to do with power, influence, security and money remain.

And after a period of détente and relative amity between Russia's Boris Yeltsin and America's Bill Clinton, new faces at the top - Vladimir Putin and George Bush - have brought with them a renewal of old fears and distrust.

Only this week, Condoleezza Rice, the US national security adviser, was quoted as saying: "I sincerely believe that Russia constitutes a threat for the west in general and our European allies in particular."

Donald Rumsfeld, the US defence secretary, recently accused Russia of exacerbating the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction - America's biggest security concern.

"Let's be very honest about what Russia is doing," Rumsfeld said. "Russia is an active proliferator. They are part of the problem. They are selling and assisting countries like Iran and North Korea and India and other countries with these technologies which are threatening other people including the United States and western Europe and countries in the Middle East."

As if in turn, Putin attacked the US this week over its air raids on Iraq which Russia deems illegal. Bush has hardly been more emollient. He has identified Russia as a potential strategic rival rather than a partner and has already moved to halt further US aid intended to promote market reforms.

Although he and Putin have talked by phone, he has not responded to Russian overtures for an early summit meeting. And, to the Kremlin's annoyance, he has refused to intervene in the case of Pavel Borodin, a senior Yeltsin era official who is in detention in New York in connection with Swiss fraud charges. From where Putin is sitting, the trend looks worrying.

America's proposed National Missile Defence system, also known as "son of Star Wars" could potentially blunt Russia's ability to defend itself by countering at least part of its offensive nuclear arsenal.

The intention of Nato to expand into eastern areas, including the Baltic republics, is strategically undesirable. The expansion of the EU into central and eastern Europe presents a parallel economic and cultural challenge.

The recent Anglo-American raids on Iraq are highly objectionable in Russian eyes, another example of American military adventurism of the very kind that they so fiercely opposed in Yugoslavia in 1999.

More broadly, they see such action as evidence that the US considers itself alarmingly free to ignore the UN and international law when it suits its purposes. When it comes to weapons proliferation, the Kremlin believes persuasion and dialogue is the best way forward, hence Putin's recent contacts with north Korea and his invitation to Iran's president to visit Moscow this spring.

It believes the US, in contrast, is set on confrontation with such so-called "rogue states" in order to justify its overweening superpower ambitions.

On top of all this, Moscow resents the way the big American oil companies have moved into the formerly Soviet-controlled Caspian region, rivalling its own efforts to exploit the area's oil and gas wealth.

From where Bush is sitting, Russia looks like a negative force opposing US interests, not as powerful as it once was but still dangerous.

Bush and his advisers genuinely believe they need a ballistic missile defence against rogue states and see Russia's opposition as unnecessarily obstructive. Putin's efforts to woo Iran and north Korea and his indirect support for Iraq are viewed at best as political opportunism and, at worst, as providing succour to the enemy.

Russia's continued espionage against US targets, its reported but unconfirmed deployment of tactical nuclear missiles in the Baltic enclave of Kaliningrad, its resumption of cold war-era air patrols, its discussions with China about a friendship treaty and, for example, Putin's recent visit to Cuba, are all seen in the same light in Washington: as an unwelcome attempt by the new Kremlin boss to reassert Russian standing in the world in opposition to America.

Washington had become accustomed to regarding Russia as a busted flush. Now it is reluctantly beginning to realise that, despite all its economic and social problems, it still has the ability to thwart or at least complicate US ambitions and security concerns.

Its disapproval of Putin's authoritarian tendencies at home, for example in his war in Chechnya and his attempts to muzzle the free media, has added to the growing gulf between the two sides.

The US also suspects Putin of seeking to reclaim Russian leadership in the former Soviet republics of central Asia and Ukraine, where economic woes and political corruption have tarnished the dream of independence.

One classic cold war manoeuvre, for example, is Putin's current attempt to woo European opinion by offering alternatives to the US missile defence plans and thereby sowing discord and dividing Nato.

Germany, closer to Russia than most, has proved to be particularly susceptible to his blandishments. France, for reasons more to do with its visceral anti-Americanism than rational calculation, is happy to see Russia opposing the domineering "Anglo-Saxons". Putin has been assiduous in courting Tony Blair.

That these various mutual suspicions and opposed ambitions will soon translate into a big new east-west confrontation remains unlikely, given Russia's relative weakness compared with the days of Brezhnev and even Gorbachev. But Bush and Putin both need to tread more carefully and show a bit more respect. Given the current levels of mutual distrust and the speed at which US-Russian relations are deteriorating, the potential for miscalculation is enormous.

fields.headline: January text messaging breaks records
fields.trailText: 9.30am: A record-breaking 929m text messages were sent in Britain last month, according to the Mobile Data Association, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
A record-breaking 929m text messages were sent in Britain last month, according to official number-crunching from the Mobile Data Association.

And now the MDA says February will be a landmark month, when a staggering 1bn text messages will be sent across UK mobile phone networks.

Valentine's Day has already been confirmed as the busiest day in February - between 22m and 25m messages were exchanged between phones.

Despite the hype around Valentine's text messages, it appears the British are conforming to their image as a reserved nation - well-wishing proved much more popular than romantic gestures.

The busiest day of the year was not February 14 but January 1, when more than 30m messages were tapped out.

The MDA, which collects figures from the four mobile networks, has now revised its estimates because of the evident boom in text messaging.

It originally said the 1bn barrier would be broken in the summer but it now expects this to happen four months earlier.

"Text messaging is a new language and a new way of communicating in a discreet way.

"It's not just for consumers - messaging has now become a business habit," said Mike Short, chairman of the MDA.

Mobile phone users also went text-message crazy over the festive season, with more than 750m messages sent in December.

Text messaging has experienced exponential growth in the past year.

Tellingly, the figures from January are almost three times those recorded 12 months ago.

While it has become something of a phenomenon in the UK, it has also permeated other markets.

The UK now represents about 8% of the total global text message industry, which is expected to witness more than 200bn messages worldwide this year.

And the method of communication has helped save lives.

Last week a British tourist was rescused from a sea storm off the coast of Thailand after she contacted her boyfriend in Britain.

She made contact with the Falmouth Coast Guard, who got in touch with their counterparts in the Pacific.

fields.headline: Reed Elsevier's profits dip
fields.trailText: 9.45am:Anglo-Dutch publishing group Reed Elsevier has reported a slip in profits, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Anglo-Dutch publishing group Reed Elsevier has reported a slip in profits, a day after the government referred its latest acquisition to competition watchdogs.

Reed's £3bn purchase of US rival Harcourt General in October last year increased access to the lucrative American educational publishing market.

But an internet investment programme also saddled the group with massive restructuring costs.

As a result, adjusted pre-tax profits for last year fell from £710m in 1999 to £690m.

Although analysts gave a broad thumbs up to the Harcourt acquisition, Reed's shares have weakened following the government's decision to refer the move to the Competition Commission.

Reed argues the Harcourt deal gives the company just 15% of the science, technical and medical publishing market in the UK and is not a threat to competition.

If the Harcourt deal receives watchdog clearance, the educational publishing market will provide 15% of Reed's earnings, which last year rose by 9% to £3.3bn.

Reed also publishes magazines and books in the science, medical, legal and business sectors.

Crispin Davis, chief executive of Reed Elsevier, brushed off news of the government enquiry and predicted the group would reach its ambitious growth targets.

"2001 should see Reed Elsevier move very significantly towards our stated goal of above market revenue growth and double-digit earnings growth in 2002 and beyond," said Mr Davis.

Reed remains a media sector favourite because of its status as a "defensive" stock.

It is less exposed to downturns in advertising growth and core markets such as education do not suffer as much during an economic slump.

Shares in Reed, listed as Reed International in the UK, rose 1.6% to 645p in early trading.

fields.headline: Pamplona protest: Spanish star condemns bull running
fields.trailText: The Hollywood actor Penelope Cruz has provoked indignation back home in Spain by lending her name to a call by US animal rights activists for a ban on the bull runs in Pamplona.
fields.body:
The Hollywood actor Penelope Cruz has provoked indignation back home in Spain by lending her name to a call by US animal rights activists for a ban on the bull runs in Pamplona.

A letter from Cruz denouncing the cruelty of the bull run has made her one of only a handful of prominent Spaniards prepared to challenge the country's passion for bullfighting.

It has caused outrage in Pamplona, where the bull runs held during the San Fermin festival in July are a tourism money-spinner as well as a revered tradition.

"Most tourists are horrified when they realise that the bulls that run in the mornings are tortured and killed in the bull-ring later in the day," the actor claimed in a letter supporting People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals.

"Please tell me when this bloody event, which should have been consigned to history ages ago, will come to an end," she asked city authorities.

Her plea has led to an angry exchange of letters with the mayoress of Pamplona, Yolanda Barcina, who urged Cruz to worry about "more important things".

"Your participation in last year's Oscars would, for example, have been a good moment for denouncing the use of the death penalty in the US," she said.

Ms Barcina claimed Cruz was selling out her own culture in order to please her friends in Hollywood.

"It is difficult to understand why you allow your name and your professional prestige to be used in order to publicly condemn our culture, in which bulls play a significant part," she said.

"The bull run is an event when bull and man face one another as equals in a race in which speed and skill are vital," she added.

fields.headline: OK! ex-staffer clinches book deal
fields.trailText: 9am: Former OK! writer Claudia Patterson is to write a book satirising the world of celebrity journalism, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Richard Desmond is bracing himself for revelations about life in the world of celebrity magazines as a former staff member is to publish a book based on her experiences at OK!

Former OK! writer Claudia Pattison has signed a six-figure deal with Macmillan to publish Wow! - an expose of the world of celebrity journalism.

Luigi Bonomi, Ms Pattison's agent, said the book was "great fun, very funny and very witty".

It will send up the world of celebrity journalism as practised at OK! and its rival Hello!.

In particular, the book plans to poke fun at the magazines' tradition of inviting readers inside the stars' "beautiful" homes.

And it is understood celebrity weddings - such as the gaudy nuptials of David and Victoria Beckham - will be satirised.

OK!'s editor Martin Townsend was unavailable for comment and staff at the magazine were unwilling to discuss the book.

fields.headline: Britannic reveals plans for new brand
fields.trailText:
9am: Britannic Money is to offer holidays through its website and has plans for an online share-dealing product, reports Julia Day.
Feb 21: Britannic to sponsor C4's Frasier
fields.body:
Britannic Money is to offer holidays and leisure activities through links on its website and is preparing to launch an online share-dealing product.

The mortgage supply arm of Britannic Assurance is also launching its new brand name this Friday with a multi-million-pound TV, press and poster advertising campaign.

To coincide with its £1m sponsorship of Channel 4 sitcom Frasier - which begins on Friday - a TV ad campaign will launch on the same day.

Created by ad agency Camp Chipperfield Hill Murray, the TV executions have the strapline: "Turn your money in to Britannic Money".

The campaign will run for a month in the first instance.

Naked Communications has provided media strategy and Optimedia has handled the media buying.

A poster and press campaign support the television ads.

In addition, the website has just gone live.

Britannic Money is the new name of First Active Financial, which Britannic Assurance acquired last year.

The company's main product is a current-account mortgage.

But the website will offer other products in association with online partners, according to Britannic Money head of marketing Matt Smith.

"Internet customers will be able to access other products, where we think our brand is right for a tie-up.

"Ee won't be offering discounted sports shoes but we will offer a discount club where members can buy holidays or leisure products," said Mr Smith.

The company will also unveil an online share-dealing product in the near future.

"Our flexible mortgage underpins everything but we want to offer the tool for an holistic approach to finances.

"We can be a one-stop shop if you want us to be," said Smith.

webTitle: Profile of the Daily Mail's editor

fields.headline: Paul Dacre: the most dangerous man in Britain?
fields.standfirst:
Paul Dacre is the Daily Mail's low-profile editor. To some - including many in government - he is a malign force, using his paper to hound minorities and other vulnerable targets, and savage liberalism in any form. To others he is the most gifted journalist of his generation, a moral man with his finger on the pulse of Middle England. Andy Beckett went in search of the truth

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Is the Daily Mail editor a malign force or the most gifted journalist of his generation? Andy Beckett investigates.
fields.body:
There is one particular story that former staff of the Daily Mail like to tell about the politics, in the broadest sense, of their old paper. A while ago, the newsdesk there noticed a report from a local press agency. A young baby had died from being fed adult food. The Mail immediately got excited: it could interview the grieving parents, make the tragedy the basis for a campaign, and warn the nation of a previously unsuspected danger.

The couple were contacted, and offered £250 for an interview. They agreed, and talked eloquently and at length. A double-page spread - the Mail's traditional mark of a significant article - was put aside in the paper. For the photograph, the parents, who were not well off, were encouraged to look smart: the husband in a suit, his wife in a dress, both of them holding hands.

The morning the feature appeared, it was judged a success at the Mail. The article was by turns sensitive, alarming and full of useful advice. Paul Dacre, the editor then and now, approved - and from him all official sentiments flowed. But then, at lunchtime, Dacre's tall, slightly stooping figure was spotted beneath one of the television monitors hanging from the low ceiling of the open-plan office. Everybody nearby, as it was usually in their interests to, stopped work and looked and listened.

Dacre was watching the one o'clock news with his narrow eyes: on it were the bereaved couple, with messier hair than before, wearing tracksuits and trainers, smoking: not the Mail's sort of people at all. The editor, who is 52, spotlessly shirtsleeved, brisk in his diction, with hair like a cerebral Tory minister, was heard to growl. Then he spoke: "These people couldn't bring up a fucking hamster!"

Real life tends to disappoint the Daily Mail. That, however, has never undermined this thick, grey tombstone of a tabloid. In more than a century of publication, with a certainty and thoroughness perhaps unique among newspapers, the Mail has never stopped trying to tidy the world to its preferred patterns. As the globe has grown more baffling and volatile and threatening - and in Britain the Mail has been instrumental in creating this impression - so the paper's solutions have grown clearer and more consistent. In 1940, it sold an average of about 1,400,000 copies a day ; in 1970, about 1,900,000; in 2000, approaching 2,400,000.

These days the Daily Express, the Mail's historic rival, struggles to sell a million; and these remaining readers have been so aggressively courted by the Mail of late that, this week, the Express has begun publicly attacking the paper for "lies" and "humbug". The Mail is retaliating - "Concern As Express Sales Go Into Freefall" - in inimitable fashion. If recent circulation trends continue, it will become Britain's favourite newspaper at some point be tween 2005 and 2010.

It is already probably the most powerful. It is a paper of the middle class, in particular the suburban and southern varieties. As these people have grown more numerous and politically potent, it has flattered their aspirations and crystallised their fears, helped form their values and fanned their discontents.

The intricacy of this to-and-fro can be gauged by the closeness of Mail readers to the newspaper's ideal: they are more likely to be married than the general population; more likely to own property; to have two or more cars; to vote Conservative. Yet only half of them do so habitually. The rest form the largest concentration of "swing voters", assumed to decide modern general elections, who can be reached through a single newspaper.

However, to a slightly different sort of person - British liberals, leftwingers, anyone it has ever persecuted - the paper is not affirming but an affront. "I stopped taking the Mail at the start of this year because it was bad for me," says one Labour MP who is attacked almost weekly. Mail reporters have repeatedly telephoned this politician's children. The MP has written to the paper with complaints and factual corrections, which "they never publish". One received this written response from a senior executive: "You are a hypocrite." When a complaint is posted now, "My stomach turns to water at what they are going to do to me for retaliating."

In recent months, the Mail's bêtes noires, to use a favourite phrase of Mail executives, have included the ailing Princess Margaret ("paying for her pursuit of pleasure"), the BBC's new political editor Andrew Marr ("Millbank Man"), and a young Iraqi chef who "has tried to sneak into Britain 20 times". The paper batters such targets with front pages and features, columnists and diarists, all following the same line for days at a time. "It is a propaganda machine not a newspaper," says a government minister. She, like almost all the politicians prepared to talk about the Mail, asked to remain anonymous.

In a sense, the very strength of such reactions only feeds the tabloid's perceived importance. The rest of the media, for one thing, often follows whichever newspaper has the most controversial stories. And the Mail's large middle-class readership makes it particularly closely read by broadcasters, who want to attract that audience. Coincidentally but perhaps appropriately, Dacre's brother Nigel is head of ITN's ITV news.

The Mail often starts national debates; even more often, it sets their parameters. For example, the receiving of asylum-seekers, whose hooded, dehumanised profiles have crowded the paper's pages remorselessly in recent years, now appears to most Britons as a problem and a danger, not an opportunity or a national duty.

Last September's protests against petrol taxes, which had been revved up by Mail editorials for months, became a people's crusade and not special pleading by the polluting classes. As for Europe, the family, equal rights for gay people, the rise of crime or otherwise - each of these complex issues has been successfully simplified by the paper into a question of identity or morality, where the Mail is famously comfortable, rather than economics or history or sociology, where its rightwing certainties would come up against awkward facts. Modern British politics, it often seems, has been remade in the Mail's image.

This has made some of the government's ambitions, for the time being at least, impossible to achieve. "The things we've lost on," says a minister, "such as [the repeal of the anti-gay] Clause 28, are because of the climate they've created." Recently, with an election expected, the paper's general hostility has grown close to hysterical. Earlier this month, one of its columnists, Simon Heffer, predicted that continued Labour rule would lead to 14m illegal immigrants in Britain, almost half the country's military personnel being disabled people, and "girls of nine" receiving "the morning-after pill from school dinner ladies". One of Blair's closest advisors concludes: "The Mail have gone into kill mode."

Other Labour politicians, however, take a rather different view of the paper. "It is extremely well-written and attractively presented," said David Blunkett, the secretary of state for education, at the 1998 party conference. The same year, when Dacre's predecessor Sir David English died, his memorial service was attended by, among others, Tony Blair, William Hague and Margaret Thatcher. In 1999, when the Mail's proprietor Viscount Rothermere also died, the prime minister read a lesson at the service of thanksgiving.

That autumn, relations appeared to cool. Blair famously attacked "the forces of conservatism". Labour began publishing a Daily Mail Monitor, to counter the newspaper's "myths" about its policies. But the editor of the Monitor, the MP Gerald Kaufman, now says that his publication is "quiescent". Has the government's view of the Mail changed? With slow emphasis, he says: "The Daily Mail is an extraordinarily able and well-conducted paper."

Heffer has been appointed to a Home Office panel reviewing jail sentencing. Last year, perhaps most revealingly of all, a personal memo written by the prime minister was leaked to the press. Under the heading "Touchstone Issues", Blair said his government should please "gut British instinct" by being "tough" on teenage criminals and asylum seekers, respecting the family more, and better understanding people such as the imprisoned Norfolk farmer Tony Martin who defended their property by force. All these points had been specifically raised, in a similar order, in a Mail editorial.

The Conservative party also appears at times to be the paper's junior partner. A grinning John Major attended its 21st birthday as "a compact newspaper" (it is not, it insists, a tabloid); three years later, the Mail backed John Redwood's attempt to topple him. Many of William Hague's initiatives as Tory leader - his promises to cut petrol duty, to detain all asylum seekers, to look more kindly on the defence of property with firearms - have also come straight, it seems, from the paper's editorials; yet one of these recently described the opposition as "a stumbling, incoherent shambles ... that has profound implications for the health of our democracy."

In such grand, impatient statements there increasingly lurks a sense of the Mail as a sort of political party, a replacement for the opposition, even a prototype government-in-waiting. "I was talking to Dacre at a party," says a senior government official, "and he said, 'You've got a big majority. The other papers are on your side. You've had it easy for too long. We're going to see you off.' And I thought, 'If you want to be prime minister, then run.' "

Since Dacre became editor in 1992, the same year that the Tories began to disintegrate, "Dacre has taken David English's middle-class siege mentality and turned it into a daily polemic," says a longtime observer of the Mail's moods. Is the paper actually malicious? And where does the anger come from?

Kensington High Street, in smartest west London, is not the first place you would probably imagine such discontent being perfected. The newspaper's offices are above the biggest local temple to Blair-era prosperity, an upmarket department store called Barker's. They have a black marble entrance, and a gold clock, and corporate lettering of great width and confidence. A long escalator ascends, smoothly and slowly, to a glass-roofed atrium six storeys high.

There are indoor trees and balconies, see-through lifts and a spiral staircase, a whole sealed kingdom of Mail-related enterprise: the Daily Mail and General Trust, its parent company, also owns the Mail on Sunday, the free commuter paper Metro, the London Evening Standard, Teletext, several websites, radio stations here and abroad, local newspapers, financial services providers, and an organiser of trade fairs. Were it not for the slightly jittery-looking men in shirtsleeves, you might forget you were at a tabloid newspaper.

Dacre joined in 1980. He was a middle-class boy from the north London suburbs who had been to University College School, a liberal private school in Hampstead, on a scholarship. His father, Peter Dacre, was a successful journalist on the Sunday Express; the family used to analyse the Sunday papers over lunch. When Dacre junior went to Leeds University in 1967, he immediately got involved in the student newspaper. Within five weeks, he was a features editor, devising double-page spreads of a heavy-type directness that any Mail reader would recognise.

Their politics, however, might come as a shock: gay people and drug takers were sympathetically portrayed, "welfare state misfits" were described as victims, and Enoch Powell's warnings about immigration were scorned. Dacre was leftwing, and remained so until the late 70s, when the Daily Express, the first national newspaper he worked for, sent him to America.

The apparent vigour and prosperity of the people he met there, and their seeming commitment to the family (Dacre had married quite young), affected him strongly. Suddenly Britain looked tribal and declining, a socialist cul-de-sac. When he came back to London in 1981, having been hired by the Mail, Dacre was a fierce free-marketeer and social conservative, at least as Thatcherite as the new Tory government. And this he has remained, it seems, ever since.

As well as being editor of the Mail, he is editor-in-chief of its major sister papers. His superiors English and Rothermere have both died. His new proprietor, the current Lord Rothermere, is relatively young and inexperienced. Dacre's opinions, according to everyone I spoke to, dominate the Mail's worldview - and are becoming more definite. "He deals with everything at the level of emotion," says someone who knows him well. "He thinks politics is basically common sense. He can't understand why people would disagree with him."

Dacre's instincts are steered by a simple morality. There are good people and bad people in the world. The good people are self-reliant, traditional in their beliefs, suspicious of officialdom, and want to better themselves. They generally work in the private sector. They are middle class, or would like to be. They are conservatives with a small 'c'.

This can mean anyone from the murdered black teenager Stephen Lawrence and his parents, for whom the Mail has very self-consciously campaigned, to the more morally austere Labour ministers. The paper currently approves of Blunkett, Paul Boateng, Jack Straw in his more severe moments, and occasionally still, Blair himself ("pretty impressive" when he visits Kensington, according to a Mail executive). There remains a clean-cut, illiberal side to New Labour that appeals to the paper, and vice versa.

Like the government, the Mail sees good people threatened by bad. By criminals, by people pushing dangerous ideas, by people setting a poor example, whether living off benefits on a council estate or being over-indulgent and rich. The job of the paper is to describe this ceaseless battle, while drawing the lessons from it which will enable the good people - assumed to be the majority of the British population - to win.

Now, Dacre himself does not live precisely like his idealised subjects and readers in Middle England. Last year, he earned £727,000. He has a chauffeur. Until quite recently, he lived part of the time in the most deliciously secluded street in Islington, the north London borough synonymous in his newspaper with decadent metropolitan liberalism.

But this prosperity should not be mistaken for a hypocritical flashiness. Dacre is shy outside the office: he does not get photographed much at parties, he is not close friends with politicians, he regards editors who enjoy being public figures as unwise and uncommitted. He would rather be watching which papers people are reading on the train, or in the pub when he risks a quiet drink after work, some time after 10pm.

Then he is driven home, either to a London flat or to his Sussex village and his wife, Kathleen, who teaches drama, and their two sons, and their neighbours whose "sensible opinions" he values, to receive the first edition of every national newspaper at midnight and call his subordinates with fresh orders.

Dacre is back in at 9am. By 11am, his next wave of views about the issues of the day is forming. There is a meeting in his office for his lieutenants, carefully choreographed: him sitting at his large dark desk, which stands confidently near the middle of the room, leaning back in his high black leather chair, his feet often up on the desktop; the news editor, Dacre's main intermediary, in a lone chair facing him; the other executives on two sofas in an L-shape, an eternity of carpet away. The room, with its cream panelling and antiques, its stripes on the sofa covers and books about the second world war, could be a parody of a Mail reader's decor. But everything at this newspaper is done completely in earnest.

The editor may be aroused by an obscure news item, a vague sense of outrage, a hunch about how to make political waves. Within a few seconds, his voice will rise from low and slightly throaty to a bellow, suggesting headlines, lines of attack, how the articles should be written and illustrated, whether a campaign should be launched. He will hammer the air with his hands. He will wave his long arms. He will swear and summon up reporters. And the news editor, in his delicate armchair, will need to know how often the Mail has done this story before.

Once Dacre's wishes have been disseminated - or, often, in advance of that - the journalists will know what is required. "You kind of know what the obsessions are," says one who recently left the paper. "And you very much know you've got to do a story in a specific way." This polemic-driven approach can have unintended consequences: "Dacre will express some random opinion, and forget about it," says another ex-reporter. "It will dominate the paper for days."

Out in the untidy world which its journalists have to probe, even the facts the Mail seeks are closely steered by its beliefs. "One of the first things the news editor will ask you is, 'What kind of house have they got?', " says someone who worked closely with him until recently. And back in the office, as afternoon turns into evening, such facts as have been gathered that day undergo a further process of refinement. A politician would call it "spin". Dacre calls it "orchestration".

For two or three hours, a second daily melodrama unfolds: this time not in his office, but out in the open-plan, where all the staff can see. The editor emerges from his corridor. He strides over to where the first rough pages of the newspaper have been arranged for him. Then he begins to change things. Unsuitable headlines are dismissed. Introductions to pieces are transformed. Pages are reshuffled, redesigned, torn up and abandoned.

Much of this happens on other newspapers, of course; but not with the Mail's intensity. Dacre and his lieutenants proudly describe their evenings as "pure adrenaline", "crashing through". Sometimes, the message of the day is so closely controlled that almost exactly the same introductory sentence will appear in different articles.

Not all the paper is overt politics, of course. But the softer daily stories about animals, the self-improvement features, the straight-faced serialisations of apocalyptic new age speculations - these also emphasise, in a more gentle fashion, the importance of aspiration and domesticity, the need to distrust official explanations, the dangerousness of the world outside your neat home.

This has always been the Mail's recipe. On May 4 1896, its first front page included "Rioting On The Continent", "Reading Murders: Sensational Letters Of Confession", and "Woman's Realm: Two Columns Of Special Interest For The Home". From the start, too, the paper had a sense of its own importance. Within two years, it was claiming "the largest circulation in the world" and had embarked on a campaign against the incompetent conduct of the Boer war. This contempt for bureaucrats and politicians quickly swelled into a desire for more formal political status. Lord Northcliffe, the Mail's founder, insisted on a seat at the Versailles peace conference in 1918 (he was refused); in 1929, the Mail and Express set up their own, fleetingly successful, Empire Free Trade party to fight by-elections.

But the Mail was not really a political party. In its dictatorial culture, strange notions could take root without consideration of their reception in the outside world. From about 1930, when the paper was in the middle of a long flirtation with fascism, until the early 70s, its circulation stagnated or fell. Social change in general and the 60s in particular proved hard for the Mail to swallow. The Mail has been hostile about that decade ever since.

By 1970, a merger with the Express was being negotiated. It took the collapse of these talks, a new editor (English), proprietor (Rothermere), and a recommendation from the management consultants McKinseys to relaunch as an imitation of semi-respectable, women-orientated American tabloids such as Newsday and the New York Post, to create the version of the Mail that has thrived since.

You could see its Christmas party as its annual conference. Last year, like every year, it was at Claridge's in Mayfair in central London. The hotel's entire ground floor had been hired: ballrooms, lounges, long shiny-floored corridors. It was as if messy modern Britain had never existed, as if a Mail lifestyle feature had been brought to life.

The Mail employees arrived with their wives and husbands. No one else appeared to have been invited. They straightened their dresses and ties, and took deep breaths by the cloakrooms. Then they walked, very erect, towards the party. In the first room, an enormous slab of ice stood under the hot lights. On it had been carved the Daily Mail logo and those of the company's other main titles, and in front of it stood Paul Dacre.

He looked quietly satisfied. A few senior staff exchanged careful smiles and shoulder pats with their editor. Yet most of the staff kept a safe distance, in small groups, drinking the champagne. Everyone seemed happy but guarded, like junior officers at a regimental drinks party. It was all over by 9.30pm - there was another paper to produce the next day - but a long line of company cars with drivers was waiting outside in the cold.

If journalists at the Mail play by its rules, from wearing skirts and not eating at their desks (if they are women) to always taking off their jacket in the office (if they are men) to just working very hard, they are very generously rewarded. Staff and ex-staff, in turn, are often loyal.

Like Mail readers, plenty of them turn out not to share the paper's politics, but they buy into its broader culture. They are proud of its thoroughness and determination and the resources it grants reporters - its famous "professionalism". More quietly, they may relish its cruelty and moralism. Enjoying other people's misfortunes is, after all, the great unspoken motivation for producing and consuming journalism.

The trouble comes when the sheer rigidity of the Mail, the repetitiveness, the regular nastiness needed to keep the paper's world in place, starts to grate or feel out of date. Staff who do not fit the paper's preferences are brutally treated, even by the standards of this industry. But reporters have been leaving in slightly worrying numbers in recent years, it is felt in Kensington. There is a faint but growing anxiety that the tabloid's best-known writers, such as Lynda Lee-Potter, Nigel Dempster and Ann Leslie are approaching retirement age. Young stars are proving harder to bring on than at other papers.

The readers, however, have yet to tire of the Mail's old-fashioned recipe - its single thick section, its fusty typefaces - or to react against its politics as they did in the 30s. Yet you do wonder whether these millions of people, who are mostly sharing in the Blair boom, will continue to welcome the bleak view of Britain the paper puts out. And if many of them, as seems likely, vote Labour again at the general election, will Dacre still be able to claim perfect empathy?

There is much talk at the paper now about being less "aggressive", "lightening up", avoiding "self-parody". Dacre wants single mothers and ethnic minorities to be criticised less, as long as they behave respectably in his eyes; a call for the decriminalisation of drugs is a possibility. There is even a suggestion that the Mail and its leftwing enemies can become allies, over the social breakdowns caused by the global free market.

But such philosophical questions are not dwelled on. At headquarters, whoever is defending what the Mail is currently doing usually reaches for the shield of sales figures before too long. As long as circulation is moving like the up escalator, inexorably and endlessly in the atrium below, then screaming at staff and bullying the subjects of articles on their doorsteps at dawn and making every complex real-world event into a simple cautionary tale is felt, officially, to be justified.

In the end, the Daily Mail tries to have it all ways. It justifies itself by temporary commercial success one minute, by eternal moral values the next. It says it admires aspiration, but loathes those who get above themselves. It idealises the home, but recognises no one's privacy. It wants law and order, but not speed cameras. It wants unfettered capitalism, but not excessive profits. It calls itself a female paper, but reserves its worst venom for prominent women. It calls itself the straightforward voice of Middle England - and seeks to impose that imagined community's values on everyone else - but its proprietors are metropolitan aristocrats, controlling its parent company by arcane share arrangements.

It is only a paper. The vast majority of Britons never even glance at it. And the hold it does have will loosen: no newspaper dominates for ever. The Mail's hold on the government, some Labour politicians say, is already slackening: less nervy attention is paid to every attack; the exclusive briefings are no longer quite so numerous; there is a new willingness to confront the paper.

Last November, it filled its pages with retired generals to condemn the government's "plans" for a "Euro army". The government, says one of Labour's main tacticians, "took a very particular strategic decision to use the row to get our facts out". Blair said the Mail was exaggerating. Opinion polls agreed with him.

"I think it has occurred to everyone from the top down," says a minister, "that some people are so relentlessly opposed that they are the enemy. However big your tent is, you can't fit them in." Perhaps New Labour's infatuation with the Mail was just that: an inexperienced and not very ideological government, in its first year or two in office, being over-impressed by a zealous and disciplined political subculture. But nowadays,"The fact that the Mail's become less keen on Blair," says a former advisor, "may be a useful thing to show Labour voters and members."

Afterwards, though, contact will need to be maintained with the millions of Mail readers. And with the Conservatives most likely marooned in opposition, the paper may be steaming into less familiar ideological waters. Mail insiders now refer to its previous decades of strict loyalty to the Tories as "slavish sycophancy".

Last month, as President George W Bush was assembling his government of christian moralists and hard capitalists, Paul Dacre was back in his favourite country. He returned, by all accounts, enthused.

A while ago, the newsdesk there noticed a report from a local press agency. A young baby had died from being fed adult food. The Mail immediately got excited: it could interview the grieving parents, make the tragedy the basis for a campaign, and warn the nation of a previously unsuspected danger. The couple were contacted, and offered £250 for an interview. They agreed, and talked eloquently and at length. A double-page spread - the Mail's traditional mark of a significant article - was put aside in the paper. For the photograph, the parents, who were not well off, were encouraged to look smart: the husband in a suit, his wife in a dress, both of them holding hands. The morning the feature appeared, it was judged a success at the Mail. The article was by turns sensitive, alarming and full of useful advice. Paul Dacre, the editor then and now, approved - and from him all official sentiments flowed. But then, at lunchtime, Dacre's tall, slightly stooping figure was spotted beneath one of the television monitors hanging from the low ceiling of the open-plan office. Everybody nearby, as it was usually in their interests to, stopped work and looked and listened. Dacre was watching the one o'clock news with his narrow eyes: on it were the bereaved couple, with messier hair than before, wearing tracksuits and trainers, smoking: not the Mail's sort of people at all. The editor, who is 52, spotlessly shirtsleeved, brisk in his diction, with hair like a cerebral Tory minister, was heard to growl. Then he spoke: "These people couldn't bring up a fucking hamster!" Real life tends to disappoint the Daily Mail. That, however, has never undermined this thick, grey tombstone of a tabloid. In more than a century of publication, with a certainty and thoroughness perhaps unique among newspapers, the Mail has never stopped trying to tidy the world to its preferred patterns. As the globe has grown more baffling and volatile and threatening - and in Britain the Mail has been instrumental in creating this impression - so the paper's solutions have grown clearer and more consistent. In 1940, it sold an average of about 1,400,000 copies a day ; in 1970, about 1,900,000; in 2000, approaching 2,400,000. These days the Daily Express, the Mail's historic rival, struggles to sell a million; and these remaining readers have been so aggressively courted by the Mail of late that, this week, the Express has begun publicly attacking the paper for "lies" and "humbug". The Mail is retaliating - "Concern As Express Sales Go Into Freefall" - in inimitable fashion. If recent circulation trends continue, it will become Britain's favourite newspaper at some point be tween 2005 and 2010. It is already probably the most powerful. It is a paper of the middle class, in particular the suburban and southern varieties. As these people have grown more numerous and politically potent, it has flattered their aspirations and crystallised their fears, helped form their values and fanned their discontents. The intricacy of this to-and-fro can be gauged by the closeness of Mail readers to the newspaper's ideal: they are more likely to be married than the general population; more likely to own property; to have two or more cars; to vote Conservative. Yet only half of them do so habitually. The rest form the largest concentration of "swing voters", assumed to decide modern general elections, who can be reached through a single newspaper. However, to a slightly different sort of person - British liberals, leftwingers, anyone it has ever persecuted - the paper is not affirming but an affront. "I stopped taking the Mail at the start of this year because it was bad for me," says one Labour MP who is attacked almost weekly. Mail reporters have repeatedly telephoned this politician's children. The MP has written to the paper with complaints and factual corrections, which "they never publish". One received this written response from a senior executive: "You are a hypocrite." When a complaint is posted now, "My stomach turns to water at what they are going to do to me for retaliating." In recent months, the Mail's bêtes noires, to use a favourite phrase of Mail executives, have included the ailing Princess Margaret ("paying for her pursuit of pleasure"), the BBC's new political editor Andrew Marr ("Millbank Man"), and a young Iraqi chef who "has tried to sneak into Britain 20 times". The paper batters such targets with front pages and features, columnists and diarists, all following the same line for days at a time. "It is a propaganda machine not a newspaper," says a government minister. She, like almost all the politicians prepared to talk about the Mail, asked to remain anonymous. In a sense, the very strength of such reactions only feeds the tabloid's perceived importance. The rest of the media, for one thing, often follows whichever newspaper has the most controversial stories. And the Mail's large middle-class readership makes it particularly closely read by broadcasters, who want to attract that audience. Coincidentally but perhaps appropriately, Dacre's brother Nigel is head of ITN's ITV news. The Mail often starts national debates; even more often, it sets their parameters. For example, the receiving of asylum-seekers, whose hooded, dehumanised profiles have crowded the paper's pages remorselessly in recent years, now appears to most Britons as a problem and a danger, not an opportunity or a national duty. Last September's protests against petrol taxes, which had been revved up by Mail editorials for months, became a people's crusade and not special pleading by the polluting classes. As for Europe, the family, equal rights for gay people, the rise of crime or otherwise - each of these complex issues has been successfully simplified by the paper into a question of identity or morality, where the Mail is famously comfortable, rather than economics or history or sociology, where its rightwing certainties would come up against awkward facts. Modern British politics, it often seems, has been remade in the Mail's image. This has made some of the government's ambitions, for the time being at least, impossible to achieve. "The things we've lost on," says a minister, "such as [the repeal of the anti-gay] Clause 28, are because of the climate they've created." Recently, with an election expected, the paper's general hostility has grown close to hysterical. Earlier this month, one of its columnists, Simon Heffer, predicted that continued Labour rule would lead to 14m illegal immigrants in Britain, almost half the country's military personnel being disabled people, and "girls of nine" receiving "the morning-after pill from school dinner ladies". One of Blair's closest advisors concludes: "The Mail have gone into kill mode." Other Labour politicians, however, take a rather different view of the paper. "It is extremely well-written and attractively presented," said David Blunkett, the secretary of state for education, at the 1998 party conference. The same year, when Dacre's predecessor Sir David English died, his memorial service was attended by, among others, Tony Blair, William Hague and Margaret Thatcher. In 1999, when the Mail's proprietor Viscount Rothermere also died, the prime minister read a lesson at the service of thanksgiving. That autumn, relations appeared to cool. Blair famously attacked "the forces of conservatism". Labour began publishing a Daily Mail Monitor, to counter the newspaper's "myths" about its policies. But the editor of the Monitor, the MP Gerald Kaufman, now says that his publication is "quiescent". Has the government's view of the Mail changed? With slow emphasis, he says: "The Daily Mail is an extraordinarily able and well-conducted paper." Heffer has been appointed to a Home Office panel reviewing jail sentencing. Last year, perhaps most revealingly of all, a personal memo written by the prime minister was leaked to the press. Under the heading "Touchstone Issues", Blair said his government should please "gut British instinct" by being "tough" on teenage criminals and asylum seekers, respecting the family more, and better understanding people such as the imprisoned Norfolk farmer Tony Martin who defended their property by force. All these points had been specifically raised, in a similar order, in a Mail editorial. The Conservative party also appears at times to be the paper's junior partner. A grinning John Major attended its 21st birthday as "a compact newspaper" (it is not, it insists, a tabloid); three years later, the Mail backed John Redwood's attempt to topple him. webTitle: Logica pumped up by text messaging

fields.headline: Logica pumped up by text messaging
fields.trailText: Logica has reported better than expected sales and profit figures, thanks to the boom in text messaging, writes John Cassy.
fields.body:
The explosive growth in mobile telephone text messaging yesterday enabled the IT services group Logica to offset a disappointing performance in its US business and report better than expected sales and profit figures.

Logica systems now handles the majority of the estimated 7bn text messages sent each month internationally.

A technology shares sell-off following a big drop in the value of the Nasdaq index on Tuesday knocked the price of Logica stock sharply, and it closed down 141p at £14.54p.

Chief executive Martin Read was at a loss to explain the fall in the shares.

"When you've just delivered a pre-tax profits increase of 52% - a figure that is at the top end of most analysts' expectations - and your share price then falls 10%, it does seem a bit perverse," he said.

"Market conditions are generally good and we're looking forward to another year of strong performance.

"When you keep on delivering on the figures you just have to let the share price scenario take care of itself."

Most analysts welcomed figures for the six months to December 31 that showed revenues up 25% to £505m, pre-tax profits up 52% at £64.8m and a 33% dividend rise.

Some observers do not believe text messaging annual growth rates of 70-90% can be sustained. Mr Read said: "I simply don't agree with the people who say that the text messaging world is dead. The average person in Japan, where there are some of the most advanced mobile services, sends 300 text messages per year, but in Germany that figure is only 30 - and in the US it is even less."

Mr Read predicted that even when the growth in text messaging does slow the big mobile network operators are likely to buy into more advanced messaging systems that will allow customers to send sound and images.

"The telcos have spent a fortune on their third-generation licences and they have to make them pay.

"They need to get as much volume through their networks as possible, and offer value-added services. We're what they need."

A Deutsche Bank telecoms analyst, David Rees, agreed: "For next-generation messaging platforms .. the group is uniquely positioned."

Telecoms accounts for about half of Logica's annual revenues, but fees from the energy and utilities sectors rose by 56% to £100m. Mr Read admitted the US is still not contributing as much to the group's turnover as he would like - and that revenues had fallen by 4% compared with the previous year. "We could certainly do better. We'll look to grow through a mixture of organic growth and acquisition." The performance in France was also below par, he said.

Last year Logica took steps to fill what it saw as a strategic gap by buying German IT services company PDV for about £370m. Sector analysts believe that Logica might eventually seek to repeat the same process in the US, where it lacks critical mass.

fields.headline: Letsbuyit ready to reopen shop
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: 9.15am: E-tailer Letsbuyit.com is to begin trading again, days after a Dutch court lifted a debt moratorium on the firm.
fields.body:
E-tailer Letsbuyit.com is to begin trading on its website again, just days after a Dutch court lifted a debt moratorium on the firm.

"The company intends to settle all creditors' demands, refund customers and fulfil outstanding orders promptly," it said after finalising a 52m euros (£33m) rescue package.

The new Letsbuyit will still offer reductions to customers who buy in groups but will be a scaled back version of the business that sprawled across Europe before it collapsed with massive debts.

Offices in Britain, Germany, France and Sweden will reopen immediately. If trading is positive, other offices might reopen in the spring.

Letsbuyit has sought to reduce its cost base by cutting more than 200 jobs and closing several offices. It plans to turn a profit by the end of 2002.

Founder John Palmer, who has returned as chief executive after the previous management quit, hopes to improve supplier relationships and sell a broader range of products.

"Recent events have left us with a renewed sense of responsibility to our shareholders, our million-plus member community and our employees to deliver on our promises.

"Now its time for us to build the kind of world class business that has long been the vision for LetsBuyIt.com and which is now within our sights."

webTitle: Branson urges US partners into bed

fields.headline: Branson urges US partners into bed
fields.trailText: 9.15am: Sir Richard Branson is on the brink of a $1bn deal to launch Virgin Mobile USA, writes Polly Sprenger.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson is on the brink of a $1bn deal to launch Virgin Mobile USA, becoming the first British mobile brand to cross the Atlantic.

The 18-month-old mobile arm of Virgin Group is in advanced talks with at least three US operators, Sir Richard said, and a deal could be announced as early as next week.

Virgin Mobile is a "virtual" operator selling services under its own name but using capacity on other companies' networks, such as One2One in Britain. Sir Richard said potential partners in the US included Sprint, Australia's Nextel and AT&T, with costs and revenues to be shared.

Speaking at the GSM Conference in Cannes, Sir Richard said: "Everybody is getting into bed with somebody. But personally I always think it's preferable to go to bed with a Virgin."

The mobile company has already expanded from the UK into Australia, where its partner is Optus, and into Asia with Singapore Telecom.

Critics say the deal is only attractive for partners that are weaker network operators in highly competitive markets.

"In certain circumstances it's beneficial for the network operator, but we didn't see working with Virgin would be good for our business," said Richard Brennan, an executive vice-president of Orange.

One2One, Mr Brennan said, is the smallest UK operator and is not selling enough usage to its own customers. Virgin says that while a partner supplies the network Virgin offers an attractive brand. "We're bringing a brand that is hopefully one of the better respected in the world," Sir Richard said.

Virgin said a US move would cost hundreds of millions of dollars and Sir Richard has considered floating part of Virgin Mobile to fund his half of the $1bn venture. He asked bankers earlier this month to review a possible float.

The company borrowed some £115m last October - money that was supposed to last until Virgin's mobile arm moved into profit in 2002.

webTitle: Free childcare - if young mothers go back to school

fields.headline: Free childcare - if young mothers go back to school
fields.trailText: The government is considering giving all teenage mothers free full-time childcare if they undergo training or return to school. A pilot scheme will be unveiled today in which mothers under 20 will be able to leave their children with registered childminders in a "rights and responsibilities" deal designed to haul them out of poverty and into work.
fields.body:
The government is considering giving all teenage mothers free full-time childcare if they undergo training or return to school. A pilot scheme will be unveiled today in which mothers under 20 will be able to leave their children with registered childminders in a "rights and responsibilities" deal designed to haul them out of poverty and into work.

The move is prompted in part by the government's determination to curb the number of teenage pregnancies. Britain has the highest rate of teenage births in western Europe - double the number of Germany, three times that of France and six times that of the Netherlands.

The £3m pilot scheme, which forms part of the government's commitment to erase child poverty, will initially help 200 teenage mothers who have little support from their families, have left home or are in care.

Four areas with low levels of education and training and high instances of teenage pregnancy will be targeted. But ministers expect the scheme to be extended nationwide to cover all teenage mothers, should the three-year pilot prove successful.

"Obviously, where families support the mothers, there isn't the need for the extra money, so we've been focusing on the most isolated cases, but if it works then we'll expand it," Margaret Hodge, the education and employment minister, said.

The move builds on the recommendations of a report into teenage pregnancy by the social exclusion unit, commissioned by the prime minister, which stressed that "young parents should have the chance to complete their education", but acknowledged that they faced "a range of barriers" including the availability and cost of childcare. The cost of a childminder averages £90 a week, with a nursery place around £110.

The report, published in June 1999, also found that teenage mothers were less likely than their childless counterparts to finish their education, less likely to find a good job, and more likely to end up both as single parents and to bring their children up in poverty.

Young girls in care are particularly likely to be caught in the teenage pregnancy trap, with a quarter pregnant at 16 and nearly half pregnant within two years of leaving care.

Last night Ms Hodge stressed that the government was trying to reduce the "unacceptable" levels of teenage pregnancy through clearer sex education in schools. She added: "When teenagers do have children - and where there is no family support, perhaps because the mother has been in care - it is in the interests of both the mother and the child for the mother to stay in education and training.

"At present 90% of teenage mums live on benefits and they are more likely to stay on benefit for longer. We must change that."

Mothers, who will initially be drawn from Blackpool, north-east Lincolnshire, and Greenwich, Dagenham and Barking in south-east London and Essex, will be able to place their children with registered childminders who will look after no more than three children each.

fields.headline: Ministry cuts back
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Ministry of Sound has shelved its plans for a publishing empire, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
A cost-cutting drive at Ministry of Sound has forced the company to shelve its plans to become a publishing empire, making the managing director and new launch director redundant.

Ministry, the publishing arm of the dance music superbrand, has integrated its online and offline operations, making three editorial staff and two managers redundant.

Launched in the mid 90s to tap into the growing demand for dance music, Ministry magazine grew quickly to rival established magazines such as Emap's Mixmag and IPC's Muzik.

Last year the company announced plans to launch various brand spin-offs, from an Australian-based men's lifestyle magazine to a book publishing concern.

But the company has axed both Mike Dash, who joined as managing director last year, and Fiona Jerome, the former editor of John Brown's men's lifestyle magazine Bizarre.

A statement from James Bethell, Ministry of Sound Media managing director, said the company was "integrating its media outlets".

He continued: "This makes sense for advertisers and the clubbing community."

But the company refused to provide any information about Mr Dash or Ms Jerome.

Observers have speculated the cuts could be a prelude to a float for Ministry.

Ministry of Sound, set up by James Palumbo, has become one of the biggest brand names in music publishing and has developed a successful business off the back of its dance music compilation CD business.
