webTitle: Battle to cut teenage pregnancy rate

fields.headline: Battle to cut teenage pregnancy rate
fields.standfirst: Ideal of giving young parents the chance to complete their education, so as to help tackle 'unacceptably high' figure, may become reality
fields.trailText: Britain has become notorious for having the highest teenage pregnancy rate in western Europe, twice that of Germany, three times higher than France and six times that of the Netherlands.
fields.body:
Britain has become notorious for having the highest teenage pregnancy rate in western Europe, twice that of Germany, three times higher than France and six times that of the Netherlands.

While the rest of the continent has seen dramatic falls in teenage parenthood since the early 80s, the UK has long been the exception with a high rate which has remained static since 1977.

Each year, around 56,000 babies are born to teenage mothers in Britain with nearly 8,000 conceived by girls under 16 and 2,200 by under 14-year-olds.

The difficulty of solving the problem - described as "unacceptably high" by the employment minister, Margaret Hodge, last night - is compounded by there being no single identifiable reason for such high rates.

Poverty, poor educational opportunities, being born to a teenage mother, and lack of work opportunities are all predicators, while rates of pregnancy have been found to be highest among the most vulnerable girls, those in deprived areas and those in care.

One recent report, for the National Children's Bureau, showed a quarter of girls leave local authority care pregnant with a further quarter becoming pregnant within 24 months of leaving.

Women in deprived areas are six times more likely to get pregnant by the age of 20 than those in the most affluent areas of Britain, according to the Family Policy Studies Centre.

Figures from the Office for National Statistics revealed the number of pregnancies per 1,000 among under-18s in 1998 was highest in Lambeth, Southwark and Lewisham (82.7), Manchester (68.3), Sandwell (67.8), and Sunderland (65.5).

The areas shown to have the fewest teenage pregnancies were East Surrey (22.5), West Surrey (25.7) Kingston and Richmond (25.7), and Oxfordshire (29.9).

While the government is committed to reducing the rate, there has been widespread concern that efforts to tackle the problem of teenage parenthood should not be reduced to moralising.

A study by the Policy Studies Institute recently revealed that most teenage mothers do not plan their pregnancies.

One in four of those interviewed said they had planned to have a baby and 40% were pleased to find they were pregnant. However, a quarter were shocked or surprised to find out they were pregnant and a further quarter were "horrified".

Placing an emphasis on prevention has always been seen as an essential part of the strategy but sustained action to understand and address the needs of teenagers during and after pregnancy is now being recognised as a fundamental requirement.

There is a strong link between teenage parenthood and an increased risk of poor health, economic and social outcomes for both mothers and children, according to several studies.

Research cited by the Family Policy Studies Centre found that, compared to those who became first-time mothers in their 20s, teenage mothers were four times more likely to be living in social housing, over eight times as likely to have been lone parents, and almost three times more likely to lack qualifications, by the age of 33.

In its report, published in June 1999, the government's social exclusion unit identified three possible reasons for Britain's higher teenage birth rates: low expectations in terms of job prospects, ignorance about contraception and the reality of motherhood, and mixed messages about sex.

It concluded that these factors pointed to a "single faultline" in past attempts to tackle teenage pregnancy: "neglect".

The report advocates a four-pronged action plan, placing greater emphasis on post-natal support for teenagers with a focus on returning to education or work. "Teenagers who become parents should not lose out on opportunities for the future. "Young parents should have the chance to complete their education," it says.

Should the government's pilot scheme - which will be unveiled today, be extended -that ideal might become a reality.

fields.headline: Hearsay prove they've got the white stuff
fields.trailText:
8.30am: The Popstars band is to star in an ad campaign for milk, reports Claire Cozens.
Feb 7: Popstars sponsor may buy into band
fields.body:
Popstars dolls have already been lined up as part of a carefully orchestrated marketing campaign to keep the band in the limelight.

And now the hype is really beginning to pay off,

The band created by ITV have clinched a deal for their first TV advertising campaign more than two weeks before their first single - which could, in theory, flop - is released.

The National Dairy Council, which runs milk marketing campaigns on behalf Britain's farmers, has approached the famous fivesome to appear in its long-running "white stuff" campaign.

A spokeswoman for the organisation said that the group - named Hearsay - had agreed in principle to appear.

"We approached their agent because we thought they'd be great in the ads - they said yes straight away," said the spokeswoman.

"The next thing is for us to come up with some appropriate storylines."

Previous White Stuff commercials have used cartoon versions of various celebrities in humorous situations in which milk drinkers are portrayed as heroes.

The ad agency behind the campaign is BMP DDB.

Rolf Harris - with didgeridoo - was the latest star to appear in a milk advert.

Chris Eubank, George Best and Prince Naseem have also allowed themselves to be transformed into cartoons for the campaign.

The £9m campaign uses the slogan: "The White Stuff - are you made of it?".

The ads are intended to encourage adults to drink milk more frequently and to remind people that milk is a credible alternative to soft drinks.

fields.headline: Foster quits Carlton
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Liz Hurley's former agent Michael Foster has left Carlton Communications, write Dan Milmo and Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Liz Hurley's former agent Michael Foster has resigned as managing director of content at Carlton Communications, after 18 months at the company.

Mr Foster was previously co-chairman of the prestigious ICM talent agency.

Carlton trumpeted his signing to a production team that included TV tycoon Lord Alli.

"Mike Foster has left to pursue other interests - we wish him well and thank him for his contribution over the last 18 months," said a Carlton spokeswoman.

Carlton insiders discounted industry rumours that Mr Foster had left to join the production company set up by Elisabeth Murdoch, the daughter of media tycoon Rupert Murdoch and former managing director of Sky Networks.

"He wanted to go and do something different. It has been great having him here, and he really wanted to do other things," said one source.

Carlton proudly paraded Mr Foster and Lord Alli as the cornerstones of its production division but both have now quit the ITV giant.

It is second time in three years Mr Foster has parted company with a high-profile television operation.

He quit ICM in December 1997 to join close friend Chris Evans as chief executive of the red-topped entrepreneur's Ginger TV company.

But nine months later Mr Foster was out of the Ginger empire, pocketing a payoff of £1.1m in the process.

At ICM, the tough-talking businessman had a reputation as one of the best deal-makers in the business, handling the business affairs of stars such as Hugh Grant and Liz Hurley.

His lengthy contacts list will attract a string of media suitors.

fields.headline: The plastic options
fields.trailText: On a credit or debit card, your bank or building society will usually charge a commission or "loading charge". This is typically 2.75% of the total value for purchases, rising to 4.25% for cash advances.
fields.body:
On a credit or debit card, your bank or building society will usually charge a commission or "loading charge". This is typically 2.75% of the total value for purchases, rising to 4.25% for cash advances.

Nationwide is one of a few that have eliminated loading charges and others may decide to follow suit. If you use this method frequently the charges can start to mount, so it may be worth looking for a card with low or no charges.

The amount of the purchase or the cash withdrawn is converted into sterling using the Mastercard or Visa wholesale exchange rate, which is usually better than the rates charged at exchange booths or for cashing travellers' cheques.

You will be charged interest on your overseas spending in the same way as if you had spent the money in the UK. If you are charged interest from the moment the item is bought and you don't clear your balance regularly, the interest will make your holiday bargains all the more expensive.

At Barclaycard for example, if you pay off part of the balance, the money will be taken to cover the first purchases made during that month. If that doesn't cover your cash advances, the interest will be calculated back to the day you took out the money.

If you plan on travelling outside big cities or in developing world countries, do not rely on being able to withdraw money from ATM machines or paying bills by credit card.

Once you know where you're going, check the location of cash machines using the ATM locators on Visa and Mastercard websites. It may also be worth taking a few travellers cheques as a precautionary measure.

If you don't have a credit card, a Visa TravelMoney card from Alliance & Leicester may be right for you. These smart cards are issued with a pre-determined amount of money, usually between £100 and £5,000, which you can then withdraw through Visa ATMs.

You can also order extra cards, at a cost of £2 each, which are useful in the event that you lose your card, or for family members to access the same pool of money.

A charge of 1.5 % of the sum purchased is made for the cards, plus a handling charge of £3.50.

fields.headline: Travellers' cheques
fields.trailText: Things to look out for when buying travellers' cheques are the commission charged and the exchange rate.
fields.body:
Things to look out for when buying travellers' cheques are the commission charged and the exchange rate.

High street banks charge between 1% and 2%, with minimum charges £2.50 and £4, but commission can be as high as 6%. You can save money by ordering them online. Nationwide charges no commission on online orders, but levies a delivery charge of £3.50. Thomas Cook also accepts online orders.

Bear in mind you will also be charged commission when you cash the cheques, although it is difficult to predict how much as it varies from country to country and outlet to outlet. In the UK, commission can be as high as 6%. Some overseas currency exchange outlets don't charge commission but offer a lower rate of exchange.

Try and buy your cheques from a retailer who will cash any unused cheques free of charge. If you buy them from your bank, check if you can pay them into your account for free.

Where you are heading for will determine the currency your travellers' cheques should be in, but buying them in sterling is often the best option as it will be cheaper for you to cash any leftover cheques back when you return to the UK. However, euro travellers' cheques can be a good idea for use within the European union.

If you are heading to remote areas or to developing countries, the currency exchange clerks may shake their heads at sterling travellers' cheques. US dollar cheques are a safer bet, especially in areas like South America, so do check before you travel.

webTitle: Clinton tells relative to return money

fields.headline: Clinton tells relative to return money
fields.trailText: The whiff of impropriety hanging over the departure of Bill Clinton from the White House intensified last night when he conceded that his brother-in-law had been paid to help win presidential favours for a con-man and a drug dealer.
fields.body:
The whiff of impropriety hanging over the departure of Bill Clinton from the White House intensified last night when he conceded that his brother-in-law had been paid to help win presidential favours for a con-man and a drug dealer.

The former president on his last day in office pardoned Glenn Braswell, a convicted fraudster who made false claims about a herbal remedy for baldness, and commuted the sentence of Carlos Vignali, a cocaine trafficker.

Hillary Clinton's brother, Hugh Rodham, a lawyer, received $200,000 (£140,000) for his work on their cases, Mr Clinton admitted yesterday. The former president said he and Hillary had known nothing of the payments until alerted by press inquiries, and had insisted that the money be returned.

The story broke while rancour is still fresh over the pardon granted to the runaway financier Marc Rich. It was known that it was going to be reported tomorrow in the National Enquirer scandal sheet, and reporters had made calls to both Mr and Mrs Clinton's offices.

Mr Clinton said last night: "Yesterday I became aware of press inquiries that Hugh Rodham received a contingency fee in connection with a pardon application for Glenn Braswell and a fee for work on Carlos Vignali's commutation application.

"Neither Hillary nor I had any knowledge of such payments. We are deeply disturbed by these reports and have insisted that Hugh return any monies received." It was understood last night that Mr Rodham had returned the $200,000.

Mr Vignali, who distributed 360kg of crack cocaine, had been told that he had little chance of having his sentence commuted after the judge and prosecutor in Minneapolis who dealt with his case opposed it. His father is a large contributor to the Democratic party in California and Mr Vignali left jail on January 20 after serving six years of a 15-year sentence.

Mr Braswell's pardon was one of 40 that bypassed the system and went straight to the White House. Sources close to Mr Clinton say that he did not know Mr Braswell was under investigation again, this time for "massive tax evasion and money-laundering," according to court papers filed in Los Angeles two years ago.

Mr Clinton's statement came only a day after former president Jimmy Carter condemned him for pardoning Mr Rich, who is said to have evaded $48m in tax payments. Mr Rich's ex-wife contributed more than $1m to the Clintons and the Democratic party.

"I think President Clinton made one of his most serious mistakes in the way he handled the pardon situation the last few hours he was in office," Mr Carter said. "I don't think there is any doubt that some of the factors in his [Rich's] pardon were attributable to his large gifts. In my opinion that was disgraceful."

Mr Clinton issued 140 pardons and commuted 36 prison sentences in the hours before he left office on January 20.

fields.headline: Prison watchdog labels youth jail 'unsafe'
fields.trailText: The chief inspector of prisons has condemned a young offenders' institution as "unsafe" in a letter to home secretary, Jack Straw.
fields.body:
The chief inspector of prisons has condemned a young offenders' institution as "unsafe" in a letter to home secretary, Jack Straw.

Sir David Ramsbotham wrote to Mr Straw after an inspection of Stoke Heath in Shropshire during which he found high numbers of injuries to juvenile inmates, some of which were sustained as a result of control and restraint techniques used by staff.

His letter indicates that he does not think it is safe for juveniles between 16 and 18 to be sent to the institution, and expresses concerns about the use of control techniques used in the removal of inmates from conflict situations and in the maintenance of order.

As part of his inspection of the institution in October, Sir David examined the number of control and restraint removals. In October there were 37, in September 31 and in August 36 - a rise from the January-September average of 25 a month.

The prison service last night pointed out that in the months since Sir David's visit such removals had fallen. In November there were 30, December 22 and last month the figure was down to 14.

A spokesman said: "The use of control and restraint is required to maintain good order and discipline. Stoke Heath like many young offenders' institutions contains volatile and often violent prisoners.

He added: "The health centre at Stoke Heath has confirmed that the injuries recorded following the use of control and restraint have ranged from sore wrists to minor abrasions all consistent with the proper and controlled application of control and restraint. There have been no serious injuries."

The content of the letter, which is based on Sir David's draft report, is understood to be known by the director general of the prison service, Martin Narey.

The prison service spokesman was unable to confirm if the home secretary had received the letter. A Home Office said: "Sir David has done an inspection of Stoke Heath and a report is due shortly."

Sir David is expected to say that the number of injuries in the institution, housing offenders aged 15 to 21, was "exceptionally high" and that officers were using "inappropriate" methods of restraint.

He is understood to have told Mr Straw that the number of injuries caused by staff "suggests that control and restraint is not being appropriately applied". Injuries were also caused by fights, self-harm and workplace accidents among boys who suffered from "a total lack of constructive activity".

webTitle: Cadet injured in blast at TA base

fields.headline: Cadet injured in blast at TA base
fields.standfirst: Fears of attack prompt anti-terrorist response
fields.trailText: An explosion at a Territorial Army base in west London last night seriously injured a 14-year-old boy and prompted an immediate anti-terrorist response amid fears that the capital could again be targeted by dissident republican groups.
fields.body:
An explosion at a Territorial Army base in west London last night seriously injured a 14-year-old boy and prompted an immediate anti-terrorist response amid fears that the capital could again be targeted by dissident republican groups.

A cadet apparently picked up a device, possibly somewhere outside the centre in South Africa Road, White City, and was holding it when it went off at 7.10pm.

A TA sergeant described the blast as sounding like "two trains colliding".

The teenager was taken to the Westminster and Chelsea hospital suffering from serious injuries - including a severed left hand - as a team from Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist branch were mobilised.

Scotland Yard played down any involvement by terrorist organisations. But the level of police response indicated the concern regarding an attempt by republican groups to pursue a mainland campaign.

The surrounding area was cordoned off and the nearby tube station closed, but residents were not evacuated.

Last night detectives were still clearing up the debris inside the base - which is the headquarters of the Fourth Battalion Parachute Regiment 10 (London) company - and were trying to establish what kind of device was responsible.

Police confirmed that no coded warning was received and an initial examination of the remains of the device by forensic experts suggested it was not the work of terrorists.

Chief Superintendent Anthony Wills, officer in charge, said: "Terrorism would not be our first line of inquiry."

He said it was very unlikely the explosion was caused by munitions used by the TA.

Mr Wills said the injured boy found the explosive device some way from the base, and carried it in.

He added: "He is very ill and is being looked after in hospital." It is understood that his left hand was blown off, and he suffered serious chest injuries.

Last night his parents were at his bedside.

Scotland Yard sources confirmed it was too early to say what had caused the explosion, but said there was nothing at this stage to suggest it was in any way linked to previous attacks in the capital by the splinter republican group, the Real IRA.

fields.headline: Asthma gene 'could aid treatment'
fields.trailText: Scientists have discovered an asthma gene which could lead to the development of more effective treatment for millions of sufferers worldwide.
fields.body:
Scientists have discovered an asthma gene which could lead to the development of more effective treatment for millions of sufferers worldwide.

The gene could account for as many as 40% of all asthma cases and might offer a target not only for new drugs but for a screening test, researchers said yesterday.

Between 30 and 50 genes believed to be associated with asthma have so far been identified by scientists. The latest find is the result of five years' work by a team at the University of Southampton's School of Medicine and two American companies which are together engaged in a £50m project to pinpoint asthma genes.

Stephen Holgate, who led the team of Southampton researchers, said the discovery of the gene was an important advance in understanding the genetic causes of asthma.

Asthma affects 3.4m people in the UK alone. It is also the most common chronic childhood disease. Extensive clinical information and DNA samples were taken from more than 300 volunteer families of asthma sufferers from the south coast of England by Professor Holgate and his research team.

The study was conducted in partnership with Genome Therapeutics Corporation of Massachusetts and the Schering-Plough Corporation.

The companies are seeking a patent for the new discovery and the researchers plan to publish their findings in a scientific journal.

fields.headline: Wednesday find fresh hope as Sibon fells shaky Forest
fields.trailText:
Nottm Forest 0 - 1 Sheff Wed
Sheffield Wednesday continued their mini-revival under their caretaker manager Peter Shreeves with a victory that lifts them out of the First Division's relegation zone.
fields.byline: Adrian Milledge at the City Ground
fields.body:
Sheffield Wednesday continued their mini-revival under their caretaker manager Peter Shreeves with a victory that lifts them out of the First Division's relegation zone.

It was Wednesday's second successive win since Shreeves succeeded Paul Jewell and it augers well for their prospects of avoiding back-to-back demotions. In contrast the victory cast doubts on Forest's ability to reach the play-offs and exit the First Division via a more favourable route.

This was not a one-off lapse at the City Ground by David Platt's team, as they have now lost seven league games at home and are making a habit of succumbing to their so-called inferiors there.

Platt is at a loss to explain his team's poor form at home but has no doubts what failure to reach the play-offs will mean. "The disappointment would be massive," he said. "The nice things that have been written and said about us would count for nothing."

It is doubtful whether anything pleasant will be said about last night's display which saw Forest huff and puff to ill effect against opponents who made it clear from the off they would be happy with a draw.

"We came here with a game plan which was to frustrate and make life difficult for them," admitted Shreeves. "Any point at this stage is very welcome, so to take three from a game against one of the division's high-flyers is a bonus."

Wednesday's game plan involved having five men strewn across the midfield in front of a flat back four and Efan Ekoku as a lone striker.

It all proved too much for Forest, who lacked the wit and invention to find a way through the congested midfield. Perversely it was Wednesday, despite their defensive bent, who posed more threat but were let down by woeful finishing, especially in the first half.

The malaise proved contagious seconds after the interval when Riccardo Scimeca scooped Ben Olsen's square ball over the crossbar when scoring looked an easier option.

Sensing Forest's impotence, Wednesday became more ambitious and were rewarded 14 minutes from time when Sibon intercepted a ill-directed pass from Chris Bart-Williams and placed his left-footed shot from distance between the diving Dave Beasant and his left-hand post.

fields.headline: Moravcik keeps O'Neill smiling but Davies leaves with a scowl
fields.trailText: Celtic 1 - 0 Motherwell
fields.body:
Lubo Moravcik came off the bench last night to produce a timely strike and give jittery Celtic a 14-point lead.

Troubled Motherwell came to Parkhead with one purpose - to frustrate the opposition. With 11 men behind the ball they succeeded for 82 minutes.

But Celtic's manager Martin O'Neill decided on one last throw of the dice by bringing on the Slovakian and within seven minutes his gamble had paid off. Moravcik was brought down outside the box but got to his feet to curl an unstoppable shot into the top corner to maintain Celtic's 100% home record.

O'Neill revealed: "I said to the players at half-time that I was delighted with them. If anything I thought we had to utilise the space a bit more and I thought Ramon Vega was trying to do that going into that space behind them. So I was very pleased with them at half-time and I thought we created one or two decent chances.

"But given the circumstances that's the best win of the season. It was brilliant the way we just kept on going."

In contrast, the Motherwell manager Billy Davies was angry with the referee John Rowbotham after awarding Celtic the free-kick for the goal and booking five of his players.

"I'm very disappointed to be honest with you," snapped Davies. "The players felt very hard done by."

It took Celtic less than 10 minutes to find the rhythm which took them to two famous victories over Rangers in the space of five days, and once in their stride Celtic produced chance after chance. It was one-way traffic and in the 15th minute the former Rangers goalkeeper Andy Goram, whose every touch was greeted with jeers from the home fans, misjudged Thompson's cross but luckily Stephen McMillan was on hand to clear.

Celtic suffered a blow when Bobby Petta limped off and Stilian Petrov joined the action, but they should have taken the lead in the dying seconds of the half when Steve Sutton picked out Vega in the centre only for the defender totally fail to connect.

Celtic were back on the attack after the break and Alan Thompson and Petrov both blazed over. Then Celtic's best move ended with a Sutton header which came back off a post. Finally Moravcik arrived to snatch the points - and there was still time for Thompson to hit the bar. - PA

It was brilliant the way we just kept on going." In contrast, the Motherwell manager Billy Davies was angry with the referee John Rowbotham after awarding Celtic the free-kick for the goal and booking five of his players. "I'm very disappointed to be honest with you," snapped Davies. "The players felt very hard done by." It took Celtic less than 10 minutes to find the rhythm which took them to two famous victories over Rangers in the space of five days, and once in their stride Celtic produced chance after chance. It was one-way traffic and in the 15th minute the former Rangers goalkeeper Andy Goram, whose every touch was greeted with jeers from the home fans, misjudged Thompson's cross but luckily Stephen McMillan was on hand to clear. Celtic suffered a blow when Bobby Petta limped off and Stilian Petrov joined the action, but they should have taken the lead in the dying seconds of the half when Steve Sutton picked out Vega in the centre only for the defender totally fail to connect. Celtic were back on the attack after the break and Alan Thompson and Petrov both blazed over. Then Celtic's best move ended with a Sutton header which came back off a post. Finally Moravcik arrived to snatch the points - and there was still time for Thompson to hit the bar. - PA  You've read the piece, now have your say. fields.headline: Liverpool 0 - 1 Roma
fields.standfirst:
Minute-by-minute match report
Liverpool win 2-1 on aggregate
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Liverpool 1-Sander Westerveld: 2-Stephane Henchoz, 3-Christian Ziege, 6-Markus Babbel, 12-Sami Hyppia: 16-Dietmar Hamann, 21-Gary McAllister, 20-Nick Barmby, 23-Jamie Carragher: 10-Michael Owen, 8-Emile Heskey. Subs: Arphexad, Smicer, Fowler, Diomede, Vignal, Wright, Navaro.

Roma 1-Francesco Antonioli: 3-Antonio Carlos Zago, 5-Marcos Assuncao, 8-Hidetoshi Nakata, 9-Vincenzo Montella, 15-Jonathan Zebina, 17-Damiano Tomassi, 19-Walter Samuel, 23-Alessandro Rinaldi, 24-Marco Delvecchio, 32-Vincent Candela. Subs: Lupatelli, Di Francesco, D'Agostino, Batistuta, Balbo, Guigou, Bovo.

Referee Jose Maria-Garcia-Aranda (Spain)

1 Liverpool kick-off and immediately hoof the ball up towards Heskey on the left. Assuncao cuts off Owen in the centre cirlce and then slides the ball towards Candela just outside the area.
2 Free-kick to Liverpool after Samuel hauls Heskey back by his shorts. Worked about on the left before Zebina takes Owen's heels for another free-kick. Cleared for Carragher to smack in a shot from 40 yards that Antonioli has to watch all the way.
3 Mix up with Westerveld almost allows in Roma before offside is called.
4 Booking Montella for a challenge on Hyppia.
8 A couple of nervous moments early doors for both teams, but Roma look on the verge of panic whenever Owen or Heskey threaten the box.
9 Nakata finds space on the left and is hussled to the by-line by Hamann.
10 Good build-up by Roma for Nakata to release Montella into the box - offside.
12 McAllister hoofs the ball upfield and over the top for Heskey to chase as Roma move up. Antonioli comes out and his clearance smacks Heskey on the temple, laying him out momentarily.
15 Nakata gets round on the overlap, but his cross from the left is way too long.
16 Good possession by Roma in the Liverpool half; finally ends when Nakata jigs past two players and slides the ball through to Delvecchio, only for the striker to give it away.
20 Clanger by Delvecchio - Nakata does well to wrong-foot the Liverpool back four with a dummy and put Delvecchio clear on goal, and what does he do? Shoot wide of the far post. Far and away Roma's best chance.
24 Nakata again finds space on the left to thread through a telling pass to the edge of the area; Montella picks it up, it goes for a Roma throw, Liverpool clear.
30 Booking Assuncao for tugging back Hamann halfway into the Roma half.
31 Referee letting lots of those great challenges that look 50-50 from distance go unpenalised, which is making for some sweeping play. Great tackle by Zebina prevents Owen from getting in around the back.
32 Corner to Roma, played short to Candela but Roma give it away.
35 Nakata brings down Babbel for a free-kick 25 yards out to the right. Ziege fires it in, forcing a save from Antonioli. Up for grabs before Roma clear.
37 Zebina for taking out Owen wide on the left.
38 Antonioli unsure as the free-kick comes floating in; he punches clear and it comes back for Owen to shoot wide of the far post after initially thinking he was offiside.
39 Roma free-kick 25 yards out, virtually square-on - Montella shoots straight at Westerveld.
42 Roma still funnelling most of their play via the left flank as they pour forward looking for a vital opening.
45 Still Roma with more of the possession. One minute extra to play. Half-time. Liverpool doing a good job of doing the job, and not much else. Roma have been kept out and Delvecchio blew their only chance. Looking tough for the visitors.

46 Roma get the second half underway.
47 Early free-kick for Roma; comes to nothing.
48 Heskey goes one on one with Antonioli from a ball by Owen; Antonioli comes late and gets the ball at the cost of a painful knock.
50 Scrappy passing at the moment, not that Liverpool will be complaining if the scoreline stays the same.
52 Liverpool corner on the right after pressure by Owen. Ziege takes towards Heskey on the far post but Antonioli claims.
54 Nakata turns away from Hamann on the left before McAllister brings him down 25 yards out. Candela wastes the free-kick on the crowd.
56 Heskey breaks through the middle, but doesn't see Owen to his left and instead sells Barmby short on the right.
57 Concerted pressure by Roma before Tomassi shoots high and wide.
58 Candela shoots straight at Westerveld.
58 Substitutions Batistuta and Guigou on for Delvecchio and Rinaldi.
61 Liverpool penalty Zebina for a push on Heskey. But it's saved by Antonioli from Owen.
62 Liverpool corner; punched clear by Antonioli.
65 Westerveld at full stretch from Zago's long-range shot.
66 Roma corner on the left; headed back to Westerveld from beyond the far post.
66 Three Liverpool players in a row chopped down - the ref lets things run until the third hack, but no one gets a booking.
67 Substitution Smicer on for Owen.
69 No let up by Roma as Liverpool invite them up by playing so deep.
70 Liverpool 0 - 1 Roma Guigou with his left foot from distance. Game on for Roma as Liverpool look to hang on
72 Batistuta fires high into the crowd from 40 yards.
75 Liverpool still unable to get up the pitch with Heskey the only player in the Roma half for much of the time.
77 Chaos The ref awards a penalty for handball by Babbel; he points to the spot and then changes his mind for a corner. Roma players go berserk and the ref waves the yellow card around like Delboy with a Filofax. Tomassi gets the booking.
79 Substitution Abelbalbo on for Montella before Candela eventaully takes the free-kick
81 Substitution Fowler on for Barmby.
82 Unrelenting action now as Liverpool have a Heskey chance hooked away from under the bar.
84 Roma flood forward with nothing to lose. Roma corner, cleared. The ref looks scared to make a decision and lets some shocking challenges go unchecked.
86 Red card Roma Captain Tomassi for a second bookable offence after a chop on Fowler as the ref summons up the courage of his convictions.
87 Liverpool corner, believe it or not. Put out for another by Assuncao. This time he heads clear.
90 Heskey gets away on the left, plays it inside for Fowler to find Smicer out on the right. Smicer takes his time instead of smacking it and loses possession. Four minutes extra to play. Roma still at it with eight players in the Liverpool half. Booking Guigou for kicking Babbel in the back of the head with a high challenge. Roma free-kick 25 yards out to the right of the Liverpool area. Assuncao takes; deflected high with everyone gathering, but Westerveld claims in the melee. Fowler gets involved in a scrap just before the ref blows for full-time. Phew!
Liverpool 0 - 1 Roma (2-1 agg)

fields.headline: Ethical consumerism
fields.trailText: Being an ethical consumer means buying products which were ethically produced and/or which are not harmful to the environment and society. This can be as simple as buying free-range eggs or as complex as boycotting goods produced by child labour.
fields.body:
Being an ethical consumer means buying products which were ethically produced and/or which are not harmful to the environment and society. This can be as simple as buying free-range eggs or as complex as boycotting goods produced by child labour.

Products which fall into the ethical category include organic produce, fair trade goods, energy-efficient light bulbs, electricity from renewable energy, recycled paper and wood products with Forest Stewardship Council approval.

Pressure groups regularly flag up companies of concern and the Ethical Consumer Research Association publishes details in its magazine, but deciding what to buy and what not to buy can be as tricky as deciding which ethical fund to invest in.

Being an ethical consumer can also involve watching your food miles: how much energy was used getting the product to you. For this reason, ethical consumers are encouraged to buy products which were produced locally. Find out if there is a farmers' market, or an allotment society near you where you can purchase products.

Ethical consumption can be a powerful tool for change, with the recent success of the anti-GM lobby being a case in point. However, there is still a long way to go. A recent report from the Co-operative Bank showed a third of UK consumers claiming to be concerned about ethical consumption, while only 3% of the UK market is devoted to the production of ethical goods.

Further information can be obtained from organisations such Get Ethical and Ethical Junction.

fields.headline: Mortgages
fields.trailText: The Ecology Building Society and the Norwich & Peterborough Building Society both offer ethical mortgages.
fields.body:
The Ecology Building Society and the Norwich & Peterborough Building Society both offer ethical mortgages.

The Ecology only lends on properties which give what it calls an ecological payback; old houses in need of renovation, new homes built with recycled or sustainable materials, or homes which will be made as energy efficient as possible.

Meanwhile, Norwich & Peterborough will plant eight trees a year over five years for every home bought or re-mortgaged with its green mortgages. Norwich & Peterborough will also give you a discount on its standard rate if you improve the energy efficiency of your property. They also provide a service to assess the efficiency of new homes.

fields.headline: Banking and credit cards
fields.trailText: The Co-operative Bank, Triodos Bank and the Ecology Building Society are the three front-runners in ethical banking and offer standard banking products.
fields.body:
The Co-operative Bank, Triodos Bank and the Ecology Building Society are the three front-runners in ethical banking and offer standard banking products.

The Co-operative Bank will not lend to oppressive regimes or companies making weapons. Triodos Bank gives a donation to the Soil Association for every organic savings account opened, and the Ecology Building Society lends on energy efficient homes.

The so-called social banking sector comprising building societies and credit unions who make loans to people who would otherwise be financially excluded rather than returning profits to shareholders.

Affinity or charity credit cards give a small percentage of your spending (usually around 0.25%) to charity. Although popular, it is worth bearing in mind that they typically attract a higher rate of interest on spending.

fields.headline: Pensions
fields.trailText: The ethical pension sector was given a major boost in July 2000 when new legislation came into force requiring trustees to disclose their stance on ethical issues.
fields.body:
The ethical pension sector was given a major boost in July 2000 when new legislation came into force requiring trustees to disclose their stance on ethical issues.

If you're a member of an occupational scheme find out what company's stance is. You may be pleasantly surprised. But if you're concerned you and your colleagues may approach the trustees for more information.

If you're not a member of an occupational scheme, ethical personal pensions are an option. Axa Sun Life, Clerical Medical, NPI Globalcare, Scottish Equitable and Standard Life all offer ethical pensions, but different providers may offer an investment fund in a pension wrapper.

fields.headline: Houllier warns against Roman backlash
fields.trailText: After the euphoria of last week, Gerard Houllier has attempted to sound a note of caution ahead of tonight's return at Anfield.
fields.body:
Amid the understandable scenes of euphoria which followed Liverpool's magnificent victory over Roma last Thursday evening, the voice of caution which rose up to appeal for some sense of perspective boasted not a scouse but a French accent.

Like any self-respecting manager, Gérard Houllier is not averse to living for the moment. Indeed, between signing autographs and receiving the thanks of countless, grinning Lazio supporters, Houllier was content - indeed, anxious - to discuss the tactical input which had provided his team with a blueprint for such improbable success.

And yet, as those around him discussed whether it would be Porto or Nantes in the Uefa Cup semi-final, Houllier cut a decidedly uncomfortable figure.

"They are not done yet," he said pondering the enviable riches available to his opposite number, Fabio Capello.

Liverpool's performance en route to a 2-0 win in the Olympic Stadium was nothing short of remarkable but Houllier is experienced enough to acknowledge that Roma are unlikely to play with such a pronounced sense of lethargy a second time.

Embarrassed by the manner in which Liverpool brushed them aside and then wounded by the level and ferocity of the media criticism which followed, Roma dare not slip tamely through the motions at Anfield tonight; if they are, indeed, to lose, it is incumbent upon them to do so with at least a few guns blazing.

Capello's desire to land the Serie A title is such that he is thought to regard the Uefa Cup as something of an irritant. Capello may be wearing blinkers but he is not so short-sighted as to believe that any Roma team can be dumped out of any competition without ramifications.

It is the prospect of Roma attempting to restore a measure of lost pride which worries Houllier - that and possible complacency by his own team.

Not that Houllier's players are readying themselves for an easy night ahead of Sunday's Worthington Cup final against Birmingham City in Cardiff.

"I know how desperate Roma are to succeed their neighbours Lazio as Italian champions but I think they'll give everything they have in this second leg," said the midfielder Gary McAllister.

With Sunday's final in mind, Houllier may well decide to make changes, possibly using Emile Heskey as a lone striker.

Roma will be lacking at least three key players with Francesco Totti suffering from flu, Cafu injured and Emerson suspended. Despite Capello's problems, the celebrated Argentinian striker Gabriel Batistuta is likely to begin the evening on the bench.

Liverpool (probable, 4-4-1-1): Westerveld; Babbel, Hyypia, Henchoz, Carragher; Barmby, Hamann, McAllister, Ziege; Smicer; Heskey.

Roma (probable, 3-4-1-2 ): Antonioli; Samuel, Rinaldi, Zebina; Bovo, Tommasi, Zago, Candela; Nakata; Montella, Delvecchio.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Comment: Blair should be a poodle that barks

fields.headline: Blair might be a poodle, but at least he should bark
fields.standfirst:
He should use the Camp David meeting to challenge the missile defence plan

Special report: George Bush's America
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: He should use the Camp David meeting to challenge the missile defence plan.
fields.body:
In Washington today, Tony Blair will do what history tells him. It isn't possible to imagine him doing anything else. He will shake George Bush by the hand, and set about getting as close to him as a weekend in Camp David permits.

It is rather a long weekend. There are people in the Foreign Office who wonder whether the two men will find enough to talk about, for Bush seems to be as pithy and ignorant as Bill Clinton was verbose and cornucopian in his interests. But Mr Blair is into promiscuous warmth. Jiang Zemin and Signor Berlusconi, I'm told, are two of the few national leaders who have failed to tap it.

Besides, Mr Bush needs him. Pitifully unversed in Europe, the president will find in the Brit the most agreeable, reassuring representative of the English-speaking world which, aside from Mexico, is about all he has to hang on to. Both men see themselves as centrist politicians. Each will rush to make the best of what might once have seemed the ugly ideological allegiance of the other. I prophesy a new best friend for London, as Clinton, forgotten like Peter Mandelson, sweats out post-presidential ignominy in a lonely house in Chappaqua, NY.

People who say this should not happen misunderstand the limits of the possible. Bush and Blair, after all, are at war together and alone, against Iraq. For Britain to have refused to go along with Washington's decision to upgrade the bombing attacks would have caused a political earthquake. We have no independence in the matter. We're locked in.

Likewise, for Blair to make any kind of open trouble over national missile defence (NMD), the son of star wars, would cause a nervous breakdown in Washington and London. Already the terms of political trade in that argument are set. The burden on Britain is not to justify joining in, but to defend the near-inconceivable notion of declaring publicly against the scheme. Thus is national sovereignty qualified by the deposit of the ages.

This accords, also, with the spirit of the new regime. Compensating for Bush's ignorance of the past are several men whose bewitchment by it is excessive. Donald Rumsfeld, the defence secretary, out of the loop for 20 years, knows of little else. This means that the Brit of the moment - when Rumsfeld last took over the Pentagon it was Harold Wilson - has a special place, notably in the Nato scheme of things. Unique relationship unchanged. The last thing Mr Blair wants to do is disappoint him.

Unfortunately, if he's to be true to the national interest, he won't find this easy to avoid. The British still pride themselves on being "upstream" in the American policy-making process. "Our embassy is like another Washington agency, almost on equal terms with other parts of the administration in the policy debate," exulted a high official, talking to me recently. Quite unlike the French, he said, who stood outside and criticised, while usually going along with important policy in the end. But the inside track puts a tremendous burden on Blair to explain that things really have changed since the veterans riding herd on the ingénu were last in the saddle.

The hardest place for such a lesson may be Iraq. Being Washington's only ally in a policy that's as immoral as it is futile makes continuing support almost axiomatic. On the other hand, it's a patent disaster. This is where the master-poodle relationship is most humiliatingly obvious: a bilateral commitment to an analysis that's contested by most of the intelligent world. But unless he's prepared for a major fracture, Blair has little leverage, even in private. It's like the old days, only worse. At least in sixties Vietnam we didn't send the bombers.

The two other big military issues are rather different. Here things are not what they were when Rumsfeld and his one-time protégé, Dick Cheney, now the vice-president, were first in charge. The change will be a theme of the Camp David meeting. Europe, Blair will explain, has developed. It is not just about Germany and France and Britain separately. The sum is greater than the parts. The parts are not willing to be picked off. But is Britain one of the parts? And can Bush be persuaded to understand this?

The Clinton people took time to accept that the potential conflicts with Nato were manageable. Their successors have to be taken through it all over again, and have already shown fewer signs of being helpful.

When Cook was in Washington the other day, it was made plain to him that Cheney and Rumsfeld would not put pressure on Turkey, a Nato member wanting to get into the EU, to abandon her stroppy resistance to the RRF. That's a change from Clinton, who tried but failed to bring Turkey into line. It could signal hard times ahead.

On national missile defence, Blair has gone out of his way to lower the temperature, saying he felt sure the problem could be defused. Bush's most emphatic commitment is to build NMD. It's the message every visitor has been given. Blair said he "totally" understood American concerns about the vulnerability of the homeland to attack from enemies that have gained from missile proliferation.

Chancellor Schröder has given similar indications. Europe as a whole, with the usual exception of France, has throttled back the horror it was expressing a year ago at the global instability NMD could create. Men of power recognise the facts of power, and adapt accordingly.

But the case against NMD hasn't gone away. The doubts about it, both technical and geo-political, are fathomless, and mere American will is by no means enough to resolve them. The unilateralist assertion of the superpower is something her allies as much as her enemies have a vital interest in challenging. The justification for Blair's smiling public acquiescence can therefore only be the most rigorous private doubt-sharing.

The hope from this get- together must be that the plaid-shirted bonhomie is misleading. The meeting should make plain the differences as much as the hoped-for intimacy. At bottom these differences are great and may be getting, of inexorable necessity, greater.

Europe, which the US has always urged to take more of the burden, has its own belief in the rapid reaction force, and its own valid viewpoint on NMD. You can't get further upstream than being the first foreign visitor to Camp David. The news from Europe will come best from the special relation.

webTitle: Labour in new cash row over invitations

fields.headline: Labour in new cash row over invitations
fields.standfirst:
Ministers asked executives to £360 dinner fundraiser

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Ministers asked executives to £360 dinner fundraiser
fields.body:
Labour faced fresh embarrassment over funding scandals last night after it was revealed that a Treasury minister had been soliciting chief executives to buy tables at £360 a time for a business dinner without disclosing that the cash will go towards Labour's general election campaign.

Andrew Smith, chief secretary to the treasury, sent personal invitations to hundreds of chief executives in the Oxford region to hear an address by him and Patricia Hewitt, the minister for e-commerce, on "the new economy and business success" next month.

The dinner and business reception cost £65 a head - with couples' tickets costing £125 and tables for six people £360. His letter - which does not mention the Labour Party - asked chief executives to bring along their colleagues "for a presentation and discussion on economic and business policies for success in the new economy."

It says: "The event will also provide an excellent opportunity to meet business colleagues from the region."

The event is to be held at the Oxford Thames Four Pillars Hotel at Sandford-on-Thames on March 8.They are asked to send cheques to the Oxford East CLP - the constituency Labour party represented by the minister.

Some firms - who did not want to be named - who were not Labour Party supporters complained to the Guardian that the invitation had not highlighted the fact it was a fundraising dinner. One, a Green Party supporter, said: "The letter has no Oxford East constituency party letterhead and looks like a business dinner on the economy addressed by ministers."

The letter tells people to reply to Edel Mooney, Oxford Business Club. When she was contacted she said she had nothing to do with the Labour Party.

John Tanner, the former Labour leader of Oxford city council, who is organising the event, said yesterday: "The event was aimed at known Labour Party supporters - though some may have gone to other people. There is no question of suggesting to people that they will get preferential treatment by having a word with the minister if they came to a fundraising dinner aimed at helping the Labour Party.

"I am sure most businessmen are pretty intelligent and know that Andrew Smith is always contactable at his constituency surgery if they want to raise anything."

Last night the Tories attacked Mr Smith for not making the fund-raising deal behind the invitation clear.

Andrew Lansley, the Tory shadow Cabinet Office minister, said: " This invitation is a wolf in sheep's clothing. It is perfectly all right for MPs to have business clubs - where there are often non-partisan discussions - but it is wrong to use them for fund raising. It is prices that are being charged that are wrong."

Unfortunately for Labour most of its supporters seem to have taken the same view and are not turning up either. Mr Tanner said: "So far we have sold 22 tickets but we are hoping the numbers will rise. We won't be making much money out of it, I am afraid."

webTitle: Labour fight to keep hunt ban in manifesto

fields.headline: Labour fight to keep hunt ban in manifesto
fields.standfirst:
Backbenchers fear Blair is ready to drop commitment

Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: Backbenchers fear Blair is ready to drop commitment.
fields.body:
Senior Labour backbenchers are fighting a rearguard action to prevent Tony Blair and the home secretary, Jack Straw, from dropping a commitment to ban fox hunting in the Labour manifesto.

Discussions are underway between the Labour leadership and members of the parliamentary commitee, the senior elected group of Labour backbenchers.

Mr Blair and Mr Straw have been told by leading figures, including the chairman of the parliamentary Labour party, Clive Soley, that any back-tracking will undermine vital trust between the leadership and the electorate.

"The impression has got abroad that we said we will get rid of fox hunting and we have to go ahead," said one senior MP. Mr Blair himself has privately argued that the issue is proving too divisive in the countryside.

All sides recognise that the bill banning fox hunting will not complete its parliamentary stages by the time Mr Blair calls a spring election. The bill is only due to have its report stage and third reading in the Commons on Tuesday and will not reach the Lords until next month.

MPs have already voted heavily for an outright ban, but cabinet ministers expect the Lords to vote simultaneously for the two other options in the bill - the status quo, or licensed hunting, the so-called middle way option.

Mr Straw openly supports the middle way, and senior MPs believe Mr Blair does not regard a ban as a high priority. The prime minister absented himself from the Commons vote on January 17, pleading urgent business in Northern Ireland. It is thought he does not want another divisive confrontation with the countryside, and would privately support a licensing option.

Mr Blair is being urged by some ministers to drop the expected reference to a further free vote on hunting in the next parliament. Ministers are nervous about the impact of the massive Countryside Alliance demonstration planned for March 17.

Mr Soley and others believe the government must press ahead with the reform and even commit Labour to use the Parliament Act to force the ban through the Lords early in the new parliament. They have told Mr Blair that the will of the Commons must be seen to prevail.

They also want a guarantee that the government will provide parliamentary time. One senior MP said: "In a way the issue is less what we say in the manifesto, but instead that we are absolutely clear that we will ban foxes. It is a matter of trust".

MPs voted by a majority of 213 for a ban, with a majority of 224 against the status quo and 200 against the middle way.

During the bill's Commons committee stages, the Home Office minister, Mike O'Brien, has made a small number of concessions. He has also hinted that the bill may be changed so that it does not apply to the killing of rabbits.

webTitle: 'Arrogant' Lord Irvine refuses to say sorry

fields.headline: 'Arrogant' Lord Irvine refuses to say sorry
fields.standfirst:
Lord chancellor speaks for first time about his decision to send donation letters to barristers

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Lord chancellor speaks for first time about his decision to send donation letters to barristers.
fields.body:
An unrepentant lord chancellor, Lord Irvine, yesterday faced new Tory charges of arrogance when he refused to apologise for raising funds for Labour, insisting he had broken no current rules.

During a tense 15 minute cross-examination, and standing the traditional two paces away from his seat on the woolsack, Lord Irvine told peers he had not undermined the integrity of his unique office.

In his only concession to critics who claim he has compromised the political independence of his post, he said he would comply with any future rules restricting such fund-raising.

He also pointed out that, from next month, a commissioner for judicial appointments will scrutinise the integrity of all appointments to the judiciary.

Speaking for the first time since he came under attack, Lord Irvine told peers: "I do not believe I have done anything wrong nor do I believe I have broken any current rules. If I did I would be the first to apologise.

"There is no real difference between party political campaigning and fundraising because I believe that fundraising is an inherent part of party political campaigning."

Every minister from the prime minister downwards was involved in fund raising for the party, he said.

Asked by Lord Strathclyde, shadow leader of the Lords, whether he would raise funds again, Lord Irvine replied that unless the rules were changed, he would consider doing it again. But he added that in practice he would first consider the furore which the issue had caused.

He insisted he did not believe any lawyer attending the Labour party fundraising dinner which he hosted could have conceivably thought it could have "bought" them an advantage in gaining appointment.

Lord Irvine's judgment was widely challenged after it emerged at the weekend that he sent a letter to Labour-sympathetic lawyers asking them to donate £200 at a party fund-raising dinner.

Lord Irvine said it was misconceived to claim that the lord chancellor was not a party political post, pointing out that Tory predecessors, including Lord Hailsham, had spoken in election campaigns.

The Labour headquarters at Millbank supplemented the claim by highlighting politically controversial interviews given in the 1992 election campaign by the last Conservative lord chancellor, Lord Mackay of Clashfern. Millbank also asserted that previous Tory lord chancellors had attended party fund raising events.

However, the former Conser vative deputy prime minister and barrister, Lord Howe, said Lord Irvine had transformed the position by personally conducting fundraising.

He said: "None of Lord Irvine's predecessors acted as hosts of fund raising dinners attended solely by people over whose professional careers they have profound influence."

Some Labour MPs and Liberal Democrats also asserted that no cabinet minister should ever seek political funds from anyone dependent on the same minister for their professional preferment.

Bob Marshall-Andrews, a Labour backbencher and QC, said: "The one thing no minister must conceivably do is to attempt to solicit funds for political purposes from those over whom he has influence, power or patronage."

Since 26,000 annual public appointments are made by ministers, such a principle would effectively prevents ministers from any fund-raising activity.

During question time in the Lords yesterday, the Liberal Democrat peer, Lord McNally, pressed Lord Irvine "whether the role of lord chancellor is compatible with that of a party fundraiser?"

He added: "There's a blurring by your behaviour of your responsibilities as a minister and your responsibilities as a politician."

Later Lord Strathcyle said: "The lord chancellor arrogantly failed to offer any kind of apology for action that has been universally condemned. He showed no humility, no sense of personal responsibility or any shred of concern for the storm of criticism".

Lord Irvine did not rule out the Labour policy of a judicial appointments commission, so handing the appointment of judges to an independent body.

He said: "It is a very controversial proposition, and you know well that there are many who are really opposed to that proposition because of the dangers which it is said to pose to appointments on merit only, as distinct from appointments which make compromises."

fields.headline: Media manipulators
fields.standfirst:
How a north London web-designer began a campaign that deluged the Guardian with emails

More net news
fields.trailText: How a north London web-designer began a campaign that deluged the Guardian with emails.
fields.body:
Why would the Guardian provide moral and medical justification for the multiple murder of innocent Israeli civilians?

It's a pretty bizarre question, but we found ourselves being asked it over and over again this week. Emails clicked in to the letters page by the hundred, all making the same weirdly alliterative points. This followed publication of a Guardian article trying to understand the motivations of the Palestinian bus driver who ploughed into a queue this month, killing eight Israelis.

The mysteriously similar emails - from all over the world - started coming in, too, to our foreign editor; to our website; and to the personal email address of our Middle East correspondent, Suzanne Goldenberg.

They were inconvenient, and also sometimes a bit scary in their violent tone - "The bloody Guardian... Have you killed a Jew today?... Are you anti-Jewish?... Unrelenting Guardian anti-Israel bias... Why would the Guardian provide moral and medical justification etc...?'

This global blitzing was tending to crowd out genuine expressions of opinion from our readers. Our suspicions aroused, we tried to discover what was going on. It wasn't straightforward. But eventually we discovered the trick. A website calling itself HonestReporting.com was set up in London last autumn.

It has recruited 12,000 subscribers to its database, it claims, all dedicated to fighting anti-Israel "bias" in the media. The aim was to recruit a total of 25,000.

Every time someone writes something they don't like, details of the offending article are circulated round the world, together with a handy form of protesting words, ready to be lightly embroidered and electronically dispatched at the push of a button.

"This is what you should do," they tell their members "Forward it on to the news company concerned at the email address provided. If you can, please change the subject of the email to 'complaint' or something similar."

Their first success, HonestReporting boasted, was with the London Evening Standard. Its columnist Brian Sewell wrote last autumn calling on Israel to "become a multicultural society" and cease exploiting the Holocaust to justify unacceptable behaviour.

"The next day, [we] sent out a letter to subscribers." Standard articles recorded "a wave of complaints... hundreds of Jewish readers have written in". Then "after more pressure" there followed a pro-Israel article by Simon Sebag-Montefiore. "This is an example of what we can do."

And now it was the Guardian's turn to get the email treatment. A long electronic bulletin went out headed: "The Guardian: a mainstream British newspaper consistently blames Israel for everything."

It complained that a Steve Bell cartoon showing Sharon's bloody handprints on the Wailing Wall "encroaches on brash anti-semitism". It complained that a Muslim, Faisal Bodi, had written questioning Israel's right to statehood; and complained that the Guardian had said Sharon had killed the peace process. "No blame is assigned to Arafat." And there too, was our old alliterative friend: "Why would the Guardian provide moral and medical justification...?"

Who was behind this internet harassment? The website gave no address. It had been registered last October under a London name and phone number that seemed not to exist. Eventually, it transpired that it had been set up by a 27-year-old Jewish web-designer from north London called Jonathan. "Don't give my full name," he asked. "Someone was killed in Stamford Hill [the Jewish district] the other day." He and his friends came up with the idea by themselves: "We were just brainstorming."

But the operation was now being funded and run from the US by an organisation concerned with media fairness, Media Watch International.

And who were they? "We're pretty new," says their director, Sharon Tzur, speaking from Manhattan. "It's a group of concerned Jewish business people in New York."

Yet a bit more inquiry reveals that this is not quite the whole story either. For this week's bulletin denouncing the Guardian was in fact composed in Israel by a man named Shraga Simmons.

And when he is not working for HonestReporting, Mr Simmons is to be found employed at another organisation altogether - Aish HaTora. This is an international group promoting orthodox Judaism. "I do some work for Aish," Mr Simmons says, from Israel. And Jonathan, the web-designer who started it all in London, also concedes: "I go to the odd class at Aish."

Aish verge on the colourful in their antics. Founded by Rabbi Noah Weinberg, who complains that "20,000 kids a year" are being lost to Judaism by marrying out, Aish invented speed-dating - eight-minute sessions in cafes to help New Yorkers find compatible Jewish partners. They're widely regarded as rightwing extremists. And they're certainly not people entitled to harass the media into what they would call "objectivity".

The mysteriously similar emails - from all over the world - started coming in, too, to our foreign editor; to our website; and to the personal email address of our Middle East correspondent, Suzanne Goldenberg. They were inconvenient, and also sometimes a bit scary in their violent tone - "The bloody Guardian... Have you killed a Jew today?... Are you anti-Jewish?... Unrelenting Guardian anti-Israel bias... Why would the Guardian provide moral and medical justification etc...?' This global blitzing was tending to crowd out genuine expressions of opinion from our readers. Our suspicions aroused, we tried to discover what was going on. It wasn't straightforward. But eventually we discovered the trick. A website calling itself HonestReporting.com was set up in London last autumn. It has recruited 12,000 subscribers to its database, it claims, all dedicated to fighting anti-Israel "bias" in the media. The aim was to recruit a total of 25,000. Every time someone writes something they don't like, details of the offending article are circulated round the world, together with a handy form of protesting words, ready to be lightly embroidered and electronically dispatched at the push of a button. "This is what you should do," they tell their members "Forward it on to the news company concerned at the email address provided. If you can, please change the subject of the email to 'complaint' or something similar." Their first success, HonestReporting boasted, was with the London Evening Standard. Its columnist Brian Sewell wrote last autumn calling on Israel to "become a multicultural society" and cease exploiting the Holocaust to justify unacceptable behaviour. "The next day, [we] sent out a letter to subscribers." Standard articles recorded "a wave of complaints... hundreds of Jewish readers have written in". Then "after more pressure" there followed a pro-Israel article by Simon Sebag-Montefiore. "This is an example of what we can do." And now it was the Guardian's turn to get the email treatment. A long electronic bulletin went out headed: "The Guardian: a mainstream British newspaper consistently blames Israel for everything." It complained that a Steve Bell cartoon showing Sharon's bloody handprints on the Wailing Wall "encroaches on brash anti-semitism". It complained that a Muslim, Faisal Bodi, had written questioning Israel's right to statehood; and complained that the Guardian had said Sharon had killed the peace process. "No blame is assigned to Arafat." And there too, was our old alliterative friend: "Why would the Guardian provide moral and medical justification...?" Who was behind this internet harassment? The website gave no address. It had been registered last October under a London name and phone number that seemed not to exist. Eventually, it transpired that it had been set up by a 27-year-old Jewish web-designer from north London called Jonathan. "Don't give my full name," he asked. "Someone was killed in Stamford Hill [the Jewish district] the other day." He and his friends came up with the idea by themselves: "We were just brainstorming." But the operation was now being funded and run from the US by an organisation concerned with media fairness, Media Watch International. And who were they? "We're pretty new," says their director, Sharon Tzur, speaking from Manhattan. "It's a group of concerned Jewish business people in New York." Yet a bit more inquiry reveals that this is not quite the whole story either. For this week's bulletin denouncing the Guardian was in fact composed in Israel by a man named Shraga Simmons. And when he is not working for HonestReporting, Mr Simmons is to be found employed at another organisation altogether - Aish HaTora. This is an international group promoting orthodox Judaism. "I do some work for Aish," Mr Simmons says, from Israel. And Jonathan, the web-designer who started it all in London, also concedes: "I go to the odd class at Aish." Aish verge on the colourful in their antics. Founded by Rabbi Noah Weinberg, who complains that "20,000 kids a year" are being lost to Judaism by marrying out, Aish invented speed-dating - eight-minute sessions in cafes to help New Yorkers find compatible Jewish partners. They're widely regarded as rightwing extremists. And they're certainly not people entitled to harass the media into what they would call "objectivity". david.leigh@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • A belated happy 50th to weirdo chancellor Gordon Brown. We hope he won't mind us making a fuss, what with him having been so low key about the event himself. No doubt that's just his old puritanism again, and nothing to do with not wanting to be seen as any less the thrusting young leader-in-waiting. For any lust for Mr Tony's job has gone, and Gordon is less concerned now with personal ambition than the happiness of his colleagues. Why, despite being more frantic than ever as Labour's election chief, Gordon has promised every single Labour backbencher 15 minutes alone with him. Incredible. Gordon is prepared to give up about 80 hours of his time - a full working week! - just when his time is most scarce. What a comfort to Mr Tony it must be, at a time when - for all the certain election win - he looks weaker than ever, to know his friend next door is doing so much for party morale.

No doubt that's just his old puritanism again, and nothing to do with not wanting to be seen as any less the thrusting young leader-in-waiting. Why, despite being more frantic than ever as Labour's election chief, Gordon has promised every single Labour backbencher 15 minutes alone with him. Incredible. Gordon is prepared to give up about 80 hours of his time - a full working week! - just when his time is most scarce. What a comfort to Mr Tony it must be, at a time when - for all the certain election win - he looks weaker than ever, to know his friend next door is doing so much for party morale.

 Meanwhile, concern mounts that Hinduja whitewash man Skippy Hammond won't be ready next week as assumed. There is no official word as to the delay, but we gather he lost his pencil sharpener yesterday and has been taking far longer than expected to colour in the sky (let's hope he's finished by the time we deliver him his jigsaw). As for rumours that Skippy is being encouraged by No 10 to delay publication until March 7, the day of the Budget, to steal Gordon's thunder, these remain stoically unconfirmed.

 By way of celebrating his tremendous success, Lord Macdonald spoke yesterday at a central London conference entitled Rail Renaissance. He was scheduled to be introduced by IPPR thinktank director Matthew Taylor, but the latter's train from Leicester sat by the platform for an hour before leaving. Still, say what you will about Gus, he always confronts the truth, however embarrassing, and when Matthew finally arrived it was to knowing looks and fraternal winks from an audience told by the transport minister that the reason for his lateness was having been out on the tiles the night before.

 This minor duplicity brings Gus in half a point in the Turncoat of Turncoats of betting. He is now outright 9-2 second favourite, behind Peter Hain who drifts slightly but still leads the market at 7-4. Meanwhile, discussions with website political supremo Oofy Wegg-Prosser have concluded, Oofy agreeing to put a full runners and riders form guide on the site in a little under three weeks' time.

 And so to misdial victim ("If you call again," he was told, "I'll be coming after you") Steve Chalke, whose sermon on conflict of interest includes the extremely topical line (from Matthew 7): "Judge not, that ye be not judged." Quite so. Speaking of conflict of interest, says my colleague Marina Hyde, what happened on Sunday when on GMTV you were the impartial referee of a debate about Faithworks, a Christian charity which in fact you run yourself? "No, I didn't declare an interest," chirps Steve. "GMTV just told me to discuss Faithworks, so that's what I did. But I did think I was an impartial referee." Excellent. The Rev's thoughts on the Hinduja affair follow shortly.

 Anyone needing advice about how to handle cold calls from political parties in the months ahead will be indebted to Stanley Gentry from Hastings for his magnificent email narrative, slightly abridged here. "My wife is upstairs. I answer the phone. 'Gentry!' 'Is that Mrs Gentry?' asks a rather important female. I am 75, bald and growing a beard. I am sure some of it shows, even over the phone! 'Whom shall I say is calling?' 'IT IS ONE OF THE MAIN POLITICAL PARTIES!' I don't do the Grauniad Quick Crossword each day in 15 minutes for nothing. 'Do they still have those?' Stunned, disbelieving pause .. 'Er, ha ha ha. Yes, I'm afraid they do.' 'Well, just you enjoy it, dear.' CLUNK !!!." Hats off, Mr Gentry. Cracking stuff.

webTitle: Comment: Wearing a T-shirt makes you a terrorist

fields.headline: Wearing a T-shirt makes you a terrorist
fields.standfirst:
Anything with a slogan could put you outside the law now

Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: Anything with a slogan could put you outside the law now.
fields.body:
Britain, Tony Blair announced at Labour's spring conference on Sunday, is on the brink of "the biggest progressive political advance for a century". To prepare for this brave new world, two days before his speech Mr Blair bombed Baghdad. On Monday, the progressive era was officially launched, with the implementation of an inclusive piece of legislation called the Terrorism Act 2000.

Terror, in the new progressive age, is no longer the preserve of the aristocracy of violence. Today almost anyone can participate, just as long as she or he wants to change the world.

Beating people up, even killing them, is not terrorism, unless it is "designed to influence the government" or conducted "for the purpose of advancing a political, religious or ideological cause". But since Monday you can become a terrorist without having to harm a living being, provided you believe in something.

In that case, causing "serious damage to property" or interfering with "an electronic system" will do. Or simply promoting or encouraging such acts, or associating with the people who perform them, or failing to tell the police what they are planning. Or, for that matter, wearing a T-shirt or a badge which might "arouse reasonable suspicion" that you sympathise with their activities.

In his speech on Sunday, Tony Blair called for a "revolution" in our schools, and spoke of "noble causes... asking us to hear their cry for help and answer by action". So perhaps we should not be surprised to learn that you can can now become a terrorist by supporting government policy.

British subjects writing pamphlets or giving lectures demanding a revolution in Iraq can be prosecuted under the new act for "incitement" of armed struggles overseas. The same clause leaves the government free to bomb Baghdad, however, as "nothing in this section imposes criminal liability on any person acting on behalf of, or holding office under, the crown."

By such means, our new century of progressive politics will be distinguished from those which have gone before. There will be no place, for example, for violent conspiracies like the Commons Preservation Society. The CPS launched its campaign of terror in 1865, by hiring a trainload of labourers to dismantle the railings around Berkhamstead Common, thus seriously damaging the property of the noble lord who had just enclosed it.

The CPS later split into two splinter groups called the Open Spaces Society and the National Trust. Under the new legislation, these subversive factions would have been banned.

Nor will the state tolerate dangerous malefactors such as the woman who claimed "there is something that governments care far more for than human life, and that is the security of property, and so it is through property that we shall strike the enemy" and "the argument of the broken windowpane is the most valuable argument in modern politics". Emmeline Pankhurst and her followers, under the act, could have been jailed for life for damaging property to advance a political or ideological cause.

Indeed, had the government's new progressive powers been in force, these cells could have been stamped out before anyone had been poisoned by their politics. The act permits police to cordon off an area in which direct action is likely to take place, and arrest anyone refusing to leave it.

Anyone believed to be plotting an action can be stopped and searched, and the protest materials she or he is carrying confiscated. Or, if they prefer, the police can seize people who may be about to commit an offence and hold them incommunicado for up to seven days.

Under the new act, the women who caused serious damage to a Hawk jet bound for East Timor could have been intercepted and imprisoned as terrorists long before they interfered with what Mr Blair described on Sunday as his mission to civilise the world. So could the desperados seeking to defend organic farmers by decontaminating fields of genetically modified maize.

Campaigners subjecting a corporation to a fax blockade become terrorists by dint of interfering with an electronic system. Indeed, by writing articles in support of such actions, I could be deemed to be "promoting and encouraging" them. Which makes me a terrorist and you, if you were foolish enough to copy my articles and send them to your friends, party to my crime.

I don't believe the government will start making use of these new measures right away: after all, as Mr Blair lamented on Sunday, "Jerusalem is not built overnight". But they can now be deployed whenever progress demands. Then, unmolested by dangerous lunatics armed with banners and custard pies, the government will be free to advance world peace by bombing Baghdad to its heart's content.
