fields.headline: Big Al shown up as weak in the bite department
fields.trailText: It was a 1 tonne killer with savage fangs and a lust for blood. Yet new research by a British scientist shows that the allosaurus, one of the most fearsome dinosaur predators of the Jurassic era, had a bite weaker than a modern alligator.
fields.body:
It was a 1 tonne killer with savage fangs and a lust for blood.

Yet new research by a British scientist shows that the allosaurus, one of the most fearsome dinosaur predators of the Jurassic era, had a bite weaker than a modern alligator.

The allosaurus - star over Christmas of a special edition of the BBC's Walking With Dinosaurs, The Ballad Of Big Al - stalked the earth in large numbers in the Jurassic period, terrorising weaker animals.

It was always thought to kill in the same way as its larger cousin, tyrannosaurus rex - using its powerful jaws to bite into its prey and tear their flesh.

But in research published today in the journal Nature, Emily Rayfield, of Cambridge University's earth sciences department, portrays the allosaurus in a different light - no kitten, but a carnivore of another sort.

"The allosaurus was such a successful carnivore, with such sharp, curved teeth, people imagined it would have a pretty strong bite," she said. "However, my research shows the bite is relatively weak. That was quite surprising."

Applying software used by present day design engineers to a digital image of the allosaurus skull, Miss Rayfield realised that the allosaurus had a relatively feeble bite - not just weaker than the alligator, but gentler even than a modern lion.

The allosaurus, whose fossilised remains have been found scattered widely across the US Midwest, was always known to have skull full of holes, hence its Latin name, allosaurus fragilis.

Yet Miss Rayfield's analysis shows that, like a bicycle helmet, the gaps in the skull made it both very light and very strong - strong enough to withstand massive impact forces of up to six tonnes before breaking.

This meant the allosaurus would be able to kill by striking downwards with massive force, using its teeth like daggers.

"It could be that it was a very strong social adaptation to a particular feeding strategy," she said.

"The animal could experience large forces, such as those created by an impact along its teeth row, and the skull would be protected.

"Perhaps it used its strong neck muscles to slam down on to its prey."

Miss Rayfield's study is the first to produce a detailed computer-generated image of the skull of an extinct animal. She hopes it will not be the last.

"Whereas the allosaurus skull seems to be built for lightness and strength, the skull of T-Rex seems to be very strong, with thick bones. So what I'd like to do is test the skull of T-Rex and then I'd be able to tell you who would win a head-on competition."

webTitle: Three held by letter bomb police

fields.headline: Three held by letter bomb police
fields.trailText: Police yesterday arrested three people in connection with a recent spate of letter bomb attacks across the north of England and Wales.
fields.body:
Police yesterday arrested three people in connection with a recent spate of letter bomb attacks across the north of England and Wales.

Officers arrested a 26-year-old man from Crewe, Cheshire, yesterday afternoon. They later arrested a 31-year-old woman and another man, aged 36, from the same area.

Police say they intercepted three letter bombs believed to be on their way to addresses in North Yorkshire, West Mercia and Wiltshire. The devices were defused by bomb disposal experts.

Since December, 10 Jiffy bags packed with nails and explosives have been sent to a range of targets.

Police suspected the devices were the work of animal rights activists.

The letter bomb targets have included charity shops, pet shops, an estate agents, and a pest control firm.

Five of the 10 original devices exploded, injuring a number of people. One of the victims, a 43-year-old employee of an estate agent in Patrington, East Yorkshire, sustained serious facial and eye injuries.

Peter Walker, deputy chief constable of North Yorkshire police and the officer in charge of the investigation, said of the attacks: "All the devices have been potentially lethal. People could have been more seriously injured".

Nine forces, including Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist squad and MI5, have been involved in the investigation.

webTitle: Hibernating bears keep fit in their sleep

fields.headline: Bears' winter workout may hold clues for human health
fields.trailText: Hibernating bears keep fit in their sleep, scientists have found.
fields.body:
Hibernating bears keep fit in their sleep, scientists have found.

The remarkable discovery that bears lose only a quarter of their muscle-power over 130 days of hibernation promises new knowledge of the way human strength wastes away among the bed-ridden or on long sojourns in space.

In research published in today's edition of the journal Nature, scientists point out that a human being who was inactive for 130 days would lose an estimated 90% of their strength.

Black bears spend five to seven months a year hibernating in their winter dens. Their body temperature drops to about four degrees centigrade below normal and they do not eat, drink, urinate, defecate or show any other perceptible activity.

Yet over a 130-day period of this deathly slumber, the bears lose less than 23% of their strength.

The researchers, led by Henry Harlow and Tom Lohuis from the University of Wyoming, suggest that there are three possible ways to keep good muscle tone while apparently doing nothing.

One is by stimulating the muscles unconsciously and rhythmically, for example by shivering.

The alternatives, since muscles are ultimately agglomerations of the very complicated molecules known as proteins, is to have a system in the body which recycles waste back into proteins, or draws on protein reserves outside the muscles.

The scientists still do not know how the bear does it. But they say: "Understanding these processes in hibernating bears may provide new insight into treating muscle disorders and into the effects of prolonged hospital-bed confinement, antigravity and long-distance space travel on humans."

Researchers from Wyoming, Colorado and Minneapolis found in an earlier study that muscle samples from black bears at the start and finish of denning show scarcely any of the muscular degradation, at cell level, seen in humans and rodents whose muscles are affected by inactivity or hunger.

In the latest study, intrepid researchers twice crept into the dens of six hibernating bears once in autumn, once in spring and attached a machine for measuring muscle strength to one of the bear's hind legs.

The device, rather like a foot pump for car tyres, was hooked up to a computer and a box which sent electrical impulses to the bear's nerve. When the nerve was stimulated, the leg jerked and a measurement of the bear's strength was taken.

Researchers from Wyoming, Colorado and Minneapolis found in an earlier study that muscle samples from black bears at the start and finish of denning show scarcely any of the muscular degradation, at cell level, seen in humans and rodents whose muscles are affected by inactivity or hunger. In the latest study, intrepid researchers twice crept into the dens of six hibernating bears once in autumn, once in spring and attached a machine for measuring muscle strength to one of the bear's hind legs. The device, rather like a foot pump for car tyres, was hooked up to a computer and a box which sent electrical impulses to the bear's nerve. When the nerve was stimulated, the leg jerked and a measurement of the bear's strength was taken.

webTitle: Battle to cut teenage pregnancy rate

fields.headline: Battle to cut teenage pregnancy rate
fields.standfirst: Ideal of giving young parents the chance to complete their education, so as to help tackle 'unacceptably high' figure, may become reality
fields.trailText: Ideal of giving young parents the chance to complete their education, so as to help tackle 'unacceptably high' figure, may become reality.
fields.body:
Britain has become notorious for having the highest teenage pregnancy rate in western Europe, twice that of Germany, three times higher than France and six times that of the Netherlands.

While the rest of the continent has seen dramatic falls in teenage parenthood since the early 80s, the UK has long been the exception with a high rate which has remained static since 1977.

Each year, around 56,000 babies are born to teenage mothers in Britain with nearly 8,000 conceived by girls under 16 and 2,200 by under 14-year-olds.

The difficulty of solving the problem - described as "unacceptably high" by the employment minister, Margaret Hodge, last night - is compounded by there being no single identifiable reason for such high rates.

Poverty, poor educational opportunities, being born to a teenage mother, and lack of work opportunities are all predicators, while rates of pregnancy have been found to be highest among the most vulnerable girls, those in deprived areas and those in care.

One recent report, for the National Children's Bureau, showed a quarter of girls leave local authority care pregnant with a further quarter becoming pregnant within 24 months of leaving.

Women in deprived areas are six times more likely to get pregnant by the age of 20 than those in the most affluent areas of Britain, according to the Family Policy Studies Centre.

Figures from the Office for National Statistics revealed the number of pregnancies per 1,000 among under-18s in 1998 was highest in Lambeth, Southwark and Lewisham (82.7), Manchester (68.3), Sandwell (67.8), and Sunderland (65.5).

The areas shown to have the fewest teenage pregnancies were East Surrey (22.5), West Surrey (25.7) Kingston and Richmond (25.7), and Oxfordshire (29.9).

While the government is committed to reducing the rate, there has been widespread concern that efforts to tackle the problem of teenage parenthood should not be reduced to moralising.

A study by the Policy Studies Institute recently revealed that most teenage mothers do not plan their pregnancies.

One in four of those interviewed said they had planned to have a baby and 40% were pleased to find they were pregnant. However, a quarter were shocked or surprised to find out they were pregnant and a further quarter were "horrified".

Placing an emphasis on prevention has always been seen as an essential part of the strategy but sustained action to understand and address the needs of teenagers during and after pregnancy is now being recognised as a fundamental requirement.

There is a strong link between teenage parenthood and an increased risk of poor health, economic and social outcomes for both mothers and children, according to several studies.

Research cited by the Family Policy Studies Centre found that, compared to those who became first-time mothers in their 20s, teenage mothers were four times more likely to be living in social housing, over eight times as likely to have been lone parents, and almost three times more likely to lack qualifications, by the age of 33.

In its report, published in June 1999, the government's social exclusion unit identified three possible reasons for Britain's higher teenage birth rates: low expectations in terms of job prospects, ignorance about contraception and the reality of motherhood, and mixed messages about sex.

It concluded that these factors pointed to a "single faultline" in past attempts to tackle teenage pregnancy: "neglect".

The report advocates a four-pronged action plan, placing greater emphasis on post-natal support for teenagers with a focus on returning to education or work. "Teenagers who become parents should not lose out on opportunities for the future. "Young parents should have the chance to complete their education," it says.

Should the government's pilot scheme - which will be unveiled today, be extended -that ideal might become a reality.

fields.headline: Arms investors named and shamed
fields.standfirst: Charities, NHS trusts, trade unions and Labour party among organisations accused of compromising ethical principles
fields.trailText: Charities, NHS trusts, trade unions and the Labour party are still holding millions of pounds in arms company shares despite pressure to invest ethically, a new report reveals today.
fields.body:
Charities, NHS trusts, trade unions and the Labour party are still holding millions of pounds in arms company shares despite pressure to invest ethically, a new report reveals today.

Campaign Against Arms Trade, which conducts an annual survey to find out which organisations hold shares in the UK's biggest arms companies, has found that some of the largest shareholdings come from organisations, including the Co-op, which publicly promotes ethical policies.

Organisations whose holdings are likely to cause embarrassment for their supporters include the Leukaemia Research Fund, a charity with more than 200 research teams. It has 10,000 shares in BAE Systems, Britain's biggest arms company. It manufactures shells tipped with depleted uranium which have been linked to leukeamia and other cancers.

Depleted uranium shells were used by US aircraft in Kosovo and by British and US tanks in the Gulf war.

The Labour party, whose government pledged an ethical dimension to its foreign policy and to work for human rights - and has banned the use of anti-personnel landmines by British troops - has 34,721 shares in BAE Systems.

Publicity surrounding organisations committed to ethical trading and found to have shares in arms companies has led to some disinvestment. The Red Cross was found to have arms trade shares two years ago and has since disinvested. The Church of England has followed the lead of the Catholic Church in getting rid of its shares in arms companies.

A spokesman for the Leukaemia Research Fund said he saw no contradiction in devoting itself to curing leukaemia and investing in a company whose shells are alleged to cause the illness.

"BAE Systems is a respected British company. We need to invest widely and wisely and ensure that we get the best returns for our money. BAE Systems are not responsible for what went on in Kosovo" a spokesman said.

The position regarding the Co-op is more complicated. There are several individual societies which the Co-op Group says are separate entities and determine their own ethical policies. The Co-op Group owns the Co-op Insurance Society, one of the biggest shareholders surveyed with 21,375,136 shares in BAE Systems.

But it says CIS is a separate entity despite being owned by the group and makes its own decisions. The Co-op Group holds shares in BAE Systems, Rolls Royce and GKN in their pension fund. It is a matter, they say, for their trustees to determine.

The Labour party's response was similar. A spokesman confirmed that Labour's position on investing in the arms trade had not changed since it was "outed" a year ago. "Our pension fund investments are a matter for the pension fund trustees," he said.

Crest, the new electronic system for holding shares, means they are often held in undesignated nominee accounts so that it is not possible to trace the beneficial owner by inspecting the company register.

The law only requires that a custodian is identified and does not require the identity of the beneficial owner be publicly available. The campaign is calling for all shares to be held in designated accounts and for one shareholder to be able to request the identity of another to improve transparency and accountability.

A campaign spokesperson said: "We know that the majority of people in the UK oppose most arms sales and support ethical investment. Despite the annual naming and shaming by CAAT, hundreds of public institutions continue to compromise their own objectives and principles by taking this dirty money."

fields.headline: Delay that foiled chance of rescue
fields.trailText: As Tim Selby and his three colleagues drove down the hill, they would have seen nothing amiss. The road was lined with tall, waving banks of elephant grass and banana trees.  It was at this remote and scenic spot in the Chittagong hills that Mr Selby, a 28-year-old engineer on his second trip to Bangladesh, was kidnapped nearly a week ago.
fields.body:
As Tim Selby and his three colleagues drove down the hill, they would have seen nothing amiss. The road was lined with tall, waving banks of elephant grass and banana trees. Down in the jungle valley below, a river oozed through the dense greenery, to the croaking of frogs. It was at this remote and scenic spot in the Chittagong hills that Mr Selby, a 28-year-old engineer on his second trip to Bangladesh, was kidnapped nearly a week ago.

Five hundred yards after passing a somnolent army camp, his four-wheel drive vehicle was stopped by six tribal bandits armed with primitive flint-lock revolvers. They had barricaded the road with bamboo poles. The kidnappers forced the group out and marched them into the teak forest, up a twisting dirt track filled with dancing butterflies.

After a short discussion the kidnappers decided to send one of their hostages, Briton David Weston, back with a ransom demand together with the group's Bangladeshi driver. It was at this critical juncture that Mr Weston dithered, officials claimed last night.

Instead of raising the alarm, he stood by the roadside for the next 30 or 40 minutes, trying to convert how much the ransom demand of 90m taka - Bangladesh's currency - came to in US dollars.

"An army patrol went past. They could have stopped it and said 'Okay gentlemen, please help', but they didn't," Chittagong's commissioner, Mobaidul Islam, complained.

Instead, Mr Weston set off back to Rangamati, a lakeside hill station two hour's drive away, where he and his colleagues working for a Danish road-building company were based. He resumed his calculations in the lobby of their hotel. It was only when he realised to his horror that the ransom came to $1.8m - not $400,000 as he had earlier thought - and would be impossible to pay, that he informed the local police.

"We only found out four or five hours after the kidnap had taken place. By this time it was dark. We are not trying to defame anyone, but if we had known sooner we might have been able to rescue the hostages in the first hour and a half," Mr Islam, the region's top civilian official, said.

Last night, as negotiators met the kidnappers for the first time for face-to-face talks, more troubling questions emerged. Senior police officials in Rangamati demanded to know why the four Europeans had failed to take a police escort with them, as they had done on the same stretch of road three days earlier.

They had been due to travel last Saturday, but instead went a day earlier without informing the authorities. "They set off without us despite the fact they were required to take an armed guard," an officer lamented.

The area is notorious for robberies and kidnappings - and for its ineffective army check-posts. Members of a dissident tribal faction opposed to a 1997 peace accord with the government are known to lurk in the hills behind the paddy terraces.

Over the past three years, the faction has murdered more than 20 political rivals and tried to blow up one senior tribal leader on the same road. The Chittagong hills, close to the border with both Burma and India, only ended up in Bangladesh because of an accident of colonial topography - and have been wracked with insurgency and violent unrest for most of the past 25 years.

The 13 tribes who live here are Buddhists, rather than Muslims, and are of Sino-Tibetan descent. They have never entirely come to terms with the fledgling Islamic state in which they live - nor with the Bengali settlers who have taken much of their land.

Last night Ushatan Talukdar, a member of the tribal party which signed a peace accord, said local hostages abducted by the faction had previously been released after "seven to 10 days". This time it might take longer, he said.

The faction was criminal rather than political in nature, he added. "If they come to any harm the kidnappers will never be excused by the local people."

Mr Selby, whose family lives in Oldham, Greater Manchester, is being kept hostage within "three to five kilometres" of where he was first seized, officials believe. The army has encircled the area with an inner and outer cordon of troops. Military commanders have agreed not to use force following instructions from British diplomats - and the Bangladeshi government 240 miles away in Dhaka, for whom the hostage crisis is an unwanted embarrassment.

Mr Selby is said to be in good spirits. He has been surviving since last Friday on bananas, pineapples, coconuts and rice. The hostages have also been given biscuits and mineral water, as well as mosquito nets, anti-malaria tablets and fresh clothes. They were able two days ago to send a handwritten letter to their families assuring them they were safe, via tribal intermediaries.

Though no one knows for certain, the three Europeans are possibly being held close to the remote village of Dagan Pana, two-and-a-half hours walk from where they were kidnapped next to a red and yellow bus stop.

"We believe they are now under some kind of shelter," Mr Islam said.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Tremors caused by 'sonic boom' | Dempster on driving charge | New hope for asthma patients | Dome sale items go on display | Man in injection blunder named | Lucie's family fly to Japan
fields.body:
Tremors caused by 'sonic boom'

A series of tremors yesterday which rattled windows and shook buildings along the coast from Scarborough, North Yorkshire, to Whitby, probably originated from a sonic boom, according to seismologists from the British Geological Survey.

Dempster on driving charge

The Daily Mail columnist Nigel Dempster appeared at Richmond magistrates court, south-west London, yesterday, charged with drink-driving, following an accident at Ham Common, Surrey, near his home. The 59-year-old pleaded not guilty and the case was adjourned until March 7.

New hope for asthma patients

An asthma gene has been discovered which could help the development of more effective treatment. The find was made by a team at Southampton University's School of Medicine and two US companies, as part of a £50m asthma project.

Dome sale items go on display

More than 17,000 items from the Millennium Dome will go on public display today prior to an auction at the south London site next week. Lots include a pair of diamond-studded football boots, a giant seagull made from recycled kitchen utensils and a 6ft hamster.

Man in injection blunder named

A patient who died after an injection blunder at the Royal Sussex County Hospital, Brighton, was named yesterday as Philip Silsbury, 74, of Littlehampton, West Sussex. An inquest in Brighton, which was adjourned until May 3, heard he died on February 10 following the blunder during routine surgery, when he received an injection into a vein instead of the spine.

Lucie's family fly to Japan

The family of murdered hostess Lucie Blackman will fly to Japan on Sunday, hoping to bring her body home. Her father, Tim Blackman, from Ryde on the Isle of Wight, will meet police to find out the progress into their inquiry. The prime suspect, Joji Obara, 48, has yet to be charged.

webTitle: Explosion rocks army base in west London

fields.headline: Explosion rocks army base
fields.trailText: Anti-terrorist officers were last night investigating an explosion at a Territorial Army base in west London, which left one man seriously injured.
fields.body:
Anti-terrorist officers were last night investigating an explosion at a Territorial Army base in west London, which left one man seriously injured.

Scotland Yard was alerted to the blast by BBC staff who heard a loud bang near Broadcasting House at 7.10pm. The explosion happened in Shepherds Bush, near the QPR football ground.

At least one man was injured - Scotland Yard said his condition was not thought to be life threatening.

A team from Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist branch were last night shifting through debris to try to establish whether the device was similar to those used by dissident republicans in previous attacks.

Scotland Yard and the security services have been expecting a further strike from republicans opposed to the peace process in Northern Ireland.

It was feared that dissidents would launch a Christmas bombing campaign and when this did not materialise senior officers suspected another attack must be imminent.

It is thought the dissidents have neither the will nor the capability to detonate a Canary Wharf or Omagh-style bomb, preferring instead to use smaller devices targeted to cause maximum disruption with the minimum risk of casualties.

Scotland Yard has been on its second highest state of alert since last autumn in expectation of a further strike in the capital.

webTitle: Vanessa Feltz on London's exclusive Voyage store

fields.headline: Fashion victims
fields.standfirst: Yesterday's news that Naomi Campbell was banned from London's most exclusive clothing store for being rude to staff didn't surprise  Vanessa Feltz. She isn't welcome there either
fields.trailText: Yesterday's news that Naomi Campbell was banned from London's most exclusive clothing store for being rude to staff didn't surprise Vanessa Feltz. She isn't welcome there either.
fields.body:
Voyage, the Fulham emporium from which Naomi Campbell has been banned, was described yesterday by the tabloids as a "boutique". Good God, they couldn't be more wrong. Voyage is no mere shop where mere money changes hands for mere goods. Voyage, as fashionistas who say their prayers to "Armani, which art in Heaven" know, is a way of life. It's a cult attracting very rich acolytes, a religion based on conforming to the nonconformist.

What's more, Voyage is an establishment at which not all cash is welcome. To purchase a Voyage creation you must first be approved. Only the right kind of customer with the right kind of £800 is graciously permitted to become a "member" and spend it on a small cardigan with wiggly seams and unspectacular applique. The wrong customer with the wrong £800 may buy eight very similar but more sturdily stitched cardies at Whistles, but, wave her Platinum card though she may, she will never be one of the Elect, entitled to waltz down Fulham Road waving the elusive, exclusive Voyage bag.

Campbell was barred from Voyage allegedly for kicking up a rumpus when staff took too long to open the door. She is not famed for her politeness and Naomi-bashing is a popular sport, particularly during London fashion week, but, having fallen foul of the Voyage praesidium myself, I feel nothing but sympathy for the supermodel. The Mazzilli family who own Voyage are a touchy lot. They employ, in their own image, famously touchy staff who specialise in not recognising Julia Roberts and failing to twig who Madonna is. Both Ms Roberts and Mrs Ritchie have been refused entry to the shrine, sorry, shop.

I managed to provoke umbrage, not to say outrage, utterly unwittingly. I'd sidled into Voyage not, you understand, as a member, but with a member as a close pal. Obviously I realised that my mate was in thrall to the clothes. To me, scion of market underwear stalls, the clothes looked like they had come from Petticoat Lane. Sketchily sewn from ragged oddments of material with limp lace straggling off them, they were frail and skimpy, yet unbelievably expensive. I knew, however, that my chum lived for (and frequently at) Voyage and wouldn't have dreamed of making a derogatory remark about the clothes for fear of wounding her deeply.

What I hadn't appreciated was that Voyage isn't just about the clothes, it's about the whole flipping existential ethos. Being rarefied enough to enter the portals, you're then supposed to indulge in worship of the quintessence of the place. The doorknobs. The scent. The patina of the floorboards. The mellow chime of the till. And, most particularly, the music.

I use that word advisedly. The cacophony pouring from the speakers was such a hellishly schmaltzy combo of dolphins, wombs and humming fridge freezers it set my fillings gyrating in their cavities. "Ugh!" I said, never realising the sword of Damocles hovered about my shoulders. "Yuck!" I declared, little thinking the mark of Cain was about to smudge my maquillage. "Call this music?" And I tripped merrily about my business.

A year or so later, I was due to do a "By golly, how slim you've grown" fashion shoot. The stylist did as stylists are wont to do and rang round all the desirable fashion houses begging and cadging the odd garment to drape across the Feltz torso. Delightful creations wafted in from Chanel, Anna Molinari, Blumarine, Ghost, Robina et al. But did Voyage send over a selection? Oh no, they didn't. Short shrift is a veritable sonnet in comparison to what this poor stylist endured on the dog and bone from the touchy Mazzillis. "No, Vanessa certainly may not have clothes from Voyage. No. There was no point discussing it. Yes. Vanessa had committed that unforgivable sin. And no, there would be no earthly pardon."

So I stand with Naomi, banned from a shop that wouldn't even have me as a member. Will I sob into my chicken soup tonight? Not a bit of it, and neither will La Campbell if she has an ounce of sense. I've been dying for years to yell from the rooftops that Voyage is the Emperor's New Clothes of emporia. The skirts, with a bit of velvet ribbon up the side, cost £1,895. The coats are £3,895. The glittery shoes get stuck in the carpet and shed glitter all over the shagpile. I asked a committed Voyageophile why she did it. "There's something about the atmosphere that sends one a tad insane," she mused. "Maybe it's something in the joss sticks." Maybe.

fields.headline: Glaxo relents on Aids drugs
fields.standfirst:
Revamped pharmaceutical company cuts treatment prices for Africa

Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: Revamped pharmaceutical company cuts treatment prices for Africa.
fields.body:
GlaxoSmithKline yesterday attempted to defuse the criticism of its role in developing countries by pledging more cut price anti-Aids and HIV drugs for terminally ill patients in Africa.

The firm's chief executive, Jean-Pierre Garnier, promised to extend a scheme of low cost medicines as the newly merged group revealed annual profits of £5.32bn - equivalent to more than £14m a day.

Mr Garnier said: "GlaxoSmithKline is a new company. I have made it a priority from day one to urgently review what more we can do to significantly help in this epidemic."

Glaxo sells four out of 10 of the world's anti-Aids drugs. The company launched an initiative last year named Accelerated Access, under which Aids treatments were made available to African governments at $2 (£1.40) a day, rather than the usual $16.

Mr Garnier said the offer would be widened so that all "not for profit agencies with the ability to deliver medicines" could take it up.

The announcement drew a guarded welcome from charities. A spokesman for Oxfam said: "It's a welcome step in the right direction. At last, it's a very public recognition by a world drugs leader that prices are a key issue to millions of sick people."

He pointed out that any new drugs for tuberculosis, pneumonia and childhood diarrhoea were likely to be similarly in demand and asked: "Africa's only one continent. When will this sort of corporate philanthropy be extended across the world?" Three countries - Senegal, Rwanda and Uganda - have agreed to buy drugs under the Accelerated Access scheme and Glaxo has received interest from a further 31 governments. Mr Garnier said: "We are not going to wait for the governments to close these deals but are going to go directly to NGOs [non-governmental organisations]."

Glaxo has come under fire for taking legal action to prevent local manufacturers from making cheap copies of its drugs. Mr Garnier made it clear the firm would continue to protect its patents: "If we can furnish governments with these drugs at affordable prices, there is not much point in allowing any other company to come in."

He added that there were continuing problems ensuring that hi-tech medicines were used appropriately: "This is not like giving aspirin to a person and sending them home. There needs to be follow-up and a proper level of care."

Glaxo's sales of Aids drugs rose 14% to £1.15bn, although this included only £114m from countries outside Europe and the US.

The group's overall profits rose 11% at constant currencies, driven by a strong performance from new diabetes drug Avandia, which contributed sales of £462m. Mr Garnier described Avandia as "the star of the show", and predicted further growth as public health campaigns lead to earlier diagnosis of the condition.

Asthma drug Seretide produced revenue of £208m. It is due to be launched in the US in April and is expected to be a big seller - Glaxo predicted that it would become "the gold standard treatment for recurrent asthma".

GlaxoSmithKline's shares rose 85p to £19.20. Analysts said the figures were on target, but many are keen for more news at a briefing on drug development today.

The group revealed that the merger of Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham cost £121m in fees to bankers, lawyers and other advisers.

Mr Garnier said: "Despite some natural anxiety and hesitation, overwhelmingly our employees have embraced the new company."

fields.headline: Cocaine claim denied
fields.trailText: An employee at CSFB, the American investment bank, was named yesterday as an alleged cocaine user, on the opening day of an employment tribunal hearing.
fields.body:
An employee at CSFB, the American investment bank, was named yesterday as an alleged cocaine user, on the opening day of an employment tribunal hearing.

Lawyers for Philip Karam, a former trader claiming racial discrimination by the bank, inadvertently named "Mr Newson" as a person who used the drug. The claim emerged because CSFB is attempting to strike out Mr Karam's case, claiming that the former trader had withdrawn a series of new allegations - including the one concerning cocaine abuse - at the last minute.

Lawyers acting for CSFB branded the accusations of cocaine abuse as "scandalous and salacious", designed to cause embarrassment and damage to the bank.

Andrew Hochhauser QC, for the bank told the hearing at Stratford, east London, that Mr Karam and his legal advisers had sent anonymous documents to senior bank officials and briefed newspapers, an abuse of process. "That publicity has caused considerable distress to CSFB and certain of its employees who were subject to the new allegations."

Judith Reed, a lawyer at CSFB, told the tribunal the bank made a "very generous settlement offer" to Mr Karam which had been rejected.

In cross-examination, Ms Reed said Mr Karam closely followed the results of employment tribunals and had seen payouts of £2m.

Mr Karam, 32, of south London, started as a desk assistant at the bank in June 1998 but claims he was doing the work of a junior trader and earned a salary, with bonuses, of £44,000.

CSFB insists he did not trade and claims internal records showing his name listed under the heading "trader" are misleading. John Hendy, QC, for Karam, said City regulations insist only the person who carried out a trade can fill in this information.

The case continues today.

webTitle: Big performance from the 206 drives Peugeot profits

fields.headline: Big performance from the 206 drives Peugeot profits
fields.trailText: French car group PSA Peugeot-Citroen which hit the profits accelerator last year announced ambitious plans yesterday to tune up its operating performance over the next three years.
fields.body:
French car group PSA Peugeot-Citroen which hit the profits accelerator last year announced ambitious plans yesterday to tune up its operating performance over the next three years.

But while PSA was moving into overdrive, fellow car maker DaimlerChrysler was stuck in the slow lane, searching for a solution to problems at Chrysler in the US.

Stuttgart-based DaimlerChrysler is expected to announce plans for a special committee under chairman Jurgen Schremp to assume control of the Mercedes-Benz and Chrysler operations.

PSA announced yesterday that profits for 2000 had climbed 80% to €1.3bn (£818m) and that it was hoist ing the dividend pay-out from €2.7 a share to €5.

The group's performance has been driven by the success of models like the Peugeot 206, which is produced at Ryton, Coventry, and the Citroen Picasso. "PSA has been able to match attractive models with lean production," an industry observer said.

But the French car maker, which ranks sixth in the world, said that it was seeking to do even better in the future. Chairman Jean-Martin Folz shrugged off worries about a downturn in the European car market and said his group would be looking for a 10% share of the main western European markets - except Germany - by 2004.

At the same time the group is aiming to increase the number of models on offer and to boost sales from last year's 2.8m units to 3.5m by 2004.

But PSA, which recently commissioned a new plant in Brazil designed to increase its share of the Latin American market, is not planning to expand by buying other car makers. "We have no plans to change our strategy. Our goal is to continue to focus on organic growth."

The performance of PSA, which does not have a manufacturing base in the US, contrasts sharply with DaimlerChrysler which has announced preliminary figures showing that underlying profits almost halved last year.

The group, which is due to give further details of its financial performance on Monday, is coming under increasing pressure from investors to reverse the decline.

webTitle: Belgians say 'we'll sue Byers over Bass'

fields.headline: Belgians say 'we'll sue Byers over Bass'
fields.trailText: The Belgian government plans to sue Britain in the European Court of Justice, claiming the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, broke the Treaty of Amsterdam by ordering Interbrew to unravel its £2.3bn purchase of Bass Brewers.
fields.body:
The Belgian government plans to sue Britain in the European Court of Justice, claiming the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, broke the Treaty of Amsterdam by ordering Interbrew to unravel its £2.3bn purchase of Bass Brewers.

A spokesman for Belgium's economic minister, Charles Picque, said yesterday papers would be filed in the European court within six weeks. The legal action marks a sharp escalation in a diplomatic row over the competition ruling.

Interbrew is one of Belgium's biggest companies, best known for producing Stella Artois. The Belgian government is furious at the damage done to the firm by Mr Byers, who ordered Interbrew to sell Bass Brewers as soon as possible, at a likely loss of at least £750m.

One Brussels source said: "This is a threat from the Belgian government, intended to raise the political stakes. What they are saying is that this has the potential to be a big issue, a big problem between Britain and Belgium."

A decision to begin legal action was taken at a meeting of prime minister Guy Verhofstadt's cabinet last week. The Belgians cite article 227 of the Amsterdam treaty, which allows EU countries to sue each other for any "alleged infringement of an obligation" under European law.

The article has not been used before to challenge a competition ruling. A spokesman for the Department of Trade and Industry said ministers wereconfident their actions were taken "correctly and in accordance with the relevant laws and procedures".

Mr Verhofstadt's government believes Mr Byers' ruling was prejudiced because Interbrew was a foreign company. The Belgians claim Interbrew, with a market share of 33% , has received disproportionately harsh treatment compared to Scottish & Newcastle, which has a 26% share.

Mr Picque has also questioned the legality of Mr Byers' order that the office of fair trading vet potential buyers of Bass Brewers. The OFT has taken such a stringent view, insiders claim, that it has cleared just one bidder, South African Breweries.

The Brussels source said: "There is a risk that this could turn into a full-blown diplomatic incident. The Belgians have left six weeks' breathing space to give the UK government an opportunity to avoid that."

Britain's minister for European competitiveness, Peter Hain, was challenged about the issue by Belgium's vice-premier, Serge Kubla, at an informal meeting about energy in Manchester this week.

The European commission is reluctant to get involved: competition commissioner Mario Monti met Mr Picque last week to discuss the issue but little of substance was agreed.

Interbrew declined to comment yesterday. It is seeking a judicial review of Mr Byers' ruling in the high court.

The Belgians are hoping to keep the issue in the headlines, particularly with a general election pending in Britain. Bass Brewers employs more than 7,000 people.

Mr Picque has also questioned the legality of Mr Byers' order that the office of fair trading vet potential buyers of Bass Brewers. The OFT has taken such a stringent view, insiders claim, that it has cleared just one bidder, South African Breweries. The Brussels source said: "There is a risk that this could turn into a full-blown diplomatic incident. The Belgians have left six weeks' breathing space to give the UK government an opportunity to avoid that." Britain's minister for European competitiveness, Peter Hain, was challenged about the issue by Belgium's vice-premier, Serge Kubla, at an informal meeting about energy in Manchester this week. The European commission is reluctant to get involved: competition commissioner Mario Monti met Mr Picque last week to discuss the issue but little of substance was agreed. Interbrew declined to comment yesterday. It is seeking a judicial review of Mr Byers' ruling in the high court. The Belgians are hoping to keep the issue in the headlines, particularly with a general election pending in Britain. Bass Brewers employs more than 7,000 people.

fields.headline: Ads growth to slow - WPP
fields.trailText: The world's biggest advertising group, WPP yesterday reported a 43% increase in pretax profits but warned that a slowdown in the US economy could hit revenues in the medium term.
fields.body:
The world's biggest advertising group, WPP yesterday reported a 43% increase in pretax profits but warned that a slowdown in the US economy could hit revenues in the medium term.

Record profits of £365.7m last year were boosted by extra advertising demand from the Olympic Games in Sydney and US presidential elections and an economic upturn in Europe and Asia.

The group, which in October bought New York advertising agency Young & Rubicam to add to its stable of J. Walter Thompson and Ogilvy & Mather, raised its operating margins from 13.4% to its targeted 14%.

Turnover rose 49% to £13.9bn over the 12 months to December 31 and a final dividend of 2.55p was declared making a total for the year of 3.75p, up 21% on last time. The shares ended the day at 843p, up 14.5p.

Sir Martin Sorrell, the chief executive, said he was delighted with the performance of the group but that the level of organic revenue growth - 15% excluding acquisitions - was clearly "unsustainable".

Paul Richards, media analyst with WestLB Panmure, said: "If the US recession is shallow then WPP has the best ad brands in the business and stands to benefit most. If it is deeper and longer then WPP will benefit from having half of its business outside of the US." The broker is raising its WPP 2001 earnings per share estimates from 31p to 32p.

The company believes it is on target to hit its 2001 goal of raising operating margins to 15%.

webTitle: Powergen chief steps down and looks westward

fields.headline: Powergen chief steps down and looks westward
fields.trailText: Ed Wallis, flamboyant head of Powergen for more than 11 years, yesterday stepped down as chief executive and set his sights on turning the integrated energy group into primarily a US operation by acquiring a second American utility.
fields.body:
Ed Wallis, flamboyant head of Powergen for more than 11 years, yesterday stepped down as chief executive and set his sights on turning the integrated energy group into primarily a US operation by acquiring a second American utility.

A previous darling of the City, Mr Wallis, 61, has recently been criticised for combining the roles of chief executive and chairman, and is handing over the executive reins to Nick Baldwin, architect of Powergen's expansion into gas, telecoms and financial services. Mr Wallis will remain as non-executive chairman.

Mr Baldwin, who wants to boost Powergen's 3.1m retail customers to 5m by the end of 2002, will now head talks with E.ON, the German multi-utility, and other groups, said to include ScottishPower, interested in acquiring Britain's second-largest power generator.

But Mr Wallis insisted these talks remained at an early stage, not least because of complications in the US where Powergen last year bought Kentucky-based LG&E for £2.2bn.

The group still plans to acquire another UK power distribution company after buying East Midlands for £1.9bn in 1998 but Mr Wallis said: "Once we have done that we will not get much further here and the big push will be in the US and the next utility ... We're attracted to the mid-west and the Californian crisis doesn't put us off that."

British operations account for 50% of the group's pre-tax profits, which dipped last year to £517m from £580m, but Mr Wallis said he wanted to see the US business providing 75% of earnings in the near future.

A regulatory squeeze on UK electricity prices and rising gas prices caused most of the dent in Powergen's annual profits but Mr Wallis said wholesale power prices were stabilising and gas prices moderating. The new wholesale power market, Neta, should see prices "firming and gently rising".

The Powergen chairman, who plans to devote more time to his two boats, the opera and ballet, raised £1.4bn through the sale of two power stations to help finance the LG&E deal but has called off the planned disposal of the 1400MW gas-fired Connah's Quay plant in Flintshire.

Yesterday it sold its East Midlands metering business, worth £25m, to Siemens.

ScottishPower, meanwhile, eased its US west coast woes by securing a 3% rate rise from the public utility commission in Oregon.

webTitle: Notebook: Eyes on Ankara for the next round of crises

fields.headline: Eyes on Ankara for the next round of crises
fields.standfirst: Turkish rates sound alarm
fields.trailText: When money market interest rates toy with the 5,000% level, as they did in Turkey yesterday, it is time to take notice. The crises in south-east Asia in 1997 and Russia in 1998 showed how quickly contagion can spread through emerging markets. Already investors as far apart as Warsaw and Buenos Aires are looking nervously at events unfolding in Ankara.
fields.body:
When money market interest rates toy with the 5,000% level, as they did in Turkey yesterday, it is time to take notice. The crises in south-east Asia in 1997 and Russia in 1998 showed how quickly contagion can spread through emerging markets. Already investors as far apart as Warsaw and Buenos Aires are looking nervously at events unfolding in Ankara.

To date the Turkish crisis is seen as essentially political - the result of a simmering row between the president and prime minister which reached boiling point at the beginning of the week.

But the line between political rows and economic fallout can be thin.

The stock market is on the floor; the central and commercial banks are locked in a battle of wills - leading to a massive spike in short-term rates.

Worst of all, the row has put a question mark over how effectively the Ankara government will be able to implement an International Monetary Fund programme designed to curb rampant inflation.

Hot money is already on the way out - £3.5bn so far this week - and rating agency downgrades for Turkish debt are on the way.

The stakes are high domestically. Last year, Turkey won its long-running campaign to be considered for European Union membership. At present, income per capita is a third of EU levels. Ankara hopes that joining the European club will boost investment and trade links, and help it close the gap.

It is a big challenge: its population of 65m is growing rapidly. Simply to keep up, it needs to grow much faster than other European countries. Anything that threatens to blow apart the economic reform programme threatens Turkey's hopes for a prosperous, western-oriented future.

But as Ankara's politicians squabble the IMF faces a dilemma, too.

If President Necdet Sezer and prime minister Bulent Ecevit are unable to bury the hatchet - except in each other's backs - Turkey may be forced to devalue. That would ease the country's short-term problems but would hardly sit well with the IMF's disinflation programme - which might then be pulled, precipitating a crisis. To date, Turkey has had 16 standby programmes with the IMF. Two have been completed. Don't hold your breath for number 17.

Maestro epitaph

Ed Wallis, the old maestro of power generation, is not quite ready to spend more time listening to opera or messing about in his two boats. But yesterday's overdue decision to give up his long-standing role as chief executive at Powergen marks the beginning of the end of his era as dominant - and domineering - architect of this privatised utility.

The smaller of the two generators formed from the break-up of the CEGB, Powergen quickly surpassed the former National Power in terms of leanness, fitness and shareholder value, driving out costs and exploiting the wholesale market to boost profits.

Mr Wallis then set it on an early course towards an integrated power group, paying £1.9bn for East Midlands - acquiring 2.3m retail customers at a hefty price.

But the man who in City eyes could do no wrong fell out of favour as the cost of trying to escape the harsh UK regulatory climate and moving into the US via the top-dollar acquisition of Kentucky-based LG&E sapped investor confidence. With its growing debt and uncertain disposals policy, Powergen became an obvious bid target for larger groups, such as Germany's E.On, itself keen to enjoy the laxer US climate.

City discontent focused on Wallis'dual role as chief executive and chairman, but that masked a desire to see him out of the way so a younger man such as Nick Baldwin, of the "consumer services" approach, could address the takeover with fewer hang-ups. But Wallis's comments yesterday show he is reluctant to give up the reins as non-executive chairman, sketching out a US-oriented strategy to restore profits. A lucrative pay-off can only be a matter of time.

In confidence

It used to be the case that when a DTI document such as the draft of the Maxwell report now wafting around the trade department was leaked, it would mean an injunction. Now we get formal statements, admonishing unnamed witness who may have broken confidence.

Progress of a kind, perhaps, except for the fact that in warning that the report on the Mirror Group Newspapers float is still unfinished, the DTI has again confirmed how painfully slow its investigations department is. It is also worth noting that certain corners of the DTI are locked in a power struggle with the FSA, whose own special powers come on stream this summer

The DTI may not have leaked on this occasion - but it has had the effect of reminding us that its companies inspectors do actually exist.

fields.headline: Dissidents plan to challenge Adams
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Sinn Fein president Gerry Adams is to face a challenge for his West Belfast Westminster constituency - from a dissident paramilitary who believes the Good Friday agreement is a sell-out of republican ideals.
fields.body:
Sinn Fein president Gerry Adams is to face a challenge for his West Belfast Westminster constituency - from a dissident paramilitary who believes the Good Friday agreement is a sell-out of republican ideals.

Republican Sinn Fein, which broke away from Mr Adams's party in 1986 and continues to support violence as a means of achieving a united Ireland, is putting forward a UK general election candidate for the first time in order to highlight its quest for political status for 14 prisoners in Northern Ireland and the Republic.

No nominee has been selected but it is likely to be Tommy Crossan, the leader of Continuity IRA inmates in Maghaberry jail, Co Antrim, where he is serving 10 years for conspiracy to murder RUC officers in a gun attack on a Belfast station.

CIRA, one of the extreme terrorist groups not on ceasefire, was responsible for bombing RUC stations in Moira, Co Down, and Portadown, Co Armagh, in 1998, as well as a blast at the Killyhevlin hotel in Enniskillen, Co Fermanagh, in 1996 and is still active in border areas and Belfast. Republican Sinn Fein has said that decommissioning weapons would be "national treachery".

Mr Adams had a majority of almost 8,000 votes in 1997, but a challenger would try their utmost to embarrass the sitting MP, particularly as Sinn Fein looks for a united front to commemorate the 20th anniversary of the Maze hunger strike, when the 10 prisoners who died became republican icons.

"Adams and his people have sold out everything those 10 men died for," said Republican Sinn Fein's vice-president, Geraldine Taylor. "Our aim is to get rid of British rule, and Stormont was brought down before, but they [Sinn Fein] are now part and parcel of the British system.

"We do not have an armed wing but believe people should, by whatever means it takes, rid Ireland of British rule."

Crossan, a 30-year-old father-of-four, is being held in the same non-segregated jail as Protestant paramilitaries like the lower Shankill Ulster Defence Association commander, Johnny Adair, currently battling a government order that had him rearrested after he was freed early under the terms of the Belfast peace accord.

webTitle: Police get powers to stop home protests

fields.headline: Police get powers to stop home protests
fields.standfirst: Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: Police powers to criminalise small, peaceful yet intimidatory protests outside the homes of company directors and others were unveiled yesterday by the home secretary, Jack Straw, in a clampdown targeted at animal rights activists.
fields.body:
Police powers to criminalise small, peaceful yet intimidatory protests outside the homes of company directors and others were unveiled yesterday by the home secretary, Jack Straw, in a clampdown targeted at animal rights activists.

He also announced he would increase the penalty for sending hate mail to six months in prison, and would clarify the law so that the act covering malicious communications clearly included email and text messages.

He stopped short of meeting demands from the scientific community that company directors and shareholders should be able to withhold their names and addresses from the companies register. Instead guidance is to be issued on keeping home addresses confidential while still registering them.

The package, tabled yesterday as amendments to the criminal justice and police bill going through parliament, is addressed at the tactics used by animal rights activists trying to close down Huntingdon Life Sciences.

Liberty, the civil rights organisation, said that the proposals would affect many more than animal rights activists. "To make the right to peaceful protest a criminal offence is unnecessary, particularly as the police already have ample powers to arrest people who engage in intimidating acts," said Liberty's associate director, Mary Cunneen.

"We may well sympathise with an individual employee who has a protest outside his house. But will this law end up protecting the official residences of the rich and powerful - cabinet ministers, foreign embassies, and the like?"

Mr Straw said the government could not tolerate the criminal actions of a few extremists who used violence and intimidation to prevent people going about their legitimate business.

"We are determined to make sure that the public are protected and that lawful businesses can operate freely; and, above all, that the appalling harassment - and much worse - of the staff, directors and suppliers of these firms, and their families including children, is dealt with. Peaceful public protest is entirely legitimate, but there is a world of difference between that and the type of intimidation, threats and violence we have seen recently."

The legislation gives the police a new power to move protesters away from homes under the threat of three months in prison or a £2,500 fine if they are likely to "cause harassment, alarm and distress to the residents".

At present the law allows police to deal with assemblies of 20 or more only, and the Home Office believes that public order powers do not cover relatively peaceful protests outside homes.

Roger Lyons, general secretary of MSF, the union representing animal laboratory staff, said the measures would "protect thousands of our members, who undertake vital scientific work, from unjustifiable acts of violence and intimidation".

Natasha Taylor, of the Stop Huntingdon Animal Cruelty campaign, said the measures would not stop the campaign from closing the animal laboratories. "We are running a legal campaign which does not condone illegal activity, but history shows there are always people in the animal rights movement who are prepared to step outside the law in order to achieve an end to animal abuse."

fields.headline: Law violates sex workers
fields.trailText: We condemn last week's police and immigration raid on women working in Soho as a violation of human and legal rights (Foreign bodies, Women, G2, February 20).
fields.body:
We condemn last week's police and immigration raid on women working in Soho as a violation of human and legal rights (Foreign bodies, Women, G2, February 20). In the name of "protecting" women from trafficking, about 40 women, including a woman from Iraq, were arrested, detained and in some cases summarily removed from Britain. If any of these women have been trafficked - whether into prostitution, domestic work or marriage - they deserve protection and resources, not punishment by expulsion.

We know that a number of those arrested have fled to UK because of the war in Kosovo and have made asylum claims. Some are rape victims. Some have young children. From our experience, the draconian voucher and dispersal system deprives asylum seekers and their families of enough to eat and other basic necessities of life. It is hardly surprising if some women end up as sex workers to feed their children and themselves.

Having forced women into destitution, the government first criminalised those who begged. Now it is trying to use prostitution as a way to make deportation of the vulnerable more acceptable. We will not allow such injustice to go unchallenged.
Niki Adams
Legal Action for Women
Tony Benn MP, Ian Macdonald QC, Gareth Peirce
and other legal and immigration professionals
CrossroadsWomensCentre@compuserve.com

 The Soho raids to "liberate" victims of trafficking was an abuse of power. Women were led to believe they could expect protection, only to find themselves arrested and deported. This raid lays the basis for trafficking legislation which would give the police greater power of arrest, while the women on whose behalf they're supposedly acting would no longer need to give evidence - the police, not the victim, would testify about the truth of her situation. She would have been deported before the trial. How convenient and corrupting.

For this dehumanisation of women we have to thank people like Julie Bindel of North London University, quoted in your article, who reduce to pornographic flesh the sex workers they research. Bindel seems particularly concerned about interracial sex: "... the men [in Cambodia] want white women, the men [in Thailand] want black women". What if some gentlemen prefer blondes and others brunettes? Is this a reason to persecute women, or even men? Surely the crime of trafficking is violence against women, not sex with men.

We recently objected that some projects, some funded by the Home Office, are not independent of the police and are being drawn into "intelligence gathering". While we picketed the Home Office following the Soho raids, they evoked no protest from these projects - some girls' jobs are more important than other girls', especially if the others are "foreigners".
Nina Lopez-Jones
English Collective of Prostitutes

fields.headline: Murphy-O'Connor made a cardinal
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: The leader of the Roman Catholic Church in England and Wales, Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, was among 44 cardinals created by the Pope at a ceremony attended by 40,000 in front of St Peter's in Rome yesterday.
fields.body:
The leader of the Roman Catholic Church in England and Wales, Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, was among 44 cardinals created by the Pope at a ceremony attended by 40,000 in front of St Peter's in Rome yesterday.

It was the greatest number ever created at one time, and takes the college of cardinals, which will one day elect a new pope, to record levels.

There are now 184 cardinals, 135 of whom are under age 80 and thus at present entitled to vote at any conclave.

Pope John Paul II, 81 in May and the fifth longest reigning pontiff, told the new cardinals in their scarlet vestments: "Is that colour not perhaps a symbol of passionate love for Christ?

"Do we not see indicated in that bright red the burning fire of love for the Church which should nourish in you the willingness, if necessary, to give the supreme witness of blood?"

Each man knelt to receive his scarlet zucchetta, or skull-cap, and four-cornered biretta. The traditional, broad-brimmed and betasselled cardinal's hat is no longer presented.

John Paul has created more cardinals in his 23 years than any predecessor. All but 10 of the voting cardinals owe their preferment to him - a situation thought likely to increase the chance of his successor also being theologically conservative.

The 44 come from 27 countries, from Vietnam to Peru. The elevation of the Archbishop of Dublin, Desmond Connell, as well as the Archbishop of Westminster gives Britain and Ireland four cardinals. For the first time a majority of cardinals is non European, increasing the chance of the next pope being for the first time being one of their number; Latin America, with 40% of the world's 1bn Catholics, has 33 cardinals.

After the ceremony Cardinal Murphy-O'Connor, who was born in Reading, Berkshire, laughed off any suggestion that he might become pope - the first Englishman since Hadrian IV died in 1159.

"It's not been going through my mind at all," he said.

webTitle: 30 dead after ethnic clashes erupt on Borneo

fields.headline: 30 dead after ethnic clashes erupt on Borneo
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: At least six people were killed yesterday in a fourth consecutive day of ethnic clashes in the Indonesian half of Borneo, bringing the death toll from the violence to at least 30.
fields.body:
At least six people were killed yesterday in a fourth consecutive day of ethnic clashes in the Indonesian half of Borneo, bringing the death toll from the violence to at least 30.

A doctor at the public hospital in the town of Sampit, 480 miles north-east of Jakarta in Central Kalimantan, said seven bodies were brought to the hospital yesterday but that one of them had clearly been dead for a couple of days.

"They all were either hacked to death or stabbed with spears or other sharp weapons," he said, adding that there were very few wounded. "It seems that if people are caught they are killed. They are not allowed to escape."

As with similar unrest that has rocked Kalimantan in the past four years and claimed hundreds of lives, the latest fighting has been between indigenous Dayaks and migrants from Madura, a densely populated island off the north-eastern tip of Java.

The fighting began early on Sunday morning when locals attacked a migrant housing estate.

The Madurese responded the following day and the situation deteriorated rapidly.

The town's police chief, assistant-commander Benjamin Selawa, said that at least 57 houses in and around the town had been destroyed or burned and that a couple of thousand people had taken refuge at police stations, local government offices or in the council building.

"The town centre is calm now, but that is probably because most people have left," he said. "Things are still tense on the edge of town as that's where we're finding most of the bodies."

Neither the doctor nor the police chief would say which ethnic group had suffered more casualties. "Let's just say it is balanced," Commander Selawa said. "We don't want to inflame a situation that is being driven by revenge."

He said the area's population was fairly evenly balanced between locals and migrants.

The national police chief, General Surojo Bimantoro, said on Tuesday that two recently sacked local government officials had provoked the riot to get their jobs back, but this has not been corroborated.

webTitle: UN to tackle tragedy of world's 25m displaced

fields.headline: UN to tackle tragedy of world's 25m displaced
fields.standfirst: Uprooted and unprotected, people fleeing war and violence in their own countries are in desperate need of aid
fields.trailText: The UN is launching a major new initiative, backed by various countries including Britain, to confront the hidden problem of the 25m people displaced by war or violence within their own countries.
fields.body:
The UN is launching a major new initiative, backed by various countries including Britain, to confront the hidden problem of the 25m people displaced by war or violence within their own countries.

Although there are twice as many as there are refugees, the displaced get only a fraction of their assistance.

"The level of human suffering and loss of hope for millions of displaced people should be unacceptable in this age of prosperity," said the UN's special coordinator for the displaced, Dennis McNamara.

"If we do not get a major increase in resources very quickly, more people will simply die unnecessarily from lack of shelter, health or basic nutrition in many countries."

He warns that the displaced are a major obstacle to stability and development, in central Africa in particular, but also in parts of Asia, Latin America and the Balkans.

Richard Holbrooke, the former US envoy to the UN, was stunned by the conditions he saw a year ago in the Angolan capital, Luanda, where desperate street children live side by side with the conspicuous consumption of the political elite.

His visit sparked a new urgency among UN officials to tackle the problem of the internally displaced. They set up a network of agencies to coordinate new aid. However, the UN immediately found itself facing delicate problems of sovereignty, lack of access, and official indifference.

The majority of those displaced are completely unprotected, from military or official abuse, sexual violence, or, in the case of minors, abduction for forced military service.

All the countries concerned are deep in civil wars which have lasted for years or even decades. In many of the worst affected states such as Sudan and the Democratic Republic of Congo, rival armies not only routinely abuse displaced civilians, but have made vast areas of the country no-go areas for aid agencies.

The majority of the displaced - up to 90% in some conflicts - tend to be the most vulnerable sections of society: women and children.

The global programme for the displaced is hard to quantify, but by combining the budgets spent by various UN agencies it amounts to several hundred million dollars annually.

"What is clear is that this must be doubled or even more in many situations. For example, Burundi got less than one quarter of what it needed in 2000, Afghanistan less than half," said Mr McNamara.

The UN's new network of agencies concerned with the displaced began a detailed review last year of a first group of seriously affected countries. In Ethiopia, Eritrea, Burundi, Colombia, Angola and Indonesia it found the most acute common problems were HIV/Aids, sexual violence, lack of basic nutrition, health and sanitation, inadequate shelter, and death and maiming by land mines. The next to be studied will be Sudan, Afghanistan, Democratic Republic of Congo, and Sri Lanka.

"Unless there is a serious and renewed effort by all governments - starting with those whose citizens are the victims, and supported by those able to provide political and economic support to them - the displaced millions will produce new generations with no place to call home," said Mr McNamara.

webTitle: Mafia arrest brings police closer to boss of bosses

fields.headline: Mafia arrest brings police closer to boss of bosses
fields.trailText: Police in Sicily believe they are closing in on the mafia's boss of bosses - who has been on the run for 38 years - after capturing the manager of his financial empire.
fields.body:
Police in Sicily believe they are closing in on the mafia's boss of bosses - who has been on the run for 38 years - after capturing the manager of his financial empire.

Magistrates who have grown old hunting Bernardo Provenzano punched the air in victory yesterday after a midnight raid netted his lieutenant, Vincenzo Virga, one of the 10 most wanted criminals in Italy, in a cottage on the outskirts of Trapani, on western tip of Sicily.

Masked officers who burst into the cottage in Trapani's Fulgatore district yesterday found Virga, 64, surrounded by documents and £5,600 in cash as he watched a documentary about the 1992 mafia assassinations of two judges.

A fugitive for more than six years, he looked astonished but offered no resistance. He faces life imprisonment for murdering a judge, a journalist and a prison guard who refused to help a jailed mafioso.

A genius for figures and persuasion propelled the former peasant to the mafia's top ranks and a job ensuring - through bribes and intimidation - public works contracts were awarded to mafia companies.

"He is a magician in piloting contracts. We have caught the business brain of Bernardo Provenzano," said police chief Giuseppe Linares.

Under Virga's direction, the apparently sleepy, non-descript town of Trapani, with more banks than Italian cities five times its size, became a magnet for hundreds of millions of pounds of mafia revenue, which was recycled by investing in land developments and waste disposal.

Before going on the run in 1994, Virga mixed with politicians, financiers and artists, some of whom may be incriminated by documents in his possession.

Police believe the real damage to Provenzano is the loss of his liaison with a new generation of mobsters who know him only as a ghost, flitting from safe houses to mountain shacks.

He dares not use a phone in case it is bugged and avoids personal contact for fear of people being followed.

Letters intercepted from Provenzano's wife, brother and two grown-up sons last month, referred to winter clothing, suggesting he was in the hills. His wife, Saveria, advised him to wash his socks in cold water. Her last known meeting with him was nine years ago.

The last known photograph of Provenzano, who was convicted in his absence for the 1992 murder of a judge, was taken in 1959 and shows a heavy-set young man with brilliantined hair, a grave expression and wearing a suit.

He disappeared in 1963 and apart from a few trips abroad is believed to have remained in Sicily.

Nicknamed "the Tractor" for mowing down his opponents, he was mocked by one godfather for shooting like an angel but having the brains of a chicken.

The godfather was wrong. Provenzano's extraordinary success in eluding capture enabled him to take command of the mafia in 1993.

Uncle Binu, as he is known, steered the mob away from blowing up judges and shooting police officers towards a quieter, slyer existence of kickbacks and racketeering.

It emerged yesterday that Provenzano came within yards of being cornered last month when police caught another mafia lieutenant in a cottage outside Palermo. Provenzano was probably in a nearby house.

A leaked letter from a carabinieri general accused police of blundering in an effort to steal glory from his rival paramilitary force.

Enzo Bianco, the interior minister, held an emergency meeting with security chiefs to improve cooperation.

webTitle: Assassin claims he was hired by Spain against Basques

fields.headline: Killer threatens to tell all about Spain's dirty war
fields.standfirst: Special report: violence in Spain
fields.trailText: A French mercenary who claims to have worked as a hired assassin for the Spanish government has threatened to reveal the full workings of the dirty war launched against Basque separatists in the 1980s.
fields.body:
A French mercenary who claims to have worked as a hired assassin for the Spanish government has threatened to reveal the full workings of the dirty war launched against Basque separatists in the 1980s.

Jean Philippe Labade was questioned at a court in Madrid this week by the investigating magistrate, Baltasar Garzon, after claiming that he was paid by Spanish anti-terrorist police to kill two Basque separatists living in France.

His evidence could reveal the facts behind a campaign of bombing, shooting and kidnapping carried out by the Anti-Terrorist Liberation Group (GAL) which claimed 23 victims in the 1980s.

It could also further damage the reputation of the former Socialist prime minister Felipe Gonzalez, whose 13 years in government ended under a cloud of corruption and dirty-war scandals at the interior ministry.

Judge Garzon also called several former senior anti-terrorist officials to his court on Tuesday to explain a series of meetings they had with Labade at a prominent hotel in Madrid. The former French mercenary has said he was handed a briefcase full of Fr500 notes.

Among those who appeared in court were Francisco Alvarez, the former head of the Spanish police's anti-terrorist unit, and the former chief of police in Bilbao, Miguel Planchuelo.

Labade was a key member of GAL who met Spanish police and hired other gunmen for a campaign against Basque separatists. At the time, the armed Basque separatist group, Eta, and other terrorist groups posed a huge problem for the Socialist government, killing up to 120 people a year.

Eta's leadership was, and still is, based in south-west France.

GAL's victims included some well-known Eta members, but it also killed innocent by standers, including Spanish Basques.

Labade has been held in a Spanish prison for the past six months awaiting extradition to France, where he will serve a life sentence for killing the Eta leader Tomas Perez Revilla in Biarritz in 1984.

Labade, whose written confessions to Judge Garzon have been leaked to Spanish newspapers, claims that the Perez Revilla killing was part of a campaign he was hired to carry out by the anti-terrorist officials he met in Madrid.

He has implicated those officials in another killing in 1984, that of the Basque separatist Javier Perez de Arenaza.

Labade is known to have hired a team Portuguese mercenaries to help carry out attacks on supposed Eta members living in south-west France.

Judge Garzon, who campaigned to extradite Chile's General Augusto Pinochet, has said he is considering bringing charges of murder or conspiracy to murder against some of the anti-terrorist officials.

Most of those officials have spent time in jail for their involvement in the two-week kidnapping of a furniture salesman, Segundo Marey, who was mistaken for an Eta leader.

Court sources said yesterday that some members of the anti-terrorist team had admitted paying Labade money, but said that they thought he was just another informer.

Judge Garzon was expected to question Labade about two of GAL's most indiscriminate attacks: its bombings of the Batzoki bar in Hendaye and of the Consolation bar in Saint Jean de Luz, where 12 people were injured.

GAL's victims hope Judge Garzon will help prove that it operated as a state-funded terrorist group, thus making them eligible for compensation from the Spanish government.

Some court officials claimed this week that Labade had only decided to talk to Judge Garzon to delay his extradition to France.

webTitle: Increase in public attacks on women

fields.headline: Increase in public attacks on women
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: More women are being attacked in pubs, on the street and in other public places, particularly during the summer, according to researchers who studied casualty records at 33 hospitals in England and Wales.
fields.body:
More women are being attacked in pubs, on the street and in other public places, particularly during the summer, according to researchers who studied casualty records at 33 hospitals in England and Wales.

The increase coincided with a 16% fall in violence against women in the home reported by the British Crime Survey between 1995 to 1997.

A significant rise in the number suffering injury from violence in public, especially a 7% increase among those in their 30s and 40s, was reported over three years by accident and emergency departments selected at random by doctors at the University of Wales College of Medicine, Cardiff.

The Cardiff researchers suggest, in the latest edition of Emergency Medicine Journal, that their figures are a more reliable indicator of trends than either police investigation and prosecution records or other surveys because they reflect the actual treatment of patients, shortly after injury and when attacks are fresh in the minds of both victims and those who accompany them to casualty.

They say a previous study in just one area had found that rates of injury from attacks in pubs and on the street were higher than those from domestic violence.

Violent offences are often not reported to authorities because of difficulties in identifying attackers, or a continuing relationship with them, fear of reprisals or antipathy towards the police. The researchers also note few facilities or sometimes little encouragement to do so in the accident and emergency departments themselves.

But their study suggests that more than 900 women attending the hospitals in July 1998 were victims of violent attack. Nevertheless nearly three-quarters of all victims of assault are men and nearly half those are between 18 and 30, reflecting the heavy drinking culture of that age group.
