fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In a report headed Postal votes 'can be crucial', page 8, February 19, it was not quite correct to suggest that pilot schemes conducted in the spring of last year showed that the best way to boost electoral turnout was to "ease all the restrictions on postal balloting".
fields.body:
In a report headed Postal votes 'can be crucial', page 8, February 19, it was not quite correct to suggest that pilot schemes conducted in the spring of last year showed that the best way to boost electoral turnout was to "ease all the restrictions on postal balloting".

They showed that the most successful schemes were those involving all-postal ballots (in other words conducted entirely by post). However, the Home Office did not conclude that the best way to increase turnout was to exclude voting at polling booths and require only postal voting. It concluded that the best solution was to ease restrictions on postal ballots.

Until now postal votes have been available for those away from home in various circumstances on election day, but not necessarily ill or abroad. A "correction" in our Diary, page 22, February 16, concluding, "Let's all try to be more careful in future," was itself wrong.

In an earlier item the Diary had confused two people called Michael Stone. The correction explained that the Michael Stone to whom it intended to refer was the loyalist gunman and not Michael Stone "awaiting retrial for the Lawrence murders". Michael Stone is awaiting retrial for the murders of Lin and Megan Russell and the attempted murder of Josie Russell.

In a caption on page 3, G2, February 20, we described Jovan Raskovic as a member of the Bosnian Serb leadership. This is incorrect. Dr Raskovic was a leader of the Serb nationalists in Croatia.

In an article on page 2 of the Science section, February 15, we said: "Out of more than 4,000 types of amphibians we have reproductive information on a handful of species. The variation is enormous: blind snakes ... sea snakes ... crocodiles ..." None of these is an amphibian. They are all reptiles. London Zoo says so.

Entrants in our daily news quiz, Take five, may safely discount question 4 (C4) in the group published yesterday, page 23, G2. The question will not be taken into account when the competition is judged. The question was: Irvine Welsh's Acid House Trilogy consists of which tales? It then gave a choice of four possible answers, but omitted the correct one. Since the question is now void, here is the answer: The Granton Star Cause, The Acid House, and A Soft Touch.

webTitle: Arts: Arthur Smith on theatrical awards

fields.headline: Arthur Smith
fields.trailText: There are certain gigs that fill the comedian with dread. Student venues, for example, can be unpleasant places to play, especially when the social secretary is too stoned to have organised a microphone or a stage.
fields.body:
There are certain gigs that fill the comedian with dread. Student venues, for example, can be unpleasant places to play, especially when the social secretary is too stoned to have organised a microphone or a stage. Students are, of course, disgusting, especially when drunk. The most frightening poster I ever saw was at Southampton University. It bore the enormous legend "FREE BAR". Added in pencil at the bottom in very small letters was, "and Arthur Smith".

Mercifully I have now retired from student gigs but I did a show last week that was in some ways, even scarier. The Critics Circle theatre awards is pitifully paid and, as presenter, you are confronted by an audience of stern-looking critics. But I did OK. There were also a lot of actors who always make boisterous laughing noises. It was interesting to see the reviewers and the reviewed, who never normally meet, circling each other warily.

My job was to introduce a succession of critics who eulogised the show, writer, director etc that had won the champagne and the inexplicable Ferrero Rocher chocolates. Critics look at stages a lot but rarely stand on them. This was their afternoon in the sun but, alas, sometimes their performance skills are in inverse proportion to their analytical abilities. It was not hard to look good among the muttered perorations. Early on I made the remark that all critics must, by law, be under five feet nine, an observation that got truer and truer as each successive award-giver got shorter and shorter. Nicholas de Jong, who is of average height, looked like a towering giant.

I do not wish to diss the reviewers (do you think I'm mad?); they put on a good, informed show and afterwards one or two joined several actors and myself outside the pub next to the New Vic. The sun put on its best show of the year and we chatted in the warmth until the end of the south London sunset sent us scuttling back to our homes and our theatres.

webTitle: Letter: the church of england's PR

fields.headline: God's press releases
fields.trailText: Stephen Bates's bad-tempered stomp (Why God needs good PR, February 19) accuses the Church of England of "a manipulative, whispering style" in its approach to the media. What nonsense.
fields.body:
Stephen Bates's bad-tempered stomp (Why God needs good PR, February 19) accuses the Church of England of "a manipulative, whispering style" in its approach to the media. What nonsense.

In the eight weeks of this year the Church of England nationally has issued some 15 releases, including challenging the government on marriage and making a controversial appointment of an adviser to improve understanding of the Holocaust. Add to that the releases from the 44 dioceses and you have lots of potential stories. As for the Archbishop's trip to Nigeria: Arun Kataria, at whom Mr Bates makes a regrettable swipe, was providing material directly from the hard-hitting debate in Gusau between the archbishop and the governor of Zamfara about the forced extension of Sharia law.

I do not know if Mr Bates wrote any of it up. I do know nothing appeared. No wonder Mr Bates is cross.
Revd Dr William Beaver
The Archbishops' Council of the Church of England
william.beaver@c-of-e.org.uk

fields.trailText: You report that the Treasury won't spend this year's £18bn surplus (Brown spurns call, February 21). On the same day (Society) you describe the very positive joint review report of Kensington and Chelsea's social services.

webTitle: Letter: Clare Short writes on WTO

fields.headline: Short on conspiracy
fields.trailText: Barry Coates of the World Development Movement (Letters, February 16) claims that the World Trade Organisation agreement on trade in services locks in place privatisation and deregulation of public services. This is absolutely false.
fields.body:
Barry Coates of the World Development Movement (Letters, February 16) claims that the World Trade Organisation agreement on trade in services locks in place privatisation and deregulation of public services. This is absolutely false. He must have no respect at all for the governments of developing countries. They make up three-quarters of the members of the WTO and so hold a veto on any deals. The GATS agreement neither forces countries to privatise nor prevents regulation of public services.

The current agreement on trade in services is "bottom up". Countries register what services they want to open up. It is entirely a matter for each country. Public services are excluded. More open trade in services can help poor people and countries. For example, poor rural people lack access to credit and this is a real blockage on them being able to buy the tractor, sewing machine or van that could improve their lives. More competition and improvement of services in banking or tourism can bring real benefits to the poor.

No one has proposed any free trade in public services and it is not on the agenda for any talks in the WTO. There is so much in the real world that needs changing to improve the life chances of the poor of the world. It is sad that people like Barry Coates spend their time on conspiracy theories.
Clare Short MP
Secretary of state, Department for International Development

fields.headline: Research is good: look at the A-bomb
fields.trailText: I agree with many points made by Christopher Ball (Education, February 20), but I must strongly disagree with his devaluing of pure research.
fields.body:
I agree with many points made by Christopher Ball (Education, February 20), but I must strongly disagree with his devaluing of pure research. Of course, I am an astroparticle physicist, and it is hard to get purer than that. But I have turned down many more lucrative careers because I strongly believe in the value of pure research.

Ball's examples make the case. He calls the research that won the second world war "strategic", as if it would somehow have materialised without pure research. But the A-bomb was a direct result of fundamental nuclear physics research of the 20s and 30s, the codebreaking expertise behind Enigma comes from pure mathematics (OK, you can get purer than astroparticle physics), and the understanding of classical electrodynamics that allowed the invention of radar was one of the crowning achievements in theoretical physics during the 19th century.

This is an important point. Once a development in science gets built into our mental furniture it is hard to remember it was once on the edge of knowledge and without immediate practical benefit. I am sure transistors and lasers are the sort of research that Ball would favour, but these were only developed thanks to advances in quantum mechanics and special relativity that were the wildest of pure science early in the century.
Prof David L Wark
University of Sussex
d.l.wark@rl.ac.uk

 It is encouraging to know that trade secretary Stephen Byers "regards universities as being at the heart of Britain's future productive capacity", (£1bn pumped into university science, February 20). But the new investment will only pay dividends if the universities can attract world-class researchers. In UK universities they earn considerably less than either their overseas colleagues or their friends who have left science altogether. Evidence last year showed that some of the UK's best young scientists were going to the US and that universities were having increasing difficulties appointing good researchers. As Labour draws up its manifesto, Mr Byers must impress on his colleagues the importance of properly rewarding world-class university scientists.
Dr Peter Cotgreave
Director, Save British Science
peter.cotgreave@ucl.ac.uk

fields.headline: More rights, fewer letters
fields.trailText: Good to see both a leading entrepreneur, Anita Roddick, and a trade unionist, Annie Watson, highlight the continuing importance of "brave trade unionists" in building economic prosperity for all (Letters, February 20).
fields.body:
Good to see both a leading entrepreneur, Anita Roddick, and a trade unionist, Annie Watson, highlight the continuing importance of "brave trade unionists" in building economic prosperity for all (Letters, February 20). Successful economies are increasingly based on the combination of knowledge, talent and enterprise. Each of these develops best where people feel confident of their rights. A distinctive feature of the UK's economic success is that it is built on both increasing trade union membership and higher rates of new business formation.
Prof Tom Cannon
Manchester
proftomcannon@hotmail.com

 I am confused. Many of your letters appear to be from councils, agencies and other government departments. Should we consider their statements official policy and, if so, why are servants of the state telling the Letters page first? Perhaps if they spent less time in conversation with your readers, I could actually get through to them on the phone.
Charles Baker
Aberystwyth

 If Alastair Morton did not spend his time baiting journalists in your Letters page (February 20), he might begin delivering the half decent rail system that he alone believes presently exists.
Alastair Partington
Great Milton, Oxon

 A solution to Lord Irvine's problems (Letters, February 20): several wigs of different colours, the appropriate colour to be worn depending on which of his many roles he is currently fulfilling.
Mathias Disney
London

 Gareth McLean (TV Review, February 20) wouldn't have lasted long on the Manchester Guardian. Every Mancunian knows for a fact that Hitler's other ball was in the Free Trade Hall.
Roy Bacon
Buxton, Derbys

fields.headline: Chaps all
fields.trailText: I read Gary Younge's column (Comment, February 21) with a pleasure that almost obliterated the pain and anger I feel over Hague's recent appeal to the darkness in the British character (I couldn't believe that gay people were again having to make the distinction between themselves and paedophiles).
fields.body:
I read Gary Younge's column (Comment, February 21) with a pleasure that almost obliterated the pain and anger I feel over Hague's recent appeal to the darkness in the British character (I couldn't believe that gay people were again having to make the distinction between themselves and paedophiles). But the fact that gays had to defend themselves at all reveals the continuing paucity of the left's policy-making.
Euan Tait
Bognor Regis, W Sussex

 As a reader of both the Guardian and the Daily Telegraph, I was amused by Gary Younge's incisive article. However, I cannot share his disapproval of the word "chap". This is because I regularly use the phrase "chap who likes chaps" instead of gay man. It is friendlier, expresses my character far better and has no connotations of divisive militancy. People can condemn "gays", but everyone likes a "chap who likes chaps". Believe me, it works.
Dr Aidan Rankin
London

webTitle: Boom spells the end of Irish innocence

fields.headline: Boom spells the end of Irish innocence
fields.trailText: Charlie McCreevy sank back into his seat and watched the lights of the airport flicker past the window of the Brussels-Dublin shuttle as it taxied to the runway for take-off. In a few moments he would be bound for home and, he reflected, a hero'  s welcome.
fields.body:
Charlie McCreevy sank back into his seat and watched the lights of the airport flicker past the window of the Brussels-Dublin shuttle as it taxied to the runway for take-off. In a few moments he would be bound for home and, he reflected, a hero' s welcome.

It had been a gruelling day, but Ireland's maverick finance mini ster knew the next day's headlines would be generous. Mr McCreevy had told his fellow European finance ministers that he would not abandon Ireland's hugely successful policies of low taxation and economic expansion. Furthermore, he told the disbelieving gathering this month, the rest of Europe would be better off copying Ireland's success, not criticising it.

Mr McCreevy had been summoned to Brussels to receive an unprecedented rebuke for pursuing policies that his European partners believe will overheat the already booming Irish economy. Europe's star pupil was being rapped across the knuckles.

His defiance would have been unimaginable in an Irish finance minister 10 years ago, but after a decade of stunning economic growth, Ireland is changing at bewildering speed. Where once it tugged its forelock to Europe and held out the begging bowl for structural funds, now it struts with the brash self-confidence of the nouveau riche. "We have come of age," said Jim O'Leary, chief economist of Davy Stockbrokers in Dublin.

Wealth is ostentatious where once it was hidden. New car sales have quadrupled, with each year's new licence plate a "must have" accessory. In Dublin's gridlocked streets top-of-the-range Mercedes jostle with brand new Jaguars. House prices have soared by more than 70% in seven years, and dinner party conversations are reminiscent of London in the mid-80s. British cities such as Glasgow and Liverpool are now investment targets for Irish developers. Jobs are also plentiful; technology companies advertising in the national press offer salaries of up to IR£100,000 ($116,800).

"This place is awash with cash. People have developed the 'loadsamoney' culture that Britain experienced in the 80s. Lunch is for wimps, greed is good and everybody wants a slice of the action," wrote one commentator last month.

The benefits of growth have been very real: emigration, the scourge of Ireland for generations, has been replaced by immigration as the booming economy creates labour shortages. The Ryanair generation, once made up of young Irish leaving in search of work, has now been replaced by tourists. Rural towns have been revitalised by commuters fleeing Dublin's high prices. Tumbling unemployment, low taxes and low interest rates have spread prosperity. For the first time in their history, the Irish have money to burn: successive Christmases have seen record retail sales, and consumer debt is running at an all-time high.

But within Ireland a debate has been rumbling about whether the country has lost its identity, even its sense of humanity, in its fevered pursuit of riches. Some believe the country's proud greeting "Cead Mile Failte" - a hundred thousand welcomes - is becoming an empty one.

Critics have much to latch on to. Racism is now an ugly reality; news of Ireland's economic boom has attracted asylum seekers. In 1992, 80 people applied for asylum in Ireland. The rate now runs at 8,000 a month. It has not been a comfortable experience: rising reports of racial abuse have been matched by an unexpected harshness and coldness in the official response to asylum seekers, which seems focused on ensuring that as few immigrants as possible succeed in setting foot on Irish soil.

Wealth has also exacerbated social problems. Last week the problem of teenage binge drinking knocked Mr McCreevy off the front pages for a day: Irish teenagers are now the heaviest drinkers in Europe, drinking themselves into oblivion with sometimes shocking consequences.

Other manifestations of the boom have troubled observers. Irish theme bars have replaced real Irish pubs, while super clubs, capable of hosting thousands of people, have mushroomed. In quiet villages unsmiling doormen are becoming commonplace.

Another disappointment has been government failure to invest some of the country's new found riches in an ageing and over-burdened health system. The transport infrastructure is also creaking under the strain.

The Irish economic miracle may have been primed by generous European structural funds in the late 80s and early 90s, but the real impetus for growth has been driven internally. Central to that growth has been a determination by successive Irish governments to cut taxes and make Ireland the most attractive region in Europe for companies to move to. A consensual approach to economic planning that wrapped employers and unions into rolling wage agreements has helped. Low taxes and a young, well-educated and English- speaking workforce (40% of the Irish population is under 25) have enticed such hi-tech titans as Intel, Apple and Microsoft.

The surge in employment has also created a labour shortage, with predictions that Ireland will create more than 350,000 new jobs in the coming years and that about 200,000 of those will have to be filled by immigrants. Some will be Irish, lured back from abroad by a government campaign, but the influx of outsiders can only accelerate the changes that have swept through Irish society. Side by side with the economic explosion has been an equally dramatic upheaval in the perception of the church and of politics.

A steady stream of sex abuse scandals throughout the 90s stripped the Roman Catholic Church of its selfconfidence and credibility. Where once priests were held in almost universal respect, now they encounter ridicule. Irish politics has also been battered by crisis. Tribunals of inquiry investigating the beef industry, payments to politicians and the distribution of contaminated blood supplies have uncovered startling levels of corruption at the very top.

Charles Haughey, the former prime minister, received millions of dollars from businessmen while in office and, inexorably, other senior politicians are being drawn into the net. Last month Liam Lawlor, another Fianna Fail politician, was jailed for a week because he had not co-operated with an investigation. More political careers are expected to be ruined before the tribunals complete their work.

In an Ireland that is both cynical and obsessed by wealth, Mr McCreevy has played a smart game. His budget, so disliked by his European partners, was exceptionally well received at home. Despite corruption scandals, the government recently received 70% approval ratings.

Mr McCreevy is already planning what will, almost certainly, be a pre-election budget, and it will not be a hairshirt one. As the price of euro membership, Brussels wants Mr McCreevy to rein in the economy, to raise or at least maintain tax rates, and to curb public spending. It seems unlikely that he will play ball.

This defiance fits the public mood. "The reaction has been tinged with xenophobia and old-fashioned raw nationalism," said Jim O'Leary. "There is a vein of Euroscepticism around." According to most economists, the money will remain in plentiful supply, and the Irish will continue to - as Mr McCreevy himself once advised - "enjoy the party". But the question remains whether the Irish can balance their wealth and hang on to a society hailed as unique for its warmth and sense of community.

As one caller on Irish radio lamented: "We are becoming obsessed with wealth creation. We used to care for old people, look after the sick, watch out for the underdog. It's not too late to turn back, to hang on to the things that made us who we are." The Observer

webTitle: Bandits beware - Old Brother is watching you

fields.headline: Bandits beware - Old Brother is watching you
fields.trailText: We call it Old Brother's Great Shoot-Out. Although that sounds like the Wild West, "shoot-out" registers the violence with which Charles Taylor runs Liberia, and which he has exported to Sierra Leone and across urban West Africa.
fields.body:
We call it Old Brother's Great Shoot-Out. Although that sounds like the Wild West, "shoot-out" registers the violence with which Charles Taylor runs Liberia, and which he has exported to Sierra Leone and across urban West Africa.

"Shoot-out" is a good description of our crazy armed robbery. Around midnight Old Brother (my neighbour and boss of our extended family) was woken by a guard from next door, where an American gold-digger and his family were renting the house.Four armed bandits had leapt out of the darkness and overpowered the guard on the gate. As they forced their way into the house, the second guard had crept away to warn Old Brother.

Old Brother's reaction was entirely foolish. He grabbed his pistol, his shotgun and his pith helmet, and raced out, shouting: "Call the police!" Convinced that she was going to lose her husband, Marie first phoned for an ambulance. Then she rang the police.

Meanwhile this overweight 60-year-old was stumbling out into the darkness to find his son Madani and set an ambush. Madani crept round to the riverbank, and approached the Americans' house from behind. On the terrace in the electric light stood a young man holding a Kalashnikov rifle. Madani, 25, uses his elephant gun (I am sorry to say) to shoot stray dogs. He reckons thieves are no better than stray dogs, so he took aim and fired. There was a scream, and the bandit fell to the ground, yelling: "They done shoot me!"

His companions abandoned their hostages and ran out of the house, firing into the night. Fortunately they missed Old Brother, who was hiding in the bushes by the road. He let off both barrels of his shotgun in the general direction of the house . . . my Jeep was peppered with birdshot. When another shot came from Madani on the riverside, the thieves fled in panic. As Old Brother was reloading, one of the men came running down the road towards him. Old Brother let fly one cartridge. The robber yelled, dropping a package as he disappeared into the trees. This turned out to be a bag containing the jewels of the American's wife.

Another robber fled to the riverbank. This was a mistake. As he stood silhouetted against the surface of the water, Madani blew a hole in the smooth skin of his back. Three days later his bloated body was found floating in Dead Man's Hole, whirling on an eddy in the rapids below the Sotuba hydroelectric station.

The ambulance and the police arrived. Wisely, they kept their distance until the shooting had stopped. At daylight they picked up the bandit who had been wounded on the terrace, following his blood trail through the bushes beside the river, where he had passed out.

Meanwhile Old Brother was receiving congratulations from every side. In some countries killing armed intruders is frowned upon (or is even considered a crime). In most countries people feel that "he who lives by the gun deserves to die by the gun": if someone manages to shoot an armed bandit before he has time to kill, why should the bandit complain? A dead thief never complains.

This gang of Liberians had been terrorising Bamako for weeks. They had even attacked the house of the minister of defence - probably by mistake. When they found it was guarded by soldiers, they slipped back into the night.

Now the gang was shattered. Police morale was restored. Old Brother was the hero of the hour. As a reward, the police gave him permits for all the guns in his house, which he had previously owned illegally.

webTitle: Coffee price slump puts producers on the spot

fields.headline: Coffee price slump puts producers on the spot
fields.trailText: An international plan by coffee-producing countries to hold back 20% of exports seems to have done nothing to persuade coffee traders that world prices could soon be back on the boil.
fields.body:
An international plan by coffee-producing countries to hold back 20% of exports seems to have done nothing to persuade coffee traders that world prices could soon be back on the boil.

The prices of the best coffee bean, arabica, halved on world markets in the year to January, from 126 US cents to 63 cents a pound, slipping to 59.80 cents last week, the lowest for a generation. Robusta beans, used for blended and instant coffees, have fared much the same and now stand at around 30 cents.

Last October members of the Association of Coffee Producing Countries (ACPC) agreed to retain a fifth of exports in order to raise prices, which they say are too low to provide an economic return. Vietnam, the world's second-largest producer,has backed the plan and will hold back 2.5m 60kg bags - the standard measure for coffee and amounting to 150,000 tonnes - from the market.

In real terms world coffee prices are less than a quarter of 1970 levels. Vietnam's emergence as a major producer, accounting for a tenth of global output, is a chief factor behind a rise in world production and a slump in prices. The fall has been catastrophic for countries such as Ethiopia and Uganda, which rely on coffee for foreign exchange earnings.

After an ACPC meeting in London in January, the association's secretary-general, Roberio Silva, predicted that the retention plan would raise prices "within a month". Brazil, the largest producer, accounting for more than a quarter of world output, has so far retained 2.2m 60kg bags, more than 10% of its exports last year, Colombia 600,000 bags and Mexico 90,000 bags.

Yet, despite the mushrooming of coffee bars in the high streets of Western countries, supply still exceeds demand. The International Coffee Organisation estimates that production in 2000-2001 will be 113m bags, of which nearly 11m will remain unsold. A total of 88.5m bags were exported in 2000, and the retention by the producers of 20% of that - 18m bags - means demand should run ahead of supply, swinging the price back in the producers' favour.

This happened in the mid-70s, when frost in Brazil and disruptions to supplies from other countries reduced world output by a quarter. The price more than tripled as a result. A cutback of 20% could be expected to at least double the world price.

But the retention plan requires discipline from producers. Holding back exports leaves unsold coffee in producing countries, which growers may be tempted to dispose of in "back door" deals at low prices rather than see it rot. Burning the surpluses is one option. The other is for producers to cut acreages. But production quotas would be even more difficult to enforce than export quotas.

The low prices are, however, likely to mean "natural" cutbacks in output. Mexico, which last year harvested 6.3m bags, is this year expected to produce only 3.5m as growers find the crop uneconomic.

The tragedy for most of the 10m people who grow coffee is that, although higher world prices will benefit the ACPC, on the ground they could make little difference. Most coffee is traded down a line of dealers before export and can change hands 150 times. The growers' returns will stay meagre. A period of low prices in the early 90s left many destitute.

But around half a million coffee growers are now receiving more than three times the world price in an alternative market. They are those who formed farmers' organisations to sell directly to coffee roasting companies awarded the "Fairtrade Mark". The companies must pay a price that gives growers a guaranteed return, including a premium for social investment. Sales of Fairtrade coffee in the UK are booming - they rose by an average 47% a year between 1994 and 1999.

fields.headline: Second sight Douglas Rushkoff
fields.standfirst:
Look at me: the flipside to internet voyeurism
More net news
fields.trailText: Look at me: the flipside to internet voyeurism
fields.body:
Do reality TV and webcams indicate the future of media? Shows like Survivor, its countless clones, and the thousands of voyeuristic web sites springing up online all point to an alarming trend: we have become more interested in watching real people than crafted entertainments such as television drama and movies.

Given the quality of fictional drama these days, that's no small wonder. Scripts for television shows are conceived and written by committee, usually in a week or less. Their stories are ripped from the headlines and translated into a three-act structure with little or no regard for their thematic power or contribution to cultural conversation. In a sense, they are just acted-out (and usually watered-down) versions of something happening in real life somewhere, anyway.

In possession of remote controls and camcorders, and other interactive devices, modern audiences are less likely to submit to the hackneyed and conventional plot structures of the commercial media machine. We channel surf the dial in search of anything authentic - even if it is as mundane as the security camera at the convenience store.

Sure, Homer, Shakespeare, and Chekhov offered us windows into the human soul with dramas as authentic, or more so, than our experience of life itself. But these playwrights spent their lives honing their crafts. As the word "playwright" suggests, their works were wrought, not just written. Authentic, compelling drama cannot be cooked up overnight - however much media conglomerates may require more fodder for their cable TV schedules.

As a result, a camcorder sitting in an office (or, better, a college dormitory) now seems to have more of a chance of catching an authentic human interchange than three Panavisions on a soundstage. And we, the viewing public, appear to have gleefully adapted to our new role as media voyeurs. We live to watch.

Or do we? My friend Josh Harris, a new media artist and entrepreneur, has been living in public for the past 100 days. The site he has created, WeLiveinPublic.com, is an experiment in internet exhibitionism. He has fitted the loft that he share with his girlfriend with 32 cameras and motion sensors that follow the couple as they engage in everything as mundane as reading the paper and as exciting as, well, you get the idea. Forty thousand people have registered to watch the couple, and 5,000 of them spend at least several hours a week on the site.

This foray into exhibitionism is really just the premiere of a new web concept. Harris will be working with another company to sell webcams with motion sensors, as well as internet access, to anyone else who might want to broadcast their own lives on the web. So far, several thousand have signed up.

So, within a few months, there will be tens of thousands of people broadcasting every intimate detail of their lives to the world. Taking their cue from MTV's show Real World, these amateur exhibitionists will most likely compete for our attention by engaging in the most outrageous acts they dare to.

While big media companies will no doubt hope to capitalise on this trend by offering to scan the net for the most engaging stream of home media (based on our personal profiles and collaborative filtering), I have a sneaking suspicion that such strategies will miss the underlying passion driving the webcam trend.

It's not about watching, it's about showing.

As Harris readily admits, "it's sexy to be watched." Of course it is. It means someone cares enough to pay attention to you. It turns your every action into a work of art. But there is a difference between this quest for immortality and the work of poets past. An artist used to earn his place in our collective memory with his craft. A web exhibitionist earns attention by doing something in front of people that most people would normally do in private. It is a willingness to reveal, not an ability to conceive or create.

Is this art? For Harris, it certainly is. He is inventing the form. For the countless exhibitionists who follow in his footsteps, I am not so sure. My guess is that a webcam-based entertainment network will simply accelerate the downward spiral of sensationalism we have been witnessing on our TVs for the past couple of decades.

Maybe it will help us reach a nadir sooner, though. With proliferation comes ubiquity. We will get our fill of voyeurism and look for something more dimensional. Intentional art. And maybe a new wave of talented people from around the world will rise to create novel forms of expression, particularly suited for the webcam.

I'm glad the internet is about to be used, once again, for expression instead of passive consumption.

But, for now, I think I'll just watch.

webTitle: Cracking down on the digital pirates

fields.headline: Cracking down on the digital pirates
fields.standfirst:
Nick Dudley came across a windswept market in Scotland with ONdigital cards on sale at £40
More net news
fields.trailText: Nick Dudley came across a windswept market in Scotland with ONdigital cards on sale at £40
fields.body:
The man in the black leather jacket looks nervously around him as he is approached by another man in a dark blue ski jacket and grey woolly hat. They talk briefly, then the first man says something into a walkie-talkie. A couple of minutes later a third, younger, man joins them.

They huddle together. The younger man hands over a bundle of green cards to the first man. The second man then hurries off, slipping a card carefully into his inside pocket.

Almost immediately the ritual exchange is repeated. This time the man in the leather jacket can be heard apologising. "Sorry, we don't want to rip anybody off. It's those bastards at ONdigital. It's a tenner to reprogramme the card."

In the space of the next 10 minutes, half a dozen customers hand over their money for a working card. It is a nice little earner for the trader: the process of reprogramming takes the token techie sitting in the back of an old van just a few seconds, using a device which only costs around £50.

These exchanges are the public face of a cat-and-mouse game being played between broadcaster ONdigi tal and a loosely linked network of pirates. The green cards - a printed circuit board mounted with two chips - offer access to every ONdigital channel. That includes Sky's sports and movie channels, Film Four, pay-per-view, even the so-called "adult" channels.

Porn is a particular attraction for purchasers of the pirate cards. However carefully the name is disguised, a man may still have to account for the £6.99 monthly subscription on his credit card or bank statement. With a pirate card this is not an issue.

Whatever the reason, the pirates at Ingliston Market on the outskirts of Edinburgh are doing a roaring trade in ONdigital cards. The trade has to be attractive for buyers and sellers because, as shopping experiences go, Ingliston on a February morning is not one of the best.

The market itself is in the midst of flat potato fields with little shelter from the falling sleet and icy wind except the ineffectual plastic awnings covering the stalls. The only permanent fixtures are a blue and white toilet block and, for some reason, a huge grey concrete statue of a gorilla.

Twenty years ago the crowds came for cheap denim and dubious antiques but, gradually, the legitimate trade has faded away. There are still legitimate stalls selling everything from fruit and veg to clothes, but while most street markets have a dodgy side few in Britain are so dominated by trade in illicit goods as this one.

Online has made several attempts to contact the managing director of the market's operating company, which is based several hundred miles away in the English Midlands. Although he did not respond to our phone messages, the initial response of the person who answered our calls was to say: "We do condemn the sale of pirate goods. But you had better speak to our managing director."

Eric Robinson, head of regulatory services at Edinburgh City Council, knows of the problem at Inglis ton. "If you said to me that the majority of stalls at Ingliston were selling counterfeit goods, I'm sure my officers would not disagree with you," he says.

The problem for the local trading standards officers is the massive amount of work created by raids on stalls. To prove their case after each raid, each counterfeit item has to be identified as such by the legitimate manufacturers. "About eight stalls is the most we can deal with in a raid. We have to target them and arrive at the same time," says Robinson. "You do get swamped by the work. It ties up a huge proportion of the staff... The work involved in bringing it to court is not worth the effort."

Robinson denies this is defeatist talk, saying the department is working on "other avenues", but in the meantime the brisk business goes on. On the day of Online's visit, stall after stall is filled with PlayStation or Dreamcast games for a fiver each. Videos of films that have just hit the cinema screens are also a steal at just £5. Elsewhere, customers flip through ring binders filled with sheets listing PC or Macintosh games and utility software sometimes worth hundreds of pounds. A CD-rom crammed with programs will set you back £10 - or £15 if you look middle class.

This is also where the black economy meets the new economy. Despite there being apparently dozens of stalls competing with each other, in fact there are rather less in terms of suppliers. And much of the trade runs through a single website.

Regular customers are told the address of this site so that they can go and see what the latest offers are and make their orders. Because of the way the trade is organised there are only a limited number of discs physically available. The pirates "burn" CD-roms as necessary.

This means that not only do they not have to hold stock that might not sell, but in the event of a raid there is little to lose. Blank CDs, their main raw material, now cost less than 50p each when bought in bulk.

The website also has another customer service role. If you have problems with the software you can get advice both from the site's operators and from other users. This goes for the ONdigital cards as well, because these generally need one vital piece of information. The codes.

In common with other pay-to-air broadcasters, ONdigital uses a combination of a set-top box and a smart card that plugs into it. These cards are the size of a credit card with a gold chip near the top which is, in effect, a tiny computer. Every month a set of codes is sent out that tell the card that channels can be unscrambled. The trick is how to get the codes onto the pirate cards.

There are two main methods. The first, which was popular at places such as Ingliston until recently, auto-updated the cards with the codes as they were broadcast. These, however, are vulnerable to "electronic countermeasures" (ECMs). What ONdigital did was to send out signals that knocked out these cards while leaving the legitimate ones untouched.

The crackers, meanwhile, had developed a way of getting updated codes on to their cards. The second method takes advantage of the "parental lock" which is intended to prevent children from watching unsuitable programmes.

It uses a pin number which is set using the ONdigital box's remote control. The viewer with the pirate card uses the same method to enter nine sets of four-digit codes with a few other key presses to get another month of free ONdigital programmes.

Or they did until recently. ONdigital began sending out a signal periodically in January which prevented the cards being recognised and updated through the child lock. Within hours, however, notices were posted in internet discussion groups explaining how two legs on a pirate card's chip could be disconnected to make them write only and, therefore, in theory invulnerable to an ECM. The following Sunday, cards began to appear at Ingliston and elsewhere with a built-in switch.

For the more sophisticated user, cards at around £8 each and programmers for £50 or so are readily available from people who advertise on the internet or who run stalls at computer fairs. From internet discussion groups it is clear that many are used by groups of friends in offices or pubs.

ONdigital claims to be unworried by the problem. "We take it seriously, but it's not a major cause of concern," says a spokesman. "There are occasional outbreaks. But it comes and goes. Generally the people who suffer are the ones who buy the cards."

The crackers exchanging information across the internet believe that ONdigital is more concerned than it lets on. One website until recently opened with a screen that looked exactly the same as ONdigital's, except the slogan was changed. Instead of "Isn't it time you switched on?", it read: "Isn't it time you stopped paying?"

The website is still operating, but sports an angry threat of legal action against any ONdigital employee attempting to enter the site.

Many of the websites are hosted overseas, which would make it hard for ONdigital to take legal action to close them down. The trade itself is also international. In Europe some estimates put as high as 20% the proportion of people watching satellite television without paying.

In North America, pirates have been able to exploit differences the law between the US and Canada to openly sell hundreds of thousands of cards for DirecTV, the satellite broadcaster currently being taken over by Rupert Murdoch. The broadcaster recently got its revenge, however, after it broadcast code, piece by piece, until it was able to knock out almost every pirate card on what has become known as 'Black Sunday'. DirecTV had waited until just before the Super Bowl to launch its attack, the equivalent of hitting the UK pirates on FA Cup Final day.

The pirate internet discussion groups, meanwhile, are filled with concern that ONdigital might be plotting a similar attack. They are even more worried that ONdigital might adopt the same form of encryption used by Sky for the last three years or so. This has never been cracked.

ONdigital's official line is that it is relying on nuisance value by making it difficult to watch for free. It also points out that subscribers since May 1999 have only rented their boxes. If they cancel their subscriptions, as currently around 20% do each year, a van comes and takes the box away. Despite this there is still a saving of more than £30 a month for couch potatoes who would otherwise pay for the full package of channels.

The trade in pirate cards at Ingliston and elsewhere continues. This Sunday the men will be there, huddled against the cold, selling cards at £40 a time or upgrading them for £10. Last year Edinburgh City Council launched two major raids which brought in more than 10,000 pirate CDs and videos. The following week the stalls were full again.

They are even more worried that ONdigital might adopt the same form of encryption used by Sky for the last three years or so. This has never been cracked. ONdigital's official line is that it is relying on nuisance value by making it difficult to watch for free. It also points out that subscribers since May 1999 have only rented their boxes. If they cancel their subscriptions, as currently around 20% do each year, a van comes and takes the box away. Despite this there is still a saving of more than £30 a month for couch potatoes who would otherwise pay for the full package of channels. The trade in pirate cards at Ingliston and elsewhere continues. This Sunday the men will be there, huddled against the cold, selling cards at £40 a time or upgrading them for £10. Last year Edinburgh City Council launched two major raids which brought in more than 10,000 pirate CDs and videos. The following week the stalls were full again.

fields.headline: Line your pocket
fields.standfirst: OmniSky lets you check your email in the taxi not by phone but by handheld, says  Jack Schofield
fields.trailText: OmniSky lets you check your email in the taxi not by phone but by handheld, says Jack Schofield
fields.body:
America's OmniSky, which delivers email and web information to pocket computers, is gunning for the UK market. In a "public beta test", the first users are being offered three months' unlimited use of the system plus a Handspring VisorPhone or equivalent for £299.

"We think we're in the right position for the market to take off," says Neville Street, chief executive of OmniSky International, a joint venture between OmniSky Inc and Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation. "It's the sort of thing everybody's been crying out for."

OmniSky lets you send and receive email from up to six standard POP3 mailboxes, and is not limited to a proprietary service such as Palm.net. Users can access almost any website, not just ones that have installed Palm Query Application (PQA) software to handle requests from devices running the Palm OS operating system.

OmniSky has signed deals with more than 30 content providers to provide material for its service. These include Google, Scoot, Sports.com, Onlineweather.com, Maporama, the Wall Street Journal Europe, the Financial Times and Guardian Unlimited.

But this is no "walled garden". Users can call up any website, with the pages being reformatted on the fly by OmniSky's servers. This is similar to AvantGo's "clipping" service, but Street says it is an interactive system rather than one where users download material and read it later.

Although some of OmniSky's senior staff used to work for Palm - Street ran Palm's international operations - the service will not be limited to Palm users. In the US, OmniSky upports Palm, Handspring, and PocketPC devices such as the HP Jornada 540 series. Street says: "We want to support the devices people really want to use."

This could include smart phones based on Microsoft's PocketPC software such as the Sagem and Mondo Trium or Symbian's Epoc operating system, which is used in Psion handhelds. OmniSky plans to show a Symbian device at next month's CeBIT computer trade show in Germany. "We'll see what the response is before we commit to supporting the product," says Street.

However, getting into the European market ahead of the Palm VII (the wireless device Palm sells in the US) has led to some sacrifices. In particular, OmniSky was supposed to be based on a faster always-on system called GPRS (General Packet Radio Service).

"Clearly, GPRS is the endgame for our service," says Street. "But because GPRS has been slipping, we decided to get into the market early with a service based on GSM" [Group System for Mobiles]. In other words, a standard cellular network: BT Cellnet. This also means users have to dial the network. But Street shows that this can be done by pushing one button, and the connection takes about 10 seconds. It's slower when the network is busy, but still much faster than a Wap (Wireless application protocol) phone.

The results also look much better than you get with a Wap phone, because handheld computer screens are much bigger and may be in colour. Put the two side by side and there is no contest.

Unfortunately, OmniSky users will not be able to leave their mobile phones behind. "For the beta test, we are not going to enable the voice channel," says Street. "We'll do that later." The aim is to avoid complications, including the problems of charging for services. However, Street thinks people will have the option to pay a flat rate for a data connection to OmniSky and buy airtime separately. "We'll partner with different airtime providers," he says.

In some ways it is disappointing to see the UK service offering less than the US, but in both cases, there is more to come. In the US, for example, OmniSky also has a deal with America Online to deliver AOL's proprietary email and content in AOL format: "It's aimed at a more consumer market," he says.

In the future, there are plans to extend the instant messaging system, which only connects people to other OmniSky users, though SMS will still be available via the phone part of the service. The next version of OmniSky will also be able to read Wap sites, and in the longer term, there will be location-based services. Users will be able to find the nearest restaurant, for example, download a map showing where it is, and phone to make a reservation. Late last year, OmniSky bought NomadIQ to develop location-based offerings.

But these are extras. Street reckons OmniSky's "killer applications" are email and messaging. The core target market is therefore made up of business professionals who already use handheld computers and need a simple way to check their email from the back of a cab. "If we can get a couple of percent of those to move to wireless, I think we'll be pretty pleased," he says.

fields.headline: Review
fields.standfirst: IBM ThinkPad X
fields.trailText: IBM ThinkPad X
fields.body:
IBM ThinkPad X
X Series Basic Specification: 500MHz Intel Mobile Celeron 64MB Ram, 10GB hard drive 12.1in screen with 800 x 600 resolution, built-in V.90 modem Weight: 1.4kg Price (including VAT): £1,567.45 (with Windows 98SE) or £1,643.83 (with Windows 2000)

Most people think the IBM ThinkPad X is sleek and amazingly neat, except me. Well, it is roughly the size of an office diary, and barely an inch thick. Not bad for an ultraportable with a 500MHz Intel Celeron or Pentium III. It only looks big to me because it is noticeably bigger than the machine it is designed to replace: the ultraportable ThinkPad 240.

The 240 has become a classic, if that term can be applied to something with a shelf life of about 18 months. However, like the old IBM Butterfly keyboard, which extended, it has become a victim of the onward march of flat-screen technology. The X Series is bigger because it has a 12.1in colour LCD, whereas the 240 could only manage 10.4in.

Unfortunately, the X as tested does not derive any particular benefit from the extra screen estate. Both machines run Windows with a resolution of only 800 by 600 pixels in 16-bit colour. As a result, you cannot see any more on the screen, it just looks a bigger - though at least you can buy an X Series with a 1024 by 768 resolution screen, which is not available on the 240.

The larger screen size also makes room for a full-size keyboard and about a dozen extra keys. Again, however, the practical benefits are rather small, and both keyboards suffer from a few odd key placings. On the X Series, the most annoying is the Esc key, which is positioned above F1 instead of next to it. It is annoying to hit the F1 (Windows Help) key at all: hitting it several times a day becomes infuriating.

Oddly, IBM has still not managed to find room for a Windows key. Even more oddly, there's no key to turn on the X's novel light, which is built in to the lid to illuminate the keyboard. There are three keys to operate the speaker (volume up, down and mute), but to turn the light on you have to press the Function and Page Up keys together.

Where the X Series thrashes the 240 is in expandability, which is important in machines that do not have built-in floppy and CD-rom drives. Both can take port replicators. However, the X Series also has a neat bus connector on the underside, to mate with the optional UltraBase X2 Media Slice. This locks securely to the bottom and adds a floppy drive, a device bay, two stereo speakers, and a number of ports. The device bay can hold a CD-Rom, CD-RW or DVD-Rom drive, a 250MB Zip or LS-120 floppy, a second hard drive or an extra battery. But, instead of a stripped-down ultraportable, the result is a full-spec machine at a heavy price. And if that's what you want, you can buy something better and cheaper, even within IBM's current three ranges of ThinkPads.

Nevertheless, I'm sure IBM is right. Today's buyers want bigger, higher-resolution screens, and they want full-sized keyboards. They also want expandable notebooks because many are now buying them as their main machine, not as adjuncts to desktop models. However, if you are the sort of oddball who wants a dinky little portable that will go almost anywhere, the ThinkPad 240 will do nicely. But buy now, because stocks are unlikely to last.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst:
Send letters to online.feedback@guardian.co.uk
Please include a full postal address and telephone number. Short letters stand a better chance of being published. No attachments, please.
fields.trailText: Your mail
fields.body:
Who really wants to be a millionaire?
Hurry -this is the last week for students and academics in Britain to pitch for part of a prize fund of £1 million established by Launchit2001. This competition is backed by Cross Atlantic Capital Partners (XACP), a venture capital management firm, and Brainspark, an internet and technology incubator ,and supported by the Guardian. Details of the competition, which closes on February 28, are at www.launchit2001.com.

It is open to any individual in higher education or teams that include a student or academic staff member. The best two or more ventures will be eligible for direct investment ranging from £100,000 to £500,000. There is also a prize for The Most Innovative University. Ideal entries will have products and services that are ready to be commercialised or ideas that have passed a proof of concept. Entries will address one of four areas: new enabling technologies (including optical networking, nanotechnology, and materials science, but excluding biotechnology); internet infrastructure; enterprise software; e-communications and wireless infrastructures and applications.

Crackerjack
I have been following the 'hacker/hack' means with interest. Isn't the common sense approach to accept that the same word can have more than one meaning?

Similarly with 'cracker/crack'. It's usually perfectly clear from the context what meaning is intended.
David Harris
da.harris@ntlworld.com

Lost property
It appears that a company called Propertysellers.co.uk has registered a domain name which is a misspelling of our website, www.findaproperty.com. Its version, www.findapropety.com, takes browsers to its site rather than to ours. Because of this, your article (Online, February 15) states that we charge £29 per week, which we don't. Another error is that the article, as printed, gives the impression that we are an estate agent, or advertise property online for people wishing to bypass estate agents, neither of which is true. Quite the contrary: we work exclusively for estate agents and charge them to advertise their properties with us.
Michael O'Flynn
Michael@HallmarkProjects.co.uk

Top of the plop
Why does the chart of top 10 games list the name of the publisher?

The piece of information is of no use whatsoever. The name of the developer may be more useful since that is where the talent involved in developing the game lies. Such a listing might give readers a way of judging the likely quality of a title.

Would a similar chart of films attribute the new movie Hannibal to Ridley Scott or MGM?
Robert Knowles-Leak
Leak@triangle-group.com

Throw it away
Isn't it odd that your article by Anita Pincas on the serious business of online education, in your weekly supplement supposedly associated with science, does not mention the possibility of learning about science online?

Business yes, management yes, art yes, even how to iron a shirt, but nothing otherwise except a throwaway reference to 'even polymer engineering'.
Janice Taverne
janice.taverne@lineone.net

Too cynical
In the article about web learning (Online, February 15) Anita Pincas' comment on the way that human beings learn is not only cynical but ill-informed. There is a vast number of home educated children and adults who have proved that human beings are more than capable of independant and autonomous learning when the material is of interest and/or relevance to them. The fact that they choose their own 'curriculum' as children also makes them much more focused and self-directed learners as adults. Eva O'Rorke
EvaandMary@aol.com

Pat on head
Suzi P's "interview" with Patricia Hewitt was more akin to a press release. More pertinent - and dare I say, more interesting - questions might have been how does Hewitt think she or her ministry have helped small e-commerce businesses while they have been in government? By (covertly) increasing taxes? K Duggan
ksduggan@hotmail.com

Virus alert
Melissa, Anna Kornikova and all their Visual Basic Script cousins are surprisingly simple to avoid. Just change the file association of .vbs files to be something that doesn't execute.

The full details are at: www.merrioncomputing.com/OnlineIssue1.htm
Duncan.Jones@AIG.COM

Orange pipped
Given that the typical speed of an office wireless LAN is 11Mbps, it hardly seems appropriate to describe the 1.5Mbps of the Orange "home of the future'"wireless LAN as "high-speed".
Mike Whittaker
mikewhittaker@totalise.co.uk

GSM? DIY
You had someone asking what the letters GSM stood for. I stuck those very three letters into the Yahoo search box.

And the search result? I found six categories, 225 sites and 32 news stories for GSM. And the first link was Global System for Mobile Communications (GSM). So why don't you tell these stupid people to find out for themselves?
Keith Scott
kscott1@ntlworld.com

webTitle: Lucent faces probity and cash crisis

fields.headline: Lucent faces probity and cash crisis
fields.standfirst: Telecoms equipment maker investigates actions of dead executive
fields.trailText: Lucent Technologies, the troubled telecommunications equipment and software manufacturer, is investigating the activities of a former recruitment executive who had been imprisoned for forgery and embezzlement.
fields.body:
Lucent Technologies, the troubled telecommunications equipment and software manufacturer, is investigating the activities of a former recruitment executive who had been imprisoned for forgery and embezzlement.

The investigation into James Baughman, who died last September, comes as the American company faces mounting questions about the management and accounting controls it has in place.

Lucent has until the end of today to raise $6.5bn (£4.5bn) in financing to stem its mounting losses. The securities and exchange commission, the American regulator, is also investigating the company's accounting practices after executives uncovered improperly booked revenues at the end of last year.

Shares in Lucent have plunged from a year's high of $71 last March to just over $12 yesterday after a series of such revelations and the departure of the former chief executive.

Michelle Davidson, a Lucent spokeswoman, said that the investigation into Mr Baughman, a recruitment director, was unconnected to the regulatory investigation.

Mr Baughman's criminal background came to light after his death, when a vendor complained about billing discrepancies. Mr Davidson said that Lucent was still "reconciling billing issues" with the vendor.

Mr Baughman spent a year in prison after pleading guilty to forgery and grand theft while a high school principal during the 1980s.

He joined Lucent in 1997, when the company bought Octel, the voice information processing company.

Ms Davidson said that the company's routine employee checks for new members of staff were suspended during acquisitions.

Lucent said yesterday that it was confident of raising the additional financing it needs to help reduce a debt burden of some $5bn.

Two leading ratings agencies have warned that the company's existing debt could be downgraded to junk status unless it raises more money. Lucent would find it difficult to raise more money after such a downgrade.

Lucent is preparing to spin off Agere Systems by the end of March in an attempt to raise more cash. The company is also looking to sell other assets to reduce its debt burden - although it declined to comment on reports that it had put its Optical Fibre solutions unit up for sale.

The unit, which contributed sales of $2bn last year, was the only part of the business that achieved year-on-year profits growth in the last quarter, when the company posted an operating loss of $1bn.

Analysts believe that the sale could raise between $4bn and $8bn with the uncertainty due to the lack of available financial details.

Monica Matyjaskiewicz, an analyst at CSFB, said: "They are going to try to raise cash through any means they can."

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Spy Nozy And The Poets | The Material World | The Mancunian Way
fields.body:
Samuel Coleridge a traitor? Impossible. But it is 1797, Sam is not yet the lauded poet, and the French are about to invade. The Home Office send a spy, James Walsh, to investigate what's going on at Nether Stowey. Coleridge sends signals at night; he must be up to no good. A report goes back to London stating that "a gang of mischievous Englishmen" is at work. But, alas, Spy Nozy And The Poets (Radio 4, 2.15pm) reveals no treachery in the Somerset village for Mr Walsh to report. Fortunately, Paul B Davies's drama does find much more interesting fun - opium-taking in the Quantocks. Martin Clunes stars as Sam and Bill Nighy plays poor Mr Walsh.

The Material World (Radio 4, 4.30pm) meets the Grid - the next revolution in computing. webTitle: Analysts sceptical as Baltimore losses hit £94m

fields.headline: Security risk
fields.standfirst: Analysts sceptical as Baltimore losses hit £94m
fields.trailText: Investors in Baltimore Technologies, the Irish e-security specialist, fled yesterday as the company faced concerns from the City about the growth of its core business.
fields.body:
Investors in Baltimore Technologies, the Irish e-security specialist, fled yesterday as the company faced concerns from the City about the growth of its core business. Baltimore, which was briefly a member of the FTSE 100, saw £150m wiped off its value as its shares dropped by nearly 10% to 282p.

Analysts expressed fears that growth had come from acquisitions rather than the core business and were worried that a slowdown in its United States market would affect business.

The company said revenues had increased from £23.3m to £74.2m last year. But analysts were cautious about Baltimore's prospects for 2001.

One analyst said the company did not show the "necessary progress" in quarter-on-quarter revenue growth for its core business.

The Dublin-based firm posted pre-tax losses of £94.2m, more than the £31.4m loss it posted for 1999 but in line with expectations. Losses for the quarter rose from £18.4m to £55.2m, due to expansion in new regions according to Baltimore.

Fran Rooney, Baltimore's chief executive, insisted the company, which has more than 40 offices in 17 countries, would be insulated from a slowdown in the US economy, partly because of the global nature of the business. Only 22% of revenues came from the US.

Mr Rooney also pointed to growing demand for e-security. "The market is expected to grow several hundred times over the next couple of years."

Baltimore had £107m in the bank, he said, enough to take it to profitability in early 2002. The company did not post a dividend.

fields.headline: On message
fields.trailText: Internet portal Lycos Europe reported a deepening first half operating loss yesterday but said it expected to break even at the cash operating level by 2003-04 at the latest.
fields.body:
 Hopeful Internet portal Lycos Europe reported a deepening first half operating loss yesterday but said it expected to break even at the cash operating level by 2003-04 at the latest. The portal, listed on the Neuer Markt and France's Nouveau Marché, reported a loss at earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation level of €116.9m (£75m) for the six months to December 31. The group said this was in line with expectations; the equivalent loss a year before was €17.4m.

 Dumped E-business software company Merant said yesterday it would drop its internet consulting business after a fall in revenue. "We will continue to reduce costs in underperforming areas while increasing our investment in growth areas, such as enterprise change and web content management," chief financial officer Ken Sexton said. Merant reported pretax, pre-exceptionals profit of £1.1m for the third quarter, down from £2.8m a year before.

 Peace terms Software developer Bristol Technology and Microsoft have settled an antitrust court battle begun by Bristol in August 1998. The terms were not disclosed.

webTitle: Westminster on a loser as visitors settle for postcards

fields.headline: Westminster on a loser as visitors settle for postcards
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: A experimental move to throw open the doors of the Palace of Westminster has been hit by the curse of the dome.
fields.body:
A experimental move to throw open the doors of the Palace of Westminster has been hit by the curse of the dome.

The palace failed to attract hoped-for flocks of high-spending visitors, according to a report on the scheme, falling well below on numbers and income.

A typical visitor to the Commons and Lords during a trial period last summer turned out to be a middle class white Londoner commemorating the trip by purchasing a 10p postcard, rather than a wealthy foreign tourist shelling out for cut-crystal whisky tumblers and silk ties with a Pugin design.

An evaluation by the Commons administration committee found that visitor numbers were below "pessimistic case targets", totalling only 40,580 rather than the expected minimum of 55,980.

The net income on merchandise - mostly souvenirs - sold to visitors was only £138,551, compared with the minimum target of £478,400. The average outlay of each visitor was only £1.17, against a projection of £5 per head, leading to a loss of £15,000 on the merchandising operation. To encourage tourists to spend more on higher cost products with a Pugin theme, guides are to be told to spend more time drawing attention to the designer's contribution to the interiors and art of parliament.

The report also found that the tours of the so-called "line of route" through the palace building were dominated by local residents, with "white, educated ABC1" people from London and the south east accounting for 78% of the total. The rest came from the US, Australia and Europe, with few from the UK regions.

Despite the setbacks, the tour is likely to be trialled again next summer, with the tickets remaining at £3.50, which can be bought on the day rather than having to be pre-booked.

fields.headline: Coke and Pringles join forces
fields.trailText: Two of the world's biggest consumer products companies - Coca Cola and Procter & Gamble - are to form a company selling juices and snacks.
fields.body:
Two of the world's biggest consumer products companies - Coca Cola and Procter & Gamble - are to form a company selling juices and snacks.

The new company, which is yet to be named, will unite the Minute Maid and Five-Alive soft drinks brands owned by Coca-Cola with Pringles crisps and Sunny Delight juice.

On its own, the new company will have annual sales of more than $4bn (£2.77bn), making it one of the 500 largest companies in the US.

Wall Street analysts said that the deal was designed to lift declining food and beverage sales at Procter & Gamble and to allow Coca-Cola to compete more effectively against Pepsi.

As sales of its trademark carbonated drink have fallen, Pepsi has gained ground against the world's largest soft drinks group by expanding its non-fizzy drinks brands. Its purchase of Quaker Oats, which owns Gatorade, emphasised the gap last year.

Coca-Cola and Procter & Gamble said they could save up to $200m within four years by pooling Coca-Cola's distribution network in more than 200 countries with Procter & Gamble's research and development expertise. They expect sales to increase to $5bn within two years. A spokeswoman for Proctor & Gamble said yesterday that job cuts were not planned.

AG Lafley, chief executive of Procter & Gamble, said: "The starting point is dramatically increased distribution. Coca-Cola has access to 16m outlets globally. In the US alone, that represents a 10-fold increase for Pringles - from 150,000 points of distribution to 1.5m."

Pringles' crisps and bottles of Coca-Cola are similar enough in size and shelf-life to be shipped together.

Wall Street was less enthusiastic about the plans, largely because of fears about Coca-Cola's mounting marketing costs. Shares in Coca-Cola fell more than 5% after the deal was announced to less than $55 while Procter & Gamble's fell to about $47.

Andrew Conway, analyst at Morgan Stanley, reduced his earnings forecasts for the drinks company for the next two years yesterday, blaming an estimated additional $300m-$500m marketing expenditure.

Earlier this week, Coca-Cola was chosen as the sole promoter for the first film featuring Harry Potter. The deal is set to cost around $150m.

The new company is expected to employ some 6,000 people and offer more than 40 brands.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Reed deal goes to regulator
fields.body:
Reed deal goes to regulator

Reed Elsevier's plans to establish itself as one of the world's largest players in the education publishing business will be closely scrutinised by regulators after its proposed £3.1bn acquisition of American group Harcourt General was referred to the competition commission.

Analysts expected Reed might be forced to dispose of one or two non-core publications to get the deal approved but insiders at the Anglo-Dutch firm were baffled by the focus of regulators' concerns.

Competition minister Kim Howells said the director general of fair trading had advised him "the market power which the merged company would have in the market for scientific, technical and medical journals could have an adverse effect on competition in that market".

Nationwide to back PO bank

Nationwide Building Society is to contribute towards the Post Office-based universal bank, becoming the eighth financial institution to agree to pay for its annual running costs.

Nationwide, which had been sceptical about the project, agreed to make a "significant financial contribution every year for the next five years".

Napster offers industry $1bn

Napster has offered $1bn (£694m) to the recording industry to settle the copyright infringement case that threatens to shut down the free internet song swapping service.

Under the proposal made on Tuesday, Napster would pay $150m annually for five years to Sony, Warner, BMG, EMI and Universal, and $50m to independent labels.

Napster believes it can generate hundreds of millions of dollars, mostly through monthly subscriptions ranging from $2.95 to $9.95. It has tried to reach agreements with record companies but has succeeded only with BMG's parent, Bertelsmann.

Analysts doubted the rest of the industry would allow Napster and Bertelsmann to control online distribution of their music.

Empire raises Standard

Standard Chartered pinned its future on its colonial past yesterday as the bank reported a 60% rise in underlying pretax profits to £811m. The bank derives less than 15% of its revenues from Britain.

Ties with former colonies in Asia give the bank an air of neutrality, chief executive Rana Talwar said. "Britishness is a fundamental competitive advantage," added chairman Sir Patrick Gillam.

Standard said it might seek listing in Asia or New York. Its shares rose by 45p to £10.50.

BoS opens on forecourt

Bank of Scotland has become the first bank in Britain to open a branch in a petrol station. The outlet in Dalgety Bay, Fife, is staffed from 11am and includes an interview room where customers can talk to staff in private.

webTitle: DTI censures leaks by Maxwell witnesses

fields.headline: DTI censures leaks by Maxwell witnesses
fields.trailText: A fresh storm broke over the Department of Trade and Industry's potentially explosive report into the collapse of Robert Maxwell's publishing empire last night when the DTI issued an unprecedented rebuke to witnesses in the investigation.
fields.body:
A fresh storm broke over the Department of Trade and Industry's potentially explosive report into the collapse of Robert Maxwell's publishing empire last night when the DTI issued an unprecedented rebuke to witnesses in the investigation.

The DTI, which is expected to publish the report by the end of next month, expressed its "concern" about leaks of the dossier. To distance the DTI from the leaks, the department blamed witnesses questioned by the inspectors who were appointed in June 1992. "The department deplores that witnesses may have revealed material, provided to them in confidence, to the media," the DTI said.

Breaking with its traditional rule of not commenting while investigations are ongoing, the DTI said that inspectors were yet to complete the report or submit it to Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary.

Brothers Kevin and Ian Maxwell, along with financier Larry Trachtenberg, were cleared of fraud charges after the most expensive criminal fraud case in Britain.

Kevin Maxwell's role is to be scrutinised again, it is believed. The report is said to find that he knew more about movements of cash between Mirror Group and the Maxwell private companies than any person apart from his father.

The report is also said to have concluded that Robert Maxwell looted money from the Mirror Group Newspaper's pension fund soon after taking over the paper in 1984.

The role played by the investment bank Samuel Montagu and accountants Coopers & Lybrand is also analysed.

webTitle: Hague's policy reversals take another turn

fields.headline: Hague's policy reversals take another turn
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Tories in opposition
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: William Hague and Michael Portillo have taken the art of political u-turns to new heights as they shed a series of policies in the run-up to the general election.
fields.body:
William Hague and Michael Portillo have taken the art of political u-turns to new heights as they shed a series of policies in the run-up to the general election.

Labour took great delight in pointing out that the Tories' £1,000 tax cut for married couple with young children, announced amid great fanfare yesterday, amounts to a u-turn on two fronts.

Mr Hague has failed, according to the Millbank spinners, to live up to his commitment of last July to restore the married couple tax allowance. His new pledge will only benefit 20% of parents. His original announcement amounted to a u-turn because the Tories first started to phase out the allowance under John Major's leadership.

Mr Portillo is quite open about his frequent changes in policy which now reach the grand total of 11. In an interview with Newsnight on Monday, he pointed out that Labour had no right to lecture the Tories because they abandoned virtually all their policies in the 1980s.

There is, however, a significant difference between Labour's reforms of the 1980s and today's Tory u-turns. Unlike Neil Kinnock and Tony Blair, who buried the policies of their predecessors, Mr Hague has abandoned policies which he promoted with enthusiasm in the early days of his leadership.

Mr Portillo forced Mr Hague to embark on his first round of u-turns when he took over as shadow chancellor last year, and the Tories dropped their opposition to Bank of England independence and the minimum wage.

Mr Portillo argued that it was foolish to oppose independence for the bank which had ensured stability by ending the chancellor's role in setting interest rates. He also said the minimum wage had been a success and was now widely accepted.

Then last summer Mr Hague embarked on his most significant shift in policy when he abandoned his tax guarantee. His 1999 pledge to cut taxes regardless of the performance of the economy was widely questioned because it meant he would have been forced to cut taxes during a recession.

The Tories insisted that they were refining the guarantee by pledging to cut taxes "in all normal circumstances". Mr Portillo said that he would use his first budget to trim public spending back to the average growth rate, giving him scope for tax cuts if Britain steered clear of a recession.

Amid Labour claims that the Tories would impose £16bn of cuts, this policy was quietly shelved in the autumn when Mr Portillo said the spending cuts would be phased in over three years. This would allow for tax cuts of £8bn. Tory fears over public spending led to the Tories' fifth u-turn of last year. In June Mr Hague watered down his patients' guarantee when he admitted that a Tory government would be unable to provide every NHS patient with a guaranteed waiting time.

A few months later, at the height of the fuel protest, Mr Hague initially said that he would not cave into the protests. Then days later he proposed a 3p a litre cut in the fuel duty.

As Tory MPs gathered in Bournemouth for their annual conference, the party embarked on what will probably go down as one of the fastest u-turns in British political history.

On the second day of the conference, Ann Widdecombe announced that cannabis smokers would face fixed penalty fines. Amid a general outcry, the policy was dropped within days.

In the past few weeks there have been four more policy reversals. The Tories have:

 dropped their pensions policy to wrap the basic state pension and other benefits, such as the winter fuel allowance, into one payment;

 abandoned plans to change the law in favour of the likes of Norfolk farmer Tony Martin who shot dead an intruder;

 offered a more generous version of the children's tax credit, days after describing the tax break as a gimmick.

Margaret Thatcher could be forgiven that Mr Hague is following in the steps of Edward Heath, who embarked on the Tories' most famous u-turn when he nationalised Rolls Royce.
