fields.headline: At this price?  EasyNet
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Shareholders in pan-European telecoms and internet service provider EasyNet know better than most what it has been like to ride the hi-tech rollercoaster.
fields.body:
Shareholders in pan-European telecoms and internet service provider EasyNet know better than most what it has been like to ride the hi-tech rollercoaster.

This time last year, as dot.com fever was at its peak, EasyNet shares were trading at about £25. Then, in the space of two months, they fell below 600p as the sector went into a tailspin. It is a level from which they have not recovered.

Yesterday the shares slipped 2.5p to 512.5p after chairman David Rowe reported results for the year to December 31 that were in line with expectations. Turnover was up 50% to £42m, cash reserves stood at £32m and corporate customer numbers have almost doubled to 16,200.

Yet losses ballooned from £1m a year ago to £12m. Mr Rowe's explanation is simple: EasyNet has used the cash to invest in new services such as broadband internet lines and data hosting centres so that it is well positioned to take advantage of the "one-off" opportunities presented by the unbundling of the local loop across Europe.

EasyNet's vision is to offer a one-stop shop for customers, connecting their PCs with remote data centres and the wider network - and then sending them a single bill for the service.

Yet moving deep into the red at a time when loss-making technology and telecoms firms are out of favour has hit the share price hard. Investors are doubly nervous because EasyNet is dependent on the speed at which national carriers such as BT relinquish their monopoly control of the local loops - and, as any rival telecoms firm can attest, it has not exactly been quick.

webTitle: Bulger killer's letters may be fakes, warns lawyer

fields.headline: Bulger killer's letters may be fakes, warns lawyer
fields.standfirst:
Sun publishes contested claims of threats to other inmates

Special report: the Bulger case
fields.trailText: A solicitor for Robert Thompson, one of the two boys who killed two-year-old James Bulger, yesterday cast doubt on the authenticity of letters claimed to have been written by his client and published by the Sun yesterday.
fields.body:
A solicitor for Robert Thompson, one of the two boys who killed two-year-old James Bulger, yesterday cast doubt on the authenticity of letters claimed to have been written by his client and published by the Sun yesterday.

The letters mention a threat to "leather" another boy and then claim self-defence, and an assertion that Thompson had to be stopped from punching another inmate. They were described as "menacing" by the Sun, but read more like laddish boasting.

They were handed to the newspaper by a 17-year-old arsonist, Leon McEwan, who befriended Thompson while he was in the secure unit where Thompson is awaiting the parole board hearing that could free him by summer.

Dominic Lloyd, Thompson's solicitor, described publication of the letters as "another step in a concerted campaign to vilify my client" and warned of the "dangers of relying on dubious documents".

The Sun's story follows publication in the Sunday People of what appeared to be an official report of an incident in which Thompson had tried to strangle a fellow inmate.

Lawyers for the Home Office told the high court last week that the report was a "complete fabrication". Reports of a second incident were overblown and the other teenager involved had been the protagonist, they said.

The reports had been produced to the court to justify a challenge by James Bulger's father, Ralph, to the decision by Lord Woolf, the lord chief justice, to set a tariff or minimum term of seven years and eight months for Thompson and his partner in the killing, Jon Venables. But the court held that victims' relatives had no standing to challenge a sentence.

An injunction imposed by Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss in the high court last month prevents any publication of leaks from staff and carers in the secure unit, any naming of its location or any publishing of details of Thompson's or Venables' appearance, any therapy they have undergone, or any other confidential information.

The ban would seem to cover publication of a genuine incident report by staff. But the latest stories appear to have skilfully kept within the in junction's terms. Tom Crone, the Sun's lawyer, said the paper had decided not to identify the shopping centre Thompson was said to have visited on an outing, for fear of pinpointing the location of the secure unit too closely, although there are five or six in the area.

David Yelland, editor of the Sun, said: "We have to be responsible and check facts, and we have to ensure that we are not breaking what the court has said in terms of identifying where they are.

"But there is a huge well of public interest about what's happened, and, no matter what the authorities do, newspapers will continue asking questions."

Mr Yelland said he fully supported the moves by the Sunday People to investigate the circumstances surrounding the alleged behaviour of Thompson.

"The motives of Neil Wallis [the editor] were laudable. We are not going to follow these boys, we are not going to be able to anyway.

"The Home Office have misjudged us. They think we are out to identify these boys, and we are not. What we are out to do is to tell the story."

The Sun stated that it had not paid any money to obtain the letters.

McEwan was said to be adamant that they were genuine.

fields.headline: AstraZeneca's ulcer worries end
fields.trailText: There was relief at AstraZeneca yesterday, as the drugs firm received approval from the US food and drugs administration for its new ulcer drug, Nexium.
fields.body:
There was relief at AstraZeneca yesterday, as the drugs firm received approval from the US food and drugs administration for its new ulcer drug, Nexium.

Nexium is intended to fill a gap left when the patent expires for Losec, the world's top selling prescription drug which generates a third of the company's sales.

The FDA has approved a label for Nexium which says it "demonstrates higher healing rates" than Losec. The news sent the company's shares up 255p to £31.35.

AstraZeneca's chief executive, Tom McKillop, said he was delighted with the news: "With this label we are confident of retaining our global leadership in the gastro-intestinal market."

Some analysts are sceptical about Nexium's claim to be significantly better than Losec. Others predict a short-term dip in the company's sales, as doctors are slow to switch patients from one drug to another.

Nexium suppresses the secretion of gastric acid.

fields.headline: Sandy Logie
fields.standfirst:
Campaigning physician who fought at the mission hospital bedside against Aids in Africa

Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: Campaigning physician who fought at the mission hospital bedside against Aids in Africa.
fields.body:
In September 1999, Drs Sandy and Dorothy Logie visited a hospital ward at Katete in Zambia where 50-80% of the medical patients had Aids, and where the only option was to discharge them back to their villages to sit on the bare earth and die. What the Logies saw there reinforced their desire to speak out in Britain about the plight of the continent they loved.

Logie, who has died aged 62, had himself been infected with HIV, having contracted it six years previously from a needle stick injury at the very same mission hospital. While the misfortune for him and his family was terrible enough, Logie was from the start conscious that the consequences for him were vastly different from those whose suffering he had tried to relieve with no more than a few paracetamol tablets or rehydration salts. He felt guilt that his virus was held in check by highly active antiretroviral treatment, at great cost to the NHS, when infected people in Africa have no hope of benefiting from such treatment in the foreseeable future.

Logie was born in Aberdeen and educated at Trinity College, Glenalmond: he and Dorothy met at Aberdeen University Medical School and married in 1966. Logie's early training included a stint in general practice, where he developed many of his patient-centred skills. In 1967, the couple went to the Gambia, where Logie worked as a medical officer at the Medical Research Council laboratories, while Dorothy did research into the neonatal and maternal transmission of malaria. This was a formative experience which laid the foundation for their shared interest in Africa, and concern about African health.

They returned to Aberdeen to have their first child in 1969, and Logie developed his special interest in diabetes and endocrinology (the study of the glands that secrete hormones directly into the bloodstream). In 1976, he was appointed consultant physician for Borders Health Board, at Peel Hospital, Galashiels, in the Borders, while Dorothy worked in general practice. Having helped to plan the new Borders general hospital, he transferred there in 1986. Fellowship of the Royal College of Physicians of Edinburgh had come in 1983, and in 1997 he was awarded honorary fellowship of the British Medical Association "as a mark of high esteem among the medical profession".

Logie was a compassionate and humorous man, a keen musician who performed enthusiastically with the Borders Eildon Singers. But he also had a penchant for going his own way. His main love was the Scottish mountains, and after a hike up a Munro he often failed to appear at an appointed meeting place.

He and Dorothy were early supporters of the Medical Campaign Against Nuclear Weapons, and later supported Medact and Jubilee 2000 in campaigning for the cancellation of the debt of the poorest countries.

Throughout their careers, the Logies had planned to return to medical practice in Africa. So in 1992, when consultant physicians were offered favourable terms to retire early, Logie took up a short introductory posting at St Francis Mission Hospital in Katete. His HIV infection and subsequent "coming out" in the British Medical Journal in June 1996 led to a major - but, mercifully, brief - media attention.

He continued to work as a locum physician, while following the guidelines of the government's expert advisory group on Aids.

His brave confession did lead the BMJ to call for a review of health department policy, urging it to support HIV-positive health-care workers who were practising safely, rather than excluding and therefore effectively punishing them.

In 1999, the Logies returned to Katete with Christian Aid to visit some Aids outreach and orphan support projects. Here Logie found that the social stigmatisation and ostracism of those infected that he had seen in 1993 was still blighting the lives of Zambians, especially the women. He argued that the only answer for the third world was prevention, increased openness about the illness, a reduction of stigma and, ultimately, of course, an affordable vaccine.

"Is there any hope for Africa?" he asked at the end of a BMJ Personal View (January 8 2001). "There are signs that the World Bank is at last appreciating the gravity of the situation, but prompt action by the major funding organisations is needed now.

"Is it too cynical and pessimistic a view that this may not happen until the pandemic starts to hurt the rich North?'

Logie is survived by Dorothy and their children David, Catherine and Andrew.

 Alexander Wylie Logie, physician, born November 5 1938; died February 16 2001

webTitle: Sword killer of MP aide sent to secure hospital

fields.headline: Sword killer of MP aide sent to secure hospital
fields.trailText: A father of two whose financial ruin triggered a mental disorder which led him to kill a political aide and try to stab his local MP with a samurai sword was last night sent to a secure hospital for an indefinite time.
fields.body:
A father of two whose financial ruin triggered a mental disorder which led him to kill a political aide and try to stab his local MP with a samurai sword was last night sent to a secure hospital for an indefinite time.

A jury of 12 took four hours to decide that former consultant engineer Robert Ashman, 50, of Lansdown Place, Cheltenham, was responsible for the frenzied attack on Liberal Democrat aide Andrew Pennington and MP Nigel Jones.

Ashman was originally charged with murdering Mr Pennington but a jury last week decided that he was unfit to stand trial. Instead he faced a three-day hearing to decide if he had carried out the sword attack.

Bristol crown court heard how, over a decade, Ashman's life had disintegrated as a result of a series of personal and financial disasters.

The respectable middle-class family man, caught in a downward spiral of debt and despair, became increasingly disillusioned by the "system" which he thought had robbed him of his job, his home and his family, the court heard.

Friends, colleagues and acquaintances, including staff from the MP's office who had listened repeatedly over an eight-year period to his money worries, dismissed Ashman as obsessive, but not dangerous. But beneath the surface was Ashman's obsession with what he perceived as justice.

His psychiatrist, Jacqueline Short, said that her patient suffered from delusions and paranoid interpretations which made him think everyone was conspiring against him, including the MP. When he finally came to believe that Nigel Jones was part of a conspiracy, he snapped.

At the town's Lib Dem offices on January 28 last year, he pulled a samurai sword on Mr Jones before repeatedly plunging the 3ft curved weapon into the back of Mr Pennington, 39, as he cowered on the floor.

The court heard the attack left the Gloucestershire county councillor with nine stab wounds, six of which passed all the way through his body. He died as a result.

Mr Jones fled the attack during a constituency surgery and escaped with severe cuts to his hands which needed 57 stitches and left him badly scarred.

Ashman was arrested minutes afterwards as he walked out of the office with blood dripping from the sword.

Mr Justice Toulson said Ashman was potentially a great danger and paid tribute to Mr Pennington's bravery.

He said: "Andrew Pennington must have made a conscious decision to stay when he encouraged Nigel Jones to escape while he grappled with the defendant, knowing he, was at the mercy of a man armed with a sword."

After the verdict, Mr Jones, 52, also paid tribute to the man he said had saved his life: "He was a wonderful person and we will never see his like again,"

Detective Chief Inspector Wayne Murdock of Gloucestershire police said after the hearing that Ashman had not shown any remorse during the police investigation.

He said: "He never even spoke about the actual events and he showed no remorse whatsoever."

Ashman's family refused to comment after the jury returned its verdict.

webTitle: Soul of Paris: Iconic images go on show

fields.headline: Soul of Paris: Iconic images go on show
fields.trailText: The smoky smouldering images of Paris taken by the photographer Brassai were literally that, their exposure timed by a cigarette, the curator of a major restrospective revealed yesterday.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The smoky smouldering images of Paris taken by the photographer Brassai were literally that, their exposure timed by a cigarette, the curator of a major restrospective revealed yesterday.

The exhibition, Brassai the Soul of Paris, opens today at the Hayward Gallery on London's south bank.

Alain Sayag, curator of the Pompidou Centre in Paris, said the apparent snap shots of every day life were as carefully constructed as a film set.

The Pompidou holds hundreds of original glass plate negatives and prints on long loan from the photographer's widow.

His photographs of foggy streets, and of prostitutes, drifters and low life types huddled in shadowy doorways, are regarded as iconic images of Paris, even though Brassai was neither French, nor a photographer until forced into it at the age of 30 when his career as a spectacularly unreliable newspaper correspondent faltered.

A self-portrait shows Brassai with his bulky German camera mounted on a tripod, a cigarette drooping from his mouth. The cigarette was a crucial tool of his trade.

Mr Sayag explained that the glass plates he used needed an extremely long exposure. Brassai used two exposure timers: an ordinary cigarette, and for the darkest shots, like his famous image of a statue in dense fog, a slower burning maize paper cigarette. "Those were his only two timings, so you can see that nothing is accidental, nothing can be done quickly, everything must be planned in advance, contrived and designed."

Brassai took his name from the town of his birth, Brasso, in Transylvania, where he was born Gyula Halasz in 1899.

He trained as an artist in Berlin, but when he came to Paris in the 1920s he survived as a correspondent for German newspapers. "He was making up stories and inventing interviews with people he never met," Mr Sayag explained, "but it did not matter because nobody realised."

When the German economic crisis hit, Brassai created his new identity, began taking photographs to illustrate his own writing, and published his first book of photographs, Paris de Nuit, in 1932. Many of the people in the photographs were long-suffering friends or employees.

In a sequence taken in a brothel called Suzy's, the naked or half-dressed women are all carefully keeping their faces partly hidden, but the "client" a caddish looking character, is looking straight at the camera.

The client was Brassai's assistant, who had to lug the camera, tripod, heavy glass plates and magnesium flash gun and powder through the streets of Paris.

Mr Sayag had assumed the man in another of the photographs, surrounded by prostitutes, for a genuine client.

But when he studied the negative carefully he could see it was the poor assistant again, disguised in muffler and flat cap.

fields.headline: Drugs are anti-depressant
fields.trailText: It might have been much worse. At one point the FTSE 100 was staring into the abyss after stronger than expected US retail inflation data raised the prospect of a premature end to the Federal Reserve's aggressive rate-cutting.
fields.body:
It might have been much worse. At one point the FTSE 100 was staring into the abyss after stronger than expected US retail inflation data raised the prospect of a premature end to the Federal Reserve's aggressive rate-cutting.

Then the leading shares pulled back from the brink. Off 59 points after release of the data, which showed US consumer prices in January rising at their quickest pace in nearly a year, the FTSE 100 recovered to close only 7.7 points lower at 5,972.4, much to the relief of traders.

Unlike Tuesday's session, when the blue chip index posted its biggest one-day points decline since early January, the heavyweight drugs sector provided a prop for the market. GlaxoSmithKline closed 75p higher at £19.20p after full-year figures met City expectations, while Astra Zeneca added 255p to £31.35 following US regulatory approval for Nexium, its follow-up to the blockbuster ulcer drug, Losec.

The calm reaction of the Nasdaq to the consumer price data also helped, although it failed to do much for the FTSE Techmark 100, which settled 75.40 points lower at 2,400.20 after a sell-off of alternative telecom stocks.

Atlantic Telecom (off 5p to 59p), Kingston Telecom (down 9.75p to 159.75p) and Redstone Telecom (15p weaker at 93.5p) all closed at record lows, undermined by the slump in US telecom stocks and bearish noises from ABN Amro. The Dutch broker, which lowered its rating on Kingston and Atlantic, gave warning to investors that there are too many players in the sector for all to achieve their long-term targets.

The misery continued for shareholders of telecoms testing specialist Spirent. It shares - 485p a week ago - finished 26p lower at 389p, rattled by gloomy news from a US rival, Agilent Technologies. Although the Hewlett Packard spin-off reported better than expected results, it now expects sales growth of 10-15% this year, as opposed to analysts' forecasts of 19%.

Back among the blue chips, Dixons, the electrical retailer, advanced 5.5p to 256p, thanks to ABN Amro repeating its "buy" rating after a meeting with company executives on Tuesday night. ABN was said to have come away with the impression that Dixons will meet its growth expectations.

fields.headline: Heat is on Grampian
fields.trailText: Things are hotting up at Grampian Holdings, the industrial holding company, that is reported to have received a 95p a share bid from private equity firm Alchemy Partners.
fields.body:
Things are hotting up at Grampian Holdings, the industrial holding company, that is reported to have received a 95p a share bid from private equity firm Alchemy Partners.

According to stock market sources, a number of Grampian's smaller institutional shareholders have been in touch with Alchemy to ask how they might be of assistance.

It seems the rebel shareholders, unhappy with the company's strategy and worried about the impending sale of Edinburgh Woollen Mills, are prepared to push the company into discussions with Alchemy. Grampian is rumoured to have rejected the offer as derisory.

According to market gossip, there has been only one serious offer for EWM, from venture capital company 3i. The board of Grampian is said to be meeting to consider the offer next Tuesday.

Grampian shares closed at 74.5p, after falling 1p.

fields.headline: Keith Latham
fields.standfirst: Dramatic baritone who found his métier in Verdi's repertoire
fields.trailText: Dramatic baritone who found his métier in Verdi's repertoire.
fields.body:
The heart attack that carried off Keith Latham between the rehearsal and the performance of a Verdi centenary concert in Birmingham deprives the British operatic stage of a marvellous singer and actor who seemed on the brink of a major international career. He was about to make his debut at the Royal Opera House, where he had also been engaged to cover for the roles of Rigoletto and of Barak in Die Frau Ohne Schatten.

But his loss at the age of 46 also underlines how careers are subject to chance, time and geography. Fifteen years ago it was already clear that Latham was of international quality when he sang Amonasro in Verdi's Aida at Opera North. It was a truly terrifying performance, bursting with energy, portraying the defeated king so realistically that he almost became the hero of the piece. It was also sung with an astonishing range of vocal colour and dynamics.

At about the same time he showed many different qualities in another Verdi role, that of Germont in La Traviata. Here he accomplished the great duet with Violetta in the second act with an apparently impossible balance of the formality, the persuasion, the threat and the suppressed sexual desire that all need to be present, and make this one of the hardest passages in any Verdi opera. The sweetness of tone that he showed here throughout his effortlessly wide register was as impressive as the powerful singing in Aïda.

He performed a wide range of music by other composers: an unexpectedly sinister and duplicitous reading of Wolfram in Wagner's Tannhäuser comes to mind. But it was with Verdi that he made his greatest and most original impact - as Di Luna in Il Trovatore, in the title role of Macbeth, and most particularly as Rigoletto, which he sang many times at the English National Opera and elsewhere internationally.

He had begun adult life in the engineering industry, singing as an amateur in the Burnley Gilbert & Sullivan Society, near his home town of Padiham, in Lancashire. Only in his late 20s did he go to study at the Royal Northern College of Music, where he sang his first great Verdi role, Don Carlo in Ernani.

After a season at Scottish Opera, he joined Opera North in 1984, moving from there to ENO in the early 1990s. Appearances at the Wexford Festival, in Australia, the Netherlands and the Czech Republic followed. Sadly, there seems to be no commercial recording of the voice that was so naturally suited to Verdi's high baritone roles.

He leaves his wife and one daughter.

 Keith Latham, operatic baritone, born January 27 1954; died January 26 2001.

fields.headline: Ronnie Hilton
fields.standfirst: Homegrown singing star whose easy listening ballads formed part of the soundtrack to the 1950s
fields.trailText: Homegrown singing star whose easy listening ballads formed part of the soundtrack to the 1950s.
fields.body:
Ronnie Hilton who has died, aged 75, was one of those 1950s vocalists whose career coincided with rock 'n' roll's 1956 onslaught on the ballad-dominated hit parade. But for a time Hilton was a star - strictly for home consumption - with nine top 20 hits between 1954 and 1957, that transitional era between 78 and 45rpm records. A quarter of a century later he became the voice of BBC Radio 2's Sounds Of The Fifties series.

Hilton's approach owed much to the "nice 'n'easy" style of Americans such as Bing Crosby, Eddie Fisher and Perry Como. Together with the likes of Dickie Valentine and Michael Holliday, his was the kind of voice and style to which youngsters smooched as they edged across those dance floors not yet vibrating to Bill Haley's Rock Around the Clock and Elvis Presley's Blue Suede Shoes.

The British singer had made his stage debut as Ronnie Hilton in July 1954, at one of the principal nurseries for his kind of singing, the Dudley Hippodrome. He was so successful that he almost immediately got his first BBC radio series. Along with it came a series of hits for EMI's HMV label.

Veni Vidi Vici and I Still Believe in December 1954 were followed in April 1955 by a cover of Nat "King" Cole's A Blossom Fell - which was a bigger hit for Valentine, a bigger star - and that September came Stars Shine in Your Eyes. In November, Hilton's cover of Mitch Miller's US hit, the Yellow Rose Of Texas brushed the charts - just as Rock Around The Clock went to number one.

What became Hilton's signature tune, No Other Love, was a May 1956 number one and was followed by two more minor hits in 1956, Who Are We and Two Different Worlds. In summer 1957, as skiffle and Elvis gripped the charts, Hilton's cover of Around The World was a bigger hit than the Bing Crosby original. A decade later there was A Windmill In Old Amsterdam, which eventually sold a million, and became a fixture across decades of Children's Favourites.

Born Adrian Hill in Hull, Hilton left school at 14 and worked in an aircraft factory in the early days of the second world war before being called up into the Highland Light Infantry. Demobbed in 1947, he became a fitter in a Leeds sewing machine plant.

But Hilton had a passion for singing. In the evenings he performed with the Johnny Addlestone band at the Starlight Roof in Leeds and it was there that he was heard by HMV's A&R manager, Walter Ridley. Ridley recommended that he change his name, have an operation for the reconstruction of a hare lip and take up his offer of a recording contract. Hilton accepted all three suggestions and success followed.

He appeared in three Royal Variety Performances. Long after that most successful period in his life, he continued to appear in summer seasons and Christmas shows.

A stroke in 1976 hindered his activities for a time and he was beset with financial problems. In 1989 the British Academy of Song Composers and Authors awarded him its gold medal for services to popular music.

His first wife, Joan, died in 1985. His second wife, Chrissy, whom he married in 1989 survives him, as do four children, three from his first marriage.

 Ronnie Hilton (Adrian Hill), singer, born January 26 1926; died February 21 2001

fields.headline: Science update
fields.trailText: Life (and death) on the edge | Serpent enters paradise
fields.body:
Life (and death) on the edge
Two billion people who live on the Pacific Rim are sooner or later all at risk from tsunamis, earthquakes, mudflows, volcanoes and storms, according to the Stanford Earth scientist Gary Ernst. He told the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) that since 1970 around 738,000 people in Bangladesh had died in floods that followed tropical cyclones. In 1983, an eruption in Colombia triggered a mudflow that killed 23,000. There have been earthquakes in California, Alaska, Mexico City, Japan and Taiwan. "As populations in the Pacific Rim continue to grow, such disasters are apt to cause greater hardship," Ernst said.

Serpent enters paradise
When the small brown tree snake arrived on the coast of Guam, it entered an island with 13 species of forest birds, 12 kinds of lizard and three species of bat. Now there is one bat, three forest birds and six native lizards and more than a million nocturnal brown snakes. Crazy ants have taken over Christmas Island. The water hyacinth is choking Lake Victoria in Africa. Harold Mooney, an environmental biologist at Stanford, told the AAAS: "If we have a fire, then we send a fire truck. People respond right away. But we have no strategy for invasive species."

Just look at those genes
Francis Collins, front man for the human genome project, and Craig Venter, chief of Celera Genomics, packed the house at the AAAS as two journals Nature and Science separately published their epoch-making papers. "It's been a very upbeat and positive experience revealing the mysteries of the genome," said Collins. Venter said: "Fortunately both teams came up with remarkably similar conclusions, even though apparently at times for very different reasons." All was serene. At the back of the hall, according to a Swedish observer, sat Bengt Norden, chairman of the Nobel committee for chemistry. His face betrayed no expression.

fields.headline: Wheel meet again
fields.standfirst: Peter Forbes  on the tiny technology that takes a spin on the cell's natural rotor
fields.trailText: Peter Forbes on the tiny technology that takes a spin on the cell's natural rotor
fields.body:
It used to be said that nature, despite her ingenious engineering, never invented the wheel. Then, in 1974, MR Silverman and MI Simon discovered that swimming bacteria move by rotating their flagella and that the mechanism has a clear axle and wheel structure. So, for 20 years the rider was added, "except in the relatively insignificant use of rotation by bacterial flagella". Then, in 1997, Paul Boyer at UCLA and John Walker at Cambridge won the Nobel Prize for discovering that the energy reaction that powers all cells - the synthesis and breakdown of adenosine triphosphate (ATP) - is a rotational reaction.

Since then detailed knowledge of the structure of the mechanism has burgeoned. A convergence is taking place between our knowledge of the 3D structures of cellular apparatus (as revealed by electron microscopy) and the chemistry and biochemistry of the cell. And this is leading to a greater convergence, between biology and engineering, and the creation of a new discipline, nanotechnology, the science of very small-scale machines.

Engineers, spurred by the miniaturisation that created the computer chip, are approaching molecular dimensions in their manipulations. It is now possible, using the scanning tunnelling microscope, to manipulate individual atoms: the molecule biphenyl was recently created by tweaking two benzene radicals held in molecular 'tweezers' under the eye of the microscope. One of the goals of nanotechnology is to make smaller and smaller electric motors.

For years ATP was called the powerhouse of the cell, but this was a metaphor: no one expected it actually to rotate like a turbine, but this is in fact what it does. The ATP motor is an enzyme, ATP synthase, with a structure that has been likened to a mushroom: six pods sit around a spindle, and the reaction precesses around the six heads. In the cell the rotation itself does not drive anything physically: it is a byproduct of the cyclic reactions that have to cascade to keep going. In living cells, the energy produced is passed down an electrochemical chain of reactions until it finds useful work to do, in moving a muscle, for example.

Now Ricky Soong, George Bachand, Carlo Montemagno and their team at the Nanotechnology centre at Cornell University, New York, have succeeded in bridging the bio/engineering interface by attaching an inorganic rotor to the biological motor in an artificial environment and filming the motion, which runs at one to eight revolutions per second. The ATP engine is amazingly efficient - as most natural mechanisms are - almost 100% efficient, in fact. By contrast, man-made engines are woeful in this respect: the steam engine is only about 40% efficient; the electric motor 75%.

Many miniaturised pieces of engineering do not use moving parts. The chip is a static lump of doped silicon through which all the patterns are woven without anything ever changing place, but many other gadgets require miniaturised motion, a computer's printer is the most obvious example, with its micro inkjets. Robotics is the classic application requiring power for actuation. Engineers would like to make miniature robots small enough to travel along blood vessels, for example, and carry out minute repairs. The biopower of the ATP engine could be the answer.

If viable bio-powered robots are produced, the question arises: are they machines or 'insects'. It has been known for a long time that many bits of cellular machinery function perfectly happily outside of the living cell, as long as their chemical environment is right. The ATP engine is not unusual in this respect. But to be alive a creature has to be self- sustaining and able to reproduce. Nanotechnology has been notorious for the fact that before a single piece of functioning nanotec had been produced, books appeared such as Eric Drexler's Engines of Creation (1987), peddling notions of a new caste of creatures, engineered by us, swamping the globe, in their independent lifestyle. Even respected engineer Bill Joy, of Sun Microsystems, recently caused alarm by suggesting that nanotec should be stopped because it could get out of control.

The more practical, sober kind of nanotec is starting to work now, although it is still very early days. The US and Japanese governments are investing heavily in it ($423 and $396 million, respectively, this year) and, as with genomics, productive applications, five to 20 years down the track now seem certain. At the moment, Cornell University's little ATP powered rotor is the cat's whiskers of our times: we can, with a little foresight, imagine the tunes of the future that will emerge from this powerful little toy.

webTitle: Life, but not as we know it

fields.headline: Life, but not as we know it
fields.standfirst: Those in search of alien life could be barking up the wrong planet, says  Henry Gee
fields.trailText: Those in search of alien life could be barking up the wrong planet, says Henry Gee
fields.body:
Astrobiology is arguably the trendiest buzzword in science after genomics. Like genomics, it is as hip as it is hard to define. Broadly speaking, it is an umbrella term for the efforts of many scientists working in diverse fields to understand the conditions of life in the universe, whether on Earth or elsewhere.

The canvas is, in fact, so broad that many scientists might be astrobiologists without knowing it: astrobiology adds glamour to all science, from astronomy to zoology. Those with long memories and a cynical mien will have seen all this before. Once upon a time, there was a research program called exobiology. Is astrobiology a new name for repackaged goods?

No, for two reasons. First, many discoveries made in the past decade have set people thinking, once again, about life elsewhere. For example, hardly a month goes by without the discovery of yet another planet orbiting a distant star (for the latest finds, go to http://exoplanets.org ). And whatever the truth about the much-disputed claims for fossils in the martian meteorite ALH-84001, the finding has rehabilitated the idea, once thought extremely left-field, of panspermia that life can spread between planets.

Second, astrobiology is the next best thing to a trademarked term. The new Nasa Astrobiology Institute (NAI) is a virtual campus linking several Nasa research centres in North America with a number of universities, all devoted to learning more about the general principles governing the origin of life in the universe. The NAI has a fair claim to be Astrobiology Central (see http://nai.arc.nasa. gov ). A report in today's Nature looks at astrobiology in all its forms, from the quest to understand how life began on Earth to the prospects of finding intelligent life elsewhere in the universe.

Not that this should be a cause for wide-eyed celebration, say its critics. Ironically, the most vociferous of these come not from the world science but from science fiction. Brian Aldiss, veteran writer and critic and leading light of the new wave of SF in the 1960s, dismisses our current obsession with life elsewhere, however much it is justified by science, as an expensively scratched itch.

Aliens, he argues, are a manifestation of a fundamental human urge to populate the universe with 'others', whether gods, ghosts, little green men or cartoon characters. Scientists should beware of taking SF too seriously: aliens are useful as plot devices, but this does not make them real.

A rather different criticism comes from scientists-turned-SF writers Jack Cohen and Ian Stewart. Both are academics - Cohen is a biologist, Stewart a mathematician - but they have worked in SF, most recently with Terry Pratchett on The Science of Discworld, and on their own novel, Wheelers. Their argument with astrobiology is not that aliens might not exist, but that we cannot help but be constrained in our search.

All organisms on Earth, from the tiniest bacterium to the biggest whales, are constructed according to the same rules. Earthly genetic information is carried in genes made of DNA, earthly life is based on polymers of carbon, and its chemistry happens in liquid water. Because this kind of life is all we know, we tend to think that the same rules need apply everywhere. So, when probes land on Mars, or scientists look at martian meteorites, they tend to look for the kinds of vital signs that betray earthly organisms when we have absolutely no reason for thinking that life elswhere should be earthlike, or that our definition of life cannot be based more broadly. When the Mars Rover sat and stared at a rock, how do we know that the rock was not staring right back?

It is a fairly simple matter to come up with a definition of life that is based on what it does, rather than what it is made of. (It is much more difficult, however, to make such a definition stick, preventing the term life becoming so inclusive as to be meaningless.)

You might start by positing three rules. The first is that life requires the existence of information that can be reproduced and inherited, with variation. Second, that living systems tend to reduce entropy locally (that is, they seem to create order and structure and maintain it in the face of chaos). Third, that living systems exist far from equilibrium. In other words, a living form has to work hard to maintain its structure, and as soon as it stops doing this (our parochial term for this state is death) it degenerates.

These rules seem, at first, to be fairly precise, in as much as they weed out quietly observant martian surface rocks. But as Cohen and Stewart show in their novel, it is possible to imagine entities that follow all three rules and which seem to be alive, but which we would not recognise as earthly. In Wheelers, they describe civilizations of floating, methane-breathing balloons in the atmosphere of Jupiter and organisms made of magnetically confined plasma, sporting in the outer layers of the sun.

Other SF writers have imagined life on the surfaces of neutron stars, inside computers, or even in interstellar space. In his latest novel, Look To Windward, Iain M Banks describes organisms the size of continents, supporting entire civilizations as their intestinal parasites. All could be said to constitute life but in Dr McCoy's immortal phrase from Star Trek, "not as we know it".

Could this mean that astrobiology, the aims of which are universal, is really no more than a parochial exercise? We might never know - perhaps even when we are visited by aliens from the other side of the galaxy who try, frantically, to gain our attention, by waving under our noses whatever it is they wave under such circumstances. It will not be their fault that they will be microscopic, and destroyed by a single sneeze. As Cohen and Stewart conclude in Wheelers: "Life goes on everywhere."

 Henry Gee is a senior editor of Nature. His book, Deep Time, comes out in paperback on March 5, from Fourth Estate.

fields.headline: Take five
fields.standfirst: The daily news quiz
fields.trailText: The daily news quiz.
fields.body:
Each weekday, we set five questions based on the news. Come up with each day's answers, then send in all 25 at the end of the week. The first correct entry out of the hat wins a £100 electronic gift card from Borders.

D1 According to a study, what percentage of 15- to 16-year-olds have been drunk at least 20 times in their lives?

a) 20 per cent

b) 30 per cent

c) 40 per cent

d) 50 per cent

D2 One pint of beer is equal to how many litres?

a) 0.057

b) 0.57

c) 0.75

d) 0.075

D3 Which of the following is not an essential ingredient of beer?

a) Malted barley

b) Hops

c) Water

d) Baking soda

D4 Which of these is an expensive type of hop?

a) Noble

b) Grand

c) Courtly

d) Gentle

D5 Hopscotch started in:

a) the early Bronze Age

b) the early Roman Empire

c) the early Byzantine Empire

d) your early childhood

 Entries must reach Take Five, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER by Wednesday February 28 . The winner will be notified by March 9. One entry per person. No purchase necessary. The daily online news quiz is at Guardian Unlimited Quiz Room.

fields.headline: Building bridges
fields.standfirst: Balnafoich
fields.trailText: Balnafoich.
fields.body:
Last spring I had been down the River Nairn in the morning and was slowly working upstream with a fly rod, while common sandpipers were thrilling me with their arched wings and whistling call notes.

Dippers were active under the ancient bridge, where their large domed nest looked like an overgrown wren's nest; a bird in front of me caught a small brown trout and bashed its head on a stone before flying to the bridge.

A grey wagtail walked purposefully over a narrow strip of sand and drank from the river's shadows, and I felt at peace with the world; and yet looking back I should have thought of the old Swedish proverb: "The afternoon knows what the morning never suspected." It was indeed that afternoon when the news broke about the old bridge being replaced, and my immediate reaction was concern about the dippers and their nest.

So I wrote to the local council and pointed out that under the Wildlife and Countryside Act, the work would have to wait until the birds had flown, and chanced my arm even further by asking if nest boxes for dippers could be placed under the new bridge. I received a very pleasant letter back saying the birds would be taken into account and, yes, nest boxes would be included in the plans.

A few weeks later another letter informed me that the RSPB had checked the nest and the young had flown so it was safe to start work. I have just come back from the bridge having seen one of the new boxes. The engineer in charge showed me the drawings of the nest box that were incorporated into the plan and was obviously very excited about the birds that had already been inspecting the new bridge. The war may not be over for wildlife, but a small battle has been won.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Whisky Galore | Men In Black | Live Test Cricket
fields.body:
Films

Whisky Galore
(Alexander Mackendrick, 1949)
9am, Carlton Cinema

This unlikely tale of a cargo ship running aground in the outer Hebrides, and bequeathing its 50,000 cases of whisky to grateful islanders, is based on a real incident. In Mackendrick of Ealing's hands, it becomes sublime comedy, as the canny folk of Todday, intent on a regular wee dram, run rings around the stuffy Sassenachs.

The Story Of Qiu Ju
(Zhang Yimou, 1992)
6pm, FilmFour

A contrast to the lavish period pieces which made him so famous, China's most celebrated director opted for a down-to-earth, modern-day setting here, largely populated by non-actors - an indication of where his future lay. His regular star, Gong Li, is accordingly toned down; here playing a pregnant peasant woman whose husband is kicked in the groin by the village chief. Her stubborn quest for justice serves as a compelling overview of Chinese society.

Men In Black
(Barry Sonnenfeld, 1997)
7pm, Disney

In Sonnenfeld's very hip, very funny sci-fi spoof the world is full of aliens living (mainly) peacefully incognito, and the Men In Black are interstellar immigration officers. And it's their reactions to the array of space beasts (created by state-of-the-art special effects) that give the film its comic buzz. Tommy Lee Jones borrows a seen-it-all-before expression from Ghostbusters' Bill Murray; Will Smith is all wide-eyed, gobsmacked incredulity, but deep-space cool: "You know the difference between you and me?" he asks Jones as he dons his first black suit: "I make this look good."

10 Things I Hate About You
(Gil Junger, 1999)
8pm, Sky Premier

This smart and funny update of Shakespeare's Taming Of The Shrew shifts the action to a Seattle high school. Julia Stiles' sulky Kate hates just about everything - boys especially - but that doesn't stop her sister Bianca (Larisa Oleynik) fixing her up with Heath Ledger's Patrick (who's a deadringer for Jim Morrison). So the scene is duly set for a raging battle of the sexes, except that director Junger retains a gently charming air throughout. As modern screen Shakespeares go, it's up there with Baz Luhrmann's Romeo And Juliet.

Close My Eyes
(Stephen Poliakoff, 1991)
10pm, FilmFour

Sex is a complicated affair in Poliakoff's unusual drama. Clive Owen and Saskia Reeves play siblings Richard and Natalie, separated as children and finding each other irresistible one torrid summer some years later. With Natalie newly married to Sinclair (a turbo-charged Alan Rickman), the passion runs out of control. Explicit, intelligent, and highly individual.
Paul Howlett & Steve Rose

Sports

Live Test Cricket 4.05am, Sky Sports

2 After an encouraging 2000, England's Test side is looking to build on their recent successes in Sri Lanka. The first Test started at a ridiculous hour this morning, but day one won't end until lunchtime. And there's the possibility of another four days to come. That's if England lasts the distance - the Sri Lankans will present more of a test than Pakistan.
Simon Burnton

fields.headline: I just can't get enough
fields.trailText: Sex And The City | Metrosexuality | Christine Keeler: Sex Bomb
fields.body:
In between draws on her cigarettes ("Smoking is cool." Discuss) and slipping into relationships almost as frightful as many of her outfits, Carrie Bradshaw will say something sagacious. Sometimes, it's simply pseudo-profound, the sort of rhetorical question or wry observation that comes to you while in the queue for a Starbucks. Bon mots from the soap-opera school of philosophy. But often, there's a genuine wisdom to her words, which make you stop and think.

Occasionally, they even make you stop and think, "Blimey. Someone just said that thing that I've always thought. Out loud. On television." I can't say that "I love a big dick. I love it inside of me. I love looking at it. I love everything about it", is one of those things, but that particular gem came from the mouth of Samantha, not Carrie.

Yet such is the strength and sassiness of Sex And The City (Channel 4), it can move from musing on the nature of love, life and everything to the smutty machinations of Samantha's mind with the elegant glide of a well-lubricated sex toy, with no snagging or jarring.

Smart and saucy, witty, wise and wonderfully well-written, Sex And The City puts to shame Metrosexuality (Channel 4) which values spectacle above any connection with the viewer or indeed with any kind of reality or truthfulness. The difference between tiresome predictable pap like Metrosexuality and the exquisite Sex And The City doesn't come down to budgets or guest stars like Vince Vaughn or Sarah Michelle Gellar but to good writing.

While the grating inanity of the former is likely to induce a migraine - and, if enough people were to watch it (which seems unlikely), cause house prices in Notting Hill , where it's set, to plummet - the latter is the cleverest kind of feel-good, aspirational television. It can convince you that New York is a state of mind, whether you're in Los Angeles or Loch Lomond. Which, I suppose, it is.

All of which leads, inexorably, to Carrie's thought for the day: "I couldn't help but wonder, no matter how far you travel or how much you run from it, can you ever escape your past?" Christine Keeler's attempts to escape from her past led her to become a dinner lady. But when the headmaster at the school at which she worked found out she was that Christine Keeler, he fired her.

Now, she lives in a rather poky flat with an MFI-esque kitchen. Now, she sits on park benches and feeds pigeons. She's a long way from that chair, but judging from what she said in Christine Keeler: Sex Bomb (ITV), you got the feeling it still wasn't far enough. Telling the well-worn but still fascinating story of Keeler, Profumo and the affair which heralded the birth of that kind of sexual-political scandal, Christine Keeler: Sex Bomb wasn't awfully good, despite its source material and access to Keeler herself and others involved back then. Third-rate reconstructions and the use of tunes from the time - which half-suggested there was a soundtrack album in the offing - were distracting annoyances that not even the fact that it was an offering on prime-time ITV can excuse.

From the fairytale gables of Spring Cottage to the Gormenghastly spires of the House of Commons, the story just about redeemed the style in which it was presented. It unravelled irresistibly and built up momentum like a giant cartoon snowball, gathering flotsam, jetsam and anyone who happened to be standing nearby. Russian spies, secret flights to Spain, illicit sex in the back of Ministerial cars ... little wonder one contributor called it "the first great national soap opera". Though you don't get many osteopaths with Communist sympathies down Coronation Street.

The most intriguing moments of Christine Keeler: Sex Bomb weren't revelations as such. Rather they were details which, when illuminated, made the whole picture more fascinating. That John Profumo is still alive was a surprise (to me anyway), though less surprising was the fact that he's super-rich and hangs about with the Queen Mother (or as my granny used to call her - for reasons entirely unknown to everyone else - the old tattie howker).

We all know how corrupt and incestuous, not to mention horsey and unattractive, the Establishment is, but who would have thought they actually had great big gangbangs? That's something that even Sex And The City's Samantha might balk at. A girl's got to have standards, after all.

fields.headline: Talking dirty
fields.trailText: "If it were legal, I'd leave the house in Manolo's work and nothing else. There are so few brushes with genius in life; I feel honoured that I will be able to say to my grandchildren, 'I met Manolo Blahnik and I owned some of his shoes' "
fields.body:
"If it were legal, I'd leave the house in Manolo's work and nothing else. There are so few brushes with genius in life; I feel honoured that I will be able to say to my grandchildren, 'I met Manolo Blahnik and I owned some of his shoes' "
Sarah Jessica Parker on shoe designer Manolo Blahnik, In Style

"Julien's dresses can change lives"
Joely Richardson on designer Julien Macdonald, In Style

"I think feminists are unaware of the tremendous extent of the role of women in history. Regarding the patronage of the arts, their influence has been immense. It's almost true to say that there wouldn't be any art if it weren't for women. Feminists wish women to seem like men. They're not men"
Vivienne Westwood on the criticism that her aesthetic is not in line with feminism, Independent

"You've got your dream girls and your real girls. I know the difference. But I wonder if girls realise that they may not get to go out with a pop star"
Fourteen-year-old David, Mizz

"I am a little nervous of older male fans"
Britney Spears, Marie Claire

"They just don't write scripts for girls to do that, like they did in the 40s. All the great women of film could be elegant but they could fall on their face as well. What was that great film with Cary Grant and Katharine Hepburn where she comes to the door and he shoves her face and she falls over? Now that would be seen as violence but, you know, everyone loved the physicality of it and there was nothing less elegant about the people. I would always read the guy's scripts and go: 'Can't we make this for a woman?' And they're like: 'No, we want Jim Carrey.' And I was like: 'I'm all for Jim, but I want Dumb and Dumber where they have a sister named stupid or something"

fields.headline: Touch and go
fields.standfirst: The more mobiles do, the less you will want to use their fiddly keys, says Michael Fitzpatrick on the
fields.trailText: The more mobiles do, the less you will want to use their fiddly keys, says Michael Fitzpatrick on the
fields.body:
Most people under 25 would rather eat their own heads than enter anything longer than a friend's name on their mobile. And yet if mobile commerce is to succeed, as many believe it will, we will need better ways of inputting text than fiddling with nine tiny keys.

So far, higher portability has meant a poorer input interface, but improvements are at hand. What is quickly becoming a global standard for mobile-phone input, T9, has soothed some of the stress. But for truly simple access, quicker interfaces are a must.

The leader in this field, with its i-mode users permanently switched on to what the Japanese are calling the Evernet, Japan's DoCoMo has come up with quite a few novel ideas, such as a pen-size scanner for its 15 million wireless subscribers. The device clips neatly into mobile phones and can be used to scan bar codes at the end of magazine articles. To check out one of the products mentioned, you pass the pen over the stripes and your phone calls up the company's website. It can also be used to place orders from product and mail order catalogues, either via email or pages on the web. Japan is also pioneering a service where you key in a company's telephone number and the web page comes up.

Wired magazine, too, is now promoting scanning of its pages, but as Jan Chipchase, a researcher at the Nokia Research Centre (NRC), Tokyo, points out: "Would you carry a pen around with you just to scan articles? I quite like the idea of scanning using a mobile. The biggest problem is having different bar code systems in different shops - there are compatibility problems - and whether there are enough magazines supporting this feature."

Meanwhile, the next- generation wireless devices are now in development by Japanese electronics giants. Despite being left out the GSM agreements years ago - which renders Japanese phones useless outside the country - Japan's mobile technology has developed rapidly and will dominate the production of the much-vaunted globally-usable G3 mobile phones.

The country's biggest handset producer, Matsushita Communication Industrial (MCI) - trading as Panasonic abroad - was also largely behind the miniaturisation methods that have resulted in a phone the size of a woman's compact case. The company's development lab in Yokohama is now busy perfecting alternative keying methods for these tiny devices. Speech recognition has already been incorporated into existing models with varying degrees of success. But the best way forward would be the reinvention of the human interface, says Toshiro Iizuka, chief product designer for MCI.

"If the mobile phone is evolved, for example, to the third generation, there might be completely new applications such as video conferencing by mobile phones, or gaming battles between mobile phones with game functions. People's lifestyles themselves will be changed by such advanced mobile phones," he says.

What Iizuka and his team have come up with is a fusion of the Game Boy and a mobile handset. By holding the pad with both hands, and pressing buttons on the top with your thumbs and on the bottom with your fingers, all manner of data can be entered. The inspiration, says Iizuka, came from watching a saxophonist play, and gamers at local arcades.

Chipchase believes Matsushita may be on the right track. "I don't think keyboards are going away in a hurry. However, look at how much fun it is to enter a name for a high score using a Game Boy-type device. I'd place bets on one-hand keyboards. Not those desktop ones but one converted to fit into your semi-open fist. So you could 'chord' [type one-handed]. You could walk around with your mobile typing at the same time.

"Some one-handed 'chording' key boards are available already such as the BAT Personal Keyboard, which claims to replicate all the functions of a full-size keyboard. However these devices also require the user to learn another new skill if they are not a regular gamer.

"Chording tends to be unsellable to the mass market because people have to learn the functionality, or the combinations on the interface need to be explained somewhere. Having said that, chording is loved by a few: pianists, Street Fighter 3 players, etc."

As far as m-commerce is concerned by far the most exciting development is Bluetooth as it will help to take some of the grind out of getting to a businesse's web site, after, say, you might have been enticed to do so by an advertising billboard. this transaction. "You can take the most difficult part of the interaction process (entering in the web site address) and zap it to the users phone seamlessly", says Chipchase.

In our convenience-crazed culture it could be the catalyst for m-commerce's success.

webTitle: Rideout rides in for a glorious sunset

fields.headline: Rideout rides in for a glorious sunset
fields.trailText: Ian Ross talks to journeyman Paul Rideout as Tranmere contemplate their FA Cup and league fates.
fields.body:
For a man who had almost single-handedly guaranteed Tranmere Rovers a place in FA Cup folklore the previous evening, Paul Rideout was in a surprisingly relaxed, almost philosophical mood yesterday.

A matter of hours after scoring the hat-trick which led the way for the First Division's bottom team to knock one of his former clubs, Southampton, out of the competition by overturning their three-goal lead, Rideout was pondering relegation and the traditional theory that in football you remain on a learning curve until the moment you retire.

"I thought I had seen it all and done most things in football but what happened on Tuesday was remarkable, utterly remarkable," he said. "That is the sort of game which comes around maybe once every 10 years if you are lucky. I just feel really privileged to have been a part of it."

Trailing 3-0 at the interval, Rideout and his team-mates were verbally shredded by their manager at half-time before emerging to register one of the most memorable fight-backs in FA Cup history.

"We had been so awful in the first half that the possibility of going on to win the game never entered anyone's head," Rideout said. "There were some harsh words exchanged during the break; there had to be. All we have to hope now is that we can play like that in our remaining league fixtures, because staying up is what really matters."

As an intelligent, thinking man it is more than understandable that Rideout should spend his quieter moments reflecting upon the moment almost six years ago when his long, chequered career appeared to have reached its peak.

It was on a May day back in 1995 that the then 30-year-old appeared to have penned a memorable footnote to his career by lifting himself off Wembley's turf to head Everton's winner in the FA Cup final against Manchester United.

Two years later Rideout, who earlier had also played in Italy for Bari and Scotland for Rangers, spent time playing in China and then moved to the United States and turned out for Kansas City Wizards before returning for a final season in English football with Tranmere.

It was to be no more than a reasonably lucrative epitaph, a halfway post between jobs. At least that is how it was until the astonishing events of Tuesday evening.

If Rideout arrived at the ground in early evening nothing more than an ageing centre-forward with a healthy reputation, he departed some five hours later a 24-carat Tranmere legend, his place in Wirral folklore confirmed.

In the space of 21 second-half minutes he claimed a faultless hat-trick before setting up Stuart Barlow for the fourth as Tranmere produced a Houdini-esque escape to shatter Glenn Hoddle's Premiership side.

The fact that the win brought a home quarter-final date with Liverpool next month was almost forgotten as Rovers wallowed in one of knockout football's greatest comebacks.

Rideout, who will celebrate his 37th birthday in August, is now seriously considering delaying his retirement for at least 12 months. "I never really expected to be playing League football again in this country," he said. "My family had settled in Kansas; they are still out there. [But] I am tempted to stay here for another season."

The man who spoke the vast majority of the harsh half-time words to to which Rideout had referred was, predictably, the forthright John Aldridge.

"I couldn't believe we had come in three goals down," the manager said. "We had been absolutely dire and I was determined to get something better out of my team. I didn't think we could do it but, when our first goal went in, I sensed that something big might happen; I could sense that some of the Southampton players were beginning to get a little worried."

Liverpool's manager Gérard Houllier was watching from the main stand. He said: "When it was tied up at 3-3 a Tranmere fan ran towards me and shouted, 'you're next, you're next'. There was no menace in his words; he simply couldn't understand what was happening and neither could I."

webTitle: Chelsea set to sue over 'load of cobblers'

fields.headline: Chelsea set to sue over 'load of cobblers'
fields.trailText: Chelsea are planning to take legal action over an article claiming that Chelsea players were involved in a bust-up with manager Claudio Ranieri during Sunday's FA Cup defeat at Arsenal.
fields.body:
Chelsea are planning to take legal action over an article which appeared in a tabloid newspaper earlier this week.

Tuesday's Sun newspaper claimed that several Chelsea players were involved in a bust-up with their manager Claudio Ranieri at half-time of Sunday's FA Cup defeat at Arsenal.

Last night Colin Hutchinson, Chelsea's chief executive, claimed that the story was "a load of cobblers.

"Ranieri did not say a lot. He was sat, reflective for a large chunk of the interval and then said a few inspiring words before the players went out.

"The article was totally out of order as well as being untrue and damaging," he added. "It was pure fabrication and we have passed it over to our solicitors to do the necessary."

Bolton, concerned that home form may hinder their promotion bid, plan to rip up the Reebok pitch after tomorrow's visit by Blackburn and have a new surface laid.

The Lancashire club, second in the First Division but with three draws from their past three games on the mud-caked pitch, will have grass in place for Gillingham's visit on March 10. "The pitch is not doing us any favours," the manager Sam Allardyce admitted. "This is the only real window we've got left to fit it in and I think that's enough time to get it done.

"Liverpool relaid their pitch after Christmas and two weeks later it was looking great."

Birmingham's manager Trevor Francis, preparing for Sunday's League Cup final with Liverpool, has responded to the recent ultimatum from the owner David Sullivan that Francis must qualify the club for the First Division play-offs or face the sack.

"Unfortunately David Sullivan has got this habit of whenever he is asked for a comment he is always free and willing," Francis said. "If only he could look at what he says, then I am sure there are things he wouldn't say.

"I know other members of the board were very disappointed about it. But you are not going to change David. He's his own man and he's put a lot of money into this football club along with David and Ralph Gold."

Steve Bruce, sacked as manager of Huddersfield in October, yesterday became the third man in a week to turn down the QPR manager's job.

Bruce, who joins Dave Bassett and Wycombe's Lawrie Sanchez, said: "I have decided against having any further discussion regarding the managerial position. I understand QPR may be seeking a replacement only for the short term."

The truth behind what went wrong with the new Wembley stadium project is expected to be revealed at a parliamentary inquiry in early March, when a Culture, Media and Sport select committee will hear from all parties involved.

Among those giving their versions of events will be the former WNSL chairman Ken Bates. The project was plunged into crisis last year after it was revealed that WNSL was having trouble raising the £410m it needed from City investors.

The Premier League chairmen will today discuss the bids to win the overseas TV rights for top-flight games. The rights could raise up to £150m over the next three years.

fields.headline: Spireites charged over 'secret bonuses'
fields.trailText: Chesterfield are to be charged today over a number of irregularities concerning payments to players and attendance figures that could jeopardise the team's push for promotion.
fields.body:
Chesterfield are to be charged today over a number of irregularities concerning payments to players and attendance figures that could jeopardise the team's push for promotion.

The Football League is writing to the club outlining the charges that relate to irregular payments to players and falsified gate receipts. The charges follow a joint investigation between the Football League and the Football Association.

According to reports, the irregular payments amount to almost £30,000 in secret bonuses.

Chesterfield are currently 14 points clear at the top of the Third Division. If the club are found guilty, then they could be relegated to the Conference or prevented from going up to the Second Division if they win promotion.

The Chesterfield chairman Darren Brown yesterday defended his club, claiming that they had done nothing wrong and that he would challenge any charges.

Brown said: "We have paid no player anything like £30,000 out of contract. No gate receipts have been fiddled at all and we will defend that to the hilt.

"I am not saying we have not made mistakes. But if they went to any league club they would find something."

Brown, a 29-year-old businessman whose company also controls Sheffield Steelers and Hull Thunder ice hockey teams, is bracing himself for the possibility of stringent penalties.

The experiences of Swindon in similar circumstances - which saw the Robins sent down a division in 1990 - is an uncomfortable precedent.

According to reports, the FA and Football League investigation found that 16 players received £900 in illegal payments and others also received money.

The payments were made outside the normal salaries and bonuses and the FA has asked the players to confess to receiving secret payments. Brown insists that the club will be able to offer an explanation to the charges and that some of the evidence submitted to the inquiry was incorrect.

Hull City's administrators return to the High Court today armed with a salvage plan. The administrators will put the plan to Hull's creditors and shareholders on March 8 in the hope that the Third Division club can survive.

Airdrie's liquidators KPMG yesterday asked the Scottish League to postpone Saturday's First Division match against Ross County - on the day that Diamonds supporters demonstrated outside the Glasgow offices of KPMG, who cancelled Steve Archibald's management contract and sacked most of the first-team squad.

fields.headline: Omar
fields.standfirst:
Jazz Cafe, London
***
fields.trailText:
Jazz Cafe, London
***
fields.body:
When Omar Lyefook's There's Nothing Like This sauntered to number 14 in the charts in 1991, it seemed as though the south Londoner might be that rarest of breeds: a British soulman who would break through internationally. When he plays the song, it's easy to understand the hullabaloo it caused at the time.

Slow, grinding and bristling with melody, it remains graceful enough to withstand both the inevitable Marvin Gaye comparisons and a wholehearted singalong. There's Nothing Like This always sounded like the start of something big. It still does but, a decade and five albums later, Omar is back where he started. He still looks the part, too: pineapple haircut, muscle-baring T-shirt, more piercings than St Sebastian, and a jovial cockney-ish demeanour. Diminishing returns have hardly cut back on his vaunting ambition - he is accompanied by a multiracial, 11-piece band, including a wind section that doubles as brass and his seemingly disinterested sister on backing vocals.

The samba-tinged Something Real, during which Omar switches from falsetto to baritone in an instant, the fiery I Guess, the symphonic ballad In the Morning and the intricate Outside all establish a handsome groove. These tunes suggest that Omar has not entirely received his just rewards, particularly when splendid backing singer Chris Ballin is given free reign. The pair's duet on Be Thankful for What You've Got is sublime.

Elsewhere, however, Omar meanders pointlessly, though to his credit he does break off during the noodling Essensual to announce, "Welcome to Jazz Club. Mmm, nice" in best Fast Show fashion. He loses his way between songs on occasions, but the set's dregs - Syleste, Music and This Is Not a Love Song - carry all the heavyweight muscle of Level 42. As if sensing his loss of focus, Omar attempts to liven proceedings with a succession of keyboard solos straight from the Rick James songbook.

Perhaps Omar's struggles are simply an accident of birth. Many Americans have achieved more with far fewer gifts. It won't happen now for him, but he may just emerge as a national treasure.

When he plays the song, it's easy to understand the hullabaloo it caused at the time. Slow, grinding and bristling with melody, it remains graceful enough to withstand both the inevitable Marvin Gaye comparisons and a wholehearted singalong. There's Nothing Like This always sounded like the start of something big. It still does but, a decade and five albums later, Omar is back where he started. He still looks the part, too: pineapple haircut, muscle-baring T-shirt, more piercings than St Sebastian, and a jovial cockney-ish demeanour. Diminishing returns have hardly cut back on his vaunting ambition - he is accompanied by a multiracial, 11-piece band, including a wind section that doubles as brass and his seemingly disinterested sister on backing vocals. The samba-tinged Something Real, during which Omar switches from falsetto to baritone in an instant, the fiery I Guess, the symphonic ballad In the Morning and the intricate Outside all establish a handsome groove. These tunes suggest that Omar has not entirely received his just rewards, particularly when splendid backing singer Chris Ballin is given free reign. The pair's duet on Be Thankful for What You've Got is sublime. Elsewhere, however, Omar meanders pointlessly, though to his credit he does break off during the noodling Essensual to announce, "Welcome to Jazz Club. Mmm, nice" in best Fast Show fashion. fields.headline: Turandot
fields.standfirst:
Royal Opera House, London
***
fields.trailText:
Royal Opera House, London
***
fields.body:
Andrei Serban's 1984 production of Puccini's Turandot remains a riotous, virtuosic spectacle in its latest revival at the Royal Opera House. Turandot's realm seethes with gaudy and grotesque imagery, from the emperor's descent on a gilded magic carpet to the wanton bloodlust of the executioner and his minions. The production is visually stunning and theatrically accomplished.

The latest cast presents, on paper at least, an unmissable blend of experience and vocal bravura. Tenor Dennis O'Neill and soprano Jane Eaglen take the central roles of Calaf and Turandot, and the other main parts are no less starry. Willard White's burnished bass-baritone makes for a luxurious Timur, while soprano Cristina Gallardo-Domas sings her Royal Opera debut as the hapless slave-girl, Liu.

Gallardo-Domas gives the performance of the production. The tenderness of her portrayal of the doomed but faithful Liu creates a moving contrast with the horrors that surround her. Her voice is supple and strong, and the arias of her torture scene in act three are the highlight of the evening, as she sacrifices herself for love.

But Eaglen and O'Neill take a totally different approach to their parts. Both give performances of unashamed stand-and-deliver force. Their limited range as actors means their performances are bound to be under-characterised, which would be forgivable had their voices alone given dramatic life to two of Puccini's most fascinating roles. But while Eaglen's voice soars infallibly across her enormous range, she never makes Turandot a sympathetic character; and though O'Neill is impressively consistent, his Calaf never engages with the humanity of the part.

It doesn't help that Sally Jacobs's lavish costumes and sets depersonalise individual characters; her elaborate use of masks turns every member of the cast into a slave of Turandot's appalling reign. The final duet is the production's low point, as Eaglen and O'Neill seem emotionally frigid. At least conductor Christian Badea provides a solid foundation for the evening, and the ROH Orchestra gives a warm-hearted performance.

 In rep until March 19. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

fields.headline: The exquisite psychodrama of Therese Racquin
fields.standfirst:
Therese Racquin
Gate Theatre, Dublin
****
fields.trailText:
Therese Racquin
Gate Theatre, Dublin
****
fields.body:
Although it now comes across more like nightmarishly symbolist melodrama than naturalism, Emile Zola's depressive horror novel of 1867 - which he himself adapted as a hugely influential stage play in 1873 - still delivers a nasty charge in Nicholas Wright's new adaptation. It also provides one of the darkest, most astringent costume dramas I've seen at the Gate in some time.

It's the claustrophobic tale of a petit-petit-bourgeois family who eke out their existence in two rooms over a shop. The limp Camille is pampered by his mother and is nastily spiteful to his adopted sister, Therese, whom he has quasi-incestuously married. However, an old family friend, the painter Laurent, returns and embarks on a furtive, intense affair with Therese, their carnal passions culminating in a boating "accident", which leads to the murder of Camille.

Laurent eventually takes the place of Camille in the oppressive family routines, becoming a replacement son for Madame Racquin and finally, according to plan, a husband to Therese. But Therese's passion has curdled into revulsion, and we are left to watch the downward spiral into terror and madness as the pair become trapped in the perversely exquisite success of their perfect crime.

It is a queasy depiction of the fickleness of lust, with Phelim Drew's Laurent full of broody, lecherous hypocrisy. But Donna Dent, as Therese, is the complex, unpredictable hub of the piece: all stymied emotion, absences and distracted utterances, except for the nervily affecting love scenes and the howling rage of the final scene.

Some groaning explicatory passages aside, the script is an excellent vehicle of purely psychological violence - and nowhere more so when the old bird, Madame Racquin, watches the young couple tear each other apart in the agony of having killed for love.

Michael Caven's direction is clear and functional throughout. In a sense, he has to work across the grain of the Gate actors who work the familiar stage like pros and on occasion threaten to veer into chocolate-box territory - as in the jolly japes of Barry McGovern and Des Cave as the two older, foolish clerks. But Zola's mortuary humour rarely allows you such easy comforts.

 Until March 17. Box office: 00 353 1 874 4045.

fields.headline: Pensioners face more means tests
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: The average pensioner will be £10 a week better off by 2003 once the government's pension reforms are fully implemented, independent experts said yesterday.
fields.body:
The average pensioner will be £10 a week better off by 2003 once the government's pension reforms are fully implemented, independent experts said yesterday.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, grabbed the headlines last November when he announced an above inflation increase in the state pension. The state pension is due to rise by £5 a week to £72.50.

But the Institute for Fiscal Studies said the biggest increase would be targeted on poorer pensioners through the increases in the means tested top-up to the state pension and the new pensioner tax credit, due to be implemented in 2003.

The IFS estimates that the entire package will cost the government an extra £4bn by 2003, and could increase the income of the poorest pensioners by as much as 20%.

"There can be no doubt that the government is diverting significant extra resources to pensioners," said Tom Clark from the IFS.

"But its basic strategy is still to extend means testing."

The pensioner tax credit could make it uneconomic for earners to save privately for retirement by extending the benefits trap faced by low income pensioners, the IFS warned.

But means testing is extremely unpopular with pension lobby groups, who have called instead for the restoration of the link between pensions and rises in average earnings. Many pensioners do not understand the present means testing system and fail to claim all the benefits to which they are entitled.

The IFS warned that the new tax credit - intended to simplify the position of those with small private pensions who at present lose most of their entitlement to the means tested portion of state pensions - could create more complications. "Unless housing and council tax benefits are also reformed, then someone who received these as well as pension credit would actually gain only 9p for every pound of private income," the institute said.
